fields.headline: Stewart treble darkens Gray day
fields.trailText: A hat-trick from Marcus Stewart made it a miserable start for Southampton's stand-in manager Stuart Gray as he saw he watched his cave in on all fronts.
fields.body:
Having watched Glenn Hoddle swap Sainthood for his own personal heaven, Southampton were last night left to contemplate the after-life. It was not a pretty sight.

The first match since Hoddle decamped to Spurs brought, significantly perhaps, defeat and the end of a run of five successive league wins.

Southampton were as ragged as anyone can remember them. Admittedly that had much to do with an organised, industrious and fluent performance from Ipswich - what else have we come to expect this season? - who deservedly reclaimed third place thanks to a hat-trick from Marcus Stewart, who becomes the Premiership's top scorer with 18 goals.

But, of course, the acrimonious departure of one man overshadowed all else. "I think it's probably had an effect on everybody," admitted Southampton's chairman Rupert Lowe. It was an understatement. Southampton looked absolutely demoralised.

Lowe was reluctant to get into a slanging match with Spurs about Hoddle; both clubs have signed a confidentiality clause. His most controversial comments were: "The whole thing could have been handled better from start to finish," and "I would not have done it the way he [Hoddle] did it."

"Disloyal" and "selfish" were the views of many fans in the local media. But others voiced a more measured opinion: that Hoddle was never going turn down a chance to manage his beloved Spurs. And that is as near the truth as dammit.

It was the speed of Hoddle's move - "it came a bit like a Spitfire out of the sun," said Lowe - which particularly irked him, though the official end of the Hoddle era had come only earlier in the day after the two clubs agreed compensation - a reputed £800,000 to Southampton for the loss of their manager and £200,000 for the loss of his No2 John Gorman.

Various names have been mentioned as Hoddle's long-term replacement - from Kevin Keegan, George Graham, Gianluca Vialli to Mickey Adams. Until the end of the season, the baton has passed to Stuart Gray, who made it clear after the game that he wanted the job full-time.

"My ambition is to be a manager," he said, "but I don't make that decision and, if we carry on playing like that, then I certainly won't get it."

Despite saying he would adhere to the old model, this was nothing like the Southampton of Hoddle. Ipswich, missing the suspended Jim Magilton and changing their shape to a more defensive 4-5-1, dominated.

"We were outfought, outpassed and the amount of times we gave the ball away, I can't believe it," said Gray.

Time and again Ipswich got behind the Southampton defence. On 21 minutes Chris Makin set up Stewart for a snap shot which Paul Jones saved brilliantly one-handed.

Martijn Reuser hit a post and Makin went close again before Ipswich inevitably went ahead. Jamie Clapham's ball was allowed to flash across goal and Stewart at the far post swept it in.

The goal ended Southampton's hopes of beating an 80-year-old record of keeping a clean sheet in eight successive league games.

Ipswich were soon sewing up their eighth Premiership away win of the season - equal best with Manchester United.

Hermann Hreidarsson, given space on the left, chipped to Stewart, who headed past Jones. Two minutes later Matt Holland was impeded by Tahar El Khalej and the referee awarded a penalty. Stewart coolly completed his hat-trick, becoming the first Ipswich player to score 20 goals in a season for 18 years and the first to strike a hat-trick in the top flight since 1985. The watching Sven-Goran Eriksson must have been impressed.

Suddenly Southampton's hopes of European football at their new stadium next season looks a long shot. And not even the return of Matt Le Tissier from six months out injured helped.

Southampton (4-3-2-1): Jones; El Khalej, Lundekvam, Richards, Bridge; Tessem, Oakley, Marsden (Le Tissier, 76); Petrescu (Dodd, 60min), Pahars (Rosler, 76); Beattie.

Ipswich Town (4-5-1): R Wright; Makin, McGreal, Bramble, Hreidarsson; Scowcroft, J Wright, Holland, Clapham, Reuser (Venus, 77); Stewart (Burchill, 86).

Referee : A Wiley.

fields.headline: Sunderland handcuff Reid with £6m deal
fields.trailText: Sunderland hope to allay any lingering fears that Peter Reid may be lured back to Everton in the summer by tying their manager to a £6m four-year contract this week.
fields.body:
Sunderland hope to allay any lingering fears that Peter Reid may be lured back to Everton in the summer by tying their manager to a £6m four-year contract this week.

Reid, who celebrated six years in charge on Wearside on Saturday, will also be offered share options in a club he has taken from the brink of relegation to the Second Division to the verge of a place in Europe. "I'd be daft to leave," he said. "I know I've got my critics and people who say I should spend more money, but I think that happens to managers anywhere."

The Nottingham Forest manager David Platt has been told failure to reach the Premiership could result in a summer clear-out of players to avoid a potential £5m loss.

The former European champions have reported an operating deficit of £3.1m for the six months to the end of November. Weekly losses have subsequently risen to £105,000, a figure which must be reduced if Forest fail to get promoted.

Queens Park Rangers have confirmed that their former director Andrew Ellis is negotiating a £9m takeover of the First Division club. The 32-year-old is the son of the club's former chairman Peter, who was at the helm between 1994 and 1996.

Celtic have accused the Scottish Football Association of interfering with the right of free speech in complaining about an article that appeared in the club magazine Celtic View criticising the performance of a match referee.

The SFA yesterday decided that there would be no formal action, and in a statement Celtic said: "The club hopes that this signals the end of the SFA's practice of attempting to stifle informed comment on matters of debate on the conduct of football matches."

Manchester United have said that Teddy Sheringham has only been offered a one-year contract. The veteran striker, 35 yesterday, is out of contract in June and had been holding out for a two-year deal.

fields.headline: Slaves of the South Bank
fields.standfirst:
Psappha/ Endymion Ensemble
South Bank Centre, London
**/***
fields.trailText:
Psappha/ Endymion Ensemble
South Bank Centre, London
**/***
fields.body:
Of all the works performed in Voices, the South Bank Centre's festival of Hans Werner Henze's music, El Cimarron is the most overtly political. Henze composed this music-theatre piece in 1969-70, after his visit to Castro's Cuba. Committed to the ideals of international socialism, Henze worked on the plantations, gave masterclasses and premiered his Sixth Symphony in Havana.

El Cimarron was conceived in the midst of this revolutionary fervour, and sets texts by Esteban Montejo. Montejo is the "cimarron", the "runaway slave" of the title, and the stories of the horrors of slavery, abuse and attempted escapes are his experiences.

Henze's settings resulted from months of collaboration with the original performers. With the solo baritone, percussionist, guitarist and flautist, Henze experimented with tortuous instrumental effects, and developed elaborate graphic notations. El Cimarron presents a special challenge to modern performers, since the fabric of the piece relies on their own creativity and imagination as much as it does on Henze's composition.

The performance by Psappha, the Manchester-based new music ensemble, featured bass-baritone Stephen Bowen, and a production by Soutra Gilmour. Everything about their interpretation was careful and considered, from the subtle way the lighting suggested different scenes to the detail of the players' performances.

Bowen told his horrific tales with the intimacy of a benevolent bedtime story. The soft-focused sounds of Allan Neave's guitar and Claire O'Neill's flutes were expertly balanced, while Tim Williams's percussion created everything from rustling backdrops to dramatic thunderclaps.

But this perfection was also the biggest problem with this production. There was little sense of anger in Bowen's interpretation, and the players never seemed to be inspired by improvisatory passion. The political force of Montejo's words was neutered by their approach, and the effect was listless and fragmented rather than combative and dynamic. El Cimarron was divorced from its roots in revolutionary struggle, and Henze's relent lessly abstract musical idiom seemed to obscure the directness of Montejo's imagery rather than amplify it.

The Endymion Ensemble's afternoon concert showcased Henze's chamber music of the late 1940s. Apollo et Hyazinthus is an astonishingly assured work, written in 1949, which shows how quickly Henze assimilated modernist idioms into his personal style. A single-movement harpsichord concerto that turns into a scena for mezzo-soprano, it is structurally lucid and warmly expressive.

Louise Mott and the Endymions gave a completely convincing performance, and the players were equally impressive in Henze's 1948 Kammersonate for piano trio. The programme, designed by Henze himself, also included Oliver Knussen's Océan de Terre, a crystalline setting of Apollinaire, which featured soprano Eileen Hulse, and the world premiere of Kenneth Hesketh's fluent and accomplished Netsuke for eight-piece ensemble.

fields.headline: Music's other Geri
fields.standfirst:
Geri Allen
Pizza Express Jazz Club, London
****
fields.trailText:
Geri Allen
Pizza Express Jazz Club, London
****
fields.body:
There aren't many Geris in contemporary music who spell their name with one R and an I, and unless a jazz fifth column had infiltrated the quiz night in your local, the name of Allen would never replace Halliwell. Yet Geri Allen, the remarkable Detroit pianist, is just as much a star in her own firmament.

You don't have to be familiar, as she is, with jazz piano legends such as Bill Evans or Keith Jarrett to get her message, but if you are, it deepens an already fascinating story. Ornette Coleman and the late Betty Carter are among the bandleaders who have confirmed their appreciation of all that by hiring her.

But in recent years Allen has more often shaped her own destiny, as a composer, improvisor and bandleader. She was at the Pizza Express for two nights last week, with a deft, sensitive trio featuring the Johnson brothers - Billy on bass and Mark on drums. As ever, the core of the performance was Allen's unwavering focus, zigzagging unpredictability of line and controlled energy.

Allen improvises in more extended lines, and with more composer-like variation of motif and mood within a solo than is common for many of her contemporaries on the instrument. And if her music can at times be prone to preoccupied longueurs and over-formality, the overwhelming impact was to suggest that a musician of sophistication and immense resources continues to grow.

Allen often began with unaccompanied overtures, rich arpeggiated melodies rippling and washing over quirkily lively left-hand figures, sometimes rather reminiscent of Wayne Shorter themes. Her timing is immaculate, enabling her to retain the sense of urgent movement in a fastmoving piece, whether pegging it explicitly to the beat, or suddenly flooding the music with melody so intensified it barely seems constructed of individual notes.

Slow features such as Angels emphasised Allen's concentration on the timbres of the piano, beginning obliquely and accelerating into a bell-pealing eagerness, with a little of Jarrett's clamorous harmony, while Feed the Fire - an uptempo postbop classic-to-be - brought out the best of Allen's originality of conception at speed (as well as the clean unfussiness of Johnson at the drums) before relaxing into a lazy blues.

fields.headline: Halifax directors deprived of bonuses
fields.trailText: James Crosby, chief executive of Halifax, and fellow directors failed to receive their long-term bonuses last year because the bank's share performance was not good enough.
fields.body:
James Crosby, chief executive of Halifax, and fellow directors failed to receive their long-term bonuses last year because the bank's share performance was not good enough.

Mr Crosby, who was paid £690,000 in 2000, had been granted options over more than 31,000 shares under a performance plan which started in 1998. He would have been able to exercise them this year if the bank's share price had outperformed a basket of its rivals.

Last year marked the expiration of the bank's first three-year performance pay deal since it floated on the stock market. As its shares underperformed its rivals over the period, Mr Crosby's options, along with those of executive directors Roger Boyes, Mike Ellis and John Lee, lapsed worthless.

According to the bank's annual report and accounts, all four directors were, however, granted fresh options last year under a three-year performance plan.

The bank, whose shares are below the 774p at which they made their stock market debut, is planning to grant share options - worth 20% of their salary - to all its employees who are not considered to be "executives" later this year provided shareholders approve.

The report shows that performance-related criteria for the three-years between January 2000 and December 2002 for Andy Hornby, the 34-year-old head of the bank's retail operation, have been waived over shares worth £150,000. This was arranged under the terms through which he was hired from Asda in 1999.

The accounts also reveal that, unusually, Charles Dunstone, the multi-millionaire founder of Carphone Warehouse who is a non-executive director of the bank, owns more shares in Halifax than all the executive directors combined. Mr Dunstone bought 100,000 shares in October at £5.08 each. They had risen in value to £7.31 by last night, making him a paper profit of £223,000.

Another non-executive director, chairman Lord Stevenson, also owns almost 73,000 shares and, in an usual arrangement for non-executives, is on a long-term performance related scheme introduced last year. He earned a basic of £250,000 last year and was awarded 36,800 options.

webTitle: City presses stock exchange to stay

fields.headline: City presses stock exchange to stay
fields.trailText: The Corporation of London today tries to persuade the London Stock Exchange not to sever its 200-year-old links with the heart of the City and move to Canary Wharf in Docklands.
fields.body:
The Corporation of London today tries to persuade the London Stock Exchange not to sever its 200-year-old links with the heart of the City and move to Canary Wharf in Docklands.

The City's local authority will step back from offering any monetary incentive but is expected to try to establish if it can offer solutions to any problems the exchange is facing in finding office space.

The exchange has pledged to move from the City by 2004. It admitted yesterday it had yet to decide between a move to Canary Wharf, the City's arch-rival, or new offices being built close to St Paul's Cathedral, known as Paternoster Square.

The competition for business between the City and Docklands, where rents have traditionally been cheaper, is intense and the loss of the exchange, albeit with fewer than 1,000 employees, would be of symbolic importance.

Clara Furse, chief executive of the LSE, said the exchange was looking at a number of options for its new building, including Canary Wharf and Paternoster Square.

The Corporation of London, which has a regular meeting with the exchange scheduled for today as part of its continuing attempts to help the bourse with its requirements, said: "We are keen to keep them in the City".

City sources believe the exchange will be reluctant to move to Docklands, despite the improved transport links. Sources say that terms for a move to Paternoster Square are close to being completed.

The exchange, which is searching for a new strategy after being forced to abandon merger talks with its German rival last year, yesterday announced the first deal to sell its technology to another exchange. The agreement with the Johannesburg exchange will be worth a minimum of £11m over the next five years.

fields.headline: Railtrack says that £1.5bn gift is too little
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Railtrack's continuing drain on the taxpayer became even more critical last night when it admitted it might need more than the £1.5bn allocated yesterday by the government to restore Britain's ailing rail network.
fields.body:
Railtrack's continuing drain on the taxpayer became even more critical last night when it admitted it might need more than the £1.5bn allocated yesterday by the government to restore Britain's ailing rail network.

Within hours of an announcement by John Prescott that he was releasing that money to underpin the cash-strapped company, Steve Marshall, Railtrack's chief executive, said it might not be enough.

The money is part of a £15bn package from the government to sustain Railtrack over the next five years, but Mr Marshall said that the company was "already overstretched".

Asked whether Railtrack would need more help, Mr Marshall replied: "We have got to be clear by summer next year what we need to spend incrementally and then put a compelling case to the rail regulator."

Railtrack then went on to reveal that the cost of the west coast main line project between London and Glasgow has increased by a further £500m to £6.3bn and that the first stage will be delayed another six months, until October next year.

This is the fourth time in less than two years that the cost of the project has risen without warning. It began at £2.2bn, but suddenly doubled and has been rising ever since. The government was only aware of the new costing yesterday.

The news also took the train operating companies by surprise. None of them had been informed officially and they said they were "outraged at the delay and lack of communication."

Railtrack's revelations took the gloss off the government's package of measures on rail improvements which were designed as a pre-election fillip for the industry.

At the core of the government's package is the appointment of a Railtrack "public interest director". Mr Prescott, who insisted on the idea, said that the presence of a non-executive director would represent "a powerful voice for the public".

The City reacted adversely to the news that the government has at last put a foot through Railtrack's door. Railtrack's shares tumbled 20% to 570p.

fields.headline: The rich are different
fields.standfirst:
But will Labour's millionaires give it away?
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Price inflation may be under control in Britain, but not the inflation of millionaires.
fields.body:
Price inflation may be under control in Britain, but not the inflation of millionaires. According to Datamonitor, the number of millionaires in Britain has grown by 17% a year since 1995 to 73,990, helped by soaring house and - until recently - stock market prices. These figures underestimate the number of millionaires because they do not include pension fund assets, often the biggest source of individual wealth. New Labour has clearly done favours for the rich as well as the poor. Whether any of the new rich will switch their votes to Labour in gratitude can only be speculated on.

What is missing in Britain is not a list of people receiving wealth, but a list of those giving it away. In the US it is different. Entrepreneurs make far bigger fortunes and flaunt them as well. But at least this is accompanied by a tradition of philanthropy. Multi-billionaires like Bill Gates and Warren Buffet recently told the new president that they did not want a reduction in estate duty because they did not want to pass on vast fortunes to a new generation that had not earned it. They have not forgotten Andrew Carnegie's axiom: " The sole purpose of being rich is to give away money."

fields.headline: Bash
fields.standfirst:
Gate Theatre, Dublin
****
fields.trailText:
Gate Theatre, Dublin
****
fields.body:
The bad conscience of whiter-than-white New England is aired once again in this odd, dark trio of playlets by Neil LaBute, in a new production he directs himself.

With a nod to Euripides, Iphigenia in Orem is a late-night confessional in the hotel bedroom of a salesman who, when his corporate livelihood was imperilled, smothered his infant daughter. Actor Jason Patric employs plenty of dramatic irony to capture the distasteful sense of descent in some stranger's appalling life.

But LaBute pays finicky attention to hand gestures and his own distracted, staccato flow of speech. It's a David Mametesque stab at naturalism that becomes arch and mannered - to say nothing of the rather wearing cavernous pauses.

Some of the same qualities pervade Medea Redux, in which a damaged young woman in custody (a pained, affecting performance by Flora Montgomery), tells her story: pregnant at 13 to a schoolteacher, an abandoned mother at 14. It gradually dawns that this is about a parallel act of child sacrifice. But, unlike corporate man, the woman doesn't get away with it, although we are left with more sympathy for her.

Even sharper is A Gaggle of Saints, a more substantial, acidly charming duologue from a privileged, church-going, young Bostonian couple who attend a high school/ church reunion party in Manhattan. The direction is far snappier here, and Justine Mitchell's snobby trophy-gal is the perfect foil for Jason O'Mara's bombastic, preening performance as her boyfriend.

The latter, affronted by an openly gay couple in Central Park, has committed murder, guilt-free and with complete impunity. O'Mara hilariously depicts the homophobia of good, clean-living white America, but although true to life, it is a rather blunt instrument.

In his programme note, LaBute describes his characters as ordinary, well-meaning folk who have "perfected the art of hurting others". He illustrates this with a photo taken in the Warsaw ghetto in 1941 of a boy dying in the street, ignored by passers-by. LaBute admits that this image humbles his own attempts to capture the monstrosity of infanticide.

 Until April 14. Box office: 00-353 1 8744045.

fields.headline: NSCD Spring Showcase
fields.standfirst:
NSCD Spring Showcase
The Riley Theatre, Leeds
****
fields.trailText:
NSCD Spring Showcase
The Riley Theatre, Leeds
****
fields.body:
Now the Arts Council has clipped the wings of Leeds-based Phoenix Dance, perhaps some cash could be invested in a new company to harness the considerable talents of these students.

Graduates from the Northern School of Contemporary Dance work with leading contemporary companies across the world and there are several dancers in this year's crop who could easily slot into Rambert. Disciplined, focused, and with plenty of stagecraft savvy, these 18-to 21-year-olds perform with such maturity that you could be watching professionals.

This three-hour marathon sported four premieres and two reprises of works from a clutch of important choreographers, including Mark Baldwin, Bernadette Iglich and award-winning Jamie Watton.

It all became a bit of a blur towards the end but the opener, Sorrowful Songs, from the excellent John Carney left a huge impression. In the same way composer John Tavener captures the essence of Greek Orthodoxy in his music, Carney evokes the heart of Judaism in his choreography, augmenting this hugely moving portrayal of mourners at the Crucifixion with traditional Jewish circle dances set to the soaring strains of Gorecki's Third Symphony.

The first years tackled this numinous creation with great solemnity, the 12 dancers like a Greek chorus, sweeping the stage in shadowy grey. Lit in a gold halo, Christ - sensitively portrayed by Belgian student Frederic Claudel - descended with arms outstretched on his wooden yoke to dance a testing solo that seemed to encapsulate the stages of the cross in his stumbling agony. Carney sculpted his groups of dancers into a final tableau, with Christ's body cradled in loving arms.

There was a riot when Nijinsky put steps to Stravinsky's The Rite of Spring in 1913. Happily, there were roars of approval for Baldwin's version, made with the students last year. This time a tribe of men and 15 maidens in denim jackets stomp out the ritual rhythms. The primal violence is all there but it has a fresh, modern feel. Burmese student Jeong Choi danced with an earthy, desperate acceptance as the sacrificial victim while Jamaican Kofi Walker is a lyrical mover with huge promise for the future.

Iglich's new Void was a kaleidoscope of small gestures and bursts of Cunningham-like energy for the second years, while Hir, Watton's confrontational piece, had them on their toes like sparring partners, bobbing and weaving, trying to outdo each other with great style.

fields.headline: C&W cuts free of fallen Pacific star
fields.trailText: Cable & Wireless yesterday decided to cut its losses by selling its 14.7% stake in Pacific Century CyberWorks, the fallen star of Hong Kong's communications industry.
fields.body:
Cable & Wireless yesterday decided to cut its losses by selling its 14.7% stake in Pacific Century CyberWorks, the fallen star of Hong Kong's communications industry.

The British telecoms and internet group said it planned to raise about £1bn by issuing bonds convertible into its PCCW shares.

The group will pay no interest on the bonds but will have to buy them back at par in June 2003, if unexchanged PCCW shares are not worth more than HK$3.60 each.

C&W acquired the PCCW stake when it sold its controlling holding in Hongkong Telecom last August, when telecom stocks were still booming. The £10.4bn deal was made up of £4.3bn in cash and the rest in PCCW shares. A month later C&W raised a further £1bn cash when it sold a 4.9% stake in PCCW in the market.

Under a lock-in agreement, it had to hold half the remaining shares until February and the rest until August this year. PCCW has agreed to waive this last restriction as part of yesterday's deal.

The bond issue will lift C&W's cash mountain to about £4bn, with several billion more to come when it completes the sale of its stake in Optus, its Australian telecom offshoot, to Singapore Telecom later in the year.

The company's strong cash position has added fuel to rumours that C&W is considering a big takeover. It has also prompted suggestions of a break-up bid for the company.

A C&W spokeswoman said that the whole bond issue had been underwritten by Warburgs. She said C&W had never intended to be a long term holder of the shares.

She denied that the company was disappointed in PCCW, whose shares have fallen by 86% since C&W acquired its stake.

"Our view is that the deal we did was strategically absolutely right for us and we maximised the amount of cash at the time," she said.

"It was always understood that we would not be a long term strategic holder of the shares. Obviously everyone would have preferred the shares not to have fallen."

C&W sold its stake in Hongkong Telecom after it ceased to be one of the group's best performing subsidiaries. The spokeswoman said HKT saw three years of double digit decline after losing its Hong Kong telecom monopoly - largely as a result of competition from rival mobile phone operators.

PCCW is headed by Richard Li, son of Hong Kong's wealthiest businessman, Li Ka Shing. The PCCW chairman yesterday admitted he had been wrong not to correct reports that he had a degree. He left Stanford University before graduating.

webTitle: Opera: I Capuleti e i Montecchi

fields.headline: Bellini's fusty Romeo and Juliet
fields.standfirst:
I Capuleti e i Montecchi
Royal Opera House, London
**
fields.trailText:
I Capuleti e i Montecchi
Royal Opera House, London
**
fields.body:
A retro effort when it was new in 1984, the Royal Opera's production of Bellini's I Capuleti e i Montecchi has now acquired the fustiness of unwanted bric-a-brac. But although Pier Luigi Pizzi's direction attempts to get to the heart of a difficult work, the results aren't always convincing.

Capuleti is Bellini's version of Romeo and Juliet, though the libretto is based not on Shakespeare, but on the 16th-century novella that formed the play's source. It is radically different: a civil war takes the place of urban factionalism, and the whole is underpinned by political manoeuvring. Romeo gets into the Capuleti stronghold by posing as an ambassador; Lorenzo is no friar, but a well-meaning, if ineffectual, diplomat.

Bellini kicks off with the lovers already embroiled, the Capuleti heir dead and Giulietta's father pushing her to marry Tebaldo (Bellini's equivalent of Paris rather than Tybalt). However, the whole piece is ultimately an exercise in Romantic erotic morbidity. Giulietta drinks the poison halfway through, and her obsequies are extended and elaborate, with the final tomb scene taking up nearly a quarter of the score.

The problem with the Royal Opera's version is that it combines the subtlety of a sledgehammer with a lack of conviction. The designs are black-on-black, with only coloured cloaks designating the various factions. The occasional sword fight and a few hunky extras looking hard are the only intimations of violence.

The lack of conviction extends in places to the musical aspects as well. The score itself is problematic. At his greatest, Bellini was a genius who conveyed acute psychological perception in music that nakedly exposes both the singers' voices and the characters' emotions. He was also a painstaking worker. Capuleti, unusually, was flung together in a matter of weeks, and the creaks in the score are more than once apparent.

The casting is also desperately uneven. Romeo was written for the dramatic mezzo Giuditta Pasta and recent interpreters include such greats as Janet Baker and Tatiana Troyanos. Here, however, we have Sonia Ganassi, who belts her way through much of the part with only an intermittent awareness of the fact that the notes are meant to connect to form phrases. Tito Beltran's Tebaldo is clarion but inelegant.

The evening's saving graces come in the form of Elena Kelessidi's Giulietta and Lorenzo Regazzo's Lorenzo. Kelessidi's passionate commitment is apparent in every phrase and gesture; Regazzo is handsome, subtle and often deeply moving. In the pit, however, Bruno Campanella takes ages to settle, and there are some curious moments of unrefined playing.

 In rep until April 20. Box office: 020-7304 4000.

webTitle: Why I dumped the City job with the six-figure salary

fields.headline: Why I dumped the City job with the six-figure salary
fields.standfirst:
Bruce Robinson on how he is happier earning a pittance working for a charity

Guardian Unlimited Work
fields.trailText: Bruce Robinson on how he is happier earning a pittance working for a charity.
fields.body:
September 1999: I'm on a trading floor, talking down a phone, selling derivatives to an obstinate American client. I'm earning six figures a year, and I'm utterly miserable. Fast-forward a year. A different office. I'm still talking down a phone, but now I'm working for a homelessness charity. I'm earning nothing and I've never been happier. How the hell did that happen?

After eight years in the Square Mile, my life in the fast lane had run out of gas. I no longer cared about the markets or my clients, and wasn't even bothered about my bonus. I snoozed in front of my screens, waking to find dribble on my desk. I was moody and moany, vacantly sullen, a fun guy to be with.

Having hated my job for a year, my performance was pretty poor. I told myself that it was just temporary, but in my heart I knew my career was comatose. Yet how could I leave? What else could I possibly do? The markets provided few skills transferable to the real world, and nothing else paid nearly as well. It took a friend to open my eyes. On discovering the ruddy-faced health of my bank balances, she pointed out that I could afford to leave the next day: the only thing stopping me was myself.

Only then did I begin to consider life outside the City. Over the next six months I applied for a few jobs, but my lack of conviction was transparent, and rewarded accordingly. I didn't know what I wanted to do; I only knew what I didn't. More months passed with me stuck in my silken rut until another friend got drunk to the point of truthfulness and, exasperated, snapped that I should "go and work for a charity or something".

Immediately everything became obvious. I decided to take some time off and volunteer for a charity. If I guaranteed them six months, I reasoned, I would surely find an interesting, challenging job that would account for my time away from paid employment. Meanwhile I could rethink my options and look for a new career. Everyone would be a winner. All I had to do was find the charity.

This proved to be the tricky part. There are a lot of voluntary organisations out there. With ignorant simplicity I discarded entire sectors and ultimately decided on 12, ranging from overseas aid to homelessness. I updated my CV, wrote some letters and sat back for the flood of replies.

It was a long wait. After a month of silence I was getting discouraged. This was compounded by the few replies that tiptoed back. One said they were very keen and would be in touch. I never heard from them again. Another said they had no need for me, a third had envelopes to be stuffed.

Finally I began to get some interest and arranged surreptitious meetings: with bonus time approaching, I didn't want anyone to know my plans. But the suggested jobs - databases, media monitoring - were useful rather than interesting. Not unreasonably, several people wanted me to twist some City arms into stumping up serious money. Yet the last thing I wanted was to turn up with a begging bowl and a big smile, trying to tap my former friends.

After three months my plan was wobbling badly. The organisations I was talking to seemed to be in a state of chaos, or unable to think beyond the narrowest boundaries. Almost every one had failed to reply, lost my details, didn't want me or needed me only as unskilled office-fodder. Only a lucky break saved the situation. A friend of a friend suggested her old employer, a campaigning charity working with homeless people. It had been on my original list of 12. I had written to them twice but received no reply. She suggested I try again, and gave me a name.

This short cut made progress delightfully swift. Within days I had met my new contact. She seemed enthusiastic and quickly came back with a proposal. As a history graduate with eight years of trading interest rates, I understood little of her spiel on green papers, but understood that she wanted me to research smart schemes that prevented or alleviated homelessness. Anything valuable would be used in their response to this green paper thingie, and so might actually achieve something, she said. After years mentally treading water, I liked the idea of learning something new, even housing policy. I was eager to start - as soon as my bonus was banked.

In February 2000, four months after I began my search, I left the City. My colleagues confided over drunken celebrations that they had thought I'd never really do it, and how they'd considered doing the same but "didn't have the nerve". Yet as a single person, with only a small mortgage and bonuses stashed away, I was in a unique position. And only I knew how desperate I was to leave.

Unusually muted and nervous, I found my first weeks endlessly surprising. Accustomed to the buzz of a trading floor, this new environment was disturbingly quiet. I could hear the tapping of keyboards and conversations on the phone. Even these were different: people spoke in whole sentences, without the "yeah, yeah, right, right, offer this, bid that, done" tempo I knew so well. As for the people, I was expecting a collection of meek do-gooders, but I was surprised to find genuine friendliness, with my previous career attracting only curiosity mixed with sympathy.

The biggest surprise, however, was me. Arriving for a six-month stint, steeped in City cynicism, I never expected to enjoy it so much. The office was basic and the computers prehistoric, but I loved it. With the tedious zeal typical of converts, I had found a home and had a new subject to bore friends with. It helped that I enjoyed the project, that the office hummed with purpose and every day brought something new. And I liked the people, even when I forgot I was no longer on a trading floor and they had to tell me to stop shouting.

It took five months to complete my project. That done, I had no desire to leave and volunteered for another couple of months, writing bits and pieces, even stuffing envelopes. Just as I was planning to go and earn some money, I was asked to stay and temp in the press office. By September I was earning much less and working much harder than ever before, but according to everyone who knew me well, I was "a new man".

This was an eye-opener, coming from an environment where your worth was your bonus. It was novel to be working 14-hour days without complaint for what I once regarded as a pittance. It was amusing to see the faces of former colleagues, who assumed I was massaging my conscience, when I told them - truthfully - that I had never worked harder.

I told myself that it was just temporary, but in my heart I knew my career was comatose. Yet how could I leave? What else could I possibly do? fields.headline: The way we work
fields.standfirst: Forget sports stars, businessmen should be listening to the Greenham Common women
fields.trailText: Forget sports stars, businessmen should be listening to the Greenham Common women
fields.body:
The rise of the business ethic in sport has filled thousands of newspaper columns: some lament the loss of the casual, few-pints-before-kick-off days, while others welcome the superiority of the finely tuned professional athlete. More worrying, though, is the migration in the opposite direction, with sporties giving lessons to the corporate classes.

Former sports players and coaches are raking in the fees by showing that increasing market share in sales of foolscap filing systems is really just the same as scaling Everest, sailing around the world or winning a major golf tournament. They can charge thousands of pounds for sharing their wisdom and come from all walks of sport: explorer Sir Ranulph Fiennes, sailor Tracy Edwards and runner Roger Black. But what's the connection with quarterly sales figures?

Edwards, who runs Team (Tracy Edwards Associates Motivation), says the unique selling point of athletes as business gurus is how similar they are to all of us. (Yeah, right.) "Our message is that we are ordinary people," she says. "And that ordinary people in all walks of life can achieve extraordinary things." In fact, it is precisely their extraordinary nature that makes them so appealing. They mesmerise the middle-aged men of the fat-cat class. It is also a reflection of the male-dominated culture of the British boardroom.

You may have been appalled that David Beckham got £20,000 to wear a pair of sunglasses. Don't be. He wears sunglasses almost as well as he kicks a football. Be appalled when, in a few years time, he could be earning £20,000 for talking about the challenges of maintaining a cost-effective monitoring system across global supply chains - and how it is really just like taking a corner. Downsizing with David Beckham: you read it here first.

In the old days, these athlete-entrepreneurs were restricted to telling a few funny stories after dinner. Now, though, they are providing the core content of courses in leadership, management and skills. And the model they use is often completely inappropriate. They continue to promote the idea of business as heroic competition against the odds - when what businesses need is skills in effective collaboration and organic growth.

Listen to Sir Ranulph's manifesto: "When you're on an expedition suffering from gangrene, you get irritable with colleagues and want to give up, but have to keep going by turning that into a fighting spirit," he says. "Similarly you can turn an underperforming sales team into a winner by encouraging competitiveness among members."

Well, maybe. Or you might turn it into a winner by discouraging competitiveness among members, improving communication, seeking clarity around a shared goal, or by encouraging a culture of fun. The model for business provided by sports is getting past its sell-by date.

The group I would most like to see touring the corporate circuit are the women founders of the Greenham Common peace protests. How did a one-off event evolve successfully into such a PR triumph? How did they work without a strict hierarchy? Their lessons would be much more appropriate to business than the repeated cliches of yesterday's yachtsmen. But in the meantime, the schoolboy sports dreams of today's top executives will continue to provide a lucrative retirement scheme for the also-rans.

 Richard Reeves (rreeves@indsoc.co.uk) writes fortnightly. Email Work: work@theguardian.com.

webTitle: Donna Karan finally falls for LVMH

fields.headline: Donna Karan finally falls for LVMH
fields.trailText: Donna Karan International, the US fashion group, finally succumbed to the attractions of LVMH yesterday after the world's largest luxury goods group sweetened its takeover offer to $243m (£171m).
fields.body:
Donna Karan International, the US fashion group, finally succumbed to the attractions of LVMH yesterday after the world's largest luxury goods group sweetened its takeover offer to $243m (£171m).

LVMH boss Bernard Arnault declared victory in gaining a US foothold for his global empire. The $10.75 a share offer, 26% higher than the price originally offered for the business last December, brings to an end a three-month takeover battle.

Several shareholders filed lawsuits against Donna Karan and the company after LVMH's earlier agreement to buy Gabrielle Studio, which owns the valuable Donna Karan trademarks and which is itself owned by the eponymous designer and her husband.

Yesterday's sweetened bid will not actually cost the French group any more money than first agreed. Under the deal with Ms Karan, the designer will give back $50m of the $450m she received for Gabrielle Studio, making up for the 26% increase in the price for the company.

John Idol, DKI's chief executive, said yesterday that the board had "done an excellent job in negotiating the price". In July, the company hired bank Merrill Lynch to prepare a valuation assessment and look for other buyers.

Ms Karan, who will remain chief designer of the new company, said the sale would help her realise her full potential. "As the co-founder of DKI, the growth and development of this company has been my life's work," she said.

Ms Karan said she was ruled by her heart rather than her head in accepting the $400m payoff.

She will take 14% of the new subsidiary business of LVMH after making an undisclosed investment.

Shareholders representing 42% of the company have agreed to the new terms of the LVMH deal.

fields.headline: Agents join the non-playing superstars
fields.trailText: Investors are now being offered the chance to share in some of the wealth football agents generate.
fields.body:
Those not blessed with a range of skills good enough to bring them a contract with a Premiership club could still fund a fleet of Ferraris by becoming an agent. Traditionally seen as dodgy geezers in dodgier suits, agents are cleaning up their act and earning eye-watering sums from football's financial boom.

Big money moves like Rio Ferdinand's £18m switch from West Ham to Leeds can bring an agent a commission in excess of £1m, plus a share of the player's wages each week for the length of his contract.

Investors are now being offered the chance to share in some of that wealth. Recent months have seen the flotations of three firms that specialise in representing sports stars - Sports Resource, Kingsbridge Holdings and First Artists.

Despite shaky stock markets all three are trading well above their issue prices. First Artists, run by brothers Phil and Jon Smith and representing footballers like Kanu of Arsenal and Kevin Phillips of Sunderland, only listed last week on the lightly regulated Ofex market. It raised £2.3m through an issue that was heavily over-subscribed.

Last year it had a turnover of £1.39m and a pre-tax profit of £447,500 but it believes it could be turning over £8.6m a year by June 30 2004 and clearing operating profits in excess of £6m.

Sports Resource is the brainchild of former Leeds United boss Chris Akers and Freepages founder Nigel Robertson. It does not have many football interests yet but has bought several sports agencies and represents stars including golfers Lee Westwood and Darren Clarke.

Kingsbridge Holdings is not an agency as such, rather a financial adviser providing pension advice to the Premier League and Nationwide League players.

Shareholders are thought to include footballers Andy Cole and David Ginola.

The doyens of English football agents remain the duo of Jon Holmes and Tony Stephens. Their firms were bought out by SFX Entertainment, which in turn has been acquired by US media firm Clear Channel. Mr Holmes and Mr Stephens represent most of English football's best known names.

fields.headline: Music moguls agree to online venture
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Three of the world's five largest record companies agreed to license their music to a new online venture yesterday in a move heralded as a breakthrough for digital downloading.
fields.body:
Three of the world's five largest record companies agreed to license their music to a new online venture yesterday in a move heralded as a breakthrough for digital downloading.

AOL Time Warner, Bertelsmann and EMI Group have all agreed to invest in a new online subscription service, to be called MusicNet. The service, to be run as a separate company, will use technology provided by RealNetworks, the streaming media company.

The new operation is expected to act as a rival to the subscription service to be launched by Napster, the song-swapping service, this year. MusicNet said yesterday that it would work with other online services, including Napster.

Oliver Herrgesell, a spokesman for Bertelsmann, said the German company would continue to work with Napster on its legal, subscription service as well as MusicNet. "We want to have our content everywhere," he said.

Online analysts believe that MusicNet is an important step in allowing consumers to legally download music online. Large record labels have previously been accused of failing to provide a viable online service, allowing Napster and other companies to take advantage of fast-growing demand.

Although financial terms of the deal were not disclosed, company insiders said that RealNetworks would own 40% of MusicNet with the three media groups owning about 20% each.

webTitle: American Express loses on junk bonds

fields.headline: American Express loses on junk bonds
fields.trailText: American Express, the credit card company, last night warned that first quarter profits would be hurt by a $185m (£130m) junk bond loss, deepening the gloom on Wall Street.
fields.body:
American Express, the credit card company, last night warned that first quarter profits would be hurt by a $185m (£130m) junk bond loss, deepening the gloom on Wall Street.

Analysts said the news, coinciding with the DuPont chemical company announcing a cut of 4,000 jobs, prompted fears that the present round of earnings announcements would be bleaker than anticipated.

Art Hogan, chief market analyst at Jefferies and Co, said: "We're definitely going to see a lot more of this, and it makes people nervous."

The Dow Jones industrial average was down more than 150 points by lunchtime to 9,725, exacerbated by deteriorating relations between the US and China. Financial companies were particularly hard hit but tech shares also fell. The Nasdaq composite index had fallen 45 points, or almost 2%, to 1,795 by lunchtime.

American Express shares fell 6% after it said earnings would be 18% lower than last year because of the losses in its junk bond portfolio.

Junk bonds, which are issued to less creditworthy companies, have caused losses for several financial companies as the slowing US economy has hindered repayments. Amex blamed asbestos-related bankruptcies and investments in health care companies for its losses. Shares in other financial services companies also fell sharply yesterday.

Amex, linked with Citigroup in takeover speculation, said it was unlikely to meet a previously reduced growth target of 12% this year.

Dupont blamed slower sales for the decision to close several factories and reduce its global workforce by 4%.

fields.headline: Recession alarm sounds
fields.standfirst: Backlash from US slowdown hits British factories
fields.trailText: Warning signals of recession in Britain's manufacturing industry were flashing strongly yesterday amid evidence that the global backlash from the slowdown in the once-booming US economy is cutting output from Britain's factories.
fields.body:
Warning signals of recession in Britain's manufacturing industry were flashing strongly yesterday amid evidence that the global backlash from the slowdown in the once-booming US economy is cutting output from Britain's factories.

After months of remaining robust despite signs of weakening activity on the other side of the Atlantic, the monthly snapshot of industry from Britain's purchasing managers showed order books weakening and activity starting to contract.

City analysts said the across-the-board gloom contained in the survey - compounded by similar downbeat news from Japan, the eurozone and the US - markedly shortened the odds on a cut in interest rates from the Bank of England on Thursday.

Although the official figures for manufacturing still suggest output is marginally rising, economists said signs of a weakening of activity both in the domestic and export markets also underlined the economic risks for the government in postponing the date of the general election until June at the earliest.

Gordon Brown, the chancellor of the exchequer, was one of the leading Cabinet ministers cautioning against delaying polling day, and yesterday's purchasing managers' in dex provided evidence that activity was slowing even in sectors unaffected by the outbreak of foot and mouth.

The Chartered Institute of Purchasing and Supply said: "Firms reported that demand had been hit both at home and abroad and that, in particular, the downturn in the market for semi-conductors had adversely affected order books.

"Overall, firms reported that contraction in export markets reflected global economic slowdown, and pointed to the knock-on effects that the US downturn has had, not only on orders to the US but also to other countries affected by lower US demand."

The institute said that any reading on its purchasing managers' index below 50 shows that manufacturing activity is contracting, and that last month the index fell from 52.2 to 49.7. For the first time since February 1999 all the main components of the index - output, new orders, export orders, employment and stocks - stood below 50.

Michael Saunders, economist with Schroder Salomon SmithBarney said the UK PMI showed that Britain was not immune from problems in the rest of the world and highlighted the "sharp global downturn in the latest surveys for manufacturing. These readings suggest that global industrial production is set to weaken markedly further in coming months, prompting most central banks to cut rates."

The Reuter's PMI for the eurozone, Britain's main export market, fell to its lowest level in two years yesterday to a level just above the recession benchmark. Meanwhile, Japan began the new business year with the return of recession fears yesterday as a key central bank survey showed the first decline in corporate confidence in 27 months.

Domestic deflation, falling stock prices and a weakening of the key export market of the United States pushed the "tankan" index of confidence among big manufacturers - usually the mainstay of Japan's economy - into negative territory for the first time since March last year.

fields.headline: Profits match Man Utd dominance
fields.trailText: Manchester United have reported soaring half-year results, despite a slowdown in sales of shirts, scarves and souvenirs to fans in Britain.
fields.body:
Extra capacity at Old Trafford helped Manchester United match its Premiership domination with soaring half-year results, despite a slowdown in sales of shirts, scarves and souvenirs to fans in Britain.

The world's richest soccer club announced a 42% jump in pretax profits to £17.3m, sending its shares up 17p to 189p.

Gate receipts were up 32%, thanks to one extra game in the period and to the completion of a new stand which increased Old Trafford's capacity from 55,400 to 67,000.

Chief executive Peter Kenyon said: "We feel very confident with the new capacity - it's important that all our games have been sold out."

New kiosks and restaurants at the stadium delivered sharp increases in income from conferences and catering. However, the club's revenue from merchandising fell 9% to £13m.

Mr Kenyon said: "There's been a general softening in the sports retail sector. There's an increasing number of new ways of supporting a club which go beyond buying merchandise."

The fall in revenue was particularly sharp for wholesalers in Britain, despite a strong launch of the team's new kit last year and a strong performance from Manchester United's superstore at Old Trafford.

The club recently signed a £303m, 13-year deal handing over much of its merchandising to Nike.

United is looking overseas for growth - research from the polling agency Mori has suggested that the club has 50m fans worldwide, including 1.8m in Bangkok where the team goes on tour this summer. Mr Kenyon said: "The strategy is to turn those fans into customers. Man United is more than a football club - it's a global football brand."

The club has introduced a new salary structure to put players on different pay scales. The club's wages bill rose by £1.9m during the period, despite a lack of any big-name new signings. Wages accounted for 35% of turnover.

Mr Kenyon said he was comfortable with a new agreement on transfers, thrashed out by European soccer chiefs over the weekend. The arrangement means players get compensation if their contracts are broken without a good reason.

"We believe it's satisfactory," Mr Kenyon said. "There were lots of doomsday scenarios being painted around this."

fields.headline: They think it's all over
fields.standfirst: TV money attracted City players to football club shares. Rising costs have sent many running to the exits
fields.trailText: TV money once attracted City players to football club shares but rising costs have sent many of these investors running to the exits.
fields.body:
They are the glamour games that Leeds United's fans and directors have been dreaming of for years. Barcelona, Lazio, Real Madrid and AC Milan have all travelled to the Yorkshire club's Elland Road ground this season to contest the European Champions League under the gaze of a worldwide television audience.

More often than not the home side has come out on top in football's most lucrative competition, delighting capacity crowds and those in the executive boxes enjoying corporate hospitality.

This is English football's promised land. A domestic game on a high, fuelled financially by £1.4bn of broadcasting revenues and millions more from merchandising, tickets and a booming corporate hospitality business.

It has persuaded 27 football clubs in England, Scotland and Wales to list their shares on various domestic stock markets over the past 10 years.

Yet for investors in Leeds United and almost every other club the revolution has never really happened. As an investment, football club shares now appear to be only for diehard fans.

Six years after shares in Leeds Sporting began trading, at 14p, they are changing hand at just 12.75p, even though turnover in the past six months was greater than the whole of 1999.

Injection of cash

It is a similar story at Chelsea Village in London where shares in the owner of the football club are trading at less than half their market debut value and last week touched an all-time low. That despite last year's injection of cash from broadcaster BSkyB, record shirt sponsorship and extra income from two hotels and a travel company. Chairman Ken Bates says profits have been depressed by the cost of developing leisure facilities that surround the club's Stamford Bridge stadium.

Further north in the capital, even Sir Alan Sugar, the belligerent founder of Amstrad, has packed his bags and sold up at Tottenham Hotspur. He accepted an 80p per share offer from investment company Enic, even though two years ago he dismissed as too cheap a bid from the same company pitched at the same price.

In a graphic illustration of how out of fashion football club shares are, Enic's stock price has fallen to a five-year low since it closed the deal to buy out Sir Alan.

Of course, investors in poorly performing clubs have done even worse. Shares in Loftus Road, owner of Queens Park Rangers as well as Wasps rugby club, were delisted yesterday as the directors admitted that the club was urgently seeking a refinancing. After four years of straight losses, chairman Chris Wright has grown weary of writing out fresh cheques.

Even shares in Manchester United, the sector's richest and best managed player which yesterday notched up half-year profits of £17.3m, have fallen 60% over the past year. Analysts say the growth in player wages - Manchester United's David Beckham is reportedly negotiating English football's first £100,000-plus weekly pay packet - combined with an ongoing review of the transfer system, which could see assets worth millions leave clubs for nothing, has weighed heavily on football shares.

"The market capitalisation of football clubs bears no relation to their true asset values," says Peter Ridsdale, chairman of Leeds Sporting, who insists he cannot understand why his share price is so depressed. "The football sector as a whole is clearly out of favour but surely we can't be valued properly? We're in the top five of the Premier League, we're in the quarter finals of the Champions League, we've done record sponsorship deals with big brands like Strongbow and Nike, we're controlling wage inflation and we've got one of the most valuable squads in the country."

In the six months ended December 2000, turnover at Leeds Sporting climbed 67% to £41m but profits fell from £6.5m to £95,000 year on year due largely to the £18m purchase of defender Rio Ferdinand.

Mr Ridsdale's complaint is echoed by chairmen at other clubs. Hugh Roberts recently left the Suffolk-based brewer Adnams to become chief executive of Sunderland plc. The club's shares have fallen 30% over the past year and now trade below their issue price.

Mr Roberts says: "At the moment the City doesn't see sustained profits in football clubs and it is up to us to show we can change that." In the six months ended last January, Sunderland's turnover climbed 25% to £25.5m and pretax profit rose 33% to £3.5m.

Dan Jones, director of sport business at accountancy firm Deloitte & Touche, says rising player wages remains the biggest threat to clubs' long-term profitability.

"As a rule of thumb, any club paying less than half of their turnover in total wages and salaries are carefully managing for the long term. Wages of over two-thirds of turnover are likely to be unsustainable in the long term and worryingly an increasing number of clubs are spending over that level. This is a crucial benchmark and the red light is already flashing."

Deloitte & Touche figures show that during the 1998-99 season 10 of the 20 Premiership clubs were already in the danger band, with Blackburn Rovers, Southampton and Liverpool the worst of fenders. Eighty per cent of all English professional clubs now exceed Deloitte & Touche's two-thirds marker.

A year ago those concerns seemed to be forgotten as media companies BSkyB, NTL and Granada Media invested in a string of top clubs including Arsenal, Aston Villa, Liverpool and Newcastle.

The broadcasters typically bought a 9.9% stake in each, in return for a share of future media revenues. Share prices rose amid the excitement of the multi-million pound windfalls but fell as shareholders realised that the minority stakes seemed to rule offside outright takeovers.

A renegotiated Premier League broadcasting contract kicks in at the start of next season and might bring some salvation for football club shareholders.

Unproven concept

It also brings the first regular pay per view games, which football clubs have long seen as a potential cash cow. However, PPV football is an unproven concept and several observers, such as Mr Ridsdale and an increasing number of City analysts, do not believe fans will be prepared to pay to watch games that are probably not even the best of the weekend. BSkyB, with the contract for live Premiership games, is likely to snaffle those.

"There are concerns about whether the games will generate the sort of revenue being talked about," says Nigel Hawkins, analyst at Williams de Broe.

Further flotations of football clubs appear unlikely. Aim-listed Leicester City last week said it would seek to raise a £28m bond to fund a new stadium rather than issue new shares. Arsenal, the nearest thing to a potential blue-chip investment after Manchester United, is thought to have looked at moving from Ofex to Aim or the main market but current conditions make that difficult.

Aston Villa chairman Doug Ellis has said that he would love to take the club private but, after watching the Birmingham side's shares fall from their February 1999 issue price of 650p to a third of that, believes he would not get shareholder approval.

Fans like being able to say that the share certificate on their living room wall is proof that they own a slice of the club. While share prices remain so depressed that is the only consolation they will have.

fields.headline: Isa clock is ticking
fields.standfirst: Time is running out if you want to make the most of your tax-free savings allowance before the end of the financial year. Marianne Curphey and Jill Insley offer advice on how to beat the deadline
fields.trailText: Time is running out if you want to make the most of your tax-free savings allowance before the end of the financial year. Marianne Curphey and Jill Insley offer advice on how to beat the deadline.
fields.body:
The tax year ends at midnight tonight. This is the final opportunity for investing in this year's Isa (Individual savings account) and you are unable to open an account retrospectively.

Many fund managers have come up with creative ways to help people beat the deadline. Some have opened up desks in hotels to enable people to organise drop-offs. Others, including banks and building societies, will stay open later, while Virgin Direct is allowing applications to be dropped off at its Virgin Megastore in London's Oxford Street.

Under Treasury rules you are allowed to put £7,000 into an Isa in this financial year up to midnight tonight, and a further £7,000 in the next one, which starts on April 6.

 Fidelity - has set up 41 Isa centres across the UK to give investors free internet access to its fund supermarket (Funds-Network.co.uk) until midnight, and drop-off points at hotels in 11 cities. Call 0800 41 41 71 for venues and opening times.

 Egg - will accept online applications until 11.30pm from customers who are already Egg savings account holders, or they can deliver completed forms to Egg's offices in London, Dudley and Derby until 5pm. Call 0870 010 7400 for details.

 Inter-Alliance - will take online applications for the Norwich Union until 9.30pm, Edinburgh up to 11pm, Aberdeen and M&G until 11.30pm, Johnson Fry 11.59pm, Britannic, Gartmore, Investec, Jupiter, Legal & General, and Royal & SunAlliance midnight.

 TQ Direct - will accept applications online until midnight or paper applications with cheques to its office at St Marks, Chapel Ash, Wolverhampton until 2pm.

 Bestinvest - will take online applications until midnight, or paper-based applications and cheques at 20 Mason's Yard, London SW1, until 4pm.

 Chase de Vere Investments - will take online applications until midnight, or paper-based applications through its offices in Bath, London and Leeds until 5pm. Call 0845 609 2001 for addresses.

Several fund managers have also made arrangements to receive very last-minute applications on 5 April.

Remember, they will be able to accept only applications for their own funds or cash deposits, and you will not benefit from a rebate in initial commission.

Aberdeen, ABN Amro, Cofunds, Henderson, In-vesco, M&G, Perpetual, Schroders and Threadneedle have combined forces to set up 12 collection points around the UK, open until 6pm. Call 0800 353737 for details.

Firms have also set up individual last-minute facilities for extra flexibility when making delivery arrangements:

 ABN Amro is running an 'Isa Cafe' at its offices at 82 Bishopsgate, London EC2, until 8pm. Staff will be on hand to help complete forms and answer any questions.

 Aberdeen Asset Management will accept applications online to its website until 11.30pm, or phone applications (0800 262443) until midnight.

 Alliance & Leicester building society (cash and equity Isas) is keeping six branches (in Belfast, Edinburgh, Leicester, Crawley, Croydon and Bath) open until midnight. Others will stay open until 8pm. Call 0800 412214 for details.

 Close Fund Management will accept applications at its admin offices - 9th Floor, 155 Bishopsgate, London EC2M 3XY, until 5pm and at Mellon Fund Administration, Mellon House, Ingrave Road, Brentwood, Essex CM15 8TG - until midnight.

 Credit Suisse will accept application forms and cheques until midnight at Mellon Fund Administration (see above), or at Beaufort House, 15 St Botolphs Street, London EC3A 7JJ until 3pm.

 Gartmore will take applications by telephone (0870 601 6103) or via the internet until midnight. Its offices in London and Brentwood will also be open until midnight, and in Glasgow until 6pm. Call 0870 601 6103 for details.

 Henderson will accept online applications until 10pm and drop-offs at the reception of its head office, at 4 Broad-gate, London EC2, until 6pm.

 Invesco will accept paper-based applications plus cheques at its office at 11 Devonshire Square in London until 7pm.

 Jupiter will accept applications online to its website or through Lastminute.com until 11.30pm. Telephone applications (0500 0500 98) can be made until 11.55pm, provided they are complete by midnight.

Jupiter is also operating 15 drop-off points around the UK, which will accept applications until 4pm (11.55pm in London and Kent). Call 0500 0500 98 for details.

 Smile will accept applications from its existing current account holders until 8pm.

 Virgin Direct will accept applications through the Oxford Street Virgin Megastore in London until 8.30pm, and at its own head office in Norwich until midnight.

One of the advantages of buying over the internet is there is very little room for error: thousands of people jeopardise their opportunity to open an Isa due to mistakes or omissions.

A common mistake is to forget to sign and date the paper form. The bonus of applying over the internet is that if you have forgotten to fill in one of the boxes, you will not be able to submit the form - it simply won't let you send it. Another advantage is that, in some cases, you can submit your form hours or minutes before the end of tax year deadline if you do it electronically.

Many of the financial websites have details of which fund managers will allow you to buy online, and details of the deadlines for submitting electronic application forms. For example, Interactive Investor has a list of the latest time you can hit the "send" button for your Isa, depending on which one you want to buy. There is also a comprehensive list.

But an online form does not ensure that you have selected the right type of fund and, therefore, before you buy, you need to be clear about what sort of Isa you want. If you are planning to hold investment funds for the long term and you want to be able to put the maximum allowance into stock market investments, then the best option is to choose a stocks and shares maxi Isa.

For more information about the different types of Isa, see the section on Isas in this site.

There is a also a useful search engine on Virgin Money to help you select the type of Isa you want, based on your attitude to risk and which geographical region you want to invest in.

With the stock market still volatile, many people have been discouraged from investing in an Isa because they are concerned about buying at the top of the market. One of the ways to reduce the risk is to use a facility called "phasing".

This means you put your full Isa allowance (or as much as you can afford) into the fund now before the end of the tax year. That money is then drip-fed into the market.

One of the fund managers offering this facility is Fidelity, which, on your behalf, then buys shares in parcels of £1,000 at monthly intervals. In this way you achieve an average price of the six-month period without having to worry about the highs and the lows of the market. This method is also known as "pound-cost averaging". Your won't earn high interest on the money - the rate is now about 4% - but you won't be in cash for long. There is more information on the Fidelity website.

An alternative to phasing is to take advantage of special offers from fund managers. For example, Perpetual is allowing investors to hold its Isa allowance in cash until market conditions improve. If you haven't invested your money after six months, Perpetual will write to you asking you to sign a declaration of intent that you intend to invest in the future.

This is to satisfy Inland Revenue regulations. You have control over when the money is invested and you can give Perpetual buying instructions when you eventually decide to buy. There is more information at the Perpetual website.

 Marianne Curphey is the editor of Guardian Unlimited Money and author of E-cash, the step-by-step guide to managing your money, mortgage, bank account, investments and shares online.

Your won't earn high interest on the money - the rate is now about 4% - but you won't be in cash for long. There is more information on the Fidelity website. An alternative to phasing is to take advantage of special offers from fund managers. For example, Perpetual is allowing investors to hold its Isa allowance in cash until market conditions improve. If you haven't invested your money after six months, Perpetual will write to you asking you to sign a declaration of intent that you intend to invest in the future. This is to satisfy Inland Revenue regulations. You have control over when the money is invested and you can give Perpetual buying instructions when you eventually decide to buy. There is more information at the Perpetual website.  Marianne Curphey is the editor of Guardian Unlimited Money and author of E-cash, the step-by-step guide to managing your money, mortgage, bank account, investments and shares online. fields.headline: Woman in the Moon
fields.standfirst:
Arcola Theatre, London
***
fields.trailText:
Arcola Theatre, London
***
fields.body:
Wernher von Braun wanted to get to the moon at any cost. The cost was the lives of the 27,000 slave workers who died in Camp Dora, a secret location in the Harz mountains where, during the second world war, Von Braun developed the technology that eventually led to the first landing on the moon. (It was the same technology that also aided the development of the mobile phone.)

Julia Pascal's dream play makes all the connections in 75 minutes that you wouldn't exactly describe as an entertaining night out but is brave, informative, intelligent and desperately moving. It entwines the stories of those who worked in Dora with that of Braun, who joined the Nazi party in 1937 and then became a member of the SS. In Dora, where his office looked out over the courtyard where the misery - and sometimes the hangings - of the slave workers took place, Braun created the V2 rockets.

After the war von Braun avoided the Nuremberg trials by fleeing into the welcoming arms of the Americans. In the US he hosted his own Disney TV show, Tomorrowland, and was a key player in fulfilling the American dream of putting a man on the moon. Now who says justice isn't political?

With a sterling performance from Thomas Huber as the all too plausible and charming Braun, whose ability to lie to others and himself matches that of the far better known Albert Speer, Pascal's play puts a human face on the misery of history. She also does it in such a way that it is never sentimental but possesses a Brechtian austerity.

The faceless become individuals here, from 15-year-old Rudi, who sees his family disappear into Auschwitz, to the slave worker musing on the links between 1492 and 1942: "Funny how being born into the wrong sequence of numbers makes all the difference." It is also passionate without being partisan, and even plays devil's advocate. "My religion is rockets and I think yours is the Holocaust," the suave Von Braun tells a Jewish journalist who is probing his Nazi past.

The play takes a little time to gather momentum, and those unfamiliar with the second world war would do well to read the excellent programme note. But this is a dense, enlightening evening that packs a real punch in a great new space. At the very least, as you leave the theatre it will make you pause as you go to turn on your mobile again, remembering the stories of those who died so long ago.

 Until April 7. Box office: 020-7503 1646.

fields.headline: European round-up
fields.trailText: Mixed fortunes for the opponents of English clubs in this week's Champions League action.
fields.body:
Bayern Munich, guests of Manchester United tomorrow for their European Cup quarter-final first leg, will also be recovering from a league defeat after a 3-2 home reversal at the hands of Werder Bremen on Saturday.

A late header from Claudio Pizarro finished off the 1999 European Cup finalists, who had not lost at home to Werder since 1992. The Peruvian had opened the scoring from the spot in the 25th minute and Marco Bode got the other just before the hour. Giovane Elber and Carsten Jancker were on target for Bayern.

Deportivo La Coruna, second in La Liga and Leeds's visitors on Wednesday, won 4-2 at home to this season's surprise team, Villarreal .

Djalminha, the Brazilian midfielder, put Deportivo ahead and then supplied the pass for Diego Tristan to double the lead. Victor pulled one back from a penalty in the second half but another from Tristan and a further goal from Roy Makaay secured the points.

Valencia, who travel to Arsenal on Wednesday, lost 1-0 at home to Espanyol and remain in third place, 10 points behind the European Cup favourites Real Madrid and five behind Valencia.

Luis Figo got Real's goal in the 1-0 win against Numancia. The holders travel to Galatasaray for tomorrow's other quarter-final first leg.

Barcelona, who entertain Liverpool in the Uefa Cup semi-final on Thursday, went a goal behind to Las Palmas at the Nou Camp but soon turned it around and won 4-1. Gabri, Marc Overmars, Rivaldo and Dani got their goals.

Rivaldo has revealed that he will leave when his contract expires in 2003. Big-spending clubs may now step in before he can go for free. "It is not my intention to return to Brazil," he said. "I want to continue playing in Europe."

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk
