webTitle: Comedy of errors as Barca make a play for midweek success

fields.headline: Comedy of errors as Barca make a play for midweek success
fields.standfirst: Party time at Barcelona, a Tommy Cooper impersonation and a Basque revolution - just another week in Spain's Primera Division
fields.trailText: Party time at Barcelona, a Tommy Cooper impersonation and a Basque revolution - Sid Lowe with the latest shenanigans in Spain's Primera Division.
fields.body:
Barcelona coach Llorenc Serra Ferrar doesn't look like he's down with the kids, but after his side's 4-1 victory over Las Palmas he invited "supporters to come en masse" to a "giant party" on Thursday night. No surprises for guessing he's talking about the Uefa Cup game against Liverpool, but you can't blame Serra Ferrar for being strangely enthusiastic. After all, he'd just seen his side comeback from a fabulous goal from Guayre to administer a comprehensive shellacking to the side from Gran Canaria.

His side were helped on their way by Las Palmas keeper Nacho González, who seemed to have been curiously effected by the proximity of Comedy Keeper Richard Dutruel. This in spite of the fact that the Frenchman was busy doing what he does best these days - warming the Barça bench.

Desperately trying to emulate the Comedy Keeper and fellow slapstick merchant Tommy Cooper, the Las Palmas goalie gifted Barça their equaliser. He came for a corner, tripped over his own player, missed the ball, got up, barged over another of his own players - who was preparing to clear Gabri's pretty harmless header - and fell into the back of the net not so much with egg on his face as a bloody great omelette. Let off the hook, Barça took control and ran out 4-1 winners, with Marc Overmars, Rivaldo and Dani completing the scoring.

Depor racked up a club record 24th consecutive home game unbeaten with an ultimately comfortable 4-2 win over Villarreal. Djalminha was busy show-boating again and he had a field day with the world's ropiest offside trap - he scored the first, set up Diego Tristán for the second and watched from the bench (rested for Leeds) as Tristán and substitute Roy Makaay got one more each.

Celta's top scorer Catanha was back at his old club Málaga on Saturday and got two more in a 4-1 win. As a sign of "respect" to his former side, Catanha didn't perform his normal (and frankly shite) arm-flapping birdie celebration. The Rosaleda crowd, already suffering enough, certainly appreciated the gesture - they applauded their one-time hero from the field.

It wasn't quite so easy for Real Madrid or Valencia. A superb Figo free-kick secured a 1-0 win for the Man in the Moustache's uninspiring side against Numancia, while Valencia surprisingly lost 1-0 at home to Espanyol. Yet again, Raul Tamudo was the match winner - this time with a powerful header from Toni Velamazán's cross.

Juan Esnaider scored Zaragoza's only goal of the weekend as they fell 2-1 to Regueiro's last minute winner for Racing Santander's new boss Gustavo Benítez.

Esnaider still hasn't agreed to continue at the Romareda next year. In fact, rumours this week suggest that he'll return to Atlético Madrid (possibly alongside Cholo Simeone), after it was revealed that he'd visited Jesús Gil at his country home. Of course, there's a perfectly rational information; Esnaider was, in fact, "picking up a horse". As you do.

"Jesús Gil gave me a horse", Esnaider insisted, "I went to collect it and met some friends for lunch - I've not even thought of signing for Atlético".

Revolution at la Real

John Benjamin has "moved upstairs" at Real Sociedad (one day someone will explain what that actually means) and has promised big changes at the club. They might include the introduction of non-Basque Spaniards for the first time, but Benjamin insists that the heart of the side's going to remain Basque: "80% of the team is a good figure" he said.

"I'm going to mould this club the way I want it", JB warned this week, "and if I have to piss people off who I consider my friends, so be it - la Real mustn't be just any old team". They'll soon be not just any old second division team if things don't improve. Despite an impressive 1-1 draw in Mallorca this weekend, JB's hard-man status, and his comic turns at press conferences, la Real are still bottom.

Back in the real world, it's looking increasingly like three from four down the bottom. Oviedo (3-3 with Alavés) and Valladolid (3-1 at home to Rayo Vallecano) are not totally safe but now stand five points clear of Numancia and Osasuna, who beat Bilbao 1-0 in the last minute. These two are anxiously looking over their shoulders - Racing Santander and Real Sociedad are just one point behind.

Spain make a meal of minnows

The cliché 'there's no easy games anymore' is surely a lie - after all, Barça, Depor and Celta scored four this weekend, and last weekend Spain went one better. Not that it was enough, though - it was against Liechtenstein, after all. Marca had run a poll in which over 85%, bless 'em (better still, lock 'em up), thought Camacho's men would get more than 11. Even the squad was confident - they ran a sweepstake before the match and the most pessimistic player went for six.

Five might not be that great but Fernando Hierro certainly enjoyed himself - he scored a penalty to become Spain's all-time joint top goalscorer, thanks to that lovely man Gaizka Mendieta. Since Raúl bottled it, Mendieta has taken Spain's spot kicks, but this time he passed that honour to Hierro. The captain was touched, scored and told the press: "I want to thank Mendieta publicly".

Of course, playing France is genuinely no easy game. Miraculously, after defeats against Argentina, Holland, Germany and England, Spain on Wednesday inflicted Les Bleus' first defeat (2-1) since becoming European champions.

Iván Helguera headed the first and Fernando Morientes cooly finished a superb move for the second. It was all to much for the poor French to take - they decided they might as well kick the Spaniards about a bit if they weren't going to win. Marcel Desailly, Patrick Viera (surprise, surprise) and the normally placid (i.e. not-arsed) Christian Karembeu all got involved.

Not that Spain didn't give as good as they got: Raúl was unusually animated and went round kicking, pushing and berating everyone in sight. Tragically, try as they might, a full-scale punch up never quite materialised.

Fans may have missed out in Valencia, but it was a different story in Seville during a "friendly" (ha!) between Sevilla and Norwegian side Stabaek. It all started when Martin Andresen decided to show off the skills perfected during his Wimbledon days and launched (and I mean launched) a shocking Kung-fu challenge on Sevilla's Inti Podestá. Not a wise move just in front of the Sevilla bench and before he knew it, Andresen was set upon by four, six, or eight of Sevilla's subs (depending on who you believe) plus some of their fans. Cue mass brawl and uncontrollable laughter.

"I've never experienced anything like it," said Stabaek's Jan Aage Fjortoft, while Sevilla captain, José Miguel Prieto claimed that "the Norwegian team thought it was a martial arts competition".

Now, as a pillar of the community this column can't possibly condone such ugly scenes, but it was pretty funny. Even if the Sevilla president, Roberto Alés - sniffing a Federación fine in the air - did claim "it was nothing serious, just a scuffle between two teams and their benches [er, and their fans]. Nothing really happened - just four pushes and four charges". No problem, then.

Meanwhile another man under attack this week was José María García Aranda, the referee who infamously took charge of the Liverpool-Roma clash. He produced another top quality performance in mid-week at a World Cup qualifier between Uruguay and Paraguay. So good, in fact, that United Airlines staff had to hide him in their office when 500 fans spotted him at Montevideo airport and decided to give him a send-off he'd never forget.

A security guard was struck by a rock, but the Kop's favourite ref escaped unscathed as he took charge at the Nou Camp this weekend. Whether Liverpool will return similarly unscathed from their visit on Thursday is another matter.

fields.headline: Vieira gives Hoddle a reality check
fields.trailText: Glenn Hoddle, with his beige suit and unseasonal suntan, could have been the man from Del Monte. One sip of orange juice, remember, and "he say yes!"
fields.body:
Glenn Hoddle, with his beige suit and unseasonal suntan, could have been the man from Del Monte. One sip of orange juice, remember, and "he say yes!"

Having cast an eye over the present crop of emerging talents at Tottenham, several of whom were drafted in to replace injured regulars for Saturday's north London derby at Highbury, Hoddle probably felt like giving a more qualified affirmative to the possibility of his taking Spurs to a place in the top three during the next five years.

This is how long Hoddle's contract as Tottenham's new manager will give him once his move from Southampton has been completed, and he is likely to need all the time he can get.

He will hardly, for example, be in the position of David O'Leary after George Graham had left Leeds for White Hart Lane. There is not an abundance of youthful quality at Spurs simply waiting for the lights to turn green.

On Saturday David Pleat, Tottenham's director of football and caretaker manager following Graham's dismissal, used six players of 21 or under. "We have some promising youngsters," he observed, "but will need to buy top-quality players." So much depends on how much Enic, the conglomerate that recently added Spurs to its club collection, is prepared to spend.

For his first match in charge, next Sunday's renewal of hostilities with Arsenal in an FA Cup semi-final at Old Trafford, Hoddle looks as if he will have to pick his side from a squad only marginally stronger than the choice available to Pleat at Highbury. The recoveries of Sol Campbell, Sergei Rebrov and Stephen Clemence would at least give Spurs a chance of reaching the final in Cardiff.

Either way Hoddle is likely to approach the tie much as Graham went about beating West Ham at Upton Park in the quarter-finals, namely by attempting to stifle the opposition in midfield while awaiting opportunities to strike on the break. Arsène Wenger's midfield, however, is less callow than Harry Redknapp's and his defence will be less accident-prone now Martin Keown and Tony Adams have been reunited.

Tottenham's best chance of springing a surprise could lie in Arsenal's contrasting set of priorities. For Spurs the Millennium stadium may be this season's Valhalla but Arsenal are looking no further ahead than Valencia, who visit Highbury on Wednesday in the Champions League quarter- finals.

For Wenger the FA Cup is a minor bauble compared to progressing in the European Cup while assuring his team of an automatic place in next season's tournament by finishing second in the Premiership. The Arsenal manager conceded that Saturday's victory over Spurs could give his players a psychological advantage for Old Trafford but a more immediate concern will be how well they can cope with Gaizka Mendieta and Pablo Cesar Aimar in 72 hours' time.

The strength in midfield of Patrick Vieira will be crucial in both matches and reports that Juventus are interested in the Frenchman will worry Highbury supporters. They are only too mindful of the way big money from Barcelona prompted the departures of Emmanuel Petit and Marc Overmars last summer. For Arsenal, losing Vieira would be akin to having a mainmast shot away.

Saturday's match merely confirmed his importance to the team's continued progress. Amid Tottenham's eager but inexperienced challenges he was a mastiff among puppies. Only the occasional dash by Simon Davies, with his willingness to take on defenders, promised to disturb the peace of David Seaman's afternoon.

If Arsenal took a while to get going it was understandable given the circumstances. The news of David Rocastle's untimely death that morning had shocked everyone and, as on other grounds, the minute's silence was impeccably observed by both sets of supporters.

Rocastle as much as anybody had typified the invigorating style of Graham's championship-winning Arsenal sides of 1989 and 1991 and the fact that for more than half the game Wenger's side lacked a similar quality was almost a mark of respect for what he had once given the team.

Yet the outcome was never seriously in doubt. "I just wondered when Arsenal were going to score," Pleat admitted while praising his makeshift Tottenham team for denying them a goal until 20 minutes from the end, although Thierry Henry had hit a post after seven.

Eventually Robert Pires gathered a pass from Vieira before cutting in from the left to beat Neil Sullivan with a fine right-footed shot into the far corner of the net. By then Nwankwo Kanu had been brought on to provide some party tricks and his was the pass which released Henry to bamboozle a head-bandaged Chris Perry before slipping in Arsenal's second.

It was a happy ending for Highbury then but, with Rocky gone, it was a sad afternoon all the same.

For his first match in charge, next Sunday's renewal of hostilities with Arsenal in an FA Cup semi-final at Old Trafford, Hoddle looks as if he will have to pick his side from a squad only marginally stronger than the choice available to Pleat at Highbury. The recoveries of Sol Campbell, Sergei Rebrov and Stephen Clemence would at least give Spurs a chance of reaching the final in Cardiff. Either way Hoddle is likely to approach the tie much as Graham went about beating West Ham at Upton Park in the quarter-finals, namely by attempting to stifle the opposition in midfield while awaiting opportunities to strike on the break. Arsène Wenger's midfield, however, is less callow than Harry Redknapp's and his defence will be less accident-prone now Martin Keown and Tony Adams have been reunited. Tottenham's best chance of springing a surprise could lie in Arsenal's contrasting set of priorities. For Spurs the Millennium stadium may be this season's Valhalla but Arsenal are looking no further ahead than Valencia, who visit Highbury on Wednesday in the Champions League quarter- finals. For Wenger the FA Cup is a minor bauble compared to progressing in the European Cup while assuring his team of an automatic place in next season's tournament by finishing second in the Premiership. The Arsenal manager conceded that Saturday's victory over Spurs could give his players a psychological advantage for Old Trafford but a more immediate concern will be how well they can cope with Gaizka Mendieta and Pablo Cesar Aimar in 72 hours' time. The strength in midfield of Patrick Vieira will be crucial in both matches and reports that Juventus are interested in the Frenchman will worry Highbury supporters. They are only too mindful of the way big money from Barcelona prompted the departures of Emmanuel Petit and Marc Overmars last summer. For Arsenal, losing Vieira would be akin to having a mainmast shot away. Saturday's match merely confirmed his importance to the team's continued progress. Amid Tottenham's eager but inexperienced challenges he was a mastiff among puppies. Only the occasional dash by Simon Davies, with his willingness to take on defenders, promised to disturb the peace of David Seaman's afternoon. If Arsenal took a while to get going it was understandable given the circumstances. The news of David Rocastle's untimely death that morning had shocked everyone and, as on other grounds, the minute's silence was impeccably observed by both sets of supporters. Rocastle as much as anybody had typified the invigorating style of Graham's championship-winning Arsenal sides of 1989 and 1991 and the fact that for more than half the game Wenger's side lacked a similar quality was almost a mark of respect for what he had once given the team. Yet the outcome was never seriously in doubt. "I just wondered when Arsenal were going to score," Pleat admitted while praising his makeshift Tottenham team for denying them a goal until 20 minutes from the end, although Thierry Henry had hit a post after seven. Eventually Robert Pires gathered a pass from Vieira before cutting in from the left to beat Neil Sullivan with a fine right-footed shot into the far corner of the net. By then Nwankwo Kanu had been brought on to provide some party tricks and his was the pass which released Henry to bamboozle a head-bandaged Chris Perry before slipping in Arsenal's second. It was a happy ending for Highbury then but, with Rocky gone, it was a sad afternoon all the same.  You've read the piece, now have your say. fields.headline: Psycho's crime has Redknapp looking for cover
fields.trailText: If Everton again beat relegation - history and the uplift of this win suggest they will - Walter Smith should send a bouquet of flowers in May to their friends in East London. After all Paolo di Canio spared Everton defeat with his honourable handball in December and Stuart Pearce made a gift of the game here with an offence that had nothing to do with sportsmanship.
fields.body:
If Everton again beat relegation - history and the uplift of this win suggest they will - Walter Smith should send a bouquet of flowers in May to their friends in East London. After all Paolo di Canio spared Everton defeat with his honourable handball in December and Stuart Pearce made a gift of the game here with an offence that had nothing to do with sportsmanship.

Given Everton's extraordinary injury misfortune, Smith was not suggesting that his team had finally turned the corner. "Some say 40 points will be enough for safety," he said, "but I don't know. We need two or three results like this." So do West Ham, now level with Everton and Derby on 35, even if Harry Redknapp sounded much more confident about getting them.

Redknapp's confidence is questionable. "Of course I'm worried," he said, "but I've had only one blip in six years. If I can't get something out of seven games, I'll be wearing a tin helmet and a bullet-proof vest. We'll turn it around." Judging by the jeers of what was left of the home support at the final whistle, he might be ordering the protective gear sooner rather than later.

West Ham's generosity, especially as hosts, knows no bounds. Four successive defeats in Premiership and Cup at Upton Park, where they have not won in 2001, have mocked the brave new year that they entered as Uefa Cup pursuers. The goals have dried up - not one in six hours 15 minutes - and confidence, especially among the younger players, has evaporated.

Redknapp's immediate remedy is to "tighten the team up, make sure we don't get beaten". To this end West Ham's manager is not helped by his own injury list and the loss of Pearce following his red card for a reckless high tackle on the debutant Tony Hibbert that reduced West Ham to 10 men just before the interval. The veteran defender, 39 this month, is considering retiring; he will now have even fewer games in which to make his final mark on the English game.

Di Canio was fortunate not to join Pearce in the stands after arguing at length over his team-mate's sending-off and then delaying the resultant penalty by theatrically repositioning the ball on the spot. All this failed to stop David Unsworth calmly putting Everton ahead.

The Italian, even if absolved by Redknapp for his team's goal drought, may be given more of a watching role next season - if he can suffer the indignity. Di Canio is the likely victim of Redknapp's plans for next season, for which another central striker is top priority.

"I'd like two quality signings and we need another goal-scorer," said Redknapp. "Freddie [Kanouté] hasn't really got a partner to play with. I'd like to change the way we play, and I know the shape I'd like but accommodating the people I've got at the moment is difficult. Perhaps it's a question of rotating."

Three free spirits - Di Canio, Kanouté and Joe Cole - is one too many and the Italian's age, 33 in July, must go against him. All three were ineffectual here, so much so that Paul Gerrard had to make only one direct save, from Kanouté, in the entire game. Two close-range shots from Cole and one from Di Canio were blocked by defenders.

After a sluggish start to the second half, Everton eventually roused themselves to exploit their numerical advantage in the 71st minute when Ferguson's superb pass, struck with the outside of his left foot, set up Niclas Alexandersson to score with a low shot inside the far post.

fields.headline: Newcastle suffer in Valley of doom
fields.trailText: They may be going down, but if Bradford continue to play like this their fans will not complain.
fields.body:
They may be going down, but if Bradford continue to play like this their fans will not complain.

Having raced into an early two-goal lead, they should in the end have lost, but it was a performance of remarkably good spirits from such a depressed team. It was as if the crushing weight of impending relegation had been lifted now that the battle has been lost.

But pity poor Andy O'Brien, the young Newcastle defender making his debut following a £2m transfer from Bradford. Just when he thought that phase of his career had been finally put behind him, he found himself back at Valley Parade and once more conceding sloppy goals.

It was his onerous responsibility to mark David Wetherall when, in the eighth minute, his former defensive partner scored the first goal via Aaron Hughes's head. Two minutes later Robbie Blake added the second from the penalty spot after Robert Molenaar crumpled under Robert Lee's challenge.

"It's the sort of thing I've been used to at Bradford, going behind early on," O'Brien admitted. It was perhaps no surprise that the Newcastle defence proved porous - the central pair of O'Brien and Hughes had never met, much less played together, before Saturday.

Newcastle last celebrated a shut-out in September, which leaves Bobby Robson, their manager, with a slight problem. "There's not a week goes by without us addressing it," he said. "We'll probably win the battle against Arsenal or someone like that, but this was the place to do it really."

Nor was it just Newcastle's defence who returned home cursing a missed opportunity. Carl Cort has never scored a league hat-trick, but he will know that this was the place to do it really.

It says something that his goal, a simple header from seven yards from Wayne Quinn's cross, was described by his manager as "the hardest chance he had".

Bradford, meanwhile, are sufficiently happy with the way their team is performing that even Benito Carbone, who delighted and distressed in equal measure with his constant trickery, may now stay.

"The chairman's said that it's not beyond the realms of possibility that we can keep him," said the Bradford manager Jim Jefferies. "He can see what we're trying to do, and I think he wants to be part of it."

With season ticket applications over 50% down on this point last year, Bradford must hope that the fans do too - though if the rest of their season is as entertaining as this, that should be the least of their problems.

fields.headline: Leicester are made to look like April fools
fields.trailText: Peter Taylor left the Valley clutching a match video that will not make pleasant viewing. His Leicester side deservedly suffered an eighth successive away defeat yesterday and find their European ambitions fading fast. From third on Boxing Day, they sit ninth after an April Fool's Day that gave them little reason to laugh.
fields.body:
Peter Taylor left the Valley clutching a match video that will not make pleasant viewing. His Leicester side deservedly suffered an eighth successive away defeat yesterday and find their European ambitions fading fast. From third on Boxing Day, they sit ninth after an April Fool's Day that gave them little reason to laugh.

Charlton, on the other hand, will be smiling contentedly. A spectacular late volley by Shaun Bartlett may have been out of keeping with much of a poor game but Alan Curbishley's players at least showed the passing, movement and ability to keep possession that Leicester desperately lacked. Having leapfrogged Taylor's team, they retain an outside chance of qualifying for the Uefa Cup.

On this form Leicester have no chance of making it into Europe. They mustered not a single shot on target and rarely threatened to equalise Andy Todd's first-half header. Taylor, to his credit, did not try to hide. He described the first-half showing as "very poor" and admitted composure was absent.

"We are missing a footballer," he said. "Away from home you need to keep possession of the ball and we are left concentrating too much on defence. I see the composure in the week in training but I don't see it on match days."

Even allowing for the absence of influential players such as Muzzy Izzet and Robbie Savage, this was a desperately poor Leicester performance that left question marks over Taylor's decision to buy in bulk from the Nationwide.

Ade Akinbiyi, a £5m signing from Wolves, started on the bench and his replacement Trevor Benjamin, a £1m arrival from Cambridge, looked laboured in attack. Junior Lewis and Callum Davidson were also peripheral figures.

"Some are inexperienced at this level and it will take time," Taylor reflected. His coaching record suggests that he could yet make it work and in any case Leicester's problems must be kept in perspective. Of late they have beaten Chelsea, Sunderland and Liverpool at home and they remain better off in terms of points than they were this time last year under Martin O'Neill.

"We are still very capable of finishing in the top six," Taylor said. "That's how I see it and that's my intention, but we have got to get our act together. We need to win our home matches and pick up something away from home." Eight successive league defeats on their travels since winning at Middlesbrough in November constitute the club's worst run for 14 years.

Charlton, too, must improve on an away record that has yielded only 11 points from a possible 45 if they are to make it into Europe for the first time. This was not their finest display but with Claus Jensen impressive in midfield it always looked a matter of time before they broke down a defensive Leicester side.

Their best early chances had come from long range, with Jensen striking the bar from 30 yards and Chris Powell forcing Simon Royce into a sharp save before Todd nodded in his first Charlton goal after Bartlett had headed Jensen's corner against the bar.

Leicester improved a little after the interval but only poor Charlton finishing and a Royce save kept them in touch before Bartlett finished them off in style.

Graham Stuart collected possession just inside his own half and clipped a perfect 50-yard pass for the South African to volley in with his left foot from around 16 yards. Charlton have agreed a deal with FC Zurich to make Bartlett's loan deal permanent, which on this evidence is a wise move.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Bottom line haunts City's Weaver
fields.trailText: Manchester City are still at the crossroads where they have been since the turn of the year, when they fell into the bottom three. The arm of theory offers hope; the arm of realism points to the First Division.
fields.body:
Manchester City are still at the crossroads where they have been since the turn of the year, when they fell into the bottom three. The arm of theory offers hope; the arm of realism points to the First Division.

If they win their last seven games, they will survive easily. As they have won two of their last 21, they may sooner fly to the moon. On Saturday, though failing in their search for a second home win since mid-October, they lost no ground, thanks to Middlesbrough's defeat, but chiefly the chance to raise morale and edge along the road to survival. Even their faithful booed.

If March came in at Maine Road like a lamb, with defeat by Southampton, it went out like an ass. At 1-1 and half-time imminent Nick (the) Weaver lost a back-pass in his feet and Dion Dublin, seemingly in trivial pursuit, took advantage. The City defender Steve Howey had said earlier: "Sometimes lumping the ball forward is the best option." The lump later was in the keeper's throat. As Bottom said: "I see their knavery; this is to make an ass of me."

Joe Royle was benevolent: "The kid's been big and brave and come out and held his hands up." When Paul Merson beat the offside trap 20 minutes later, putting Lee Hendrie clear, Weaver still had his hands up, barely attempting a save.

Merson, celebrating before Hendrie shot, is possibly the first man to punch the air for a through-ball. As John Gregory said: "Sometimes he is two or three passes ahead of everyone else." Perhaps Merson, given a standing ovation by the home fans, was expressing relief from frustration. Villa were as loose as City in mind and touch.

The referee Rob Styles, unable to distinguish between malevolence and incompetence, caught the malaise, booking nine and sending off Danny Tiatto for two more yellow cards in four late minutes. City will miss their most dynamic force. He is the third Premiership man to be sent off twice this season, joining Hendrie and Patrick Vieira. Styles did for him the first time too, against Arsenal in October.

For two minutes it looked as if March might go out like a goat. Tiatto's quick release of the excellent Jeff Whitley on the left led to Shaun Goater scoring City's third goal in seven home games. But Hendrie at once set up Merson's equaliser.

The quality in Villa's squad speaks of huge potential unfulfilled. Gareth Southgate said as much in confirming his wish for one last move: "I feel the club has underachieved and I don't see it challenging in the next few years." Under Gregory he is probably right.

On Saturday David James got away with his regulation fumble; Dublin raised his strike rate to a goal per 345 minutes; Julian Joachim (154 min) was on the bench with David Ginola; and Juan Pablo Angel was out altogether despite his two midweek goals for Colombia. Presumably Gregory had revised his Friday impression, "bright as a button", to bright as a flash in the pan.

Royle says team spirit is no problem. On a short break in Spain - City barely troubled the national selectors - "the lads all went around together". At times in defence they still were. Royle is reported to be releasing 10 this summer; he calls it "housekeeping". But these are the ones he is keeping. Judging by some of the rumps in defence he might try lining them up, head to toe, like sandbags. It could be the bottom line.

fields.headline: Short the catalyst as Rovers coast in
fields.trailText: It has been 17 years, and one Premiership title for Blackburn Rovers, since Burnley competed on a level footing with their east Lancashire rivals and after this neighbourly skirmish it was tempting to wonder how long it will be before local hostilities are renewed again.
fields.body:
It has been 17 years, and one Premiership title for Blackburn Rovers, since Burnley competed on a level footing with their east Lancashire rivals and after this neighbourly skirmish it was tempting to wonder how long it will be before local hostilities are renewed again.

By completing this league double over Burnley with almost contemptuous ease, Graeme Souness's side yesterday not only re-affirmed their metamorphosis from pampered fat-cats to mean predators but moved into the automatic promotion places for the first time this season.

With two games in hand over third-placed Bolton Wanderers the chances are that is where they will remain and, with the tawdry days of Brian Kidd's tenure now a dim memory, Blackburn are slowly but surely re-emerging as a force to be reckoned with.

"Success for us is getting out of this division and we've got ourselves in the right position now," said Souness. "We will probably have to win six or seven of our last 10 games and we will be going into every one as if it is the last game of our lives."

The catalyst arrived via an unlikely source. Before yesterday Craig Short had not scored for five years, yet before half-time he had opened Blackburn's account and played a decisive part in Steve Davis putting into his own net.

Two goals from Matt Jansen after the interval did not flatter the hosts and, when the substitute Craig Hignett rattled in a fifth, Blackburn had registered their most comprehensive post-war victory over their old foes.

"It's frustrating and embar rassing but, in my opinion, Blackburn are by far the best team in this division," said the Burnley manager Stan Ternent.

The rout began on 14 minutes. Alan Mahon's corner was punched out weakly by Nic Michopoulos and, when David Dunn fired a first-time shot back towards goal, Short's deft flick diverted the ball beyond the out-of-position Burnley goalkeeper.

Allowing himself another foray into opposition territory 15 minutes later, Short's run along the left would have been brought to a premature halt had the referee Alan Butler adhered to a linesman's flag for an infringement against Mahon.

Instead the advantage rule was deployed and Short worked his way to the byline. It was only his intention to flick a cross into the six-yard area but, agonisingly for Davis, the ball ricocheted off his instep, wrong-footing Michopoulos and trickling into the Burnley net.

fields.headline: Stylish Liverpool closing the gap
fields.trailText: Liverpool reached a new tier of excellence as Steven Gerrard and Michael Owen secured Liverpool's first league double over United since 1979.
fields.body:
After the most anaemic title race since the Premiership's formation, the prospect of new blood is an enticing one. In the evolution of Gérard Houllier's Liverpool team, this performance represented a new tier of excellence, compelling evidence that, if Manchester United's omnipotence is to be challenged next season, the most durable challenge will emanate from Anfield.

There are still questions to be asked. How, for example, can new Liverpool bludgeon United into the realms of mediocrity yet take only one point from their previous league fixtures against Leicester and Derby? Consistency remains a characteristic of Sir Alex Ferguson's men that Houllier can only envy.

If the restoration job is to be concluded, the Frenchman will have to find more answers. But there are the first tantalising signs that even if United are favourites to retain the title next season, Liverpool may just ensure that Ferguson's final year is not the last hurrah everyone expects.

Meanwhile, when the story of Manchester United's seventh title in nine seasons is penned, the concession of a first league double to Liverpool since 1979 will merit little more than small print. But for all the haughty references to more pressing engagements, the plethora of players rested ahead of tomorrow's Champions League appointment with Bayern Munich - "maybe our season starts then," Ferguson volunteered - and the defiant statements that the damage was only superficial, there was no disguising that Saturday will have hurt.

For United to treat possession with such wanton disregard was an oddity in itself, but to be out-hustled as well as out-manoeuvred is a matter worthy of more serious contemplation. In front of Bayern's scout Alexander Weiss, they had the chance to send out the right signals and failed.

By stark contrast Liverpool will approach Thursday's Uefa Cup quarter-final in Barcelona with chests swelling from the best kind of psychological preparation. The Nou Camp can be a bear pit for travelling sides, but if Houllier's players can reproduce this sort of performance (and Steven Gerrard is fit) they need not feel any sense of inferiority complex.

Not for the first time, and probably not the last, Gerrard was the driving influence of this Liverpool triumph, an indomitable presence on the right of midfield. His 16th-minute haymaker, a sure-fire contender for goal of the season, was an object lesson how to strike a long shot and watching him dominate Roy Keane et al just confirmed that Liverpool have a future England captain on their payroll. Possibly, even, this season's player of the year.

By the time Robbie Fowler scored four minutes before the interval, capitalising on Gary Neville's slip to finish beautifully from Gerrard's cross, Liverpool were looking so dangerous, so in control, it was tempting to believe it was all a trick of the mind.

Even after Danny Murphy had procured a second yellow card for raking his studs along Denis Irwin's calves on 69 minutes, having been booked for an earlier indiscretion against Nicky Butt, United's forays into home territory were predominantly of the limp-wristed variety. In truth, Liverpool held on with a modicum of fuss.

"We've known for the last few years that it's up to us to close the gap," said Fowler. "It's taken time but now there's the first chink of light at the end of the tunnel. We can't go over the top but maybe, just maybe, we will be up with them in a year or so."

For the sake of the Premiership, a competition that has been stagnating since the turn of the year, it can only be hoped that the renaissance continues.

fields.headline: Hartson sets up another great escape
fields.standfirst: Hadji 44, Hartson 49
fields.trailText: Gordon Strachan took time out to ring John Hartson and ask his in-form striker for a big favour early last week, when the striker was preparing for his country's World Cup qualifier with Ukraine.
fields.body:
Gordon Strachan took time out to ring John Hartson and ask his in-form striker for a big favour early last week, when the striker was preparing for his country's World Cup qualifier with Ukraine.

"The manager said to me not to score all your goals for Wales; try and save a couple for us on Saturday," said Hartson, who managed one for his country on Wednesday evening and duly obliged for his club with a powerful header from Paul Telfer's corner. His fourth goal in eight days secured Coventry's biggest league win of the season and their first since Boxing Day.

Just as importantly, it came a matter of minutes after the interval and helped relax a distinctly edgy home crowd, who before long were belting out the Great Escape. "The players are not getting carried away but we'll enjoy this win," Hartson said. "We've still got a big job to do but if we can apply ourselves for the last seven games, then we might have a chance [of staying up]."

Five of those games are due this month, all against sides in the top eight. A tall order then, and they will be without Mustapha Hadji for at least two of them as the Moroccan was shown a straight red card for spitting at Danny Higginbotham after an altercation with 19 minutes to go.

"That sort of behaviour is just not on in any walk of life," Strachan said. "I'll ensure it won't happen again, but total pros are entitled to one mistake in their lifetime."

His players have been making them all season, but at this time of year Coventry have a habit of starting to make up for them. These three points brought them level with Man chester City and only four points adrift of Middlesbrough. Teams as far up the table as West Ham will be looking over their shoulders.

Coventry were promoted 34 seasons ago - in 1967 when Britain was last in the grip of foot and mouth epidemic - and on 11 occasions they have finished within two points of the relegated teams, seven of them in the final safety position.

Strachan had cited that tradition in his programme notes and was delighted to see it starting to be upheld once more. "We needed that to put some pressure on the teams above us and see how they react," he said.

One of those teams are now Derby, who could have put clear water between them and their rivals but who slipped to 16th place after what the assistant manager Colin Todd bemoaned as their worst performance since he arrived at Pride Park in November.

There were mitigating circumstances, however, as the defence was reshuffled as Taribo West was absent, apparently with flu, and Chris Riggott had a groin strain. But apart from a late howler from Rory Delap, who skied over an empty net, they never looked like scoring.

Derby also had to replace the goalkeeper Andy Oakes, who injured knee ligaments challenging for a weak backpass with the blameless Hadji. The Moroccan also made another significant contribution before the break, a headed goal from 10 yards after Mart Poom, Oakes's replacement, had blocked John Eustace's chip.

"They didn't have to work for their goals and will be delighted to have won 2-0," Todd added. "We need two more from seven games and if we aren't capable of getting them it's going to cause us a lot of trouble." Just like Hartson did here, in fact.

fields.headline: Big spenders reap unhappy returns
fields.trailText: They may sit at opposite ends of the Premiership, but both of these clubs agree on one thing: that addiction to success can be a dangerous game.
fields.body:
They may sit at opposite ends of the Premiership, but both of these clubs agree on one thing: that addiction to success can be a dangerous game.

Chelsea, having gambled heavily on players in a bid to become a major power, now find themselves without the Champions League subsidy that helped pay the bills, or even the loose change from a Uefa Cup run since they lost in the first round.

Recent figures attest to the financial impact on the club. So Chelsea's run-in to the end of this season has become a desperate, late push to clinch a passport back into Europe's land of milk and money.

Saturday's win lifted them closer to that point, though the third Champions League spot still looks a long way off if the uninspiring football Claudio Ranieri's team produced in this match is anything to go by.

A Uefa Cup place looks more achievable but such is the club's desperation to get into Europe at any cost they have even put their names down for the Lada of continental competition, the Intertoto Cup.

Middlesbrough's plight represents the other side of the same coin. After spending millions in the attempt to become a major player, the chairman Steve Gibson finds all his hard work in danger of disappearing into the First Division.

The 999 call he made to Terry Venables has brought results. But mainly draws. Relegation still threatens and with a run-in from hell - Boro's remaining seven games include meetings with Sunderland, Arsenal, Ipswich, Leicester and Manchester United - Venables and Bryan Robson must rely on the indifferent form of Manchester City and Coventry to escape the drop.

It certainly does not help the escapologist's task when one of your own players gifts the opposition a goal. With about half an hour to go Middlesbrough were holding their own at 1-1 and looking well capable of pocketing their eighth draw in 13 games.

But poor old Noel Whelan, a player whose confidence always looks brittle, under-hit a totally unnecessary back-pass to his keeper and Eidur Gudjohnsen nipped in to restore Chelsea's lead.

It was rough justice on a Boro side who had fought back determinedly after allowing little Gianfranco Zola of all people to head Chelsea into the lead from Celestine Babayaro's cross. But the organisation instilled by Venables enabled Boro to shrug off that second set-back, having already coped without the sus pended Paul Ince, Ugo Ehiogu and Phil Stamp.

Nine minutes into the second half Dean Windass celebrated his debut following a £600,000 move from Bradford with a diving header from Christian Karembeu's cross.

That Chelsea needed a gift to beat the Premiership's fourth-bottom team says much about their current state. Despite making four changes to the side that capitulated 4-2 at home to Sunderland, Ranieri was still forced to watch another unconvincing performance, as slick and persuasive as a Ken Bates rant.

The Ranieri reign has certainly not yet seen Chelsea make the great strides forward that were the thrust of his brief on taking over from Gianluca Vialli. The enigmatic Italian remains as unconvincing as his team and, unless performances and results improve, will discover that failure, too, can be a dangerous game.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Former head of poverty forum faces fraud charges

fields.headline: Former head of poverty forum faces fraud charges
fields.trailText: The former head of the National Local Government Forum Against Poverty has been charged with fraud following police investigations into allegations that money had gone missing from the fund.
fields.body:
The former head of the National Local Government Forum Against Poverty has been charged with fraud following police investigations into allegations that money had gone missing from the fund.

Garvin Reed, former national convenor and finance chair of the organisation, was charged on Friday with conspiracy to defraud following a two-year investigation, codenamed Operation Fear, by fraud officers from South Yorkshire police.

Two former Rotherham council officials, Bob Bone and John Cook, who were seconded to work for the forum, were also charged with conspiracy to defraud. All three will appear before Rotherham magistrates on April 12.

A Labour councillor, Mr Reed was also deputy leader of Rotherham council - the original host authority for the forum.

He stood down from that position when the investigation started but continues to sit as a councillor - although he is suspended from the Labour party pending the outcome of the charges.

The forum, set up in the 1990s, provided councils with statistical information on poverty and advice on how to tackle the problem.

It is believed that at its height more than 200 local authorities in England, Scotland and Wales contributed money to the forum, but many withdrew membership following allegations of fraudulent practices in 1998.

The forum is now understood to have ceased operations.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Cheryl
fields.trailText: Hi Sue, I met you on the trip to Canberra and I have advice for Buenos Aires and Chile. Here goes.
fields.body:
Hi Sue, I met you on the trip to Canberra and I have advice for Buenos Aires and Chile. Here goes.

Go to a tango show. I went to Casa Blanca for the show and it was excellent. I also went on a day to to an estancia, where we rode horses, had a barbeque and were given special riding demonstrations. Definitely go on the tour of Teatro Colon and try to get a ticket for an opera: sit up high, the sound is excellent. Definitely go to Iguazo Falls, and try to get a visa for the Brazilian side. Also, go for two nights so that you can see it all. Stay in Puerto Iguazo and a bus will take you to the Sheraton which is in the park by the Falls. Sign up for the three-part tour which takes you on a Zodiac into the Falls, a four-wheel drive through the lush forest and then a walk down to the river with a view the Falls.

When you're back in Buenos Aires, visit the area of the city known as La Recoleta. Take a tour of the Casa Rosado government building and go shopping on the Camenito

Love from (jealous) Cheryl

Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties):

Scott Murray = £168.04

The Prince of Punts aka Paul MacInnes = £55.01

The Guardian Unlimited Punters Collective = £43.46

Sean Ingle = £12.32

Scott Murray: Everton to win at West Ham - £5 @ 5/2

The final month of the football season is a strange time for the value seeking punter. Before striking a bet, we must look at the motivation of both teams involved, as well as the usual considerations of current form, injuries, suspensions and the recent record against the opponent in question.

West Ham are a typical example of a team in a late season slump, losing the appetite for battle once all their targets are out of their reach. The Hammers have had only the FA Cup to aim for since the turn of the year, and they crashed out to Tottenham last month. Now they appear simply to be marking time until next season.

Everton, meanwhile, can certainly not be accused of being an in-form outfit. But at least they had an incentive for getting a result at Upton Park. In recent weeks they have slipped into the relegation mire and were in desperate need of three points A bad team does not become a good one overnight, but just how good would Everton have to be to beat a poorly motivated West Ham?

I would think odds of 5/2 were just about acceptable here, and you were rewarded with a nice winner. Congratulations.

James Araci from the Football Unlimited Punters Collective - £5 treble - Colchester v Luton: Luton to win @ 9/4; Arsenal v Tottenham: Tottenham to win @ 9/2; Liverpool v Man Utd: Liverpool to win @ 13/8

The phrase a "value treble" is almost an oxymoron. Bookmakers have an edge of approximately 12% when pricing up each match. When putting 3 matches in an accumulative bet, you are increasing this margin to almost 36%. I don't care how talented an individual is at picking the results of football matches, he has to be extremely fortunate to be able to buck this edge and show a long-term profit.

As for the selections you chose, I certainly couldn't contemplate Tottenham at Highbury at odds of 9/2. I could never back a team so injury riddled and with so little to play for, even in a local derby where the form-book can often be thrown away. Arsenal are still shooting at the runners-up berth in the Premiership and a Champions League place, whereas Spurs will be concentrating on the FA Cup clash next week.

webTitle: New Athens airport descends into chaos

fields.headline: New Athens airport descends into chaos
fields.trailText: For the thousands flying in and out of Athens at the weekend the new Eleftherios Venizelos international airport, hailed as "the most extensively tested airport in the history of aviation", quickly became a nightmare of lost luggage, bewildering delays and technical meltdown.
fields.body:
It was hailed as "the most extensively tested airport in the history of aviation": a bright shiny symbol of progress for the host city of the 2004 Olympic Games.

But for the thousands flying in and out of Athens at the weekend the new Eleftherios Venizelos international airport, named after Greece's most revered 20th-century statesman, quickly became a nightmare of lost luggage, bewildering delays and technical meltdown.

The ailing state-owned Olympic Airways cancelled 46 flights on Saturday and a further 34 yesterday as the "state-of-the-art" airport, built by Germans at the cost of £1.4bn and opened to a great fanfare last week, struggled to cope with the demand.

Everything that could go wrong, did - from the malfunctioning check-in system to the glitch-prone flight information board.

Thousands of pieces of luggage were reported lost. Many Olympic Airways tickets listed departures gates for the old Athens airport, on the coast at Hellenikon, which closed three days earlier.

To make matters worse, traffic ground to a halt outside the terminal as thousands of Athenians drove the 18 miles east to the airport, at Spata, for a spot of sightseeing.

Beleaguered officials blamed the staff's lack of familiarity with the new airport's computer systems and the failure to install enough high-speed phone lines.

Air traffic controllers were also reported to be having problems with the new electronic equipment.

As the delays grew worse, arguments broke out among the exasperated passengers.

"It's complete chaos in there," an American tourist said, leaving the terminal three hours after his plane touched down.

"Everyone's shouting, and the staff seem to know as little about what is going on as the passengers."

Christos Verelis, the transport minister, promised that the problems would be swiftly resolved.

The teething problems are an embarrassment to the reformist Socialist government of Costas Simitis.

The airport is a key part of the programme to improve the transport infrastructure for the Olympics: it helped to persuade doubting International Olympic Committee officials that Greece was serious in its bid to stage the Games.

Critics said yesterday that the government, worried about missing yet more deadlines, had rushed the airport into service before everything, including the staff, was really ready, despite the terminal having been finished last October.

webTitle: Scotland promised more investment and junior doctors

fields.headline: Scotland promised more investment and junior doctors
fields.trailText: The Scottish executive has announced plans to recruit 375 more junior doctors across the NHS in Scotland, with an investment of £11.5m over the next three years.
fields.body:
The Scottish executive has announced plans to recruit 375 more junior doctors across the NHS in Scotland, with an investment of £11.5m over the next three years.

The executive says the increase would support key priorities in the Scottish NHS plan and significantly improve the working hours and conditions of junior doctors.

The announcement means Scotland's workforce of more than 4,200 junior doctors is set to expand by about 9% over the next three years, fuelling a long-term growth in the number of consultants.

Scottish first minister Henry McLeish said he recognised that junior doctors played a huge part in the successful running of the NHS in Scotland.

"More junior doctors in every part of the country will help us to tackle areas in which we know the NHS can improve - reducing waiting, improving access, and raising the quality of care."

Health minister Susan Deacon claimed the investment was an important step towards addressing the long-term problem of junior doctors' hours.

"Too many junior doctors in Scotland are still working too long. They are not always getting the training and support they need. Providing extra resources and more junior doctors is a start towards tackling these problems."

The British Medical Association (BMA), which earlier this year warned of a crisis among GPs in Scotland with low morale and increasing levels of stress, welcomed the initiative but warned it should not be seen as a long-term solution.

Jim McCaul, chairman of the BMA's Scottish junior doctors committee, said: "This is good news for everyone. The current high level of hours and intensity of work going on in our hospitals is unacceptable.

"But providing these training posts will be just a quick fix if these doctors do not have jobs to go to when trained as consultants and GPs.

fields.headline: Brainspark boss wins board backing
fields.trailText: The chairman of Brainspark, a company which invests in and nurtures internet firms, has moved to quash rumours that a mutiny of board members occurred at the listed company last week, writes Amy Vickers
fields.body:
The chairman of Brainspark, a company which invests in and nurtures internet firms, has moved to quash rumours that a mutiny of board members occurred at the listed company last week.

In a statement to the stock exchange this afternoon, Chairman Don Caldwell said: "In response to speculation in today's UK press, I want to place on record that I have total confidence in Stewart Dodd as chief executive and Noah Freedman as chief technology officer."

He also reaffirmed his conviction in "the value created by Brainspark's incubation process."

But a report in The Times today suggested the recently appointed finance director Jasper Judd had staged a coup to become chief executive, having secured what was thought to be the backing of other directors and shareholders.

Brainspark would not return calls, and the spokesman would not elaborate on the reports.

The company was locked in meetings this morning in a bid to smooth over disagreements between directors. Chairman Mr Caldwell's backing of Mr Dodd and Mr Freedman may go some way to easing the tensions that have developed since Brainspark axed staff and revamped its management board at the end of February.

But the shroud of secrecy around the internal spat has only left the market second-guessing what is really going on at the incubator whose share price is currently stuck around 11p.

fields.headline: Three days to register
fields.trailText:
People moving house were warned today that they have until Thursday to get their
names on the electoral roll at their new address in time for a June 7 general election.
fields.body:
People moving house were warned today that they have until Thursday to get their names on the electoral roll at their new address in time for a June 7 general election.

The newly introduced "rolling" electoral register allows names to be added at any time during the year rather than having to wait for the annual updating process in the autumn which comes into force the following February 16.

Steve Lake, of the Association of Electoral Administrators, today urged those moving home to apply to the town hall electoral registration department at their new address by Thursday April 5 at the latest.

fields.headline: Jack Christian
fields.standfirst: Brilliant scientist who expanded the understanding of metallurgy
fields.trailText: The metallurgist Jack Christian, who has died aged 74, wrote The Theory Of Transformations in Metals and Alloys (1965), a masterpiece which set the standard for graduate-level teaching in the subject worldwide.
fields.body:
The metallurgist Jack Christian, who has died aged 74, wrote a masterpiece. The Theory Of Transformations in Metals and Alloys (1965), set the standard for graduate-level teaching in the subject worldwide. Its breadth and depth of coverage were unsurpassed. Drawing together the work of international researchers in this field in a lucid manner, the book demonstrated relationships between different approaches and theories which sometimes even the researchers had not suspected.

Jack was one of the most eminent Oxford scientists of his generation. He brought a profound intellect to bear on metallurgy, a subject which traditionally had been as much craft as science.

He also worked on fundamental scientific problems that were of great practical importance. He explored what happens at an atomic level when different metals are mixed together to form alloys. He investigated why certain metals (such as iron) become harder and more brittle when they are cold, whereas other metals (such as copper) have roughly the same properties at all temperatures. He studied the internal processes that take place when metals and alloys are heat-treated, especially the structural changes that occur during rapid cooling (quenching) from high temperatures.

Both of Jack's grandfathers were Scarborough fishermen, and his father was a trawler skipper unemployed for much of the 1930s. Jack attended Scarborough boys' high school between 1936 and 1943, and graduated after the shortened war-time physics course from Queen's College, Oxford.

He became a research student in the laboratory of Dr William Hume-Rothery, the founder of Oxford's metallurgy department. He received his doctorate in 1949, and after short-term research appointments, became a university lecturer in 1955, a reader in 1958, fellow of St Edmund Hall, Oxford in 1963, and professor of physical metallurgy in 1963. He received many national and international honours, including fellowship of the Royal Society (1975).

A superb tutor, Jack challenged and inspired the best from students. He was also modest and charming, held in great affection by his many colleagues and friends throughout the world. He would take on any departmental teaching or administrative chore without complaint, and encouraged the generation of scientists following in his footsteps.

He had an enduringly happy marriage, and was immensely proud when his wife, Maureen, was elected lord mayor of Oxford in 2000. In the late 1970s he began to develop Parkinson's disease, and for the rest of his life fought this affliction withcourage and determination. He continued with his scientific work until the very end and completed a new edition of his book, although he did not live to see it in print. It will be a fitting memorial to a brilliant scientist who was also an exceptional person.

He leaves his wife, his daughter, Louise, and son, John. His younger son, Tim, predeceased him.

 Professor John (Jack) Wyrill Christian, scientist, born April 9 1926; died February 27 2001

webTitle: Rowing: Cambridge snatch victory on the line

fields.headline: Cambridge snatch victory on the line
fields.trailText: Cambridge's three-foot win in the Women's Boat Race yesterday was the closest verdict since the match began in 1927.
fields.body:
Cambridge's three-foot win in the Women's Boat Race yesterday was the closest verdict since the match began in 1927.

Oxford established a lead of almost a length until Cambridge began a sustained push and relentlessly narrowed the gap until their bow ball went in front in the last three strokes to record their ninth success in 10 years.

This was the highlight of the five-race programme between the two universities in sunshine and a light cross headwind at the National Water Sport Centre.

The fixture was moved from Henley to Nottingham a week ago because the upper Thames is still in spate and the towpath there is closed as a foot and mouth precaution.

The day belonged to the crews from the Fens, Cambridge winning the men's and women's lightweight races, Oxford having to settle for the women's and lightweight men's reserves verdicts.

Cambridge's lightweight men were impressive by establishing clear water after 500 metres and stretching this to 3 lengths by the line.

Oxford led in the women's lightweight race until Cambridge drew level after 500 metres and gradually pulled ahead. The Cambridge Blue Boat reserves, Blondie, lost to their Oxford counterparts, Osiris.

 Guy Pooley, an Eton schoolmaster who represented Britain in the 1992 and 1996 Olympics, won Saturday's Scullers Head of the River race from Mortlake to Putney, two-fifths of a second ahead of Ian Watson of London RC.

He won the 4-mile time trial once before, in 1992. The first woman home was Sue Appelboom in 21.46, finishing 126th.

webTitle: Oxygen and sugar boost brain power

fields.headline: Oxygen and sugar boost brain power
fields.trailText: Mental performance and agility can be considerably improved by inhaling pure oxygen or by taking a high dose of glucose, scientists revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
Mental performance and agility can be considerably improved by inhaling pure oxygen or by taking a high dose of glucose, scientists revealed yesterday.

Just as athletes can increase their physical performance by eating the right foods, students can better their performance by inhaling a shot of oxygen or swallowing some glucose just before a test.

Andrew Scholey, director of the Human Cognitive Neuroscience unit at the University of Northumbria, discovered through tests that mental strength could be improved by giving the brain the right fuel.

The brain is one of the most energetic organs in the body. Though it accounts for only 2% of our body weight, it uses between 20% and 30% of the body's energy. Despite this need for energy, the brain has what can be thought of as a design fault: it stores only a negligible amount of glucose and needs the blood stream to deliver a constant supply.

Dr Scholey gave a group of students around 30g of glucose and asked to perform a "serial seven" test, where they had to continually subtract seven from an arbitrary starting figure. The students who took the glucose could do between two and three more calculations a minute than another group that did not receive the sugar.

Dr Scholey said that a single dose of the herbal extract gingko - which is thought to boost blood flow and increase glucose metabolism - improved the attention of students for up to six hours.

In another test students had a one-minute blast of oxygen immediately before being given a list of words to remember. The students who took the oxygen remembered two or three more words from a list of 15 than those who did not.

Students who took oxygen while playing the Tetris computer game on its most demanding level were also shown to play significantly better. But oxygen had little effect on performance at lower difficulty levels.

"It looks like the types of cognitive function most affected by oxygen and glucose are tasks with a high level of cognitive demand," said Dr Scholey at the British Psychological Society's centenary meeting in Glasgow.

Blood samples taken from people performing a demanding mental task show lower glucose levels and Dr Scholey believes the body delivers oxygen and glucose to the brain when it faces a difficult task.

"Even the most esoteric brain functions obey biological rules. By tweaking fuel availability to the brain, simply by throwing a bit more fuel on to the fire, you can improve cognitive function to some degree," he said.

webTitle: Motion in row with female student

fields.headline: Motion in row with female student
fields.standfirst:
Poet laureate is accused of harassment but says he is victim

Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Poet laureate is accused of harassment but says he is victim.
fields.body:
Andrew Motion, the poet laureate, has become involved in a dispute with a student he teaches on the creative writing MA course at the University of East Anglia, it emerged yesterday.

Laura Fish, the author of a critically acclaimed novel, is alleging that Motion harassed her. She has a series of emails from him which she is expected to present to the university when it formally investigates the matter.

Motion, 48, who is married with three children, has responded by complaining to the university that Ms Fish is harassing him, although he does not deny that he kissed her or sent her personal emails.

It will be down to the university authorities to unravel the dispute. A spokesman said it would take any "appropriate action" after it had formally investigated the complaints.

Ms Fish, 37, enrolled on the one-year course last autumn. It is understood that Motion accepted her because he was impressed by her novel, Flight of Black Swans.

Ms Fish, who lives with her five-year old son on the campus at Norwich, claims that she complained to the university authorities about Mr Motion, but believes she was not taken seriously.

However in a letter to Ms Fish dated December 8 last year, the dean of English and American studies, Jon Cook, says the matters she raised are "of the greatest concern". The dean says he will sit in on tutorial meetings she has with Motion and writes that he has instructed the professor only to contact her in relation to work.

"I will be speaking to Professor Motion about the consequences of his behaviour towards you," he says. "I will warn him that he risks dismissal if he behaves towards others as he has behaved towards you ... I have no doubt he is aware of the seriousness of the situation.

"He will be told emphatically that no repetition of what has happened to you can be tolerated."

It is understood that in January Ms Fish wrote to the dean that she was satisfied with the steps that had been taken and saw no need for further action. But now she is insistent that a full investigation should take place.

Motion, however, claims that he is the victim. In a statement issued yesterday he said: "I have reluctantly been obliged to make a formal complaint to the university authorities about a mature student on the creative writing MA course in which I have accused her of harassing me, and some of her fellow students, and of slandering me to the press and elsewhere."

"It is not appropriate for me to make any further comment while this process is under way in the university. Further legal action is also under discussion at this point."

fields.headline: Clifford takes on internet babies case
fields.trailText: PR guru Max Clifford is to help the Kilshaws in their battle to win custody of the twins they adopted through the internet, writes Julia Day
fields.body:
PR guru Max Clifford is to help Judith and Alan Kilshaw in their battle to win custody of the twins they adopted through the internet.

Mr Clifford is to offer his services to the Kilshaws for free, because he feels sorry for them.

As the couple's struggle to gain custody of the twins returned to the High Court today, it emerged that Mr Clifford will be giving them public relations advice.

Mr Clifford said: "Judith and Alan Kilshaw were thrown to the wolves and I feel very sorry for them. I will be offering them free advice and guidance, which if they follow it, should make the best of a bad situation."

He continued: "They got themselves into this mess and found out to their cost that handling the media without knowing the game is like walking in a minefield without a mine detector.

"All they wanted to do was offer a safe home to two little girls but the whole thing blew up in their face."

The Kilshaws have so far done themselves no favours in the eyes of a media critical of the US phenomena of adoption using the internet.

The couple reneged on a promise to the High Court not to speak publicly about the adoption row by appearing on the Oprah Winfrey TV show.

The Kilshaws join Mr Clifford's ecclectic client list which includes Mohamed al-Fayed, Pamela Bordes, Octuplets mother-to-be Mandy Allwood, OJ Simpson and Louise Woodward.

fields.headline: Southampton release Hoddle's registration
fields.trailText: Southampton have released Glenn Hoddle's managerial registration allowing him finally to become the new manager of Tottenham.
fields.body:
Southampton have released Glenn Hoddle's managerial registration allowing him finally to become the new manager of Tottenham.

The decision by Saints chairman Rupert Lowe came late this afternoon after Spurs agreed a compensation package for Hoddle's services.

The news puts to end six days of legal wrangling between the two clubs. Hoddle and his assistant John Gorman are now free to take charge and prepare the club for their FA Cup semi-final with Arsenal this weekend.

Early today, Spurs released a statement to the stock exchange officially announcing their new manager. The statement read: "The board of Tottenham Hotspur announces that Glenn Hoddle has been appointed as football manager and John Gorman as assistant football manager of Tottenham Hotspur Football Club, both under five-year contracts.

"The appointments take effect as of 2 April and remain subject to the completion of certain legal formalities with Southampton Football Club."

But with Southampton and Spurs unable to come to an agreement on a compensation package for Hoddle's services until just after 5pm tonight, Hoddle was unable to take training today.

webTitle: Brazilian grand prix: Coulthard revels in the rain

fields.headline: Coulthard revels in the rain
fields.standfirst: The Scot ends Schumacher's run with one of his finest races after Montoya makes an early mark
fields.trailText: The Scot ends Schumacher's run with one of his finest races after Montoya makes an early mark.
fields.body:
David Coulthard, benefitting from the quick thinking of his McLaren team and a clever choice of race set-up, drove one of the best races of his career yesterday to win an incident-filled Brazilian grand prix in Sao Paulo.

The decisive moment came on lap 50 of the 71-lap race, after the Scot had opted for "intermediate" rain tyres when a thunderstorm briefly doused the circuit. Pursuing Michael Schumacher down the curved pit straight, Coulthard took the lead with an inspired dive down the inside as the two men ran either side of Tarso Marques's Minardi. From then on, nothing stood between him and his 10th grand prix victory - bringing to an end Schumacher's run of six consecutive wins.

The other star of the race was the Colombian Juan Pablo Montoya, who confirmed his status as the most exciting new formula one driver to emerge in a decade yesterday by romping away into the early lead of the race, having elbowed his way ahead of Michael Schumacher's Ferrari in a dazzling display of car control in only his third outing for the BMW-Williams team.

But just as it seemed he had gained the upper hand over the three times world champion, Montoya was shunted dramatically out of the race when Jos Verstappen's Arrows, which the Colombian had just lapped, slammed into the back of his Williams. The two cars pirouetted to a halt, but Montoya was cheered to the echo as he walked back to the pits, leaving Schumacher to fend off an increasingly determined Coulthard.

Before the race, the Scot had opted for a "compromise" chassis setting which enabled him to make better use of the intermediate tyres than Michael Schumacher, whose car was on full dry settings. The German, who like Coulthard put on the Bridgestone intermediates during his second pitstop - having used them to such good effect a fortnight ago when he won the Malaysian grand prix - now found them working against him.

As a result, spectators were treated to the uncharacteristic sight of Schumacher half-spinning and then sliding off the circuit as he struggled to keep touch with the McLaren, eventually dropping to second place some 16.1sec behind Coulthard at the chequered flag. The result strengthened Coulthard's credibility as a serious world championship contender with 20 points, only six behind Schumacher.

On a day when mere survival was difficult on the treacherous track surface, the German Nick Heidfeld drove magnificently to take his Sauber-Ferrari across the line in third place, ahead of Olivier Panis's BAR-Honda. Jarno Trulli's Jordan-Honda and Giancarlo Fisichella's Benetton-Renault completed the top half-dozen.

Even before the cars had taken their place on the starting grid, a collective groan had come from the passionately enthusiastic crowd as their hero Rubens Barrichello rolled to a standstill when his Ferrari's oil pressure plummeted on his first lap out of the pits.

This was the latest in a long line of frustrations for the Sao Paulo driver, who had suffered an engine failure on Friday and then grappled with understeer throughout qualifying, and was only able to claim a disappointing sixth on the starting grid.

In sweltering temperatures of around 35C (95F), Barrichello jogged back to the pits where he slumped exhausted on the floor while the Ferrari mechanics busied themselves changing the settings on Michael Schumacher's spare car, so the local hero could take up his position for the start.

The task of changing pedal settings, adjusting his seat harness and fitting him into the car meant it was touch and go whether Barrichello would manage to get out on to the circuit before the pit lane exit closed 15 minutes prior to the start. In the event he made it with 26 seconds to spare, but it had been an uncomfortably close call.

If this was a shaky moment for the Ferrari team, nothing compared with the crushing disappointment waiting for the McLaren-Mercedes team when Mika Hakkinen stalled on the grid. As Michael Schumacher led away from pole position, the pack scattered in all directions to avoid the stationary McLaren, and the dejected Finn climbed from the cockpit and walked back to his pit as the safety car was brought out to slow the field.

At the end of the second lap the car was withdrawn again and, as a first rain shower doused the circuit, Montoya seized his chance to lunge down the inside of Schumacher going into the first turn.

Not in the least intimidated by Schumacher's celebrity status, the Colombian ruthlessly banged wheels with the Ferrari team leader as he forced his way ahead. On the same lap the hapless Barrichello's bruising weekend ended when he slammed into the back of Ralf Schumacher's Williams-BMW under-braking at the end of the long straight beyond the pits. The Ferrari's right-front wheel was ripped off in the impact, but the Brazilian was unhurt.

The characteristics of Montoya's Michelin tyres meant he was expecting to lose grip after the first couple of laps, but if he could only hang on ahead then the grip would return after half a dozen or so laps.

Thereafter the Colombian drove with unflustered confidence and maturity, revelling in the prodigious acceleration of his powerful BMW engine to out-accelerate Michael Schumacher time and again as they climbed the long hill up to the start-finish line.

On this rare occasion Schumacher seemed to have no answers, but then came the collision and the end of Montoya's dream. Not for long, one suspects.

Summary of incidents

Lap 1 Mika Hakkinen's McLaren stalls on grid and fails to start, bringing out safety car.

Lap 3 Juan Pablo Montoya's Williams overtakes Michael Schumacher into first corner. Rubens Barrichello drives into back of Ralf Schumacher.

Lap 38 Jos Verstappen allows leader Montoya past, then shunts him from behind. Verstappen careers into gravel trap, Montoya out.

Lap 47 Michael Schumacher spins in deluge but stays in front.

Lap 50 Coulthard overtakes Schumacher as they pass either side of backmarker.

Lap 53 Schumacher off again into gravel trap but retains second place. Coulthard holds on for victory.
