fields.headline: Hod, Wad, and Prod
fields.trailText: HOW LOWE CAN YOU GO?
fields.body:
HOW LOWE CAN YOU GO?

Threats! Confusion! Talk of legal action! No, we're not talking about the Fiver's crazy weekend - although my, was it a close run thing - but the continued wrangling over Glenn Hoddle's move to his spiritual home [i.e. Spurs, not Eileen Drewery's semi in Basildon]. Day six of the saga - think North and South without the large bosoms - started with Spurs making a statement to the Stock Exchange, as the club is required to by City regulations, in which it confirmed that Hod and John Gorman had joined the club.

Confusion then reigned. Heavily. First Spurs got a little mixed up over whether they'd even released a statement ("It didn't come from us", a spokesbloke told the Fiver). Then Saints chairman Rupert Lowe threatened - not for the first time - to stop Hod starting his new job. "There is quite a list of requirements on a legal document that have to be agreed," he said, underlining each and every one of them with a yellow marker. "As I hold Glenn's registration, I insist they be met before he takes over at the club."

As a result, when Spurs' born-again saviour arrived at Tottenham's Chigwell training ground this morning, he had to find something else to do (which isn't easy in Chigwell, especially when you're a man of God). Not only that, but he couldn't even meet half the first team because they were out injured, and the reserves had already left for a match in Leicester. "It is frustrating," seethed Hod-kick John Gorman. "The sooner we get this situation sorted out the better so we can get on with the big job we face in the FA Cup semi-final." And the big job you face turning a mediocre team around too, the Fiver might add.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE MANC OF ENGLAND

By common consent, Manchester United are now washed up. Following that 2-0 defeat at Anfield, every true football fan knows that United will be lucky to avoid relegation next season and that Roy Keane is rubbish. But speak to a man in a suit (that's a combination of trousers, jacket, tie, and shirt, often in complimentary colours) and they'll tell you that United are set to reign for some time yet, and all thanks to these little paper things called 'money'.

Man Utd plc today announced its financial results for the last six months and they read: Profit 1 - Loss 0 and Hope 0 - Despair 16. Up until January 31, United clocked up a turnover of £72m, an increase of 13% on the previous year. Profits went up too, and the club made a record operating profit of £21.4m (roughly half the amount David Beckham will earn from wearing clothes over the next year). Turnstile receipts were also up 33%, although singing was slashed by 64.9%.

Of course, the Fiver couldn't tell the true meaning of these figures from a hole in the ground. In fact, it has trouble distinguishing holes in the ground full stop. But it is probably safe to infer that more money means more expansion, more players, and more trophies. Unless United's nearest rivals can compete with them in the financial sphere then true competition will be difficult to achieve. Which is why Robbie Fowler and Steven Gerrard are pulling stockings over their heads and heading for the nearest Bradford and Bingley as we speak.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"To tell the truth I just went up into the penalty area to create a bit of chaos but the corner was too inviting and I just stuck it in the net with all my anger." Former United howler Massimo Taibi celebrates scoring for his club Reggina yesterday. Wonder where all that anger came from?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

CHEER UP, IT'S EUROPE!

Permanently gagging on the stench of rotting cattle? Election postponement made you question the judgment of top newspaper the Sun? Been invited round Michael Barrymore's for a party? Hey, don't let it get you down, cos this week is Euroweek, and there's gonna be thrills galore!

For starters, there's Herr Controversial, Bayern Munich striker Elber. Not content with calling Arsenal "the worst team that I have ever seen ever. They are so bad that I'm going to puke right now. Bleeuurrgh"*, the Brazilian has now laid into sexy Dave Beckham before tomorrow's Big Cup quarter-final clash. "To my eyes he is no way a world class player," Elber mind-gamed on his personal web-thing. "Okay, he can cross the ball well, but apart from that he's nothing special," he went on, giving Ottmar Hitzfeld a cheeky wink.

But try as he might, Elber is not the only gob in football. Deportivo midfielder Victor has had a pop ahead of his side's match with Leeds, saying: "We were very pleased when we drew Leeds. They are the weakest side in the competition." And Barcelona coach Lorenzo Serra Ferrer has encouraged his fans to come and watch his team lay on a "fiesta of football" against Liverpool on Thursday.

Meanwhile Jaap Stam has done his part for the Brits and turned up the heat. He told his web-thing: "I've been giving some thought to the foot-and-mouth crisis back home in Holland. It's a sickening sight to see so many animals being killed, especially the ones who don't have the disease yet." Take our word for it, this could be the most exciting Euroweek yet!

*the exact wording may have been lost in translation.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Patrick Vieira will not be joining Juventus or anyone else, according to the Mirror. "I've got four years left on my contract and I want to stay at Highbury," he said. "I love Arsenal. The club is in my heart and leaving does not interest me."

Rivaldo has confirmed that he will leave Barcelona, but not until 2003. Denying rumours that he was set to leave Catalonia this summer, Rivaldo said: "The president has already said that he wants me to stay and I want to stay. But I will not be renewing my contract when it finishes in two seasons."

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Teddy Sheringham may leave Manchester United this summer after only being offered a one-year contract as opposed to the two years he was hoping for.

Dennis Bergkamp has been ruled out of Arsenal's Champions' League quarter-final first-leg against Valencia tomorrow because of an Achilles injury. Alan Smith could miss Leeds match against Deportivo La Coruna on Wednesday after picking up a calf injury at Sunderland at the weekend.

Croatia forward Davor Suker has told reporters he has no intention of playing for West Ham again. "If I play one more match, my contract would be automatically renewed - and I don't want that," he said.

Manchester City chairman David Bernstein has promised that he will not sack Joe Royle if the team are relegated from the Premiership.

QPR have confirmed that former director Andrew Ellis is considering launching a take-over of the club. The 32-year-old property developer is the son of the club's former chairman Peter, who was at the Loftus Road helm between 1994 and 1996.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: Champions League weekly (11.30pm)

Soccer heroes (Midnight)

Football extra (12.30am)

Channel 5: Dutch football (4.40am)

Football League review (6.30pm)

Live Monday night football - Southampton v Ipswich (7pm)

You're on Sky Sports! (10.30pm)

Eurosport: British Eurogoals (10.15pm)

Radio 5 Live: Sport on Five with Ian Payne (7pm)

Talksport: Football First with Steve Bowers from Manchester (7pm) Today's TV and radio section was brought to you by the Trappist monks of Cologne.

fields.headline: Music giants join forces to rival Napster
fields.trailText: 5.30pm: Three of the world's biggest music companies have decided to collaborate on a new online music service, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Three of the world's biggest music companies have decided to collaborate on a new online music service that will take on the mighty song-swapping service Napster.

AOL Time Warner, Bertelsmann and EMI have joined forces with internet video and audio giant RealNetworks to create MusicNet.

MusicNet will licence its service to companies seeking to sell music subscription services under their own brands, and could also end up doing a deal with Napster.

Notable is the absence of Vivendi Universal and Sony Music, the other two major music companies, who last month got together to develop their own rival online music service, called Duet.

EMI, Bertelsmann and AOL Time Warner will each own a minority stake in MusicNet and licence their music to the new service.

RealNetworks, which also has a minority stake, will develop the internet media delivery technology.

MusicNet will be a subscription-based service offering secure access to a catalogue of mainstream recordings, available either in streamed or downloadable format.

While the industry applauded this new collaboration, opinion was guarded because of the lack of coherent business and revenue models.

RealNetworks chief executive Rob Glaser and acting CEO of MusicNet, said: "The launch of MusicNet will catalyse an exciting new era in digital music distribution.

"MusicNet will offer consumers an easy, simple way to get the highest-quality music while also protecting the intellectual property of record companies and artists.

"We hope all the major and independent labels will join MusicNet.

fields.headline: Superintendent answers his accusers
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: On lawyers' advice Ali Dizaei declined to be interviewed. Here are extracts from the disciplinary notice served on him by the Metropolitan police, called a N163. Friends of Dizaei who have spoken to him have provided his response, with additional details from witnesses.
fields.body:
On lawyers' advice Ali Dizaei declined to be interviewed. Here are extracts from the disciplinary notice served on him by the Metropolitan police, called a N163. Friends of Dizaei who have spoken to him have provided his response, with additional details from witnesses.

You drove a car on diplomatic plates between June 12 and 14, 2000.

Accepted. Believes he did nothing wrong.

You improperly used your position to interfere in a long-term civil dispute between a builder and your friend, Mr Ghavami.

Denied. These two allegations centre on Mr Dizaei's friendship with Ali Ghavami, the Liberian ambassador at large, based in London. An Iranian national, he is a longstanding friend of Mr Dizaei's father. The officer borrowed a car from Mr Ghavami, who told the Guardian this had been done with his knowledge and permission.

Mr Ghavami says he asked Mr Dizaei for advice about a dispute he was having with a builder. Both were suing each other and the diplomat says the builder had threatened him and his son if money was not paid. Mr Ghavami says Mr Dizaei asked a local beat officer to "keep an eye" on Mr Ghavami and reassure him. Mr Ghavami says that when the civil dispute came to court, he won the case.

On numerous occasions (between April 4 and October 26 2000) you entered licensed premises and accepted gratuities such as free meals and drinks. You accepted other gratuities in the form of tickets for the WWF wrestling at Earl's Court and a Crockford diary and Filofax from the Ambassadors Club.

Friends say Mr Dizaei admits accepting WWF tickets which were sent unsolicited to the station. They say other officers took tickets for other events and Mr Dizaei was unaware this breached any rules. He admits accepting the diary and Filofax from the Ambassadors, a casino.

He accepts that he had meals without paying at the Yas restaurant, west London. It is owned by Sohrab Eshraghi, 60, a long-standing friend of his father. Mr Eshraghi says he would have been insulted if Mr Dizaei had tried to pay. It would have been culturally unacceptable.

Mr Eshraghi says officers from Mr Dizaei's station held an early morning meeting at his restaurant. No payment was made or sought for the room they used or drinks they had. Mr Eshraghi also says a senior officer dined with Mr Dizaei at the restaurant, and neither paid. That officer is not believed to be under investigation

Mr Eshraghi said there was no question of corruption over free meals: "He couldn't do me any favours as a police officer. If I'm in the restaurant I will not let him pay because I'm only too happy to see him."

Police investigating Mr Dizaei have also visited the Caspian restaurant near Harrods. Mr Dizaei went there with Mr Eshraghi on New Year's Eve. The owner, Masoud Abzarian, said officers had interviewed him twice and his wife once. Mr Abzarian said Mr Dizaei had stayed a short time and drunk a glass of water, probably from the tap, which would have been free. Friends of the officer say he does not believe he had free meals or drink anywhere else.

In August 2000 legal proceedings began against the Paparazzi cafe. You conspired with the owner/licensee, Tony Aalam, to improperly discontinue those proceedings by engineering an adjournment. Following the adjournment you met with him on November 15 2000, when you took possession of an envelope outside the Paparazzi cafe.

Denied. Mr Aalam was a good friend of Mr Dizaei, who after complaints about excess noise from his cafe in Kensington where Mr Dizaei was officer in charge of licensing decisions, faced having his licence revoked. Friends of Mr Dizaei say he excused himself from any involvement in the decision and told his superiors of his friendship.

At one stage Mr Aalam's lawyers rang Mr Dizaei saying the police had served crucial papers 48 hours before a court hearing. Mr Dizaei, according to supporters, rang the police lawyer and inform ed him of the late service of the papers. They say the police lawyer made a decision to adjourn the hearing.

Later, Mr Dizaei met Mr Aalam where he was handed an envelope. Supporters say it merely contained a report on the cafe's noise levels, commissioned by Mr Aalam.

Following Aized Sheikh's [businessman friend] arrest and charge for drink driving in September 2000, you met with him whilst he was on bail, [and] you assisted him in formulating a defence; a service for which you appear to have received payment.

Denied. Friends of Mr Dizaei say the officer told Mr Sheikh to get a lawyer after his Bentley was stopped late at night by police. Mr Dizaei agreed that the way he had been treated appeared unfair.

On October 26 2000 you were made aware of a crime in the form of a malicious document concerning Mr Vousoogh [an Iranian musician] and his family. You neither had the matter investigated or caused a risk assessment to be completed.

Denied.

On or before January 5 2001, you obtained a gratuity, namely seven concert tickets for the Googoosh [Iranian music] concert.

Accepted. Mr Dizaei told friends the tickets were sent to him unsolicited. He gave them to a friend who sold them on. The proceeds went to a charity, the Mohammad-Salehi medical fund, which according to charity commission records, pays for treatment of sick Iranians in Britain.

From September 1999 it is alleged that you have been engaged in acts of criminality and serious misconduct.

There are also allegations that you improperly used your position to interfere with an ongoing investigation into the c riminal damage of a motor vehicle (August 22 2000), where you divulged details to Dr Bastami.

Denied. Friends of Mr Dizaei say these relate to a London imam being stopped by an officer and told to attend the police station the next day. The imam was scared and got a friend, Dr Bastami, to ring Mr Dizaei to ask what it was about. Mr Dizaei made a call to another officer to find out why the imam had been stopped. He has told friends he told Dr Bastami that the imam should attend the station regarding an allegation of criminal damage and reassured him he would not be maltreated.

You provided false information to the investigating team regarding the criminal damage to your own car on September 6 2000.

Denied.

You visited foreign embassies (Ethiopian, Liberian and Iranian) without informing special branch or the diplomatic protection group.

Denied. The officer has told friends he always informed special branch before visiting foreign embassies, of which there were more than 90 on his patch in Kensington. He had friends at the Liberian and Iranian embassies. He does not believe the rules required him to inform the diplomatic protection group.

You failed to provide information regarding an individual (Sanchez) wanted for questioning in the Saul Nahome murder inquiry.

Denied. Mr Dizaei has told friends he had no idea who Sanchez was, and can only think he was at a function with him. He says that Sanchez was later ruled out of the murder inquiry.

In October 2000, without authority and in full uniform, you spoke to an Iranian business meeting in Los Angeles.

Mr Dizaei accepted he spoke there, but does not believe wearing his uniform broke any rules. Lorraine Johnson, British consul for investment at the British consulate general in Los Angeles, was present and said: "There was nothing unusual about his performance."

webTitle: Met officer fights back in 'racist witch-hunt'

fields.headline: Met officer fights back in 'racist witch-hunt'
fields.standfirst:
Suspended superintendent tipped as future chief constable faces catalogue of charges including assault, misuse of drugs and corruption

Special report: race issues in the UK

Superintendent answers his accusers
fields.trailText: Suspended superintendent tipped as future chief constable faces catalogue of charges including assault, misuse of drugs and corruption.
fields.body:
The Metropolitan police have been accused of a "racist witch-hunt" against one of the country's most senior ethnic minority officers, suspended over a host of criminal and disciplinary allegations.

Superintendent Ali Dizaei, suspended since January 18 from his £52,000 a year post, will today launch a fightback against the force.

The Guardian has learned extensive details of the allegations against the officer, one of the Met's most vocal internal critics on race, who was tipped as a future chief constable.

They include assault, misuse of drugs, deception, seeking pecuniary advantage, corrupt practice, divulging confidential information, unregistered business interests, sex with prostitutes, accepting gratuities and being beholden to individuals, all of which are denied.

Supt Dizaei, who has joint British and Iranian citizenship and was based at Kensington police station, in west London, has not yet been charged with any criminal or disciplinary offence. Supporters will today demand the Met "put up or shut up".

Two of the counts contained in the disciplinary notice and part of a third allegation are true, the Guardian has established.

Supt Dizaei did accept a Filofax and diary from a casino, two tickets for a World Wrestling Federation event in London, and seven tickets for an Iranian music concert he was policing, and did drive a car with diplomatic licence plates belonging to a friend for two days.

Supporters say these are either very minor offences or not even offences at all against the police disciplinary code.

The other allegations are described by the National Black Police Association, representing Supt Dizaei, as either false or trivial and not warranting the manpower and estimated £1m expense of the operation against him.

The investigation against Supt Dizaei was staffed and resourced to the same level as a murder inquiry, with up to 42 officers involved at one stage.

Tory MP Peter Bottomley, who tabled parliamentary questions about the affair, said the size of the investigation can only be justified if it produces "a series of very serious criminal charges". Scotland Yard and the Home Office refused to confirm or deny whether covert surveillance, including phone taps, were used. At least one surveillance team was also deployed to tail the officer, who was legal adviser to the National Black Police Association, and has a doctorate in law.

The NBPA chairman, Sergeant Ravi Chand, says he believes the investigation is crumbling. "It is not the norm to investigate alleged trivial offences if you suspect a senior officer of serious criminal offences. The only reason is if you fear that the bigger allegations are crumbling. It is a racist witch-hunt."

One allegation has already seemingly backfired. Officers went to the Met branch of the National Black Police Association, which they believed had been deceived. Supt Dizaei had claimed £688 for a plane ticket to speak in Los Angeles last year.

Officers said he had been supposed to talk about the Stephen Lawrence case, but instead spoke about broader policing issues and that this might amount to deception. A senior official described the allegation as rubbish.

Friends say Supt Dizaei was suspended when he was within days of suing the Met for racial discrimination. Lawyers acting for Supt Dizaei are expected this week to start suing the Met for racial discrimination.

Two allegations centre on a diplomat, Ali Ghavami, who is the Liberian ambassador at large. He has been questioned by police about his friendship with Supt Dizaei and said: "I resent my name and that of the country I represent being dragged into this."

Supt Dizaei joined the Met two years ago from the Thames Valley force. Today he was supposed to be on the first day of a strategic command course, gateway to the elite ranks of the police.

Friends say he was "hated" by some white officers. He did not socialise with other officers and was seen at London venues such as the Roof Gardens, where he had membership costing £400 a year.

Scotland Yard declined to discuss any details of the investigation.

fields.headline: Hit TV shows 'ignore ethnic minorities'
fields.standfirst:
Special report: race issues in the UK
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Ethnic minorities are barely represented in some of the most popular programmes on British television, reports Matt Wells.
fields.body:
Ethnic minorities are barely represented in some of the most popular programmes on British television, according to one of the most comprehensive studies on race in the media.

Black and Asian people were found to be almost non-existent in makeover shows such as Ground Force and Home Front. And in one week on BBC2, the only ethnic minority faces to be seen in the channel's top 10 programmes - with combined viewing figures of 33m - were cartoon characters in the Simpsons.

In drama, broadcasters are often guilty of "colour-blind" casting: in other words, characters from minority communities could just as easily have been white, because they display no evidence of their ethnic background.

The appearance of ethnic minority characters in EastEnders and Coronation Street was patchy, even though the programmes are set in London and Manchester, cities with large ethnic minority populations. Only Channel 4's Brookside, set in Liverpool, is consistent.

Apart from the occasional contribution to cookery programmes, ethnic minorities were almost invisible in the area of lifestyle programmes.

By examining 204 programmes between November 20 and December 17 last year - the heart of the most competitive autumn season between the broadcasters for years - the researchers found that the overall ethnic minority representation was 8.4%, compared with 6.7% in the "real world".

But when foreign (mainly US) films and the portrayal of visitors to the UK (such as foreign dignitaries) were excluded, the figure fell to 5.2%. Black people appeared more frequently on TV (3.7%) than in real life (2.1%). Asians were the most under-represented group: they account for 3.7% of the population but were statistically almost invisible on TV.

The results of the survey come a year after the formation of the Cultural Diversity Network, set up by the broadcasters to monitor progress against published targets, and after the BBC director general, Greg Dyke, urged the TV industry to reflect the real world.

Guy Cumberbatch, from the Communications Research Group, which carried out the research for the commission for racial equality, said it was not good enough simply for broadcasters to cast black people in white roles.

"We were struck by how few of the ethnic minority characters we observed were displaying cultural diversity." The days in which people from ethnic minorities were portrayed as "chanting savages" were over, but there was still a great deal to be done, he said.

Gurbux Singh, chairman of the CRE, which is mounting the annual race in the media awards on Friday, said: "Britain's most popular television programmes, broadcast to millions, still fall short of representing the full range of people that live here.

"While there are encouraging signs that the number of ethnic minority faces on television is rising, there is clearly some way to go. And for some programme makers, a very long way to go before they can call their output truly representative of the British TV audience."

By examining 204 programmes between November 20 and December 17 last year - the heart of the most competitive autumn season between the broadcasters for years - the researchers found that the overall ethnic minority representation was 8.4%, compared with 6.7% in the "real world". But when foreign (mainly US) films and the portrayal of visitors to the UK (such as foreign dignitaries) were excluded, the figure fell to 5.2%. Black people appeared more frequently on TV (3.7%) than in real life (2.1%). Asians were the most under-represented group: they account for 3.7% of the population but were statistically almost invisible on TV. The results of the survey come a year after the formation of the Cultural Diversity Network, set up by the broadcasters to monitor progress against published targets, and after the BBC director general, Greg Dyke, urged the TV industry to reflect the real world. Guy Cumberbatch, from the Communications Research Group, which carried out the research for the commission for racial equality, said it was not good enough simply for broadcasters to cast black people in white roles. "We were struck by how few of the ethnic minority characters we observed were displaying cultural diversity." The days in which people from ethnic minorities were portrayed as "chanting savages" were over, but there was still a great deal to be done, he said. Gurbux Singh, chairman of the CRE, which is mounting the annual race in the media awards on Friday, said: "Britain's most popular television programmes, broadcast to millions, still fall short of representing the full range of people that live here. "While there are encouraging signs that the number of ethnic minority faces on television is rising, there is clearly some way to go. And for some programme makers, a very long way to go before they can call their output truly representative of the British TV audience."

fields.headline: Milosevic facing life behind bars
fields.trailText: Slobodan Milosevic, the former Yugoslav president, was today charged with inciting his bodyguards to shoot at police as they attempted to arrest him.
fields.body:
Slobodan Milosevic, the former Yugoslav president, was today charged with inciting his bodyguards to shoot at police as they attempted to arrest him.

If found guilty, Mr Milosevic could spend an extra 15 years in jail, in addition to the five years he would serve if convicted on corruption charges.

More serious charges could be raised in the months ahead, possibly including involvement in political assassinations during his 13-year rule.

And if Mr Milosevic is convicted by the international tribunal for war crimes at the Hague, he will serve a life sentence, Carla Del Ponte, the chief prosecutor, said today.

New indictments concerning genocide in the 1991-95 Bosnian and Croatian wars are nearly complete.

They will be in addition to an arrest warrant first issued in May 1999 in connection with the murder of hundreds of ethnic Albanians in Kosovo and the persecution or displacement of 740,000 people during the 1999 Kosovo war.

"If there's one thing that is not in doubt, it is that Milosevic will be taken to The Hague to be prosecuted on these charges that he committed war crimes in Kosovo," Ms Del Ponte told reporters.

Mr Milosevic was arrested in the early hours of Sunday morning after a 26-hour stand off. A police spokesman, Sreten Lukic, said the former president's bodyguards wounded four policemen on Saturday when they charged his residence.

Three of the bodyguards are in custody, including one, Sinisa Vucinic, who is also being investigated on suspicion of planning an armed rebellion against the new regime.

After Mr Milosevic was taken to Belgrade's central prison, police entered his compound and said that they found a major arsenal. It included two armoured personnel carriers, 30 automatic weapons, three heavy machine guns, an anti-tank grenade launcher, 23 pistols of varying calibres, 30 rifle grenades, two cases of hand grenades and several cases of machine-gun clips and other ammunition.

Mr Milosevic had vowed not to be taken alive, and brandished a pistol during the negotiations that led to his surrender. His daughter, Marija, fired pistol shots after her father agreed to give up.

He maintains his innocence.

fields.headline: Blair delays elections
fields.standfirst:
 Council polls now on June 7
 May 3 general election off
 'No indefinite postponement'

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText:
 Council polls now on June 7
 May 3 general election off
 'No indefinite postponement'
fields.body:
The prime minister, Tony Blair, today postponed local elections until June 7 in order to give the government time to bring foot and mouth disease under control - but he made no announcement about the general election.

Describing the decision to move the local elections back from May 3 as a "need to balance competing interests", Mr Blair said that an indefinite postponement would be "highly damaging to the national interest", as industries such as tourism would continue to suffer from an atmosphere of uncertainty.

Last week church leaders called for the election to be put back to the autumn while the Tory leader, William Hague, said that holding an election while the foot and mouth crisis was raging would put "party above country". But speaking at Downing Street today, Mr Blair dismissed those calls.

"It is right that while we're putting in the mechanisms to fight this disease we have this postponement," he said. "But in addition to the farming community I must listen to the tourist industry and the wider community. They will accept the delay I have set out but will not accept an indefinite postponement."

John Edmonds, general secretary of the GMB union, said: "In the circumstances this is a responsible decision, but it is vital that the prime minister draws a line in the sand for June 7. If we were to be forced beyond that date it would be disastrous for tourism and the economy as a whole."

Sir Ken Jackson, general secretary of the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union, said he would have preferred a May election, but he recognised that pressure had built up for a delay.

"The prime minister was in a no-win situation and I have a lot of sympathy for the position he was in," he said.

Though Mr Blair refused to be drawn on the timing of a general election, his original preferred date of May 3 now seems an impossible target.

Addressing the media at Conservative central office earlier today, Mr Hague argued against setting a new date for the local elections.

Mr Hague said: "If - as seems likely, and has been leaked by the government - elections cannot take place while this crisis continues, then we would accept that. But, since they cannot possibly know when the crisis will end, in our view it would not be possible to set any new precise date for these elections to be held."

Asked if the Tories would oppose the legislation needed to postpone the local elections, Mr Hague replied: "While we would accept legislation in principle, postponing the elections, we would not be in favour of a new particular date being set for those elections at this moment until the crisis is resolved."

This afternoon the home secretary, Jack Straw, confirmed that emergency legislation will be introduced to postpone the local elections until June 7.

Mr Straw told the Commons that the government had responded to the "feelings and sensitivities of people" in the communities most severely hit by foot and mouth.

He said elections to 34 English county councils and 11 English unitary authorities had been scheduled for May 3, with elections for 26 district councils in Northern Ireland due on May 16.

But he added: "The House will, however, be aware of the considerable scale of representations which we have received to defer these elections because of the extent of foot and mouth disease."

Amid rowdy scenes, the shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, accused ministers of "dither and delay", but welcomed the government's "belated recognition" of the crisis in the countryside.

webTitle: Players cashing in leaves a bitter taste for Sugar

fields.headline: Players cashing in leaves a bitter taste for Sugar
fields.trailText: Martin Kelner's screen break Alan Sugar on the evils of players wages, deluded agents on respect for the game and Jonathan Pearce's economically tainted commentary.
fields.body:
BBC2's revival of the justly revered film This Is Spinal Tap on Saturday was fortuitous, coming as it did a few days after the conclusion of the same channel's documentary - soccumentary, if you will - about The Men Who Changed Football, which featured Alan Sugar doing his hilarious Artie Fufkin act.

Fufkin, devotees of the film (Tappies, I believe they call us) will recognise, is the press and publicity guy who fails to whip up any interest in a public appearance by the eponymous heavy metal act, for which he takes responsibility in a mock ironic way. "Kick my ass. Go on, kick it," Fufkin says, bending over before the band. It is not Fufkin's fault, of course. Nobody has turned up because the band is a dismal act trading on past glories.

Far be it from me to make a direct link to Tottenham Hotspur but Sugar seemed to be doing as much when he complained about the fans' unrealistic expectations. In the same way that Tap expected to be playing 20,000-seater stadiums long past their prime, Spurs' fans expected to watch their heroes in Europe every year.

"My fault," said Sugar, "I only pissed thirty million pounds of my own money against the wall. I should have pissed a hundred million."

The nub of Sugar's complaint was that television money - £1.1bn in the latest deal - goes straight into the players' pockets.

"You're like someone eating prunes and figs at the same time," Sugar moaned. "The TV money just flows right the way through, without touching the sides."

Sugar has a case - another director said players' wages would "eat you alive," accounting for 60 or 70% of total costs.

It is the way of the world these days, I am afraid, but Sugar would perhaps get more sympathy if he did not look quite so much like Sid James's dyspeptic brother.

It would not come from the players' agent Eric Hall, though. "Schmucks" was Hall's considered assessment of people like Sugar, who cave in to players' outrageous wage demands.

Chutzpah, I think, is le mot juste for Hall's stance, given that wage negotiations these days are usually driven by Hall and his like.

"Listen bubbelah, nobody holds a gun to their head and says you've got to pay £50,000 a week," said Hall, "We're just asking politely."

And he smiled beatifically. It might have taken the breath away, were we not already dazzled by the reflection from the lovable rascal's sun-kissed dome.

If Hall represents the agents' provisional wing, Jerome Anderson, who must take much of the credit - or blame - for creating the Ian Wright phenomenon, presented himself as the sober-suited functionary merely offering "help and assistance to players" as they pursue their dreams.

One must assume, therefore, that when Wrightie - as we are now contractually obliged to call him - was setting out on his career his dreams included a Chicken Tonight ad and singing a duet with Lionel Richie.

As chance would have it, another of the players Anderson represented was David Rocastle, and the agent, appearing on Richard Littlejohn's Radio Five Live show on Saturday evening to pay tribute, took the opportunity to have a swipe at the BBC2 documentary - which seemed odd as his testimony was prominent among those helping the programme build up its picture of the state of soccer today.

"The programme gave the impression that football is all about money, money, money," complained Anderson, "but the fans this afternoon showed that's not the case. When there's a tragedy, football people get together and show where their hearts really are."

Was Anderson really saying that an "immaculately observed" minute's silence for a well-liked player who had died of cancer at a shockingly young age leaving a widow and three young children proved all was well in the world of football? If so, I think we are entitled to reply that it was the least you would expect.

If you were in any doubt that football is dominated by money these days, you needed only to listen to Jonathan Pearce's commentary on the Albania-England match. Pearce regaled us with more facts about the relative economic positions of Albania and England than we will ever need.

So now we know that, when the state housing was sold off in Albania, you could have bought a two-bedroomed flat for £120; and an Albanian fan would have to work for 100 years to earn what McManaman does in a week.

Favourite piece of commentary of the week, though, came from Saturday's rugby league semi-final on Grandstand. As Leeds's Francis Cummins prevented St Helens' Kevin Iro from touching down by getting his body in the way of the line, Ray French said: "Cummins grabbed Iro and he wanted him to go down on him."

For some reason this made me laugh.

martin@kelner.demon.co.uk

fields.headline: What chance an upset?
fields.standfirst: Despite the polls all pointing to another big election win for Tony Blair, foot and mouth and voter apathy might just make a difference, writes the Guardian's home affairs editor, Alan Travis
fields.trailText: Despite the polls all pointing to another big election win for Tony Blair, foot and mouth and voter apathy might just make a difference, writes the Guardian's home affairs editor, Alan Travis.
fields.body:
In the nine weeks remaining between now and the likely date of the general election, it is William Hague's job to remain publicly committed to the idea that the Conservatives can pull off a shock victory.

Inside Conservative central office, however, speculation centres as much on the scale of the party's coming defeat and whether it will prove so crushing that Mr Hague finds himself the shortest-lived Tory leader since Sir Alec Douglas-Home. Few insiders expect the delay in the election to make much of a difference to the result.

Yet it might. The Conservative leader dreams fondly of repeating Ted Heath's shock win in the 1970 election. As polling day approached most opinion polls predicted Harold Wilson's Labour government would win with a comfortable majority; most Labour MPs were sure that they would win. But Ted Heath to pull off a famous victory, with an overall majority of 30.

What chance a repeat on June 7 2001? One crucial difference lies in the polls. Mr Wilson lost his opinion poll lead within a year of the 1966 election. His claim that Labour was the "natural party of government" was repeatedly battered by byelection losses and Gallup polls that showed the Tories lead averaging 18 points through 1968 and 15 points in 1969.

With hindsight it is clear that the "shock result" would actually have been a Labour win, rather than the modest Tory victory that William Hague hopes to emulate.

So what does the long-term trend in the polls tell us about what might happen in this election?

First, it is well to remember what a historic victory the 1997 landslide actually was. Labour won by 13 points, with 44% of the vote, compared with the Tories' 31% and the Liberal Democrats' 17%.

Some 31m people voted, a turnout of 71% of the registered electors. It was enough to give Tony Blair a 179-seat majority as he led the first Labour government for 18 years.

Since then Labour has registered unprecedented poll leads. The Guardian/ICM poll recorded an average Labour lead of between nine and 19 points over the last three years.

In polls that are even more favourable to the government, the Telegraph/Gallup has put Labour ahead for the past year by, on average, 15 points while the Times/Mori poll has had the party ahead by 16 points.

The only blip came last September, during the petrol crisis. Despite this, the government swiftly rebuilt its lead in the polls.

From a Conservative point of view, the last four years have seen the party floundering. They struggled in the immediate aftermath of the Blair victory and hit rock bottom at 23% in October 1997, before recovering a measure of dignity in early 1998, when they clawed their way back to 30% in the polls. Here they stayed for most of 1998 and 1999, during two years of what was termed "flatlining".

Last summer saw a further modest advance for Mr Hague as Tony Blair admitted in a leaked memo that the government was widely perceived to be "somehow out of touch with gut British instincts" on key populist issues such as crime and asylum seekers.

The Tory share of the vote went up to the 34/35% level on the ICM, where it has remained in a further bout of "flatlining", albeit at a higher level.

If the Liberal Democrats share of the vote stays at its current 16/17-point level, it can be expected that a nine-point lead for Labour would translate into a 140-seat majority.

Mr Hague must hope that he can squeeze the Labour lead during the campaign, which is why Labour want to keep it as short as possible. However, if he is to survive as Tory leader then he surely must cut Labour's majority to below 100 seats. In crude terms that will mean lowering Labour's lead below 5 points.

In part William Hague's survival will depend on the turnout, and whether there is an electoral price to be paid by calling the general election in the middle of the foot and mouth epidemic.

Recent polls have supported the argument that the reluctance of core Labour voters to get to the polling booths is greatest in its heartland seats, where it already has piled up big majorities.

An ICM/News of the World poll showed that Labour's vote in 139 key marginals has actually gone up by 3.9% since May 1997. In the same seats, the Tories have only made a gain of 0.9%.

The implication is that Mr Blair could win big again on June 7, perhaps with a majority of over 100, even if the turnout is very low. In fact, it is possible that the bigger the turnout, the bigger the Labour majority.

The scale of tactical voting in individual seats is expected to be less developed than in 1997, but for many voters Mr Hague is even less attractive than John Major was in 1997.

Perhaps for Mr Hague the more apt comparison is not 1970 but Mrs Thatcher's 1987 victory. Then the government party was re-elected with 42% of the vote against Labour's 31%.

Mrs Thatcher's majority was cut to 101, a net loss of 21 seats. Those figures do not look too far out of line with what the polls have been telling us about Mr Blair's chances for the past four years.

The Labour party gave Neil Kinnock the benefit of the doubt in the aftermath of their 1987 general election defeat. It would be no surprise were the Conservatives to do the same with William Hague.

Mr Hague must hope that he can squeeze the Labour lead during the campaign, which is why Labour want to keep it as short as possible. However, if he is to survive as Tory leader then he surely must cut Labour's majority to below 100 seats. In crude terms that will mean lowering Labour's lead below 5 points. In part William Hague's survival will depend on the turnout, and whether there is an electoral price to be paid by calling the general election in the middle of the foot and mouth epidemic. Recent polls have supported the argument that the reluctance of core Labour voters to get to the polling booths is greatest in its heartland seats, where it already has piled up big majorities. An ICM/News of the World poll showed that Labour's vote in 139 key marginals has actually gone up by 3.9% since May 1997. In the same seats, the Tories have only made a gain of 0.9%. The implication is that Mr Blair could win big again on June 7, perhaps with a majority of over 100, even if the turnout is very low. In fact, it is possible that the bigger the turnout, the bigger the Labour majority. The scale of tactical voting in individual seats is expected to be less developed than in 1997, but for many voters Mr Hague is even less attractive than John Major was in 1997. Perhaps for Mr Hague the more apt comparison is not 1970 but Mrs Thatcher's 1987 victory. Then the government party was re-elected with 42% of the vote against Labour's 31%. Mrs Thatcher's majority was cut to 101, a net loss of 21 seats. Those figures do not look too far out of line with what the polls have been telling us about Mr Blair's chances for the past four years. The Labour party gave Neil Kinnock the benefit of the doubt in the aftermath of their 1987 general election defeat. It would be no surprise were the Conservatives to do the same with William Hague. fields.headline: ONdigital set for rebranding
fields.trailText: 4.30pm: ONdigital's owners are considering dumping the brand and relaunching it as ITV Digital, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
ITV giants Granada and Carlton Communications are considering dumping the ONdigital brand and relaunching it as ITV Digital.

Rob Fyfe, chief operating officer of ONdigital, confirmed the radical move was under consideration as the channel tries to catch up with arch-rival BSkyB.

He told the European media and entertainment summit in London that Independent Television Commission rules are frustrating the company by preventing ITV programmes from plugging the channel.

"We have a number of restrictions in terms of how ONdigital can be promoted by ITV programmes, so when they promote specific content they cannot refer to ONdigital," he said.

"We are looking at ways to overcome these constraints so that we draw people to free-to-air and pay-TV content."

Under current ITC rules, Des Lynam can plug a Champions' League match on ITV2, but he cannot mention that it is on ONdigital.

"Rebranding is one of a range of options," added Mr Fyfe.

Analysts have been pressing ONdigital to undergo a branding revamp because the name does not attract anywhere near the same public recognition as ITV.

However, Mr Fyfe added that ONdigital had succeeded in establishing a foothold in the digital market, although it only has 1m subscribers compared with BSkyB's 4.7m.

"We are at the stage where 95% of the active population have heard of our brand and in retail stores we are achieving about 50% of pay-TV sales. There are clear negatives to moving on," he said.

Mr Fyfe stressed the restructuring was in its "early days", although there was an "ongoing dialogue" between the company and its major shareholders about the future of ONdigital.

fields.headline: Railtrack clinches £1.5bn cash bailout
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Railtrack today secured an early release of a government cash package worth £1.5bn, in return for a pledge to stop "over-promising and under-delivering" in its stewardship of the railways.
fields.body:
Railtrack today secured an early release of a government cash package worth £1.5bn, in return for a pledge to stop "over-promising and under-delivering" in its stewardship of the railways.

To secure the money, originally due in 2006, the company agreed to allow other firms a more prominent role in rail projects, including phase two of the channel tunnel high-speed rail link.

It also agreed to appoint a director to its board, who would be charged with handling passengers' interests.

"Railtrack has in the past been guilty of over-promising and under-delivering, particularly to its customers and also to its shareholders. This has got to stop," said Railtrack's chief executive, Steve Marshall.

Announcing the package today, John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, said it represented a "fresh start for our railways."

He added that since the Hatfield rail crash last October, "it has been clear that Railtrack needs to concentrate more on its basic job: making the existing railway network better and safer."

He said passengers should expect some disruption to services while improvements on the railways were carried out.

The government said the £1.5bn promised to Railtrack were part of a £7.5bn budget approved today for rail improvements. The £7.5bn make up the first installment of a £60bn railways provision included in Labour's 10-year transport plan announced last year.

Today's measure revealed that Railtrack would not exercise its option to build phase two of the channel tunnel rail link from north Kent to St Pancras in London. Instead, the project will be completed by London & Continental Railways, in partnership with the US engineering company, Bechtel.

The strategic rail authority also decided to make Stagecoach the preferred bidder for the South West Trains franchise, in a deal that would see £1.7bn of improvements over the first 10 years of the 20-year franchise.

Stagecoach, the current franchise holder of South West Trains, has been bitterly criticised for driver shortages, which have led to numerous cancellations.

The rail passengers committee for southern England said today that the decision to give Stagecoach a second chance "won't be popular with all SWT passengers, especially those who have been complaining bitterly about late trains and trains that stop short of their destination." The strategic rail authority stressed today that the new franchise decision was "a tough one" and that Stagecoach would suffer harsh penalties for poor performance.

The following projects were also included in today's announcement:

 A plan to relieve Railtrack of the sole responsibility for the £2.8bn upgrade of the East Coast main line. The present operator, GNER, and Sir Richard Branson's Virgin Train company are competing for the new franchise.

 A £39m cash injection to extend the tube's East London line and link it with the North London main line.

 Further improvements on the Chiltern and Anglia main line routes.

webTitle: 'Cut benefits to electoral roll dodgers to boost turnout'

fields.headline: 'Cut benefits to electoral roll dodgers to boost turnout'
fields.standfirst: With voter turnout expected to drop below 70% at the next election, Phil Woolas, the Labour MP, explains why he wants to link benefits to to the electoral register.
fields.trailText: With voter turnout expected to drop below 70% at the next election, Phil Woolas, the Labour MP, explains why he wants to link benefits to to the electoral register.
fields.body:
I'm not going to pretend that ensuring everybody who claims benefits is on the electoral roll means that they will vote. It doesn't. But it makes it more likely, not least because it gives the local political parties a contact point for the individual to help them get involved.

Beyond that, it almost goes back to the principle of "No taxation without representation" - at least in that if you are claiming money back from the taxpayer, you should be part of the democratic process.

My idea for a private members bill arose out of the 1997 general election. Then I noticed there were estates in my constituency where 80% of the electoral roll comprised of women - despite the estates being 50-50 male/female like anywhere else.

The reason was the men would leave the women, often single mothers, to register alone so they could claim the single person rebate on the council tax - about a 25% discount. Now sometimes this was fraud, and sometimes it wasn't, but what it means for the bigger picture is that their local council wasn't getting as much money from central government as it should.

That's because spending is allocated per capita, and the local authority will use the electoral roll to calculate the population rather than the census, because it is more up to date. However, if there are significant numbers of people missing from the roll, we're not getting the money we are entitled to - shooting ourselves in the foot, essentially.

What I am proposing is for benefits claimants to be able to show they have an electoral roll number before receiving welfare.

There may be complaints from people worried about civil liberties, but - although not many people know it - you can register privately on the electoral roll if you so wish. Battered women in refuges, for example, already do.

I'm not suggesting it will be a panacea for low turnouts, but it can only help.

 Phil Woolas is the Labour MP for Oldham East and Saddleworth

fields.headline: Son of God performs small miracle for BBC
fields.trailText: 4pm TV overnights: The BBC's heavily publicised look at the life of Jesus Christ pulled in 6m viewers on Sunday night, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Son of God, the BBC's heavily publicised look at the life of Jesus Christ, proved that even a religious documentary can have popular appeal after pulling in 6m viewers on Sunday night.

The three-part programme went some way to rescuing BBC1's troubled Sunday night line-up, securing a respectable 25% share of the viewing between 9.10pm and 10pm.

This compares with viewing figures of around 4m and a 17% share for Human Face, the John Cleese-fronted documentary that Son of God replaced.

The lead-in from Son of God gave a boost to the BBC's 10pm news broadcast, which secured 5.7m viewers.

And the return of that bankable old favourite, Last of the Summer Wine, earlier in the evening helped the BBC to shrug off the Sunday evening doldrums, although ITV's peaktime line-up of Heartbeat and London's Burning still looks pretty invincible.

But advance publicity failed to draw viewers to another documentary on Sunday night.

Channel 4's Witness courted controversy with an hour-long look at the work of Laura Boyle, author of the anti-feminist self-help book the Surrendered Wife.

But in spite of heavy media coverage of the book, the programme attracted just 1m viewers to give it a 4% share.

On Saturday, BBC1 and ITV had a fairly even match with BBC1's Casualty attracting 7.5m viewers against 8.3m for ITV's Who Wants to be a Millionaire?.

Later in the evening, BBC1's Parkinson and ITV's Midsomer Murders were neck and neck with 6.6m viewers each.

And on Friday BBC1 secured 6.5m viewers with a re-run of the ever-popular Only Fools & Horses, followed by the Weakest Link, which secured 5.5m.

Channel 5's weekly figures were the second best since it launched four years ago.

The coverage of the England World Cup football qualifier against Albania helped boost audience share levels for the week to 7.3%.

And Sky TV is claiming a ratings success with all three of its Star Wars movies making it into its top three places in the film charts.

fields.headline: Moonfruit comes down to earth
fields.trailText: 4pm: Moonfruit, the website that encouraged users to develop "communities", has put itself up for sale, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
It became a dot.com darling in last year's internet heyday and its chief executive, Wendy Tan, was hyped up as an icon on a par with Lastminute.com's Martha Lane Fox.

But a year on, Moonfruit, the website that encouraged users to develop 'communities', has hit hard times and today put itself up for sale.

Ms Tan denied the move was a result of "bankruptcy", insisting the decision to sell was driven by a desire to preserve the business

"The management team believes the best way to survive is through acquisition into a larger company that is better equipped to come through the current market downturn," said Ms Tan.

"We have chosen the acquisition route as we believe it is the way forward for the product."

Potential buyers will be purchasing something of a shell, given that Moonfruit plans to make 40 of its 45 staff redundant.

However, its core product, which allows users to build and host their own website on Moonfruit.com, has been an arguable success as it notches up more than 38m page impressions a month and hosts around 130,000 user websites.

Moonfruit, which has also been a regular in the Sunday Times e-League, has set itself until the end of May to find a buyer.

webTitle: The election decision: reaction in quotes

fields.headline: The election decision: reaction in quotes
fields.standfirst: Election 2001
fields.trailText:
"Since they cannot possibly know when the crisis will end, in our view it would not be possible to set any new precise date for these elections to be held."
William Hague, Conservative party leader
fields.body:
"Since they cannot possibly know when the crisis will end, in our view it would not be possible to set any new precise date for these elections to be held."
William Hague, Conservative party leader

"The advice he values most strongly is that of his cabinet colleagues - especially those most affected. He spoke to everybody in the cabinet."
Alastair Campbell, the prime minister's official spokesman

"He should have made [the decision] weeks ago."
Margaret Squires, beef farmer from Crediton, Devon

"In the circumstances this is a responsible decision, but it is vital that the prime minister draws a line in the sand for June 7. If we were to be forced beyond that date it would be disastrous for tourism and the economy as a whole."
John Edmonds, general secretary of the General Medical Board

"The prime minister was in a no-win situation and I have a lot of sympathy for the position he was in."
Sir Ken Jackson, general secretary of the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union

"Mr Blair could easily have said the election will go ahead nationally with the exception of Cumbria and Devon, where they could be left until next year."
Devon landowner, Alan Roberton

webTitle: Humiliated Milosevic spends his first night behind bars

fields.headline: Humiliated Milosevic spends his first night behind bars
fields.standfirst:
The arrest in pictures
Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Slobodan Milosevic, the man who did more than any other Balkan leader to plunge the region into a decade of bloodshed and ethnic cleansing, was spending his first night in prison yesterday in a cell with a peephole in the door.
fields.body:
Slobodan Milosevic, the man who did more than any other Balkan leader to plunge the region into a decade of bloodshed and ethnic cleansing, was spending his first night in prison yesterday in a cell with a peephole in the door.

It was a dramatic humiliation for a man who ruled for 13 years, turning Yugoslavia from a pillar of cold war independence into a pariah state with a crony capitalist economy and a huge fall in living standards for all but his friends.

But as people across Serbia applauded the former Yugoslav president's pre-dawn arrest, the battle over his image continued with as much fury and contradiction as it had done when he was at large.

Friends say Mr Milosevic believes there is no evidence to convict him, that he can escape extradition to the war crimes tribunal in the Hague, and that one day he may even make a political comeback.

A different viewpoint was expressed by opponents. Ministers in the government which won last autumn's election have told reporters he was erratic and volatile, perhaps even drunk, during the 36-hour standoff which preceded his surrender.

When a senior police commander first tried to get him to give up shortly after midnight on Saturday, after police made a bungled effort to storm the luxury villa where he was staying, Mr Milosevic brandished a gun with threats to kill himself, his wife and daughter, according to Serbia's interior minister, Dusan Mihailovic.

"I have 25 bullets," witnesses heard Milosevic mutter, according to one report, as he lay on the white living-room sofa cradling his chrome-plated Crvena Zastava pistol. "Twenty are for the assailants - the rest for my family and me."

Yugoslavia's top police chief, Zoran Zivkovic, said: "I thought Milosevic would act irrationally, like he did throughout his rule. I'm happy that this time I was wrong."

Also said to be in the house was the wife of their troublesome son, Marko, who fled to Russia soon after the October 5 uprising, and their grandson.

But despite vowing not to be taken to prison alive, the end came at around 3am on Sunday.

"OK, I'll go," Milosevic was alleged to have said, sparking chaotic scenes. His daughter Marija is said to have grabbed her gun and screamed at three masked police officers to back off as they took her father and hustled him outside to a parked car with tinted windows.

She fired five shots as her father was driven off. There were no injuries.

A very different version of Mr Milosevic's mood was given to the Guardian by the man who took part in the negotiations. Zivorad Igic, the vice-president of Mr Milosevic's Socialist party, said last night: "His conscience is absolutely clear so he was very stable when he said goodbye to his family and the rest of us."

Mr Igic, who watched the former Yugoslav leader's final hours of freedom, said: "There were no tears. He left in his own car and with his own driver. He rang me from prison at about 1pm today. His wife visited him at 3 o'clock. Any member of his family is allowed to visit him every day."

As we spoke, Mr Igic's mobile phone rang and he took a call from Borislav Milosevic, the former president's elder brother who was the Yugoslav ambassador in Moscow and still lives there. He wanted to know how his brother was. "Fine," said Mr Igic.

"He joked to us before he went off. You have a more popular president now because he is in jail, and your party will do better".

Belgrade B-92 radio reported that a small arsenal, including two armoured personnel carriers and a rocket-propelled grenade launcher, had been found in the villa. It said Marija was found with a 9mm Beretta, a 9mm Walther and a "lady's pistol".

Outside Belgrade's central prison yesterday there was no sign of the supporters who had mounted a so-called "People's Guard" at the gates of the villa.

But there was also only a handful of people celebrating. As gleeful as any tricoteuses watching the glint of the falling guillotine, two women of indeterminate age but very determinate tints to their hair, sat by a wall. "It would have been better if he had killed himself. Otherwise he can return. He's like a devil," said Mira Trikic, her sunglasses flashing as she moved. "I voted for him in 1990 but then we saw how he and his friends got richer and we all got poorer."

Inside the prison, Mr Milosevic told the investigative judge he was innocent. His lawyer, Toma Fila, said he was ordered to be detained for 30 days. He said he would appeal, but conceded that he doubted an early release. Questioning was to resume tomorrow.

The Serbian justice minister, Vladan Batic, described his conditions as good. "He has his own room. He will be allowed to wear his own clothes and get books and newspapers. He will not be subjected to any kind of physical harassment or psychological pressure."

I'm happy that this time I was wrong." Also said to be in the house was the wife of their troublesome son, Marko, who fled to Russia soon after the October 5 uprising, and their grandson. But despite vowing not to be taken to prison alive, the end came at around 3am on Sunday. "OK, I'll go," Milosevic was alleged to have said, sparking chaotic scenes. His daughter Marija is said to have grabbed her gun and screamed at three masked police officers to back off as they took her father and hustled him outside to a parked car with tinted windows. She fired five shots as her father was driven off. There were no injuries. A very different version of Mr Milosevic's mood was given to the Guardian by the man who took part in the negotiations. Zivorad Igic, the vice-president of Mr Milosevic's Socialist party, said last night: "His conscience is absolutely clear so he was very stable when he said goodbye to his family and the rest of us." Mr Igic, who watched the former Yugoslav leader's final hours of freedom, said: "There were no tears. He left in his own car and with his own driver. He rang me from prison at about 1pm today. His wife visited him at 3 o'clock. Any member of his family is allowed to visit him every day." As we spoke, Mr Igic's mobile phone rang and he took a call from Borislav Milosevic, the former president's elder brother who was the Yugoslav ambassador in Moscow and still lives there. He wanted to know how his brother was. "Fine," said Mr Igic. "He joked to us before he went off. You have a more popular president now because he is in jail, and your party will do better". Belgrade B-92 radio reported that a small arsenal, including two armoured personnel carriers and a rocket-propelled grenade launcher, had been found in the villa. It said Marija was found with a 9mm Beretta, a 9mm Walther and a "lady's pistol". Outside Belgrade's central prison yesterday there was no sign of the supporters who had mounted a so-called "People's Guard" at the gates of the villa. But there was also only a handful of people celebrating. As gleeful as any tricoteuses watching the glint of the falling guillotine, two women of indeterminate age but very determinate tints to their hair, sat by a wall. "It would have been better if he had killed himself. Otherwise he can return. He's like a devil," said Mira Trikic, her sunglasses flashing as she moved. "I voted for him in 1990 but then we saw how he and his friends got richer and we all got poorer." Inside the prison, Mr Milosevic told the investigative judge he was innocent. His lawyer, Toma Fila, said he was ordered to be detained for 30 days. He said he would appeal, but conceded that he doubted an early release. Questioning was to resume tomorrow. The Serbian justice minister, Vladan Batic, described his conditions as good. "He has his own room. He will be allowed to wear his own clothes and get books and newspapers. He will not be subjected to any kind of physical harassment or psychological pressure."

webTitle: Milosevic in the dock: accused of theft and power abuse

fields.headline: Belgrade takes first steps to justice
fields.standfirst:
Serbia's fallen leader stands accused of theft and abuse of power

The story in pictures
fields.trailText: For at least the next 30 days Yugoslavia's former president Slobodan Milosevic will bide his time in Belgrade's central prison, listening to a slow trickle of accusations of venality and brutality during his 13 years in power.
fields.body:
For at least the next 30 days Yugoslavia's former president Slobodan Milosevic will bide his time in Belgrade's central prison, listening to a slow trickle of accusations of venality and brutality during his 13 years in power.

Mr Milosevic, who can be held for up to six months at the discretion of the investigating magistrates, and several key cronies face charges of abuse of power, embezzlement and siphoning off government assets and budget funds into the special accounts of favoured companies.

All the alleged transgressions, prosecutors say, were aimed at keeping him and his socialist party in power.

The Serbian police have released details of the charges against Mr Milosevic, confirming the Guardian's report on Thursday that the Yugoslav customs service was used by his regime to salt away hundreds of millions of pounds.

Mihalj Kertes, the regime's customs chief, Nikola Sainovic, the former deputy prime minister, and Dusan Matkovic, a key Milosevic crony, are all implicated as conspirators in the alleged financial and embezzlement scams.

Vladan Batic, the Serbian justice minister, said yesterday that parliament would have to agree to lift the immunity from prosecution which protects its MPs, as some of those accused with Mr Milosevic sit in parliament and can operate with impunity.

Further charges against Mr Milosevic are expected, including the graver accusations of ordering political violence against his opponents and war crimes against his own people.

For the moment, however, he could face a jail term of up to 15 years for corruption and abuse of office, the first offences to be laid at his door.

The charge sheet reveals that Mr Milosevic and his fellow conspirators allegedly embezzled $400m (£282m) in state funds.

"It has been established that Milosevic, as president of Serbia and later Yugoslavia, committed a criminal deed of abuse of power with the aims of profiting financially and staying in power," Miodrag Vukovic, a senior detective, said.

The indictment is not final: it is the product of the initial police investigation and has to be validated by the investigating magistrate, who will decide whether the prosecution should proceed.

The prosecutors allege that Mr Milosevic deliberately oversaw the near destruction of the Serbian monetary system, intentionally promoting hyper-inflation and black market dealing in currency for political and private profit.

In a scam that dates back to 1994, the indictment alleges, Mr Milosevic instructed Mr Kertes, the customs boss and a former secret police chief, to divert customs receipts to special accounts set up at Serbia's biggest bank, Beogradska Banka, which Mr Milosevic headed in the early 80s before his political career took off.

The money was to go to certain state companies, state organisations and individuals decided by Mr Milosevic and his cohorts.

Mr Kertes has been questioned by Serbian detectives and is said to be frightened, and perhaps mentally unstable. He is also said to be providing information on Mr Milosevic and deeply implicated in alleged assassination plots against Mr Milosevic's foes.

Mr Sainovic, the former deputy prime minister who controlled Serbia's precious metals trade, has also been indicted by the Hague tribunal for war crimes in Kosovo. He has been questioned by Serbian police, but has claimed parliamentary immunity.

Mr Matkovic was one of the key members of Mr Milosevic's socialist party and ran the big steel works at Smederovo, outside Belgrade. Both he and Mr Sainovic are said by regime insiders and diplomats to have private bank accounts in Lebanon.

The indictment also alleges that Mr Sainovic was given a further £80,000 in customs revenue later in 1996. "All the money was paid in the office of Mihalj Kertes on the orders of Slobodan Milosevic."

Although Mr Milosevic and Mr Sainovic have been indicted by the Hague tribunal, they are unlikely to be sent there soon. While western authorities such as the tribunal, Washington and the EU called again yesterday for the former president's transfer to the Hague, it is thought that the pressure on Belgrade to act against him and his cronies will now recede.

The US ultimatum which prompted the weekend drama insisted on Belgrade's cooperation with the Hague, but the Serb authorities were also told that the key condition was to arrest Mr Milosevic and put him in prison - any prison.

Officials in the Hague, however, were more bullish about his extradition in the hours after his arrest. "We are expecting him soon," their spokeswoman, Florence Hartmann, said. "It will be Milosevic in the Hague in 2001."

Senior government figures in Belgrade say that Mr Milosevic could eventually go to the Hague to be tried, but first he has to be called to account at home, a saga which could run for months, if not years.

fields.headline: BBC clears Dyke's £1m theatre investment
fields.trailText:
2.30pm: The BBC will not refer Greg Dyke's shareholding in Ambassador Theatre Group to the governors, writes Jessica Hodgson.
Mar 15: BBC governors under fire
Special report: the BBC
fields.body:
The BBC said today it would not refer Greg Dyke's controversial £1m shareholding in Ambassador Theatre Group to the board of governors.

A spokeswoman said reports that ATG had "a programme-making alliance" with ITV company Carlton were inaccurate.

"It does not make programmes at all," she said. "Nor will it under this new deal with Carlton."

She said the investment would be referred to the board of governors should there be any potential for a conflict of interest.

However, as there was no conflict "at this stage", it would not be referred.

Nevertheless, corporation insiders say the fact Mr Dyke has invested in ATG shows he may not have learned a lesson from the controversy surrounding his considerable investments last year.

Carlton last week concluded a rights deal with ATG, which also has a joint venture with Natural Nylon, the production company owned by Jude Law, Sadie Frost and Ewan McGregor.

Two of the first three plays to be produced by Natural Nylon are classics - Dr Faustus and Christopher Hampton's translation of Chekhov's Three Sisters. The third will be an adaptation of John Fowles's novel the Collector.

The Carlton deal will give the two companies access to the rights to each other's programmes.

The BBC spokeswoman said the deal was valuable to Carlton because it will enable it to use its extensive programming archive to develop stage plays.

In a press statement, the BBC underlined the fact Mr Dyke made the board of governors aware of the investment when it was made last year, "as is required".

There was no conflict of interest then, and there isn't know, a spokeswoman said.

The statement continued: "Mr Dyke plays no active role in ATG. He is not a director and has not attended any company meetings. He is a passive investor."

Rupert Gavin, chief executive of BBC Worldwide, also has shares - worth about £50,000 - in the company.

The BBC spokeswoman said Mr Gavin's investment was no secret and had been declared in the BBC's register of personal interests.

Mr Dyke was forced to sell £6m-worth of shares last year after it emerged he held a stake in Granada TV.

He became a millionaire while he was the head of LWT, which was subsequently taken over by Granada.

He also came under fire when it was revealed he had £275,000-worth of shares in Pearson Television after he was appointed director-general of the BBC.

Mr Dyke sold the shares after facing public opprobium.

fields.headline: Sun election scoop enrages rivals
fields.standfirst: Click here to read the Sun's triumphant leader
fields.trailText:
11.30am: The Sun was basking in glory today after Tony Blair confirmed 'wot the paper already knew, accouncing a May 3 election was off, writes Jessica Hodgson.
The Sun's triumphant leader
fields.body:
The Sun was basking in glory today after Tony Blair confirmed "wot the paper already knew", announcing the general election was off for May 3.

The prime minister said the national interest was best served by the postponement of the election, which is now likely to take place on June 7.

It signals what will be start of a 10-week election battle - one of the longest in history.

Today the Sun's political editor Trevor Kavanagh rebuffed suggestions the paper was given a special briefing before it revealed on Saturday morning that the May general election was off.

But he has refused to deny the story came from either Tony Blair's press secretary Alastair Campbell or his personal assistant Anji Hunter.

He told MediaGuardian.co.uk: "Nobody knows how I got the story. That is a matter for me and the person I spoke to."

But he added: "I'm not denying I had a conversation with anyone in order for people to narrow it down."

The remarks follow claims from rival newspapers that Mr Kavanagh was given special treatment by Tony Blair's inner circle and media relations team because the Sun is considered pivotal to Labour's general election strategy.

"This is no way to run a democracy," said one furious newspaper executive.

"It is outrageous the Sun should know what date the election is going to be held before the rest of the cabinet is briefed.

"Even if the cabinet had been briefed, it was clear it was not briefed about Alastair Campbell's media strategy - to give an exclusive to the Sun."

Mr Kavanagh's story caught several newspapers and members of Mr Blair's cabinet on the hop.

On Saturday morning, culture secretary Chris Smith was left looking foolish when he went on the BBC's Today programme and failed to indicate he knew the election had been delayed.

He remained "on message" and spoke of the need to avoid delay, suggesting he was not informed of the Sun's front-page splash declaring "Election off".

And journalists on the Observer were furious not to have been briefed on the story, having printed an 80-page election booklet.

The Daily Mail today claimed Mr Blair's office gave the Sun and the Times briefings ahead of the rest of the newspapers.

The Sun today made it plain it believed it got the scoop simply because it is the paper that matters.

Mr Kavanagh said: "I think the story was there for anyone who wanted to find it."

But many commentators said Labour had to give the paper the exclusive story because it had "led it up the garden path" a week earlier by providing it with another splash declaring May 3 was the election date.

Labour believes the paper to be absolutely crucial in securing the support of swing voters.

Three weeks ago, the party was relieved by the Sun's public backing of Mr Blair for a second term in government.

Today the paper crows about its exclusive in its leader column.

It revels in the fact the BBC's Frost programme on Sunday morning "revealed" to viewers the election had been postponed.

In a triumphant leader, the Sun says it was obvious BBC political editor Andrew Marr had nipped down to the newsagent to pick up a copy of the Sun to learn the news.

"Once again, this paper has infuriated the political establishment by leading the way," it says.
