webTitle: John Patterson's weekly look at new US movies

fields.headline: Catch me a spy
fields.standfirst: Pierce Brosnan is deliciously evil; Antonio Banderas is magically silly. John Patterson takes his weekly look at the new US movies
fields.trailText: Pierce Brosnan is deliciously evil; Antonio Banderas is magically silly. John Patterson takes his weekly look at the new US movies.
fields.body:
I'll get spat on in the street for saying it but, after Sean Connery, Pierce Brosnan is far and away my favourite 007. The rest of them are so far behind these two that they are all but invisible (weirdly though, these days my top Bond movie is George Lazenby's On Her Majesty's Secret Service - the one with the saucy Simon Raven dialogue). Brosnan spent much of his early career circling around the Bond persona in pseudo-superspy fluff such as Remington Steele, as if in long-term training for his Licence To Kill. When Roger Moore retired, the Irishman - who knows it takes a Celt to give 007 his feral edge - pressed his own case strongly and publicly, and was vocally unhappy when Cubby Broccoli chose instead to take the fateful Timothy Dalton detour.

After the franchisers wised up and offloaded Dalton, Brosnan made 007 his first priority. Not for him Roger Moore's biennial working vacations from his Swiss eyrie, or the gnawing sense that the stage-based Dalton was slumming in the role. Brosnan came aboard knowing he could revitalise the series, and seems to have done just that. Now that his stint is drawing to a close, he's laying down the basis for an interesting post-Bond career. Much as he shadow-boxed around Bond before he actually was Bond, now he's taking the 007 persona apart piece by piece in his non-007 projects.

Last year he took a character with all Bond's primary characteristics - Thomas Crown - and infused him with sexual neuroses, identity crises and a deeply ambiguous personal morality. The result wasn't exactly a work of genius, but Brosnan was the producer and clearly he wasn't interested in staying within Bond's chalk outline of a character.

Now, in John Boorman's clever, cheeky thriller The Tailor of Panama, Brosnan plays the evil, amoral spy Andy Osman, and he is having the time of his life. Tailor, based on John Le Carré's novel (which in turn bears a slightly unhealthy resemblance to Graham Greene's Our Man In Havana, but no matter), knowingly tweaks the Bond/Brosnan connection. One of the first things we see is a picture of Connery on the schmutter-cutter's wall.

"He's a valued customer," says Geoffrey Rush. "With a golfer's build!" Then Connery's successor appears and the only thing he shakes or stirs up is shit, taking Rush's life apart the same way Peter Cook roasted, stuffed and ate Dudley Moore in Bedazzled.

Bond's amiable "sexist dinosaur" is here a man who blurts out, "Look at those fuckin' tits!" and whose irrepressible sex-drive makes him more rapist than bedroom trampolinist. Brosnan presence is the movie's subversive little masterstroke, and we can forget those sneaking suspicions we may once have had about his thespian limitations. He's nasty!

The shadow of 007 also fell, albeit a little less heavily, across the weekend's other interesting release, the bouncy children's comedy-thriller Spy Kids. It's directed by, of all people, Robert Rodriguez of El Mariachi fame, and it feels a little like a Tim Burton Bond movie - which, come to think of it, might be a fantastic idea. In Rodriguez's hands this story of two kids rescuing their superspy parents (Antonio Banderas and Carla Gugino) from a host of evil supervillains has a magical silliness that keeps one eye on the adults who bought the tickets. The Spy Kids' suburban house throbs with secret-agent devices ranging from micro-cameras to explosive bubble-gum, and the villains' HQ is like something Ken Adam might have come up with after being locked in a cell with 10 tabs of acid and the collected works of Dr Seuss and R Crumb.

That leaves us with the weekend's waste by-products, Someone Like You, a fraudulent, emotionally coercive romantic comedy starring Ashley Judd and Hugh Jackman (X-Men's Wolverine), and Tomcats, yet another Farrellyesque gross-out comedy. The latter manages to be offensive and grimly unfunny at the same time, unless your idea of great comedy is a man chasing a recently removed cancerous testicle around a hospital floor. Somewhere in heaven Buster Keaton is puking into his cupped hands.

fields.headline: Media Business
fields.standfirst: Publication date: April 2
fields.trailText: April 2: Phase 2 Media closed its UK office last Friday after 12 weeks of trading.
fields.body:
Phase 2 Media closed its UK office last Friday after 12 weeks of trading.

New figures from ACNielden MMS look set to silence the doom merchants who claim the media industry is already slumping into recession.

webTitle: West insists on trial at Hague for Milosevic

fields.headline: West insists on trial at Hague
fields.standfirst:
Fear that road to justice will end at Belgrade jail

The story in pictures
Special report: Serbia
Special report: war crimes in the former Yugoslavia
fields.trailText: The US, European Union and Britain yesterday hailed the arrest of Slobodan Milosevic, but insisted that he must answer for his war crimes at the UN tribunal in the Hague.
fields.byline: Ian Black  in Brussels and  Richard Norton-Taylor in London
fields.body:
The US, European Union and Britain yesterday hailed the arrest of Slobodan Milosevic, but insisted that he must answer for his war crimes at the UN tribunal in the Hague.

Amid relief in the Balkans and anger in Russia, there was western concern that the detention of the ex-president in Belgrade might be the end rather than the beginning of the long search for justice.

President George Bush said the detention was an important step toward ending "the tragic era of brutal dictatorship and a first move toward trying Mr Milosevic for crimes against humanity. "We cannot and must not forget the chilling images of terrified women and children herded on to trains, emaciated prisoners interned behind barbed wire and mass graves unearthed by UN investigators," he said.

Britain's foreign secretary, Robin Cook, described the arrest as "another important step towards bringing Milosevic and his cronies to book".

Mr Milosevic could stand trial on domestic charges in Belgrade first, he suggested, but added: "We want to see him in the Hague so justice can be done, but also because it is important for reconciliation in the Balkans."

The US-based Human Rights Watch organisation insisted it was not enough for Serbia to try him on corruption charges after his indictment by the Hague for the slaughter of thousands of ethnic Albanians in Kosovo. Amnesty International echoed this call.

In France, President Jacques Chirac said: "Justice must be done." But his foreign minister, Hubert Védrine, warned Colin Powell, the US secretary of state, last week that there was a danger of destabilising Yugoslavia's fragile new democracy if Belgrade was subjected to outside pressure.

Goran Persson, the prime minister of Sweden, the current holder of the EU presidency, appeared to reflect this concern, saying that Brussels would refrain from direct pressure on Belgrade. "It would not be right to expose starving and freezing people to risk by refusing aid," he said. Mr Milosevic's arrest followed threats by the US to suspend aid if the new government did not show willingness by Saturday's deadline to cooperate with the UN tribunal.

In Brussels, Javier Solana, the EU's foreign policy chief; Romano Prodi, the president of the European Commission, and Chris Patten, the external relations commissioner, all hailed the arrest. But in Moscow, Dmitri Rogozin, chairman of the duma's international affairs committee, said it would be a serious mistake for Yugoslavia to surrender Mr Milosevic to the Hague.

A surrender would "justify Nato's aggression against Yugoslavia," he warned.

Carl Bildt, the UN's special envoy to the Balkans, argued that extradition was unlikely in the immediate future, even if the chances had increased.

"I do not think this is the issue of the day," Mr Bildt told Swedish radio. "The issue now is that Serbian justice and Serbian democracy will take in hand a person who destroyed so much of his own country."

Across the Balkans, news of the arrest was greeted with relief and some cynicism. "I don't believe he was arrested. They've just put him somewhere safe so as not to send him to the Hague," Jahir Rexhepi, 43, said in the Kosovan capital, Pristina.

Political figures in Croatia, Slovenia and Bosnia, whose struggles from 1991 to 1995 for independence from Serb-dominated Yugoslavia left more than 200,000 dead, repeated that Mr Milosevic must face international justice.

"Going to a Belgrade jail, Milosevic has embarked on a journey of no return which must end in front of the judges of the Hague. I am certain Belgrade authorities are aware of that," Croatia's president, Stipe Mesic, said.

Slovenia's president, Milan Kucan, said the arrest was an important break with the expansionist nationalism that was the hallmark of Serb policy throughout the 1990s. "I believe the new democratic political and legal authorities in Serbia will manage to design politics that will be a clear alternative to the concept of greater Serbia pursued ruthlessly by the Milosevic regime."

fields.headline: Camelot reviews below-the-line marketing
fields.trailText: 8.30pm: Camelot is reviewing its multimillion-pound below-the-line arrangements, reports Julia Day.
fields.body:
Camelot is reviewing its multimillion-pound below-the-line marketing arrangements as part of a reappraisal of the brand.

The account is held by the direct marketing agency Hicklin Slade & Partners, which was hired last year to create in-store merchandising material for the National Lottery online game and National Lottery Instants.

The account was previously held by Saatchi & Saatchi.

A Camelot spokeswoman confirmed the review was taking place but refused to divulge which agencies had been asked to pitch for the below-the-line account.

She said the lottery operator was not conducting a review of its main £30m advertising account, which is held by WCRS.

Camelot will increase its annual marketing spend from £58m to about £75m as it goes into the second licence period.

fields.headline: Microsoft to sponsor 2002 Commonwealth Games
fields.trailText:
2.45pm: Micrsosoft has signed up as headline sponsor for the Manchester 2002 Commonwealth Games, writes Julia Day.
Official games site: commonwealthgames.com
fields.body:
Micrsosoft has signed up as headline sponsor for the Manchester 2002 Commonwealth Games.

The deal was announced today by Commonwealth and Olympic gold medallist Denise Lewis.

Microsoft has signed as the exclusive software sponsor of the Commonwealth Games XVII, being held in Manchester from July 25 to August 4 next year.

The company will use Microsoft software to run all the games' computer applications including results, accreditation and content management.

It will also provide a range of services for the games, including internet and mobile phone results services. It will also link with third party companies to deliver services.

"Sponsoring this event allows us to showcase many of our newest technologies and also support a world-class sporting event," says Shaun Orpen, director of corporate marketing at Microsoft.

Other official sponsors already signed are Manchester Airport, Atlantic, Adecco and Guardian Media Group.

United Utilities and Addleshaw Booth & Co have signed as official partners, a lower-level sponsorship.

webTitle: Helping sufferers of a little-known genetic disorder

fields.headline: Helping sufferers of a little-known genetic disorder
fields.trailText: Mention the illness tuberous sclerosis (TSC) and most people won't know what you are talking about. Some might confuse it with tuberculosis or multiple sclerosis, but hardly anyone is aware of this harrowing genetic disorder.
fields.body:
Mention the illness tuberous sclerosis (TSC) and most people won't know what you are talking about. Some might confuse it with tuberculosis or multiple sclerosis, but hardly anyone is aware of this harrowing genetic disorder.

It may have a low public profile but TSC can wreck people's lives and lead to premature deaths. The Tuberous Sclerosis Association (TSA) was established in 1977 to raise the profile of this disease, to fund research and to offer practical support to sufferers and their families.

TSC gets its name from the tumours that grow and harden anywhere in the body. These tumours can cause chronic physical, behavioural-learning and neurological problems. Epilepsy, brain tumours, autism, kidney and lung problems, heart tumours, hyperactivity and facial rashes are just some of the problems sufferers have to face. Nothing can stop these tumours from developing. However, early diagnosis and monitoring can help to minimise the effects of the disease.

The disease affects one in 6,000 people. There are around 8,500 cases in the UK and more than a million worldwide. Although it is a genetic disorder, 70% of cases are born to families with no medical history of TSC. Indeed, many parents do not know they carry the disease until it is too late. Even with only mild symptoms there is a 50% chance of passing TSC on to your children.

This may make grim reading. But there is now hope. In 1993 and 1997 there were medical breakthroughs. Research - backed by the TSA - identified the faulty genes that trigger the disease. The next step for researchers is to use this knowledge to create effective treatment and prevention for TSC. One particular project - the TSC 2000 cohort study - will follow 250 affected children over 10 years. This will help develop treatments tailored for each child's disorders.

The TSA has earmarked £450,000 to fund this and other research. In the meantime it gets on with the more practical aspect of its work: offering care and support to sufferers.

It does this in several ways:

 Running a helpline that gives sufferers and their families invaluable information and support about TSC.
 Employing a family care officer who helps sort out practical problems with education, social services and health care.
 Administering a benevolent fund. This gives financial support for specialised toys and equipment. It also helps with travelling expenses so sufferers can visit specialist clinics.
 Running activity weekends for younger sufferers. This gives them the chance to make friends and relax with others who can understand what they are going through.

Since special needs TSC children can often dominate a family's attention, their brothers and sisters can become the "forgotten" family members. The TSA has recently established a sibling support group. This gives brothers and sisters of TSC sufferers the opportunity to share their concerns and feelings with each other.

The TSA also runs parent training days. At these events up to 150 parents and carers learn from leading health professionals about the latest developments in medical, behavioural and psychological care for people with TSC.

There is still a considerable number of medical professionals who are unaware of TSC's various symptoms. Educating health workers about TSC to ensure the disease is diagnosed at the earliest possible opportunity is a key objective of the charity. This month the TSA is launching a CD rom - Understanding Tuberous Sclerosis - that is specifically produced for doctors.

The TSA remains small. It relies on a network of volunteers and a small core staff team of six. Yet with TSC continuing to wreck havoc on people's lives, more than 1,500 families in the UK now rely on its services. It is running an appeal to raise an additional £5m. Once this has been achieved, the plight of TSC sufferers and their families will become just a little bit easier.

fields.headline: Election postponed
fields.standfirst: The prime minister Tony Blair today announced the postponement of local elections in England and Wales. What does this mean for voters, and for the date of the general election? Matthew Tempest explains
fields.trailText: The prime minister Tony Blair today announced the postponement of local elections in England and Wales. What does this mean for voters, and for the date of the general election? Matthew Tempest explains.
fields.body:
Why are the local elections being delayed?
Because the prime minister says so. After visiting farmers affected by the foot and mouth epidemic all last week, Mr Blair took the decision late on Friday to put off the local elections - and with them, the general election.

It would be politically impossible to justify a general election campaign in areas where the local polls have been postponed.

However, the decision was not made easier by the fact that tourism bosses were warning Mr Blair that the industry was losing up to £200m a week in cancelled bookings, Labour's Millbank machine had geared up for a May 3 date and the Sun had already declared the date on its front page. As recently as Friday the leader of the house, Margaret Beckett, was telling parliament that any delay in the local elections would send out the message that "Britain was closed for business".

This is the first delay to local elections since the second world war.

Where are these local elections?
There are county council elections in 34 areas, including the worst hit foot and mouth areas of Labour-held Cumbria and Liberal Democrat-held Devon. These councils - which have major spending powers - are elected all in one go, and there are 2,203 seats up for grabs. At present, the Tories control 11, Labour eight, Liberal Democrats two and there is no overall control in 13.

There are also 11 unitary councils holding elections, all (except in two cases) electing a third of their seats. Of the 11, seven are Labour-controlled, one Conservative and three where there is no overall control.

Voters in these areas will be able to vote on the new date as usual.

Traditionally, it is seen as an advantage to hold the general election on the same day as the local elections, as it boosts turnout, and Labour will be hoping to firm up its high 1997 local vote with the substantial push that a general election gives to a campaign.

Why does Mr Blair not just announce now when the general election will be and get it over with?
As soon as a date is set for polling in a general election, auditors start counting all election expenses. Under new rules from the electoral commission, the parties are capped at a limit of just under £15m each, although this will rise slightly due to the postponement of a general election.

In addition, ministers and MPs have strict curtailments of their roles imposed during an election campaign. Although ministers continue in their jobs, they cannot take decisions on matters arising beyond the election date, and MPs face restrictions on the use of their Commons offices.

Virtually everybody assumes the local election dates are being used by Downing Street as a code for the general election, and Mr Blair has stated categorically they will be on June 7 - this is not an "indefinite postponement", he said.

So when will a general election be called?
The last and most likely date for the dissolution of parliament and the start of the election campaign proper is May 14 - although for most people it will feel like a rolling election campaign from here on in.

What does this mean for the census?
The nationwide census is going ahead as planned on April 29. Volunteers who deliver census forms have been told not to cross foot and mouth warning signs, whether they be official warnings from the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food, or placards posted by local farmers or land owners.

Instead, census forms will be left at a central collection point in affected villages for personal collection, or sent out by post.

The office for national statistics, which organises the census every decade, says it is not worried by the logistics of getting around the foot and mouth epidemic. It is important to update the census every ten years at the same time, as all Treasury projections of future spending are based on the information gleaned from census data.

webTitle: With apologies to the sheep, it should have been May

fields.headline: With apologies to the sheep, it should have been May
fields.trailText: From beneath his familiar black fedora Kenneth Clarke ventured a cheerful mid-week prediction about the date of the general election. "It's decision time for Tony Blair, isn't it? And he's not very good at taking decisions."
fields.body:
From beneath his familiar black fedora Kenneth Clarke ventured a cheerful mid-week prediction about the date of the general election. "It's decision time for Tony Blair, isn't it? And he's not very good at taking decisions."

So would the election be on May 3 or June 7? "He'd be mad to postpone it," said Clarke without a moment's hesitation. I thought that too. So did the Labour MP who excitedly reported that he'd just seen General Sir Mike Jackson on TV - in camouflage and red beret - taking on all those unarmed cattle.

"That means it must be May 3," the MP explained. Until they read Saturday morning's Sun - New Labour's equivalent of the Official Gazette - most cabinet ministers thought so too, though those with long memories will remember that 10 days earlier the Sun had said with equally self-important certainty that it would not be June. The editor had virtually been to the Palace to tell the Queen. Equally unembarrassable, ministers have also been coming round fast since learning that the prime minister had changed his mind at the end of a week of intermittent wobbling. The party machine at Millbank - and in the constituencies - will be less easily placated.

This was not an aircraft taxiing down the runway, only to be called back by air traffic control. The election plane was airborne somewhere over the Irish Sea when the drinks were spilled in first class and the peanuts scattered in economy on Friday night. The result: an emergency landing, burned rubber, money leaking like fuel, adrenalin gone to waste. And for what, activists and officials will be asking each other today when postponement of the county council elections obliquely confirms the larger delay.

To appease the farmers who don't like Labour anyway ? To impress the Countryside Alliance and the editor of the Daily Telegraph, who don't vote for Blair either? To please the bishops whom Mrs Thatcher spent 11 largely-successful years taking no notice of whatsoever?

I must admit I had a wobble myself long before Downing Street appeared to cotton on to just how grim things were in much of the countryside. It would obviously be logistically possible to stage the elections. Telephone canvassing, postal votes, Millbank had all the answers. But would it be appropriate amid so much rural distress? Or a bit like going to a party straight after granny's funeral?

It did not take much to unwobble me. As the scale of the traffic in infected animals emerged from the agri-economy and the logistics of slaughter/burial/vaccination loomed ever larger, it became obvious that Britain will not be out of this crisis in a hurry. Certainly not by June 7, this year or next.

To make matters worse it was, pre-Milosevic, a slow news month. As the story was spread around the world by our efficient (and hysterical) media, the growing damage to tourism - a far more important industry by any test - could only be compounded by delay. Americans already think our feet and hands are dropping off.

So, delay will benefit no one and may add to the financial burdens in already hard-pressed regions. With lanes closed and hungry sheep on the Ridgeway, prosperous west Berkshire looked disease-free but quietly miserable yesterday. Cumbria - and it is mainly Cumbria - must be awful. But not many of us live or work there. Life goes on, except in Whitehall where the decision-making process, never hyperactive, remains grid-locked until the election is won or lost.

There is also the question of will. If Mr Blair is seen in four weeks' time to have got on top of the crisis and earned well-deserved plaudits after an admittedly slow start, he may well claim to have "put country before party" and re-earned his laurels as a One Nation leader. A handsome second term majority will be his just reward. That is what cabinet loyalists say. "Tony's great strength is his One Nation instinct," says one of the pro-June 7 minority. "The decision will undermine the claims that Labour is anti-countryside. It will also make it awkward for William Hague to conduct an election campaign over the next 10 weeks after what he's said."

That is the sort of upbeat spin I expect Alastair Campbell to put on events when he feeds the vultures at this morning's 11 o'clock briefing in the basement of No 10, albeit, I suspect, with more enthusiasm than he privately feels. Yet the same result could have been achieved by Blair devoting the first half of the campaign - until after Easter - to the rural crisis, leaving the vulgar electioneering to Gordon Brown. As things stand, Blair-bashers, Ken Clarke for instance, will crow that the prime minister has again been pushed off course by his own lack of inner certainty and belief, or by his desire to be liked. Quite. Yet the chancellor's March 7 budget quietly paid £1.9bn worth of Danegeld to the road protest lobby, despite the No Surrender rhetoric. fields.trailText:
"Since they cannot possibly know when the crisis will end, in our view it would not be possible to set any new precise date for these elections to be held."
William Hague, Conservative party leader

"Since they cannot possibly know when the crisis will end, in our view it would not be possible to set any new precise date for these elections to be held."
William Hague, Conservative party leader

"The advice he values most strongly is that of his cabinet colleagues - especially those most affected. He spoke to everybody in the cabinet."
Alastair Campbell, the prime minister's official spokesman

"He should have made [the decision] weeks ago."
Margaret Squires, beef farmer from Crediton, Devon

"In the circumstances this is a responsible decision, but it is vital that the prime minister draws a line in the sand for June 7. If we were to be forced beyond that date it would be disastrous for tourism and the economy as a whole."
John Edmonds, general secretary of the General Medical Board

"The prime minister was in a no-win situation and I have a lot of sympathy for the position he was in."
Sir Ken Jackson, general secretary of the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union

"Mr Blair could easily have said the election will go ahead nationally with the exception of Cumbria and Devon, where they could be left until next year."
Devon landowner, Alan Roberton

webTitle: How protests, polls and political instinct convinced Blair to move election day

fields.headline: How protests, polls and political instinct convinced Blair to move election day
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is not a man to make a decision before he feels politically compelled to, but in the case of the May 3 election he must have felt like a man prematurely committed. For weeks he and his aides had insisted any delay in the council elections would send a desperate message to overseas visitors and cripple the British tourist industry.
fields.body:
Tony Blair is not a man to make a decision before he feels politically compelled to, but in the case of the May 3 election he must have felt like a man prematurely committed. For weeks he and his aides had insisted any delay in the council elections would send a desperate message to overseas visitors and cripple the British tourist industry.

The Sun, on the personal advice of Alastair Campbell, Mr Blair's press secretary, had reported that May 3 was the official election date - news that was a present from Downing Street to the paper for its backing of Labour. The Sun in turn praised Mr Blair for sticking to his guns.

Yet privately there had always been more doubts that the foot and mouth epidemic might destroy the planning. By Thursday Mr Blair, Mr Campbell and the inner circle had come to believe delay was unavoidable.

The final decision appears to have been made by Mr Blair on Friday, when the news started to seep through the higher echelons of the party. The prime minister's decision was resolved after meetings with farmers in Dumfries and Galloway. Cabinet members were not individually told until Saturday, by phone by Mr Blair.

Straining at the leash

Many of the big figures in the cabinet and at the party's headquarters at Millbank had favoured May, but with one or two exceptions everyone accepted the final judgment on date to be finely balanced. The only proviso was that if Mr Blair plumped for June there could be no further slippage - he would not only look weak but be prey to rightwing interests.

One ministerial source said: "It would be wrong to characterise this as a united cabinet defied by the prime minister. We all have the same political instincts and are subject to the same pressures as [Mr Blair]. A lot of people were shifting last week to June and ultimately everyone accepted that anyway this was a decision for the prime minister."

The first indications of a serious wobble came on Thursday when Mr Blair met the chancellor Gordon Brown - who is also the party election coordinator - after some gruelling meetings with the National Farmers' Union. He also had a meeting with his inner circle, which included Pat MacFadden, Anji Hunter, Mr Campbell and his pollster Philip Gould.

Mr Brown, like John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, had favoured May. Close to the Millbank machine, Mr Prescott and Mr Brown were straining at the leash.

But Mr Blair felt that the Ministry of Agriculture figures were showing no clear sign that the foot and mouth epidemic could be credibly described as under control. New cases were running at 40 a day, requiring the culling not just of these animals but those on neighbouring farms. The logistical exercise was massive.

In Cumbria the proposed 24 hours target from detection of the virus to slaughter was nowhere near being met and the number of animals to be buried was rising. Protests were rising over plans to open up new burial sites. And the farmers' union could not be persuaded to vaccinate dairy cattle in Cumbria.

Mr Blair feared he could not credibly promise to make foot and mouth his top priority, then call an election. In conversation with cabinet ministers he set out the case for delay, including his belief that he did not want to win the election on the basis of a split in the country and bitter arguments over the campaign's timing.

One cabinet source said Mr Blair seemed to see himself not just as a one nation leader but almost as father to the nation.

Mr Blair was strongly supported at that time by some of his closest Downing Street confidantes, including the Cabinet Office minister Lord Falconer, his personal assistant Ms Hunter, and Mr Gould.

According to Mr Gould, 25 seats were likely to be lost due to public anger if the poll occurred in May; he felt strengthened by his own private poll for the party last weekend and the Mori poll in the Times showing a rock solid 18-19 point lead that was unlikely to evaporate. A Telegraph poll at the weekend confirmed the view at Downing Street that the public opposed an early poll. The Gallup poll showed 13% thought that in a May poll they would be less likely to vote Labour.

Throughout, Blair was canvassing opinion. Supposedly in exile, Peter Mandelson, the former Northern Ireland secretary, had persistently advised Mr Blair of the necessity of delay to make a credible one nation appeal. However some cabinet members, including Alan Milburn, the health secretary, also favoured June, warning that the first two weeks of the election would be about foot and mouth rather than Labour's agenda of jobs, public services and the Tory threat.

Knife-edge decision

Mr Milburn was sure that delay from May did not raise the threat of being knocked off course in June. David Blunkett, the education secretary, favoured May but told Blair it was a knife-edge decision. Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, wanted May but by the end of the week had swung to June. Jack Straw, the home secretary, was for May but in the past few days realised the virtue of delay. He did not see a practical case against May - such as rural areas being unable to vote - but accepted the case for sensitivity.

The strongest opposition came from Mr Prescott and Mr Brown, the two most closely associated with the Millbank campaign machine. Mr Prescott's people on Wednesday claimed no one favoured June. But neither of these men fought Mr Blair to the death over it.

On Thursday Mr Brown met his closest electoral advisers in a private room at a Soho restaurant - some present, including advisers linked to US Democrats, warned that the first two weeks would be dominated by the foot and mouth outbreak. Those who wanted to press ahead pointed out that only the rightwing press, the farmers and the Tories championed delay. Less than 1% of farms had suffered an outbreak of the disease. One cabinet member even blamed the BBC, saying it was "run by youngsters running a vegetarian agenda; the coverage ... totally out of proportion".

The party general secretary, Margaret McDonagh, advised that Labour had set aside millions for poster spending in April linked to good economic news, and these billboards could not be cancelled. Equally the party and unions had published a lot of election literature. The GMB union had printed 500,000 leaflets - but little, or none of it, said "Vote Labour on May 3".

The prime minister knows his decision is not one by which he is likely to benefit partywise. Whatever the result on June 7 there will be voices claiming that if he had gone earlier he would saved more seats.

Doubtless by now he will be seeing the great virtue of fixed term parliaments.

fields.headline: Cumbrian leader: 'Blair was right'
fields.trailText: Cumbria council leader Stewart Young applauds the prime minister's 'brave' decision to delay the local elections.
fields.body:
Stewart Young, leader of Cumbria council:

"I've consistently said the local elections should be on May 3, but I changed my position on Friday. In my view, Mr Blair was right to delay. There was this strategy of having a firebreak in north Cumbria to contain foot and mouth disease, and what changed my mind was the number of instances of foot and mouth beyond the firebreak. It undermined the strategy.

We were consulted by Downing Street on Saturday, and by that time I came round to my current position - we haven't made progress on tackling the disease as quickly as we would have hoped.

The government officials just asked me what the feeling was on the ground, and I said at this point in time, with the election campaign about to start, and assessing the position as it was then, I'd have been in favour of a deferral.

I don't think the prime minister made up his mind until yesterday, and it was a very finely balanced judgment. The disease takes away the concentration of the politicians involved in fighting the spread of foot and mouth. That's the first issue.

The second is that election campaigns are fought in the media. If the media aren't reporting on things like your record on education because foot and mouth is on all the front pages, it's a complete waste of time.

The month's delay is long enough. We're beginning to get on top of the disease. The time between a foot and mouth diagnosis and a kill is coming down all the time. We're aiming for 24 hours and reaching it in the vast majority of cases. The crisis might not have peaked in a week's time, but if we can deal with the outbreaks quickly we'll feel we're on top of it, in so far as you can be.

When you're here in Cumbria, in the eye of the storm, there's a different public perception of the crisis, because it's such a huge issue. I suspect in other parts of the country it's not the same size of issue. There's half a million people in Cumbria - 1% of the country's population - so I know they had to look at the national picture. That's why I think Mr Blair took a brave decision really."

 Interview by Simon Parker

fields.headline: Blair delays local elections
fields.trailText: The prime minister today confirmed that the planned May 3 local elections will be delayed for a month while the government struggles to contain the spiralling foot and mouth crisis. Simon Parker reports.
fields.body:
The prime minister today confirmed that the planned May 3 local elections will be delayed for a month while the government struggles to contain the spiralling foot and mouth crisis.

Speaking outside Downing Street, Tony Blair said the delay was in the country's best interests, but rejected calls for an indefinite postponement of the council polls, which he said could cause even more harm to the tourism industry.

Instead, the government plans to bring in emergency legislation that will move the council elections to June 7, effectively putting back the date of the general election, which was expected on the same day as the local vote.

Mr Blair said the government's focus had to be on tackling the disease: "Our task therefore, now, is to complete the putting in place of the short, medium and long-term strategies to ensure the eventual eradication of the disease. Whilst this is going on, I believe it would not be appropriate to hold these elections on the 3rd of May. But equally, we cannot, should not and will not indefinitely suspend the democratic process."

The prime minister has come under pressure to delay from the Conservatives and some county council leaders. They argue that holding the elections while foot and mouth is still raging would block effective canvassing and disenfranchise rural voters trapped in their homes by movement restrictions designed to fight the spread of the disease.

The government has, however, come in for cross-party criticism for setting such a short delay, and some Labour figures complained that the foot and mouth situation might not significantly improve by June, rendering the postponement pointless.

Conservative leader William Hague said the prime minister was wrong to set the new date so soon: "We just think it would not be possible or wise to set a precise date at this point when they don't know how the crisis will continue and when it will be resolved."

The Tory leader also hinted that, although the party supported the principle of a delay, its total support for the government's emergency bill is not guaranteed: "How we would handle a bill in detail depends on what form the bill would take."

Labour's local government chief, Sir Jeremy Beecham, admitted that he would have preferred a May 3 date for both the local and general elections. Along with other senior Labour local government figures, he has in the past called for increased use of postal voting to allow isolated voters to take part in the polls.

Councils would not, he said, find the delay practically difficult, but it would be inconvenient.

Sir Jeremy said: "I can understand the sensitivities that drove the prime minister to defer, but I'm not sure much will change in a month."

Somerset county council leader Chris Clarke, a Liberal Democrat, added: "It's very hard to know whether a month is long enough There's no way people in a rural area could have their minds clear enough to think about local elections with this hanging over them."

webTitle: But has he done the right thing?

fields.headline: But has he done the right thing?
fields.trailText: Reponse to Tony Blair changing the date of the local government elections to June 7.
fields.body:
John Curtice, deputy director, ESRC centre for research into elections and social trends

Yesterday's Mori poll showed that, although the percentage of people who think the government is handling foot and mouth well has almost doubled since a week ago, they don't think Tony Blair can run an election campaign and deal with foot and mouth at the same time.

Delaying the election until June is the decision I'd have made. But there's a risk that foot and mouth won't be better by then, and that will have wider implications for agriculture and tourism and mean economic confidence declines. Blair made a decision against the advice of the majority of his party, so the stakes are raised. If he doesn't get a large majority, he can forget commanding the party in the way he has for seven years.

fields.headline: Beecham: 'It won't make a difference'
fields.trailText: Holding the local elections in June isn't going to make any difference to the outcome, says Local Government Association Labour leader Sir Jeremy Beecham.
fields.body:
Sir Jeremy Beecham, Local Government Association Labour leader:

"I'm describing the prime minister's decision to postpone the local elections as a "respectful pause". My personal preference would have been to go for May 3 for both local and general elections. I can understand the sensitivities that drove the prime minister to defer, but I'm not sure much will change in a month.

When the Local Government Association surveyed local authorities with elections it was split roughly evenly between those who did and didn't want to go ahead. The councils won't find this delay a problem practically speaking, although it is inconvenient, and a certain amount of expense will have been incurred.

I don't think the delay will affect the outcome of the local elections. The better grip that's now being exercised over the foot and mouth crisis will bode quite well for the government.

As for the message the delay sends out on tourism, I think there's a concern that the Northern Ireland secretary John Reid has raised that the industry's already suffered because of the media coverage. You see the pictures of cows burning and you get the impression from the media that the whole country is like that. I don't think deferring the election for a month is going to make any difference."

 Interview by Simon Parker

fields.headline: Emergency law to delay election
fields.trailText: Tony Blair will today announce that he has abandoned plans for a general election on May 3 in deference to the foot and mouth crisis, but his aides insisted that he would not let the polling date slide beyond his new target date of June 7.
fields.body:
Tony Blair will today announce that he has abandoned plans for a general election on May 3 in deference to the foot and mouth crisis, but his aides insisted that he would not let the polling date slide beyond his new target date of June 7.

No formal announcement of the new date will be made today, because civil service rules would interpret such an announcement as the start of the election campaign and require ministers to go into a form of purdah.

Instead, Jack Straw, the home secretary, will tell the Commons that he intends to table emergency legislation to delay the county council elections, planned for May 3, until June 7.

Mr Blair telephoned cabinet members on Saturday to tell them that he had finally come down in favour of delay. The mood switched in his camp on Thursday and Friday. Cabinet members and union leaders were willing to accept the risks inherent in his one-month delay, but only on the proviso that the prime minister gives a private commitment not to postpone again.

No one in the Labour movement is willing to countenance an autumn poll during a possible economic downturn. "We have shown the farmers we are listening, but we are not going to do this again," said one cabinet minister.

The deferral to June, the subject of heartsearching in Downing Street all last week, means parliament need not be dissolved until Tuesday May 15, giving exhausted ministers nearly another four weeks of parliament, including the difficult Easter season when the teaching union conferences meet. But it also gives the army, the vets and the embattled Ministry of Agriculture six weeks to produce clear signs that the foot and mouth epidemic is under control.

Mr Blair made the decision against the fluctuating advice of some cabinet ministers after accepting that foot and mouth would still dominate his and the media's attention for the foreseeable future. A majority of the public, the farming unions, bishops, the Tory leader William Hague and the Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy had all supported delay.

The only serious countervailing force had been the beleaguered tourist industry and some senior cabinet ministers, including Gordon Brown and John Prescott. Neither was in the mood to condemn Mr Blair in private or public, although some claimed that Mr Blair's unelected advisers had en joyed undue influence. All sides accept that the choice of the election date is the prerogative of the prime minister, but some Labour aides fear that Mr Blair will take a short-term knock for looking weak and no longer in control of events.

Michael Portillo, the shadow chancellor, accused him of dithering and other Tories called for a delay until the autumn when the rural crisis should be cleared.

There were more than 40 new cases on Saturday, and the total number reached 891 by yesterday afternoon.

Nick Brown, the minister of agriculture, will today again delay the decision on whether to vaccinate dairy cattle in Cumbria, despite promising on Friday to make a decision within 48 hours.

The deferral reflects continuing opposition from farming unions. Mr Blair will again meet scientific experts today aware that a vacinnation go-ahead could lead to a year long ban on British meat exports and damage to the Cumbrian milk industry.

More than 940,000 animals have been earmarked for slaughter, with 353,000 waiting to be killed and 166,000 carcasses awaiting disposal.

Tim Yeo, Mr Brown's Tory shadow, said the number of animals waiting to be killed was more than double the number than when Tony Blair took personal charge. But the army hopes to have 180 trucks shifting cattle and sheep for burial by today taking them closer to their target of 24 hours from diagnosis to slaughter.

Despite the lack of a formal announcement,ministers went out in a phalanx yesterday to explain Mr Blair's thinking. John Reid, the Northern Ireland secretary, said on GMTV: "The prime minister is someone who by instinct believes in unity rather than division, somone who wants to be inclusive rather than exclusive." A slight delay in the elections would, he said, be a sign of sensitivity.

Mr Straw stressed that the delay was likely to be a one-off show of support to rural communities. He said the decision had not been governed "in terms of the practicalities of running polls but it's much more to do with sensitivity about the issue and the countryside, taking account of the national mood".

Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, said: "I can well understand why he may well come to the view that we need some more time to make sure we have got in place the methods, the mechanisms, the resources to cope with the foot and mouth outbreak before we go to the country."

Nevertheless, ministers will be forced to eat their words over claims that delay of the county council elections will seriously damage the tourist industry. Industry chiefs claim they are losing £200m a week in lost revenue and expressed deep disappointment at the decision.

John Redwood, the Tory campaigns chief, said local elections should be postponed in the worst affected areas and Mr Blair should announce when the council polls would be held in other areas.

The disease continued to affect sporting events with yesterday's decision to cancel the Cheltenham festival race meeting, which had been rearranged from March to later this month, after officials confirmed that it was within the foot and mouth exclusion zone. The meeting, which was postponed because of the livestock movement restrictions, was doomed after a new case was confirmed yesterday in Woolstone, a village five miles from the track.

What happens now?

April 2

Prime minister and home secretary to confirm local council elections will be held on June 7.

April 3

Party managers will seek advice from the electoral commission on new spending limits. Expect to be told they can spend an extra £800,000 each.

April 6

Class size and pupil teacher ratio figures released.

April 15

Easter Sunday and teaching union conferences.

April 26

New Deal figures released.

May 14

Last date for dissolution of parliament.

June 6

Monetary policy committee to give interest rate decision.

June 7

General and county council elections.

webTitle: Election delay may cost councils millions

fields.headline: Election delay may cost councils millions
fields.trailText: English councils could face a multi-million pound bill to cover the costs of preparing for this year's delayed local elections - but the government today promised that it would meet the costs.
fields.body:
English councils could face a multi-million pound bill to cover the costs of preparing for this year's delayed local elections - but the government today promised that it would meet the costs.

The 45 authorities with polls this year will be legally forced to continue preparing, despite the prime minister's announcement that he wants the ballots moved to June 7.

The councils can only bring their work to a halt when emergency legislation to move the local election date is passed

Announcing the legislation in the Commons today, the home secretary, Jack Straw, said the government would use the bill to compensate councils for their lost funds.

The actual costs for each council will vary enormously, partly due to the differing size of the authorities involved.

Local Government Association assistant director John Rees said: "We're pleased about the government's move because councils have had to carry on, and still have to carry on, preparing for elections on May 3 until the emergency legislation is through. Some costs have been incurred that now have to be thrown away. It's right that authorities should be compensated."

Mr Straw said the five-week delay of the elections, originally planned for May 3, was an "appropriate response" to the foot and mouth crisis, and that politicians needed to be "focused on the fight against foot-and-mouth".

The bill will also delay district and borough council by-elections due on or after May 3.

fields.headline: David Bowie on glam: 'Doesn't it look like I'm having fun?'
fields.standfirst: Bowie remembers the platforms, the pretension and the joy of convincing butch bricklayers ‘that a smidgen of blusher really attracted the birds’
fields.trailText: Bowie remembers the platforms, the pretension and the joy of convincing butch bricklayers ‘that a smidgen of blusher really attracted the birds’
fields.body:
Of course, when it comes down to it, glam rock was all very amusing. At the time it was funny, then a few years later it became sort of serious-looking and a bit foreboding. Lots of postmodernist juxtapositions and “significant” ciphers – that kind of twaddle. Now? Well, now it’s just funny again, albeit with a certain clout. I still derive immense pleasure from remembering how many hod-carrying brickies were ­encouraged to put on lurex tights and mince up and down the high street, having been assured by know-it-alls like me that a smidgen of blusher really attracted the birds.

This was true, of course, and has been since woad. ­However, for the likes of Roxy Music and me, mascara was merely the conveyance by which great globs of non-rock flotsam and ­jetsam were to be delivered. Japanese kabuki, Dada, Dietrich and Riefenstahl, Piaf and futurism, and above all “elegant gloom”, as the author Barney Hoskyns has put it. Not for us the couple of pints in the backroom bar after the gig. We were wondering where to lay our hands on absinthe and puzzling through the big question: greasepaint or pancake?

Climbing the heights of what we felt was much-needed pretension, we were above common-or-garden chat-up lines to dodgy slappers. We craved the ­rarefied ­stratosphere whence we dropped really heavy names: Burroughs, Brecht and Baudelaire tumbled ­meaninglessly over Warhol and Wittgenstein in a blur of de- and reconstructed pop.

Let me backpedal for a ­second. Pretension, or the “School of ­Pretension” as I pretentiously dubbed Eno and myself in 1978, was a quick-fix category for it all. By 1970, the knock-on effect of The Dice Man, Warhol’s culture-flattening and the break dances of Derrida and Foucault had substantially changed the notion of “the absolute”, of reality. It was no longer possible to take seriously the history of things as stage-managed by the media and the ­educational system. Everything we knew was wrong. ­Burroughs, being the John the Baptist of postmodernism, had proselytised over this point for years. Free at last – or, if you like, at sea without a paddle – we were giving ourselves permission to reinvent culture the way we wanted it: with great big shoes.

We couldn't have pounced without Marc Bolan. The little imp opened the door

Well, all right, if you insist: we couldn’t have pounced without Marc Bolan. The little imp opened the door. What was so great, however, was that we knew he hadn’t got it quite right – sort of Glam 1.0. We were straining in the wings with versions 1.01 and 1.02, while Marc was still struggling with satin. But boy, he really rocked. He did, y’know.

Annoyingly, Americans often make territorial claims for the US as the spawning ground for this brief movement, as they usually do with punk and television. Yes, we loved American underground music and John Rechy’s City of Night, but we really did have our own drag queens and drugs in London, thank you very much.

We also had A Clockwork Orange, Lindsay Kemp, Berlin and Fritz Lang, George Orwell and Nietzsche, Kansai Yamamoto (100% responsible for the Ziggy haircut and colour, by the by), Mishima’s gay army and Colin Wilson to draw upon. (I could list ad nauseam, and have been known to do so, as high-glam’s ingredients were dizzyingly disparate.) And if I read one more self-aggrandising denizen of the Big Apple screaming blue murder over the issue of who established the shaved eyebrow – well, gosh, I’ll just hurl.

The truth is, as wonderful as the New York Dolls were, they were just the Stones in lame. The Americans at heart are a pure and noble people; things to them are in black and white. It’s either “rawk” or it’s not. We Brits putter around in the grey area. In our minds it’s “a little bit rock, a little bit snigger”.

British glam-rock never made much of an impact on middle America. Before and after, we were bookended by Alice Cooper and Kiss – butch, “manly” glam with lots of guillotines and fireworks, muscle and metal. No mistaking the sexual bent of those fellers: “Nothing ambiguous about our boys.” That’s the only way Ohio could accept lipstick on males. So we limeys all swanned off sniffily to the wings where we did make an impression. For a brief moment or two, we ruled in New York and Los Angeles. Have a look at the jolly pictures on these pages. Doesn’t it look like I’m having fun?

Next week, I’ll be showing you how to turn all those ­earrings into a perfectly serviceable chain with which you can anchor yourself for the oncoming tremors of 1975. All you’ll need will be a snotty nose, an abused Ziggy haircut and an ­ability to ­pronounce “anarchy”. Me? I’ll be pissing off to Berlin, thanks.

This extract from Glam! An ­Eyewitness Account by Mick Rock (Omnibus Press) was first published in 2001.

webTitle: Australia tries to ban online gambling

fields.headline: Australia tries to ban online gambling
fields.standfirst: The rightwing federal government hopes to cure Aussies of their betting addiction by regulating the internet, Patrick Barkham reports
fields.trailText: The rightwing federal government hopes to cure Aussies of their betting addiction by regulating the internet, Patrick Barkham reports.
fields.body:
Punters in Australia flock to place dollars on every kind of race, whether it features dogs, horses, camels, cane toads, lizards or cockroaches.

But they may not be able to bet on the internet for much longer. Last May, the federal government passed a law temporarily banning the establishment of new gambling websites here. Now it wants a permanent ban, preventing Australians from gambling on websites run in the country.

Australia has the largest number of gambling addicts in the world. A report last year classed 290,000 people as problem gamblers and the number is growing. Ten years ago Australians on average gambled away 1.8% of their disposable income. They now fritter away 3.6%.

The Liberal government's bill is the first attempt by federal authorities for more than 30 years to put a legislative brake on the growth of gambling and has been applauded by many churches and anti-gambling groups.

Richard Alston, the federal communications minister, said the internet had the potential to make every home a virtual casino.

"It is incumbent upon governments at all levels and of all political persuasions to take strong action to combat the tragic economic and social consequences of gambling in this country," he said.

But with many in the opposition Labor and Democrat parties vowing to fight the legislation, it faces a battle to get through the upper house in the next few weeks.

Democrat senator John Woodley welcomed the legislation but attacked its detail, especially the provision allowing Australian companies to build and run lucrative online gambling sites for foreign users.

Australia's online gambling industry is advanced and could be a major area of export growth. It can also provide an additional source of state income from taxation.

The gaming industry and the Northern Territory government are considering challenging the bill in the high court. The gambling lobby claims jobs will be lost and argues that it is illogical to ban online lotteries and sports betting on the internet, when people can just as easily pick up a telephone to place their bets.

The Labor party says the bill is unworkable. "The government's proposal in this bill will do absolutely nothing to prevent those who want to gamble online from finding the sites to do that," said opposition spokeswoman on information technology Kate Lundy.

The legislation will not demand that internet service providers block gambling sites, but it will require Australian online gambling firms to detect and ban users based in the country. Gamblers will still be able to use sites abroad.

Critics say the rightwing Liberal party is simply in a panic over how to regulate the internet. At state level, the Liberal government in South Australia is trying to ban any information deemed offensive from being posted on the web, adding to the impression that rightwing forces in Australia just don't get the net. But the argument that banning internet gambling is pointless is most commonly sounded by businesses that stand to make big bucks out of problem gamblers.

Labor has strongly denied that its fairly laissez faire attitude towards gambling at state and federal levels is influenced by the fact that one of the party's major donors is Kerry Packer, Australia's wealthiest man, who has hefty stakes in casinos and online gambling firms.

Though clumsy, the federal legislation is a rare government move against the interests of big business. With gambling companies requiring expensive licences and paying high taxes, the industry is a lucrative source of state income.

The refusal of Labour state governments in New South Wales and Victoria to put the brakes on their burgeoning offline gambling industries only adds to the suspicion that, in the words of anti-gambling crusader Tim Costello, the governments are the greatest gambling addicts in Australia.

fields.headline: Blair's big gamble
fields.trailText: Tony Blair attempted to cast himself as the father of the nation this morning when he appeared in Downing Street to announce that the local elections - and therefore the general election - would be postponed until June 7.
fields.body:
Tony Blair attempted to cast himself as the father of the nation this morning when he appeared in Downing Street to announce that the local elections - and therefore the general election - would be postponed until June 7.

With a pained expression on his face, the prime minister said that his decision was designed to unite opponents and supporters of the government. "It is time to unify and not divide," he said.

After weeks of agonising, in which he wavered between delaying and pressing ahead with the elections on May 3, the prime minister finally decided that Friday that June 7 was the least damaging compromise.

To have gone to the country on 3 May, as he had planned to do since 1997, would have left Labour open to charges of placing party before country which could have cost up to 25 seats. That may have made little difference to the parliamentary arithmetic, but a 3 May election could have left a sour taste which would have helped a Tory recovery.

Downing Street also feared that holding an election in the middle of the foot and mouth crisis could have left the prime minister at the mercy of events. If the crisis worsens over the coming weeks, Mr Blair's energies could have been diverted from the campaign to trail to dealing with foot and mouth.

By delaying, the prime minister has shown that he is reaching out to conservative-minded groups, such as the Church of England and the Countryside Alliance, which had all said that it would be inappropriate to hold an election in the middle of a national crisis.

His decision demonstrates that the prime minister is still prepared to face down the Labour party - which overwhelmingly favoured an election on May 3 - showing that he has not lost his knack for understanding the fears and aspirations of Middle Britain.

However, the prime minister made clear this morning that the delay would not be indefinite, as he dismissed William Hague's call for the elections to be put on hold until foot and mouth is eradicated. Indefinite postponement would deliver "real and lasting damage to our democratic and economic stability," the prime minister said.

The anguish on the prime minister's face showed that he knows that he has taken one of the biggest gambles of his career. Virtually the entire cabinet were in favour of holding the general election sooner rather than later, ensuring that they will line up to tear strips off the Mr Blair if Labour has a bad result on June 7. For the first time, the prime minister has displayed signs of fallibility.

webTitle: At last, Blair finds his courage

fields.headline: At last, Blair finds his courage
fields.standfirst: Tony Blair's decision to delay the general election will be greeted with despair in Millbank - but joy by 'one nation' Blairites. He should use it as a platform to do more, writes Benjamin Wegg-Prosser
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's decision to delay the general election has been greeted with despair in Millbank - but joy by 'one nation' Blairites. He should use it as a platform to do more, writes Benjamin Wegg-Prosser.
fields.body:
The prime minister has finally done it. In postponing the general election he has for once made a brave decision. Even his words outside No 10 were pure Blairism: "This is a decision that has to be taken in the interests of the whole country, the parts that don't support the government as well as the parts that do. It is time to unify and not divide, to work together to help the communities most affected. That is what we will do."

The announcement to delay the local council and general election is unpopular with his ministers and flies in the face of pressure from the press. It is all very different from January, when Peter Mandelson suffered at Mr Blair's hands. Then, under pressure from the media and Home Office, he caved in and sacked his closest ministerial ally. This time he waited a little, weighed up the pros and cons, and made a decision in the national interest.

Rarely will a prime ministerial statement have been greeted with such dismay in Millbank. Detailed plans are now being rewritten, brochures scrapped and posters put on hold. The prime minister will want the campaigning donkey work to continue in key marginals. However, he will call a halt on the national hostilities until progress is made in managing the spread of foot and mouth.

Mr Blair should see this crisis as a valuable learning experience. The decision to postpone the election - against opposition from both his chief election strategist, Gordon Brown, and his deputy, John Prescott - is genuinely courageous. It is also, in recent Labour history, somewhat unique.

Blairites will take heart from this move. Of late they have become a little disgruntled with their leader. They look back with misty eyes to his decision to scrap clause IV in 1994 or the refusal to raise income taxes before the last election. To some this dynamic progress has not been maintained in government. They cite the government's failure to get a grip on welfare reform, the inability to clearly define Britain's role in Europe or Mr Blair's willingness to grant responsibility for huge swathes of government policy to Mr Brown.

Most pointedly, they cite the prime minister's attempt to do a deal with the unions during the pensions debate at the last year's party conference. This struck a raw nerve. True Blairites, it is said, would have refused to negotiate beyond a certain point.

As he travels the country over the next month trying to alleviate the problems of the disease, let us hope he has the chance to leaf through the drafts of Labour's election manifesto with a more critical eye. Having stuck his neck out on the election date he should keep it there.

First of all he needs to reassess how the government is run. Why did it take so long for him to get directly involved in this current crisis? How did he allow the government to coast through the early days of the disaster? Is it right that the department responsible for farming should also have ultimate responsibility for food safety? Before the last election and intermittently during this parliament we have heard great talk of Whitehall reform. It is time to turn this aspiration into a pledge, with root and branch reform of the system.

He also needs to reassess his relationship with his ministers. Mr Blair should not be in the position he is today, where it is known that many of his senior colleagues openly disagree with the most important political decision he has taken since he became prime minister. Greater consultation and collective responsibility may be time consuming but it makes important people happy and keeps them onside. In the long run it is in his interest to make the effort.

He might want to reconsider how to rejuvenate his stalled attempts at constitutional reform. As Tony Wright MP argued on this site last week, fixed term parliaments would, at a stroke, have wiped this issue off the agenda. If Tony Blair is serious about reform then he needs to grasp these issues and make a stand.

Last on the list, he should seriously re-assess his relationship with the Sun newspaper. For more than a month the paper has gone out of its way lavishing praise on the government that was frankly embarrassing. It drooled at Mr Brown's budget, which would have made Rupert Murdoch wince. Now it is in the absurd position of consistently and slavishly calling for a May 3 election only to u-turn in Saturday's edition via its Thatcherite political editor, Trevor Kavanagh. You can only imagine how much it infuriates Mr Blair's colleagues, other journalists and many members of the public that the government now uses the Sun has its unofficial mouthpiece.

With June 7 now the latest target date for polling day Mr Blair will have until to 2006 to hold the election after next if he is successful at the polls this year. If he is, and fails to introduce fixed term parliaments, then that campaign could start as late as June 2006 - coinciding perfectly with the football World Cup in Germany.

With the rejuvenated England team likely to do well in this competition maybe this was in the back of Blair's mind when he made his announcement this morning. Just think, as he attempts to secure a third term of office as Sven Goran Eriksson is returning to England with the World Cup.

Had the spin doctors spotted this one before I did - or is it a step too far?

fields.headline: Fingertips losing its grip
fields.trailText: 2pm: Channel 4 has become the latest casualty of the dot.com downturn after the first company it invested it ran out of money. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Channel 4 has become the latest casualty of the dot.com crisis after the first company it invested it ran out of money.

Fingertips.co.uk, an entertainment listings business that planned to offer a personalised version of Time Out, could be out of business within a month, say sources.

The closure will be a blow to Channel 4, which took an undisclosed stake last summer.

The site has failed to find a rescue package after seed funding - thought to be about £1.5m - from Channel 4 and the founders ran out.

Andy Anson, head of strategic planning and interactive at Channel 4, said it was a regrettable decision but that Channel 4 had never intended to put second round funding into Fingertips.

"We had been hoping that the strong management team at Fingertips would raise new cash. We even got involved in trying to help them raise more cash over the past couple of weeks," he said.

"We still believe in the product but it's just not a good time for internet companies to get investment. It's sad that it's got to the point where liquidators are close to being called in."

Founders Ross Sleight and Robert Fields, former BMP interactive specialists, said they were trying everything they could to avoid calling in the liquidators.

"We're looking at every option about where to go next and we're still hoping for fresh investment, but it's a dead market out there and we're not finding the financial community very receptive," said Mr Sleight.

He said Fingertips needed £300,000 to stay afloat, but around £1.5m was needed for the business to become profitable.

The two founders refused to set a deadline but it is thought a decision will be taken at the end of this week. Some of the 12 staff had already been laid off.

Fingertips.co.uk launched as a test website in February. Channel 4 got involved and planned to incorporate the technology, which has taken two-and-a-half years to develop, in its new entertainment portal e4.com.

Channel 4's other dot.com investment to date has been in Popworld, the music portal co-founded by ex-Spice Girls manager Simon Fuller.

fields.headline: WPP swoops for branding consultancy
fields.trailText:
1.30pm: Marketing and advertising giant WPP has bought European branding consultancy icon, writes Julia Day.

Mar 30: Hill & Knowlton buys ProMarc Agency

Mar 28: Sorrell hints at acquisitions

Online interview: Sir Martin Sorrell
fields.body:
Marketing and advertising giant WPP continues to add to its communications cachet with the acquisition of European branding consultancy icon.

Nuremberg-based icon's client list includes Nokia, Nestle, Colgate-Palmolive, Kellogg's and Deutsche Post.

The company provides brand and communications consultancy, product research, tracking and customer satisfaction studies.

Icon employs 220 people across its offices in Nuremberg, Hamburg, Istanbul, Madrid, Milan, Munich, Paris and New York.

The company will work on developing corporate and brand positioning closely with WPP-owned branding and identity group Enterprise IG.

webTitle: Scudetto comes ever closer for Roma

fields.headline: Scudetto comes ever closer for Roma
fields.trailText: "Il Verona graffia, la Roma lo travolge," screams the headline on the Gazzetta dello Sport website today. It translates as 'Verona scratches, Roma sweeps up,' - which not only sums up yesterday's game, a match the giallorossi won 3-1 despite going behind, but tips a wink to the destination of this season's title.
fields.body:
"Il Verona graffia, la Roma lo travolge," screams the headline on the Gazzetta dello Sport website today. It translates as 'Verona scratches, Roma sweeps up,' - which not only sums up yesterday's game, a match the giallorossi won 3-1 despite going behind, but tips a wink to the destination of this season's title.

Barring a modern-day miracle, Roma are about to sweep up their first scudetto since 1983. There are still ten matches to go, of course, and rival coaches are still - a la Lenny Kravitz - insisting that it ain't over til it's over. But with Juventus being held by Brescia, and Lazio losing to AC Milan, Roma's lead of nine points will be mighty hard to rein in. No wonder they were celebrating at the Stadio Olimpico yesterday.

But early on there were more whistles than cheers in the Curva Sud, especially when Verona took a shock lead after 26 minutes through a Mauro Camoranesi toe-poke. Cue an unconvincing Roma performance and a bad miss from Emiliano Bonazzoli which would have put the gialloblù two goals up.

During the break Fabio Capello gave another a coaching masterclass, switching things in midfield to give Cafu had more space on the right. Suddenly Roma, who had played like wallflowers, looked world-beaters.

Vincenzo Montella continued his excellent run with two goals, while Gabriel Batistuta marked his first game back from injury with the third.

But despite the win Capello refused - yet again - to get carried away. "We have to play ten more matches and the final victory will be very hard," he insisted.

"After the first half I talked to the team. My players were concerned and were unable to create chances and play well. But they were convinced they could win the match.

"The supporters didn't help us when we were unable to play well and I was afraid of that."

Juventus stumble, Lazio lose

As a Buddhist, Roberto Baggio believes in reincarnation. Which is appropriate, as after a dismal season the Divine Ponytail came back to life yesterday with a stunning late goal against Juventus to earn Brescia a 1-1 draw.

Until Baggio's goal, Juventus looked like wheezing to an unconvincing win on the back of Gianluca Zambrotta's first half volley. But on 86 minutes Baggio beat Juve's offside trap, caressed a long pass under control and rounded Edwin van der Sar for the equaliser.

Despite the lacklustre performance Juventus coach Carlo Ancelotti was confident his side could claw back the nine-point deficit that separates them from Roma. "I talked with my players and obviously everything is now more difficult, but last year we were in the same position as Roma are now," he insisted.

"We have to believe and to keep playing. It's true that in the second half we didn't play as well as in the first. Maybe we were too confident that we were going to win. Now we have to react to this."

They can react all they like, but if Roma keep up their current run of form (eight wins and a draw in their last nine Serie A matches) the Bianconeri will end up runners-up.

As for Lazio coach Dino Zoff, he sounded less confident after seeing his side drop 12 points off the pace after a 1-0 defeat at AC Milan. "Throughout the match we did the best things," Zoff said. "We had many good chances to equalise and to win as well, but that's football. "We have done all we could in these past few weeks, but Roma won again and we didn't. Roma are now well ahead of us."

Milan coach Cesare Maldini felt his side deserved their victory, which came from a Zvonimir Boban goal 15 minutes into the second half.

"At the restart we became faster and faster, thanks to the excellent wing play of Thomas Helveg, Serginho and Francesco Coco," Maldini said. "I knew they could play like that because they have all the gifts to do that."

"We won a really difficult match against a team with so many great stars, which has a large gap over us in the ranking."

Internazionale eye Champions League spot

Last week Internazionale striker Christian Vieri revealed he wanted to play for a team in the Champions League next season. As one, the Italian media interpreted his comments as a not-so-secret signal that he was off to his 11th club in 12 seasons. Now they are not so sure.

After playing like a pub team for half the season, Inter's 3-2 win away at Perugia yesterday - thanks to a Vieri hat-trick - has re-ignited their Champions League ambitions. And with Parma and Atalanta both drawing yesterday, Inter are just three points off the vital fourth Champions League spot.

Vieri has now scored 11 goals this season, and his hat-trick only confirmed his pedigree as one of Serie A's top strikers. His first was a header, his third a left-foot strike, and his second a rather ungainly scoop over Perugia keeper Andrea Mazzantini while lying prone on the floor. "It's been a while now that we just haven't been able to take our chances," he lamented. "The team cannot go on relying on Marco Materazzi's goals.

It translates as 'Verona scratches, Roma sweeps up,' - which not only sums up yesterday's game, a match the giallorossi won 3-1 despite going behind, but tips a wink to the destination of this season's title. Barring a modern-day miracle, Roma are about to sweep up their first scudetto since 1983. There are still ten matches to go, of course, and rival coaches are still - a la Lenny Kravitz - insisting that it ain't over til it's over. But with Juventus being held by Brescia, and Lazio losing to AC Milan, Roma's lead of nine points will be mighty hard to rein in. No wonder they were celebrating at the Stadio Olimpico yesterday. fields.headline: WPP swoops for branding consultancy
fields.trailText:
Marketing and advertising giant WPP has bought European branding consultancy icon, writes Julia Day.

Mar 30: Hill & Knowlton buys ProMarc Agency

Mar 28: Sorrell hints at acquisitions

How WPP chief answered your questions
fields.body:
Marketing and advertising giant WPP continues to add to its communications cachet with the acquisition of European branding consultancy icon.

Nuremberg-based icon's client list includes Nokia, Nestle, Colgate-Palmolive, Kellogg's and Deutsche Post.

The company provides brand and communications consultancy, product research, tracking and customer satisfaction studies.

Icon employs 220 people across its offices in Nuremberg, Hamburg, Istanbul, Madrid, Milan, Munich, Paris and New York.

The company will work on developing corporate and brand positioning closely with WPP-owned branding and identity group Enterprise IG.
