fields.headline: United announce record turnover
fields.trailText: While Liverpool's 2-0 victory at Anfield on Saturday hinted at an eventual end to Manchester United's dominance on the field, their pre-eminence off it shows no signs of slowing up after the club's plc announced a record turnover of £72m for the six-month period to January 31.
fields.body:
While Liverpool's 2-0 victory at Anfield on Saturday hinted at an eventual end to Manchester United's dominance on the field, their pre-eminence off it shows no signs of slowing up after the club's plc announced a record turnover of £72m for the six-month period to January 31.

United also revealed they made a pre-tax profit of £17.3m - a jump of 42% on the £12.2m profit made this time last year. And the results show a record operating profit, before taking into account transfers of players, of £21.4m against a figure of £18.6m last year.

United's increased capacity at Old Trafford - 67,700 this season against 55,300 last year - means gate receipts brought in £28.4m, against £21.4m last year.

Sponsorship income, boosted by the agreement with Vodafone and Platinum Sponsors, increased to £11.1m - surpassing the £8.8m mark in 2000. Other highlights included the £303m strategic alliance with Nike for 13 years, starting from August 1 2002.

According to financial expert William Davies, of stockbrokers Capel-Cure Sharp, United's profits were better than expected.

"They are very good results. Profits are better than last year and higher than many people's expectations," he said.

And, in an ominous warning to their rivals he warned there was no reason to expect profits to dip in the second half of the financial year.

"They have got tens of millions of pounds more revenue than anybody else, and that means they need to spend a smaller proportion of that revenue on players - leaving more for profits," he said.

"The only way other clubs can hope to compete with United is by trying to match their revenue."

fields.headline: Police give Hell's Angels hell
fields.standfirst: Unprecedented sting operation in Quebec aims to end bikers' rule of terror, Anne McIlroy reports
fields.trailText: Unprecedented sting operation in Quebec aims to end bikers' rule of terror, Anne McIlroy reports.
fields.body:
In the biggest operation of its kind in Canadian history, 2,000 police officers raided the bunkers and homes of violent biker gangs in Quebec this week, arresting 120 people.

Biker gangs have terrorised the French-speaking province for years, thumbing their noses at the authorities. The police, however, claim they have lacked the resources or legislative power to deal with the Hell's Angels, Evil Ones, Rock Machine and other gangs who have turned residential neighbourhoods into violent fiefdoms.

A six-year war between the Hell's Angels and their Rock Machine rivals has claimed more than 160 lives, including that of an 11-year-old boy killed when a bomb exploded near his Montreal home as he played outside. Another 170 have escaped assassination, including a Montreal crime journalist who was shot and wounded in a car park on his way to work.

This week's early morning raids may mark a turning point. Police say the massive dragnet operation was a major blow to Hell's Angels, the most powerful biker gang in the country. The arrests followed a three-year investigation.

Police were taking no chances with the detainees. The 87 suspects arrested in Montreal made their first court appearance by video link from prison, where extra guards were hired to deal with the influx of bikers. There are an estimated 250 full-fledged Hell's Angels in Canada, and as many as 3,000 associates. While not all were arrested, many of the most powerful figures are now in jail.

Hell's Angels control a sizeable share of the country's drug trade, with highly paid lawyers and investment advisers handling their affairs. They are major players in organised crime and are involved in a wide range of underworld activity, from prostitution and the forced overworking of strippers to the robbing of elderly people through telemarketing scams.

Quebec has suffered from their reign of terror more than any other province, but bikers are active from coast and coast, even in the Arctic. They have infiltrated the police, and copies of police intelligence reports were found in the possession of suspects arrested in the past.

The most feared Hell's Angel is Maurice (Mom) Boucher, whose chubby bespectacled image is as familiar to Quebeckers as the faces of pop stars and politicians.

After he was acquitted in 1998 of ordering the murder of two prison guards, following the disappearance and deaths of witnesses, Boucher tore out of the courthouse, racing through a red light in a show of defiance.

During last week's raid, Boucher was in prison on charges of murder, but police have charged him with an additional 13 counts of first-degree murder and three counts of attempted murder. He was in prison when two or more of the murders were carried out.

The bikers arrested in the raids have chosen trial by jury, which could prove difficult. Prosecutors fear that potential jurors will try to evade jury duty for fear of retribution.

fields.headline: Former Tiscali boss slams 'Euroland'
fields.trailText: 1pm: The American former boss of internet giant Tiscali has launched a scathing attack on Europe, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
The American-born former chief executive of pan-European internet giant Tiscali has launched a scathing attack on Europe, claiming xenophobia is wrecking good businesses.

James Kinsella said northern countries simply can't work with mediterranean countries and dismissed the concept of a "Euroland" as a pipedream.

"There is a divide between north and south. It became clear to me that Euroland is a total myth," he said.

"The notion that Euroland is coming together is just not happening."

Mr Kinsella, who was chairman of the internet service provider World Online when it was bought by Tiscali last year, added that he was bewildered by the rivalry between the different European cultures.

"As an executive in the US, you have it beaten into you to be indifferent about cultural backgrounds.

"In Europe it is discussed at boardroom level. You run into different cultures imposing pejorative differences on each other.

"It is amazing how bad customer service is in Europe. It is amazing how anyone wants to use the internet.

"There are not even people who can answer basic questions and the totally free internet service providers are a total joke," he said.

Mr Kinsella's argument hinges on the fact that the difference between the two diametrically opposed areas of Europe will determine the future of the internet across the continent.

"The idea that there is a total Euroland is total bullshit. Even the technology is split between north and south. They are very different. We need to split the audience in two," he said.

"Northern Europe is driving for broadband and southern Europe is using cellphones."

He was speaking at the European media and entertainment summit in London this morning.

Mr Kinsella left Tiscali at the end of February after a high-profile "culture clash" with his boss Renato Soru over lunch breaks.

The question of whether staff should eat lunch at their desk, or go out for their food, proved a major bone of contention between the two men.

Mr Kinsella thought lunch was for wimps, whereas the more flamboyant Mr Soru preferred that employees take breaks.

Mr Kinsella has not yet revealed his next move.

webTitle: Clooney aims to get Winslet on board

fields.headline: Clooney aims to get Winslet on board
fields.trailText: Plus: James Coburn signs up for gun mystery; Nicole Kidman's publicist confirms her miscarriage; Kevin Costner and Tommy Lee Jones battle over false imprisonment role
fields.body:
 George Clooney is apparently keen to get Kate Winslet on board for his new World War II thriller The Good German according to Ananova. Clooney is collaborating with Oscar-winning director Steven Soderbergh on the project, which is set in Berlin. The two, who are currently working on the re-make of Ocean's 11 in Las Vegas, want an 'English rose' to play the romantic lead opposite Clooney. According to an insider "George saw her in Titanic and then in Hideous Kinky and thought: "There is nobody else."

 Hollywood tough guy James Coburn, has signed up to star in mystery-thriller American Gun. The independently financed project centres on a World War II veteran (played by Coburn) who, following the death of his daughter, sets out to find the killer. From the serial number on the handgun used in the murder, he traces the gun's 20-year history across the US from the factory where it was made to the hand that pulled the trigger. Filming is set to begin on Friday in Los Angeles, directed by Alan Jacobs, who will work from his own script. Virginia Madsen, Barbara Bain and Alexandra Holden are to co-star.

 Nicole Kidman's publicist, Wendy Day, has confirmed rumours that the 33 year-old-actress who was nearly three months pregnant has suffered a miscarriage. "It is a private matter for Tom and Nicole to work out," Day told the Associated Press. "I believe the story is out there and running and we can't deny the story." Cruise, 38, filed for divorce on February 7 after the pair separated in December, just shy of their 10-year anniversary. The couple, who blamed the split on "divergent careers which constantly kept them apart", have two adopted children, Connor, six, and Isabella, eight.

 Hollywood big-shots Kevin Costner and Tommy Lee Jones are battling for the lead role in the biopic of Irishman Nicky Kelly, who was falsely imprisoned for a train robbery in 1976. Both stars are keen to play Kelly, who was finally pardoned in 1995, and are using their agents to bombard the film's producers. Kelly told reporters: "Movie bosses at Universal Studios in Los Angeles think it's a great human story. There's a very good possibility of a deal this year." Kelly, who is now an independent councillor and wants to run for the Irish parliament in the next elections, is keen to be involved in the screen version.

fields.headline: The Tories must show the country what they have learned
fields.standfirst: Tony Blair's decision to delay the election is what the Conservatives wanted - now they must use it to their advantage, says Ed Vaizey
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's decision to delay the election is what the Tories wanted - now they must use it to their advantage.
fields.body:
Tony Blair has fallen off his perch. What was merely a tantalising wobble during last September's fuel crisis has become a full-blown, head-over-heels, flat on his backside trip by the prime minister. Like the native girl in The Man Who Would Be King, Hague has bitten and drawn blood. Blair is no longer impervious to assault.

But now that the Tories have got what they apparently wanted - a delay in the timing of the election for "the national interest" - what are they going to do with it? Will they be like a spoilt child at Christmas, who, having ripped off the wrapping paper soon tosses the gift petulantly away? Or will they, for once, have a strategy in place to take advantage of this opportunity?

For a strategy they must have. What has been all too apparent over the last four years is that Labour, even when they drop the ball, have a formidable strategy for picking it up and charging on relentlessly. Even now Labour's strategists are saying that the huge poll lead they command means that they can afford to delay and delay, because the Tories will never catch up.

So Mr Hague's most important task, above all else, is to make this delay his victory. Alongside the remarkably resurgent Tim Yeo, his agriculture spokesman, he must catalogue again and again the errors and delays that have become a feature of this government's handling of foot and mouth. It is imperative that people do not see Mr Blair's equivocation as the act of a statesman, but as the act of a man who is now being dictated to by events.

Mr Hague must also remember the prerogative of the opposition, which is to constantly shift its ground without recourse to fairness or principle. Forget the Queensbury rules. There must be a subtle shift this week towards the "principle" that no election can be held until foot and mouth is beaten. Mr Blair's decision to go for June 7 must be seen as silly and pointless, and a May election campaign should see him as harried over this issue as he would have been during an April campaign.

Mr Hague should also remember that a little goes a long way. What has been telling about the way that Mr Yeo has handled this crisis so far is that he has known when to speak and when to shut up. The Tories have a terrible habit if believing that once they are on the front pages, they can talk about lots of other things and still get coverage. Who can forget Mr Hague's decision to announce shadow cabinet changes just a few days after Mr Mandelson's first resignation, thereby moving the story on when he should have let it run? The Tories must not seek to be the story and, where appropriate, should just be content to sit back and let Labour hang themselves.

In this respect, a bit of tea room dissent might not go amiss. Mr Blair has become the Grand Old Duke of York. He has marched his men up to the top of the hill and now he is marching them down again. Bizarre though the comparison may be, Tony Blair's MPs, like a well-drilled army, have been primed to fight on a certain day. Delay causes unease, unrest and dissent. The Tories should fan these flames and allow these feelings to grow.

 Ed Vaizey is a former Conservative adviser

fields.headline: No decision on vaccination
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: The agriculture minister, Nick Brown, today postponed the decision on whether or not to start vaccinating animals against foot and mouth disease.
fields.body:
The agriculture minister, Nick Brown, today postponed the decision on whether or not to start vaccinating animals against foot and mouth disease.

This delay comes despite strong indications from the government last week that a statement would be made today.

But as Mr Brown arrived at a meeting in Cumbria this morning of Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food (Maff) officials and the army, he said a firm policy had yet to be finalised.

As the number of confirmed cases of foot and mouth in the UK reached 911, Mr Brown said: "I have not come here to make any announcement. The issue is still under review. The arguments are not all one way. There are a range of strategies under consideration."

The prime minister, Tony Blair, is said to favour a "firebreak" vaccination, believing it could help control the crisis, but opponents have warned that they could do long-term damage to British exports and the officials at Maff are said to be unconvinced.

There have been growing calls in recent weeks from groups like the Soil Association and Farmers For Action for vaccinations to be introduced.

The government was not believed to favour a mass vaccination policy, which is not favoured by any EU member state, but was more likely to consider "firebreak" or emergency vaccinations.

Opponents of emergency vaccination have argued that it is costly, does not guarantee success, takes up to three weeks to become effective and needs repeating every six months. Mass vaccination would mean the loss of Britain's disease-free status and would cripple exports, worth £1.3bn a year according to Maff figures.

Meanwhile today, health officials gave the go-ahead to bury some 2,500 cattle carcasses at the mass pit in Cumbria following a delay while officials debated whether there could be a risk to human health from BSE.

Cattle under five years old ought to be free from mad cow disease - and therefore safe to bury rather than burn. But, before the burial operation went ahead, the Department of Health stepped in to double check the public health implications with experts from the official BSE advisory committee.

"There were obvious concerns raised about the BSE issue," said a spokeswoman. But the Department of Health said today that it was now satisfied that there was no threat from BSE in burying the cattle.

On a separate front in the battle against the disease, it was announced today that a "tourism cabinet" has been set up to work out a foot and mouth recovery plan for the industry, which faces losses of up to £250m.

Scotland's tourism industry received a boost from the James Bond star, Sir Sean Connery, who, it was revealed yesterday, is to spearhead a campaign to restore confidence in the US, which accounts for around 20% of visitors to the UK.

More than 940,000 animals have been earmarked for slaughter, with 353,000 waiting to be killed and 166,000 carcasses awaiting disposal.

It was also confirmed today that the Cheltenham Festival has been cancelled after officials, who had hoped it would just be delayed, revealed that it was still within the disease exclusion zone following the discovery of a new case nearby.

fields.headline: The Rumour Mill
fields.standfirst: All today's rumours have got on their hands and knees and begged the farmers for mercy
fields.trailText: Rivaldo has confirmed that he will leave Barcelona, but not until 2003. Denying rumours that he was set to leave Catalonia this summer, Rivaldo said: "The president has already said that he wants me to stay and I want to stay. But I will not be renewing my contract when it finishes in two seasons." The Brazilian star, who will be 31 in 2003, also said he would be leaving Spain altogether, which may come as interesting news to long-time admirers Man Utd.
fields.body:
Rivaldo has confirmed that he will leave Barcelona, but not until 2003. Denying rumours that he was set to leave Catalonia this summer, Rivaldo said: "The president has already said that he wants me to stay and I want to stay. But I will not be renewing my contract when it finishes in two seasons." The Brazilian star, who will be 31 in 2003, also said he would be leaving Spain altogether, which may come as interesting news to long-time admirers Man Utd.

Patrick Vieira will not be joining Juventus or anyone else, according to the Mirror. "I've got four years left on my contract and I want to stay at Highbury", he said. "I love Arsenal. The club is in my heart and leaving does not interest me."

Harry Redknapp is set to sign a new striker in the summer, after confessing that his trio of Cole, Kanoute and Di Canio cannot play together. "Having Joe Cole, Paolo and Freddie in the same team is not easy", he said after Saturday's home defeat by Everton. "Freddie hasn't got a real strike partner to play with and that's something I need to address."

Walter Smith has denied that Paul Gascoigne's career is at an end. Gazza has spent the majority of this season out injured with a knee problem, but Smith insisted yesterday that, "Talk of the injury ending his career is premature and, as far as we are aware at this stage, incorrect."

webTitle: Cannes Film Festival to honour Loach

fields.headline: Cannes Film Festival to honour Loach
fields.trailText: The British director is to be the second ever patron of the festival's Critics' Week
fields.body:
The BBC report that this year's Cannes Film Festival will be honouring Ken Loach.

The British director will be the second ever patron of Critics' Week - a role taken last year by Bernardo Bertolucci. The patron must be a film-maker who first came to attention through Critics' Week: Loach's second movie, Kes, was shown at the festival in 1970 and duly launched his international career.

Kes will be shown again as part of this year's Critics' Week, a part of the festival aimed to showcase the work of upcoming directors.

 The festival opens on May 9 with Baz Luhrman's Moulin Rouge. Liv Ullmann is to head up the jury, replacing Jodie Foster, whose work commitments forced her to withdraw from the event earlier this year.

webTitle: Foot and mouth and the media

fields.headline: Day 42: foot and mouth and the media
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk keeps you informed with a daily briefing on the press coverage of foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Day 42: The tabloids have all but given up on foot and mouth, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The Mirror

The tabloids have all but given up on foot and mouth. The Mirror relegates its coverage to a small story at the bottom of page 2 in which it reveals that the government has still not decided whether to resort to vaccination to stop the spread of the disease.

Daily Express

The Express also puts its coverage on page 2, with a round-up of all things foot and mouth. Under the headline "Cheltenham Festival is called off", the paper reveals that the number of foot and mouth cases in Britain has now risen to 890.

The Financial Times
More page 2 coverage as the FT focuses on the decision to cancel the Cheltenham Festival after a case of foot and mouth was discovered within five miles of the race track. The only other coverage has rural leaders giving a cautious welcome to Tony Blair's decision to delay the elections.

The Independent

A man driving a stolen bulldozer crushed a van carrying two policemen in a night-time rampage at a foot-and-mouth burial site, the Indy reports in a full-page foot and mouth special under the image of the mangled van. Another story reveals that both ministers and farmers are turning away from vaccination.

The Guardian

The Guardian also devotes an entire page to its coverage of the crisis, revealing that unemployment may rise back over the 1m as the epidemic starts to cost jobs. The paper also carries the dramatic image of a mangled police van.

fields.headline: Emergency law to delay election
fields.standfirst:
Prime minister to delay election until June 7

Special report: New Labour in power
Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: Tony Blair will today announce that he has abandoned plans for a general election on May 3 in deference to the foot and mouth crisis, but his aides insisted that he would not let the polling date slide beyond his new target date of June 7.
fields.body:
Tony Blair will today announce that he has abandoned plans for a general election on May 3 in deference to the foot and mouth crisis, but his aides insisted that he would not let the polling date slide beyond his new target date of June 7.

No formal announcement of the new date will be made today, because civil service rules would interpret such an announcement as the start of the election campaign and require ministers to go into a form of purdah.

Instead, Jack Straw, the home secretary, will tell the Commons that he intends to table emergency legislation to delay the county council elections, planned for May 3, until June 7.

Mr Blair telephoned cabinet members on Saturday to tell them that he had finally come down in favour of delay. The mood switched in his camp on Thursday and Friday. Cabinet members and union leaders were willing to accept the risks inherent in his one-month delay, but only on the proviso that the prime minister gives a private commitment not to postpone again.

No one in the Labour movement is willing to countenance an autumn poll during a possible economic downturn. "We have shown the farmers we are listening, but we are not going to do this again," said one cabinet minister.

The deferral to June, the subject of heartsearching in Downing Street all last week, means parliament need not be dissolved until Tuesday May 15, giving exhausted ministers nearly another four weeks of parliament, including the difficult Easter season when the teaching union conferences meet. But it also gives the army, the vets and the embattled Ministry of Agriculture six weeks to produce clear signs that the foot and mouth epidemic is under control.

Mr Blair made the decision against the fluctuating advice of some cabinet ministers after accepting that foot and mouth would still dominate his and the media's attention for the foreseeable future. A majority of the public, the farming unions, bishops, the Tory leader William Hague and the Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy had all supported delay.

The only serious countervailing force had been the beleaguered tourist industry and some senior cabinet ministers, including Gordon Brown and John Prescott. Neither was in the mood to condemn Mr Blair in private or public, although some claimed that Mr Blair's unelected advisers had en joyed undue influence. All sides accept that the choice of the election date is the prerogative of the prime minister, but some Labour aides fear that Mr Blair will take a short-term knock for looking weak and no longer in control of events.

Michael Portillo, the shadow chancellor, accused him of dithering and other Tories called for a delay until the autumn when the rural crisis should be cleared.

There were more than 40 new cases on Saturday, and the total number reached 891 by yesterday afternoon.

Nick Brown, the minister of agriculture, will today again delay the decision on whether to vaccinate dairy cattle in Cumbria, despite promising on Friday to make a decision within 48 hours.

The deferral reflects continuing opposition from farming unions. Mr Blair will again meet scientific experts today aware that a vacinnation go-ahead could lead to a year long ban on British meat exports and damage to the Cumbrian milk industry.

More than 940,000 animals have been earmarked for slaughter, with 353,000 waiting to be killed and 166,000 carcasses awaiting disposal.

Tim Yeo, Mr Brown's Tory shadow, said the number of animals waiting to be killed was more than double the number than when Tony Blair took personal charge. But the army hopes to have 180 trucks shifting cattle and sheep for burial by today taking them closer to their target of 24 hours from diagnosis to slaughter.

Despite the lack of a formal announcement,ministers went out in a phalanx yesterday to explain Mr Blair's thinking. John Reid, the Northern Ireland secretary, said on GMTV: "The prime minister is someone who by instinct believes in unity rather than division, somone who wants to be inclusive rather than exclusive." A slight delay in the elections would, he said, be a sign of sensitivity.

Mr Straw stressed that the delay was likely to be a one-off show of support to rural communities. He said the decision had not been governed "in terms of the practicalities of running polls but it's much more to do with sensitivity about the issue and the countryside, taking account of the national mood".

Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, said: "I can well understand why he may well come to the view that we need some more time to make sure we have got in place the methods, the mechanisms, the resources to cope with the foot and mouth outbreak before we go to the country."

Nevertheless, ministers will be forced to eat their words over claims that delay of the county council elections will seriously damage the tourist industry. Industry chiefs claim they are losing £200m a week in lost revenue and expressed deep disappointment at the decision.

John Redwood, the Tory campaigns chief, said local elections should be postponed in the worst affected areas and Mr Blair should announce when the council polls would be held in other areas.

April 26

May 14

Last date for dissolution of parliament.

June 6

Monetary policy committee to give interest rate decision.

June 7

General and county council elections.

fields.headline: New-look sports team for BBC News
fields.trailText:
12.15pm: BBC News has revamped its sports reporting line-up, bringing in new faces including Sunday Business's Adam Parsons, writes Jason Deans.

Special report: the BBC
fields.body:
BBC News has revamped its sports reporting team, bringing in Sunday Business sports editor Adam Parsons as one of three new appointments.

Mr Parsons, who worked as Sunday Times motor racing correspondent before joining Sunday Business, has joined BBC News as a sports correspondent.

BBC Belfast correspondent David Eades is also joining the BBC News sports team as a correspondent; while general news reporter Daniella Relph comes in on a sports reporter attachment.

They replace Paul Newman, who has joined the Football Association, and Adam Mynott, who has moved to the BBC's Delhi bureau.

All three will work alongside sports correspondent Kevin Gearey and report to BBC home news editor Richard Clark.

Related stories

fields.headline: 007 stirs for tourist crisis
fields.trailText: 10.45am: Sir Sean Connery is to join forces with Scotland's first minister to woo American tourists back to the country in the wake of the foot and mouth crisis, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Sir Sean Connery is to join forces with Scotland's first minister to woo American tourists back to the country in the wake of the foot and mouth crisis.

Henry McLeish will join the former James Bond star on a week-long visit to the US, where Sir Sean will spearhead a drive to restore confidence in Scotland as a tourist destination.

The move is designed to combat the negative impact that images of burning carcasses and mass animal burial sites is having on the multibillion pound Scottish tourism industry.

The Scottish tourist industry is worth £2.5bn a year, the equivalent of 5% of the country's gross domestic product. It accounts for 180,000 jobs, making it Scotland's third-largest employer after health and education.

Experts fear as many as 36,000 of those jobs could be lost as the effects of the foot and mouth crisis are felt.

The news came as the government announced a new "tourism cabinet" had been set up to work out a foot-and-mouth recovery plan for the industry.

The cabinet, set up by the English Tourism Council, will update the government on the impact of the disease and oversee an advertising campaign to stimulate tourism over the vital Easter and May bank holidays.

Visits to Britain have slumped since the beginning of the outbreak and culture secretary Chris Smith warned it was costing the industry about £100m per week.

It was feared that figure could rise to as much as £250m if the disease was not under control by the time the main tourist season starts.

The tourism cabinet for England, due to meet on Friday, includes representatives from the ETC, the cabinet office, the British Tourist Authority, the National Trust and other industry bodies and individual attractions.

It will work on international, domestic and regional recovery plans for the industry.

And it emerged yesterday that British Airways is to launch an advertising campaign in the US to prevent a slide in passenger numbers as a result of fears over foot and mouth.

The airline plans to advertise on TV and in newspapers to convey the message that Britain is open for business.

webTitle: Ashley Judd crawls centre stage as Catwoman

fields.headline: Ashley Judd crawls centre stage as Catwoman
fields.trailText: Ashley Judd will play Catwoman, Batman's famous feline adversary, as the comic book character takes centre stage in a film of her own.
fields.body:
Ashley Judd will play Catwoman, Batman's famous feline adversary, as the comic book character takes centre stage in a film of her own.

The 32-year-old actress, who is about to start work with Sandra Bullock and Ellen Burstyn in the screen adaptation of Rebecca Well's book The Divine Secrets of the Ya-Ya Sisterhood, signed the deal with Warner Bros last week reports Variety.

It is thought the studio is keen to continue the success of their Batman films, which proved globally lucrative throughout the 1990s. Michelle Pfeiffer took the role of the evil kitty in Batman Returns in 1992.

Warner Bros are also working on two further Batman films, a live action prequel to be directed by Darren "Requiem for a Dream" Aronofsky and a futuristic version based on the cartoon Batman Beyond, as we mentioned last year.

Judd was propelled into the Hollywood big league with the 1999 thriller Double Jeopardy in which she starred with Tommy Lee Jones. She will be seen later this year in the comedy Someone Like You which was the second biggest opener in America this weekend, taking an estimated $10.3m.

Although there is no indication of who will star alongside Judd, it is believed Warner Bros are keen to move the project along as quickly as possible before the potential actors and writers strike in June.

fields.headline: Spring means war in Afghanistan
fields.standfirst: While the snow is melting in the mountains, the Taliban and the opposition alliance are preparing for further battles, writes Luke Harding
fields.trailText: While the snow is melting in the mountains, the Taliban and the opposition alliance are preparing for further battles, writes Luke Harding.
fields.body:
Over the next two weeks, in the mountains and rugged valleys of Afghanistan, the snow will begin to melt. Spring is arriving and, with it, the dark prospect of war.

Though both sides deny it, the Taliban and the opposition alliance are busy making preparations for a renewed offensive. Fighting between these two groups is almost a seasonal ritual - almost, because unusually this year the battle continued into the freezing winter months.

The Taliban currently control 95% of Afghanistan. Their aim over the coming weeks is to wipe out the remaining pockets or resistance.

There are two main fronts: in the north-eastern province of Badakhshan, where the opposition commander, Ahmed Shah Masood, has stubbornly held out against the Taliban's advance; and in the beautiful central province of Bamiyan, the scene of the destruction of Afghanistan's two epic Buddhas last month.

Here, the sound of mortar fire could last week be heard echoing across the valley: opposition fighters from Afghanistan's Hazara ethnic minority, led by General Karim Khalil, are not far away.

Bamiyan, where journalists were escorted last week, feels like an embattled town. Most of the mud-walled houses have been abandoned. The civilian population has fled, save for a few old farmers and donkeys.

Machine-gun posts protrude from the rooftops. In the streets young, black-turbaned Taliban fighters can be seen nursing Russian-made ZKO1 anti-aircraft guns and rocket launchers.

It is at this frontline, in chilly darkness, that most of the recent fighting has taken place. Hazara troops belonging to the Hezb-e-Wahdat faction seized Bamiyan for four days in February - only to lose the town again to a massive Taliban onslaught.

Two months previously the opposition soldiers took control of the neighbouring town of Yakaolang. What happened next is the subject of controversy.

The soldiers appear to have executed four shopkeepers, accusing them of colluding with the Taliban. Worse was to follow.

In January, the Taliban retook control of Yakaolong, in a devastating high-speed attack using Toyota pick-up trucks. According to Amnesty International, while the Hazara fighters retreated into the hills, the Taliban then proceeded to execute as many as 300 male members of the community. They were taken out of their homes and shot.

The Taliban have angrily denied that the massacre ever took place. But since journalists are forbidden from travelling to Yakaolong, the reports are impossible to refute. The episode appears to have followed the same depressing pattern as so many other battles in Afghanistan's long civil war: with the civilian population coming off worse.

Diplomatic effort, meanwhile, to resolve the conflict has virtually ceased. General Masood is expected to leave his base in the Panjsher valley later this week for a rare trip to Europe, where he will visit Paris and the European parliament in Strasbourg.

The UN continues to recognise the ousted regime of President Burhanuddin Rabbani, who is now confined to a single town in the far north-east, Faizabad. Russia and Iran are covertly supplying Masood's troops in advance of the expected spring offensive.

"Masood has recently received several choppers and tanks from these two countries," the Taliban's spokesman Abdul Hai Mutmaen claimed yesterday. "He is trying his luck again and we are ready to abort it."

An opposition spokesman, Dr Abdullah, yesterday said Taliban emissaries in Pakistan had started recruiting "more combatants from Islamic schools there". He claimed that 60% of the Taliban troops stationed on the frontline were Afghan, with the remainder made up of Arab supporters of Osama bin Laden and Pakistani regulars.

Few military analysts, though, believe that General Masood will be able to win back much territory from the Taliban, despite logistical help from the west. He does not have enough fighters, they point out.

And in Kabul, transformed by rain last week into a sea of mud, memories are still fresh of when Masood controlled the city in the mid-1990s, and his soldiers carried out numerous atrocities.

In short, then, the civil war looks set to continue through a long hot summer, to the detriment of the ordinary Afghans who have not already fled this desperate but beautiful land.

fields.headline: Blair delays elections
fields.trailText: The prime minister, Tony Blair, today postponed local elections until June 7 in order to give the government time to bring foot and mouth disease under control, but he made no announcement about the general election.
fields.body:
The prime minister, Tony Blair, today postponed local elections until June 7 in order to give the government time to bring foot and mouth disease under control, but he made no announcement about the general election.

Describing the decision as a "need to balance competing interests", Mr Blair said that an indefinite postponement would be "highly damaging to the national interest" as industries such as tourism would continue to suffer from an atmosphere of uncertainty.

"It is right that while we're putting in the mechanisms to fight this disease we have this postponement," he said.

"But in addition to the farming community, I must listen to the tourist industry and the wider community. They will accept the delay I have set out but will not accept an indefinite postponement."

Excuse us while we clear our throats here at The Sun.
EH!!!! YOU WHAT???? webTitle: 'Mass affluents' get richer as the poor get poorer

fields.headline: 'Mass affluents' get richer as the poor get poorer
fields.trailText: The millionaires club in Britain is growing at a rate of 17% a year and now has 74,000 members. But it is not just the super-rich who have been getting richer: another club is emerging made up of those who have liquid assets of between £30,000 and £200,000.
fields.body:
The millionaires club in Britain is growing at a rate of 17% a year and now has 74,000 members. But it is not just the super-rich who have been getting richer: another club is emerging made up of those who have liquid assets of between £30,000 and £200,000.

Nearly 4m people, or 8% of the population over 16 years of age, can now claim membership of this group of "mass affluents", according to research from Datamonitor, the independent market analysis experts - and its numbers have been growing by 12% a year for the past five years.

These new rich are mostly white, male, over 35, and living in the south east. They win inclusion in the £30-200k club by virtue of money in cash and shares, before the value of any property or pension funds they hold is taken into account.

Soaring property prices in the south have created many new paper millionaires, as did the dot.com bubble. But the "mass affluents" do not just hold paper fortunes.

"A lot of the growth has come out of the finance industry, where the numbers employed have grown by 2.3% between 1999 and 2000," said Antony Kelsey, Datamonitor analyst. "These are people who work in banks, on mergers and acquisitions, they are very well paid industries, and it is these types who are fuelling growth." New technologies have also created new wealth.

But another factor is fear that traditional sources of pensions will not provide for retirement and many members of the club are those who have been building up a pool of assets for their old age.

However, the younger members may be wealthy but are not necessarily wise.

Mr Kelsey said: "Seventeen per cent of them hold no investments at all, and although 62% of them have equity holdings, only 40% have ISAs."

While the rich get richer, the poor get poorer - and the regional gaps become more stark.

The mass affluent are concentrated in London (19%), the south east (a further 19%), East Anglia (12%), and Yorkshire and Humberside (11%). Only 1% of people with assets of £30-200k live in Merseyside, 5% in Scotland, and 4% in Wales.

A survey based on fieldwork from the Office for National Statistics last September by Bristol, York, Loughborough and Herriot-Watt universities found that by the end of 1999, a quarter (26%) of the British population was living in poverty, measured in terms of low income and multiple deprivation of necessities.

The survey confirmed that poverty rates have risen sharply. In 1983, 14% of households lacked three or more necessities because they could not afford them.

That proportion had increased to 21% in 1990 and to over 24% by 1999.

About 8m people cannot afford one or more essential household goods. Almost 7.5m people are too poor to engage in common social activities such as are considered necessary by the majority of the population.

A survey based on fieldwork from the Office for National Statistics last September by Bristol, York, Loughborough and Herriot-Watt universities found that by the end of 1999, a quarter (26%) of the British population was living in poverty, measured in terms of low income and multiple deprivation of necessities. The survey confirmed that poverty rates have risen sharply. In 1983, 14% of households lacked three or more necessities because they could not afford them. That proportion had increased to 21% in 1990 and to over 24% by 1999. About 8m people cannot afford one or more essential household goods. Almost 7.5m people are too poor to engage in common social activities such as are considered necessary by the majority of the population.

fields.headline: Life 'alone on Mars'
fields.standfirst: It took six years for doctors to correctly diagnose Angela's son with a genetic disease that she had never heard of. Thankfully there was help at hand
fields.trailText: It took six years for doctors to correctly diagnose Angela's son with a genetic disease that she had never heard of. Thankfully there was help at hand.
fields.body:
David was a difficult baby. At first doctors thought he was had colic and that his mother, Angela, was a little bit neurotic. Eventually he was taken to hospital where he was diagnosed as having fits. Another doctor said he was also deaf.

Angela found it hard to believe. She remembers clearly how she felt: "I went home thinking that I had a deaf, sub-normal baby with epilepsy."

As a child, Angela had to hold David all the time to comfort him, he needed constant attention. He did go to playgroup, but he wrecked it. A psychologist assessed him but could not give clear answers.

David became obsessed with light switches. Angela explains: "He threw everything that could be thrown. He threw anything he could lay his hands on - including Matchbox cars - at the light fittings."

Like other young children he learned to read, write and count. However, according to Angela: "He had short-term memory problems and autism. He could not pretend play like other children. He was like an island in a crowd".

When he was six David developed white skin patches and spots on his face; a paediatrician diagnosed tuberous sclerosis. Angela was numb with shock. She knew little about the illness and thought that David might die at any time.

But Angela turned to the TSA for help and advice. Ann Hunt, the TSA family support worker, "was like a light in the darkness," according to Angela.

Angela realised she was trying to accommodate David's obsession with time, clocks, money, escalators and other items. After taking the issues through with Ann, she realised she had to change tack. Angela said: "I knew I had to help David overcome his obsessive behaviour."

David attended a special unit attached to the local primary school before moving to a school for those with moderate learning disabilities.

By the age of 11 David had blossomed but the school closed, so Angela had to look around for an alternative placement. David attended a residential school where emphasis was placed on life skills. Recalling this period in their lives, Angela says: "It was a traumatic time for us. But David gained more and more skills, including woodwork, pottery, sewing and how to travel safely."

Visits to a local farm run by an outdoor charity allowed David to mix with peers and gain confidence in the more adult surroundings.

Now 24, David works in a gift shop part time and also has a job as a waiter in a local teashop. He enjoys life to the full, learning French, swimming, and abseiling in his spare time.

Angela believes David's present happiness is largely due to help she received from the TSA when he was younger. "It helped us find the right doctors and provided the right information about tuberous sclerosis," she explains. Most importantly, it offered her a support network when times were tough. She urges other parents to join the TSA. She says: "Having a disabled child was like finding yourself alone on Mars. Don't be alone out there. Join your fellow Martians."

webTitle: Down's children 'denied heart ops by biased doctors'

fields.headline: Down's children 'denied heart ops by biased doctors'
fields.trailText: Doctors at a leading heart hospital discriminated against children with Down's syndrome by refusing them operations, an inquiry reports today.
fields.body:
Doctors at a leading heart hospital discriminated against children with Down's syndrome by refusing them operations, an inquiry reports today.

Parents whose offspring had the chromosome disorder were told frequently by the Royal Brompton hospital, London, that the risks of heart surgery were not worthwhile, and that the children's condition meant extra pressure on those carers looking after the patients into adulthood.

The inquiry team accepts that doctors may not have been intentionally discriminatory over treatment but concludes "that was, in our opinion, the effect of their approach".

The Down's Syndrome Association said the report vindicated the families who believed they had been discriminated against because of their children's condition, which affects one in 650 babies and leaves one in three of that number with a heart defect.

The 400-page report, covering 49 families' complaints, written by a team headed by Ruth Evans, former head of the National Consumer Council, adds that some doctors "did not focus sufficiently on what was in the best interests of the child as the patient".

The report is also understood to be critical about how parents of children who died after heart surgery were treated by the authorities - a further embarrassment to the medical profession after the Alder Hey organ scandal and the controversial heart procedures at Bristol royal infirmary, on which a report is expected later this year.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, wants to change what he fears is still a paternalistic culture among doctors, shown in their attitude towards patients' families - especially those whose children have died or are surviving with a life-threatening condition.

But the criticism from the inquiry about poor communication with parents was balanced by an understanding of the pressure doctors face making life-and-death decisions, and the lack of resources. The treatments by the hospital were said to be consistently satisfactory or good.

No one from the Royal Brompton, or its sister hospital at Harefield, where parents had also criticised procedures, is named in the report. The parents who made the complaints - most of whose children were at the Royal Brompton - had said their views were not taken into proper account. Two are taking legal action.

The report has failed to convince the Brompton and Harefield Heart Action Group. Bereaved parent Josephine Ocloo said that it failed to "penetrate the secretive and unaccountable world of medical decision-making".

webTitle: High street retailers appal online testers

fields.headline: High street retailers appal online testers
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: The efforts of bricks and mortar retailers to build an online presence are being let down by late deliveries, hard to use websites and abysmal levels of customer service, according to a report published today.
fields.body:
The efforts of bricks and mortar retailers to build an online presence are being let down by late deliveries, hard to use websites and abysmal levels of customer service, according to a report published today.

The survey, during which mystery shoppers spent 800 hours dealing with 38 leading online retailers, found six of the high street retailers performed "very poorly".

Clothing chain Next came bottom while the others, including Asda, Toys R Us, and Sainsbury, were bad enough to put a shopper off ever going back, the report said.

Two specialist e-tailers, Amazon and Gameplay, "set the standard for the rest".

Dixons, the electrical retailer, was among those criticised. The company's call centre was described as the worst tested. Researchers claim to have called the centre "many times to be greeted only by a busy tone or an unhelpful message saying 'all lines are busy, goodbye'."

Six of 52 items ordered by the testers were delivered late. Dixons was 13 days late, at Next one item was 11 days late, and one of Sainsbury's did not arrive at all.

Marks & Spencer came in for praise, being ranked fourth in the survey, with Homebase the only high street retailer to do better.

The report is published by Javelin Group, a retail consultancy specialising in mail order and e-commerce. "The worst performers were Next and Toys R Us, who failed to meet our expectations across the board," the report said.

 Amazon.co.uk yesterday said it had reached the 3m customer mark. The retailer of books and CDs said the rate of growth in customer numbers was accelerating.

It took Amazon.co.uk 15 months to reach its millionth customer, eight months for 2m and another six months to hit 3m.

fields.headline: Italiani Alle Urne
fields.standfirst: When Italy goes to the polls on May 13, the main battle will be between two coalitions: the centre-right and the centre-left. Mariacarla Pavoni talked to four students about to vote in their first General Election
fields.trailText: When Italy goes to the polls on May 13, the main battle will be between two coalitions: the centre-right and the centre-left. Mariacarla Pavoni talked to four students about to vote in their first General Election
fields.body:
Quarantanove milioni di italiani si recheranno alle urne il 13 maggio per scegliere chi siederà in Parlamento nei prossimi cinque anni. Il sistema elettorale è misto: il 75% dei nuovi parlamentari sarà eletto col maggioritario, il 25% col proporzionale. Oltre ai partiti non-allineati, si presentano agli elettori due grosse coalizioni: centro-destra e centro-sinistra.

Il centro-sinistra, che ha governato negli ultimi cinque anni, risanando l'economia e portando l'Italia in Europa, candida a Presidente del Consiglio Francesco Rutelli, ex-sindaco di Roma. Il governo uscente lascia un paese in buona salute ed ha avviato molte importanti riforme. Non ha però sempre saputo pubblicizzare i propri successi. Inoltre il Parlamento non ha risolto la questione del conflitto d'interessi.

Problema non secondario, poiché il leader del centro-destra, Silvio Berlusconi, possiede - fra l'altro - tre reti televisive, testate editoriali, compagnie di assicurazione e finanziarie e una nota squadra di calcio. Ciò lo rende molto popolare presso chi lo considera creatore di ricchezza. Berlusconi, che è abile comunicatore, fa leva sugli umori della gente, con slogan forti, promesse trascinanti ma anche inquietanti attacchi a magistratura, istituzioni e riforme.

Come si orienteranno i giovani?

Come ti prepari alle prossime elezioni?

Rosanna (17) studentessa: Compirò 18 anni in aprile, quindi voterò per la prima volta. Per ora non ho idee precise, penso chiederò consiglio ai miei genitori.

Guido (18) studente: Non mi preparo, per ora. Penso soprattutto all'esame di maturità che mi aspetta a giugno!

Elena (18) studentessa: Leggo i giornali, guardo la televisione, discuto tra amici e mi scanno coi compagni di scuola! Discuto volentieri anche con chi non la pensa come me, ma non sopporto chi parla per sentito dire e sputa sentenze senza essere informato.

Stefano (21) studente: Ho già votato alle elezioni amministrative, quindi non è la mia prima esperienza. Per ora ho letto solo il programma di una coalizione, ma ho intenzione di informarmi.

Cosa pensi della politica?

Rosanna: Il mondo politico italiano mi sembra uno spettacolo di baruffe continue.

Guido: Penso che ci appartenga e che dobbiamo occuparcene, anche se al momento non lo sto facendo.

Elena: Ritengo che sia importante che tutti partecipino e si informino, che ci sia un confronto di idee. Può servire a confermare le proprie convinzioni, oppure a cambiare idea!

Stefano: La politica? È facile giudicare dall'esterno, ma penso sia difficile viverla con coerenza.

Cosa pensi si dovrebbe fare per coinvolgere i giovani nella politica?

Rosanna: Interessarsi ai loro problemi. Fare battaglie serie contro la droga e il fumo. Lavorare con impegno per la crescita della scuola.

Guido: Penso che chi amministra o governa debba dimostrare di saper affrontare e risolvere i problemi di tutti i giorni. I giovani non vogliono chiacchiere, ma fatti.

Elena: Bisogna dare entusiasmo. Troppi giovani non fanno neppure più lo sforzo di andare a votare.

Stefano: Penso si debbano dare ideali, lavoro, giustizia sociale...

Hai già deciso come votare?

Rosanna: No.

Guido: Non ancora, anche se so che non voterò certo Berlusconi, perché promette cose che non si possono mantenere.

Elena: Si, però lo farò senza troppo entusiasmo. La cosa triste della politica del nostro paese è che ci porta a votare per il meno peggio.

Stefano: Voterò certamente, lo sento come un diritto e un dovere. Non ho fatto ancora scelte precise, ma voterò nell'ambito del cento-sinistra.

Quali qualità dovrebbe avere il tuo leader ideale?

Rosanna: La sincerità. Non vorrei sentire promesse false.

Guido: Vorrei che avesse idee chiare, e fosse pronto a rispettarle e mantenerle fino in fondo.

Elena: Coerenza, che non vuol dire ostinazione, ma capacità di progredire. Poi onestà e impegno personale per il bene comune e non per difendere i propri interessi, come penso che facciano molti di coloro che entrano in politica.

Stefano: Determinazione e non corruttibilità, serietà e volontà di fare quello per cui si è impegnato. Vorrei poi che avesse una smisurata sensibilità nei confronti delle problematiche ed esigenze della gente e non dimenticasse i più deboli.

Glossario/glossary

la baruffa (coll) quarrel

le chiacchiere idle words

il conflitto d'interessi clash of interests

elezioni amministrative local elections

l'esame di maturità the final exam at the end of secondary education
il meno peggio (coll) the least bad

non la pensa come me doesn't share my views

per sentito dire by hearsay

il Presidente del Consiglio Prime Minister

recarsi alle urne to go to the polls

scannarsi (coll) to have a row

sputare sentenze to play the wise guy

webTitle: Stella McCartney has designs on Gucci

fields.headline: Stella McCartney has designs on Gucci
fields.standfirst:
Feathers ruffled at Chloe as ex-Beatle's daughter and Italian company come to agreement over an animal-friendly line

Special report: London Fashion Week 2001
fields.trailText: Stella McCartney, fashion designer and self-proclaimed "rock royalty", is to leave the French house of Chloe and begin designing under her own name, funded by Italian luxury group Gucci.
fields.body:
Stella McCartney, fashion designer and self-proclaimed "rock royalty", is to leave the French house of Chloe and begin designing under her own name, funded by Italian luxury group Gucci.

The move, anticipated for some time, looks likely to be made official this week with the publication of an interview in the American magazine Talk with Gucci chairman Domenico de Sole.

Mesh Chhibber, communications director for Chloe, said at the weekend that he could "neither confirm nor verify" the story.

A major Stella McCartney label would reflect the meteoric rise of the 30-year-old designer, who graduated just six years ago. When she landed the job of designer at Chloe, she was running a tiny own-name label in West London.

Eyebrows were raised at the appointment, with many commentators sceptical that she would have risen so fast had she not been Paul McCartney's daughter.

But four years later, she has proved critics wrong, stamping her style on Chloe and quadrupling the company's profits. The Stella look - feminine touches, sexy tailoring and a very English wit - has won ardent admirers the world over, including Kate Moss, Madonna, Kate Hudson and Liv Tyler. As McCartney puts it, she "knows what makes chicks tick."

McCartney has been linked to Gucci before, designer Tom Ford being both a friend and admirer. He recently said: "I love Stella. All the women in my office love her and want to wear her clothes."

McCartney's dynamic image and gossip column friendly lifestyle create a natural synergy with the glamorous Milanese company. But in the past, discussions have broken down over McCartney's refusal to use fur or leather, central both to Gucci's image and its profits. Now, it seems, Gucci has come round to the possibility that an animal-friendly label could still make money.

For Gucci, the acquisition of McCartney is a major coup. In the battle for supremacy with French rivals LVMH, Gucci has taken an aggressive strategy, acquiring in the past 18 months the prestigious house of Yves Saint Laurent and major London talent Alexander McQueen. While LVMH is still the larger and more powerful company, with the McCartney deal Gucci is rapidly cornering the market in cool.

Details of the agreement are not yet known, but it is likely that Gucci will own at least 51% of the new Stella McCartney company. Initial reports suggest that the new label will be based in London, a boost for a city whose fashion show schedule has been hard hit by the success of young British designers such as Julien Macdonald finding high profile posts in Europe.

Details of the agreement are not yet known, but it is likely that Gucci will own at least 51% of the new Stella McCartney company. Initial reports suggest that the new label will be based in London, a boost for a city whose fashion show schedule has been hard hit by the success of young British designers such as Julien Macdonald finding high profile posts in Europe.

fields.headline: Hit TV shows 'ignore ethnic minorities'
fields.trailText: Ethnic minorities are barely represented in some of the most popular programmes on British television, according to one of the most comprehensive studies on race in the media.
fields.body:
Ethnic minorities are barely represented in some of the most popular programmes on British television, according to one of the most comprehensive studies on race in the media.

Black and Asian people were found to be almost non-existent in makeover shows such as Ground Force and Home Front. And in one week on BBC2, the only ethnic minority faces to be seen in the channel's top 10 programmes - with combined viewing figures of 33m - were cartoon characters in the Simpsons.

In drama, broadcasters are often guilty of "colour-blind" casting: in other words, characters from minority communities could just as easily have been white, because they display no evidence of their ethnic background.

The appearance of ethnic minority characters in EastEnders and Coronation Street was patchy, even though the programmes are set in London and Manchester, cities with large ethnic minority populations. Only Channel 4's Brookside, set in Liverpool, is consistent.

Apart from the occasional contribution to cookery programmes, ethnic minorities were almost invisible in the area of lifestyle programmes.

By examining 204 programmes between November 20 and December 17 last year - the heart of the most competitive autumn season between the broadcasters for years - the researchers found that the overall ethnic minority representation was 8.4%, compared with 6.7% in the "real world".

But when foreign (mainly US) films and the portrayal of visitors to the UK (such as foreign dignitaries) were excluded, the figure fell to 5.2%. Black people appeared more frequently on TV (3.7%) than in real life (2.1%). Asians were the most under-represented group: they account for 3.7% of the population but were statistically almost invisible on TV.

The results of the survey come a year after the formation of the Cultural Diversity Network, set up by the broadcasters to monitor progress against published targets, and after the BBC director general, Greg Dyke, urged the TV industry to reflect the real world.

Guy Cumberbatch, from the Communications Research Group, which carried out the research for the commission for racial equality, said it was not good enough simply for broadcasters to cast black people in white roles.

"We were struck by how few of the ethnic minority characters we observed were displaying cultural diversity." The days in which people from ethnic minorities were portrayed as "chanting savages" were over, but there was still a great deal to be done, he said.

Gurbux Singh, chairman of the CRE, which is mounting the annual race in the media awards on Friday, said: "Britain's most popular television programmes, broadcast to millions, still fall short of representing the full range of people that live here.

"While there are encouraging signs that the number of ethnic minority faces on television is rising, there is clearly some way to go. And for some programme makers, a very long way to go before they can call their output truly representative of the British TV audience."

fields.headline: US and Chinese planes clash
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: The worsening relationship between China and the United States faced its first serious crisis of the George Bush era yesterday when an American surveillance aircraft was forced to land in China after a midair collision with one of two Chinese fighter planes that were tracking it.
fields.byline: John Gittings  in Shanghai, Martin Kettle  in Washington and  Richard Norton-Taylor
fields.body:
The worsening relationship between China and the United States faced its first serious crisis of the George Bush era yesterday when an American surveillance aircraft was forced to land in China after a midair collision with one of two Chinese fighter planes that were tracking it.

The Chinese F-8 plane crashed into the South China Sea after the collision, Chinese television announced. The pilot was reported missing.

The US Navy EP-3 plane, with its 24-member Okinawa-based crew, made an emergency landing at Lingshui airfield on the semi-tropical Hainan island off China's southern coast, a statement from US pacific command in Hawaii said yesterday.

The incident pushed the two countries closer towards a serious diplomatic confrontation. Relations were already tense after the recent arrest of two US-based scholars in China and the defection to the US of a senior Chinese military official last month.

The Bush administration, which has signalled a more aggressive stance towards China, is also due to decide this month whether to sell a new generation of arms to Taiwan.

Mr Bush was informed about the incident at Camp David shortly after it took place. The White House said it expected China to return the US aircraft and crew immediately.

However, the Chinese foreign ministry said the US plane had entered Chinese airspace without authority and had "violated flying procedure".

The two sides gave markedly different accounts of the incident. According to the US military, it was an accident caused by a Chinese jet damaging the underside of the US plane. But the Chinese blamed the Americans and hinted that the clash was deliberate.

fields.headline: Crash widens US-China rift
fields.standfirst:
Special report: George Bush's America
Graphic: how the crash happened
fields.trailText: The weekend's aerial clash between a US surveillance plane and Chinese fighter jets came at a delicate moment in US-China relations, as the Bush administration adopts a harder line towards Beijing.
fields.body:
The weekend's aerial clash between a US surveillance plane and Chinese fighter jets came at a delicate moment in US-China relations, as the Bush administration adopts a harder line towards Beijing.

The tension has been increased in particular by the US claim that China is adding to its missile force aimed at Taiwan and Beijing's accusation that Washington is planning to sell Taipei advanced anti-missile equipment.

Taiwan has been lobbying hard in Washington for four guided missile destroyers equipped with the hi-tech Aegis battle management system. The sale of the Aegis long-distance radar system would amount to the recognition by all sides that Washington intends to equip Taiwan with a missile defence system, and it is bitterly opposed by Beijing.

A decision on the sale is expected within three weeks.

"This has to be resolved very quickly. It's a serious matter," Senator Chuck Hagel, a senior Republican foreign affairs specialist, said yesterday.

"We are at a very delicate point in our relationship with China. How this is handled will go a long way [in determining] the future of that relationship."

The Chinese president, Jiang Zemin, has warned the US that it is inviting a new arms race, saying: "The more weapons you sell, the more we will prepare ourselves in terms of our national defence. That is logical."

Beijing strongly denies that it is building up its missile force against Taiwan. It says the report has been fabricated by an "anti-China lobby" to justify the US supplying Taiwan with the Aegis system.

Relations between the two countries have also been strained by the defection of a Chinese colonel to the US, and the arrest in China of a number of Chinese-born scholars with American connections.

Colonel Xu Junping, an official in the ministry of defence, has been described as the most senior military defector from China. At least two Chinese-American scholars are being held after being detained separately in February, the US embassy in Beijing has confirmed. There is speculation that this may be a tit-for-tat measure in response to Col Xu's defection.

The future of the strategic relationship between the US and China is also in doubt as the Pentagon moves towards upgrading the Pacific as the most likely theatre of future conflict. The defence secretary, Donald Rumfeld, supports this new course, which casts China as the principal adversary.

While issuing strong warnings against the supply of missile defence systems to Taiwan, senior Chinese officials have tried to avoid comment on the broader US strategic shift.

The deputy prime minister, Qian Qichen, reiterated Beijing's conviction that the two countries could be friends when he visited Washington and met Mr Bush.

Diplomatic advisers in Beijing have so far been successful in persuading the leadership to give Mr Bush time to adjust. But observers believe that this moderate line is unpopular in the military and security services and will be impossible to maintain if the US sells the Aegis system to Taiwan.

Any military incident on China's maritime borders, such as yesterday's aerial clash, touches on extremely sensitive nerves in Beijing. Patriotic anger may be quickly aroused by actions which may seem to infringe Chinese sovereignty in the South China Sea, as well as over Taiwan.

The Chinese army has shown in the Taiwan Strait crisis of 1995-96 that it is prepared to run a higher risk. Beijing refuses to renounce the "use of force" in the area, saying that this is not a threat to Taiwan but to those who may try to intervene to frustrate its reunification.

Both China and the US regard the South China Sea as of immense strategic importance. China strongly asserts its claim of historical sovereignty over the Nansha (Spratly) and other island groups - and what it is describes ambiguously as the "adjacent sea areas".

The US regards the sea lanes in the area as critical strategic interests where free passage of oil and other commercial resources must be defended.

On the detention of the academics, China says Gao Zhan, a US-based sociologist held since February 11, has confessed to "damaging state security." Li Shaomin, an American who works at Hong Kong's City University, has been held since February 25, after crossing the border to China proper. Another Hong Kong academic, Xu Zerong, has been missing since last August, it was confirmed at the weekend.

webTitle: US hit for Queer As Folk

fields.headline: Queer As Folk big in America
fields.trailText: 11am: Channel 4 gay drama Queer As Folk has proved so successful in the US it has been recommissioned for a second series, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The US version of controversial Channel 4 gay drama Queer As Folk has proved so successful that it has been recommissioned for a second series.

US cable broadcaster Showtime has ordered a second 22-part run of the 60-minute show.

The first 20-part run of Queer As Folk, which opened in the US in December, is thought to have been the channel's most popular drama ever.

But the programme's controversial subject matter meant the owners of brands including Polo, Prada and Versace refused to be associated with the Showtime version, according to US newspaper reports.

The US version was set in Pittsburgh rather than Manchester, but kept Queer As Folk's central plot line of a twentysomething who becomes involved with a teenager.

webTitle: The countess and a tabloid sting

fields.headline: The countess and a tabloid sting
fields.standfirst:
Sophie Wessex is humiliated as papers reveal allegedly embarrassing remarks about the royals and politicians
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Sophie Wessex is humiliated as papers reveal allegedly embarrassing remarks about the royals and politicians.
fields.body:
As the Countess of Wessex flew out of Britain on an official visit to the Middle East at the weekend, it was in the certain knowledge that her next encounter with a sheikh would not have such catastrophic results as her last. For, despite the best efforts of Buckingham Palace, Prince Edward's wife was embroiled in controversy over toe-curlingly embarrassing remarks about other royals and politicians that she is alleged to have made to an investigative reporter posing as a Middle Eastern businessman.

The countess was alleged to have described the prime minister as "too presidential" and Cherie Blair as "horrid, absolutely horrid, horrid, horrid". William Hague was said to be "deformed". She was said to have referred to the Queen as "the old dear" and to have claimed that Prince Charles and Camilla Parker-Bowles would marry after "the old lady" - the Queen Mother - dies.

Buckingham Palace warned of "wholesale inaccuracies" in the story. "We suggest that no serious journalist gives this story the time of day," it said, apparently more in hope than expectation.

Indeed, the countess, formerly Sophie Rhys-Jones, appeared to give the reports credence by writing to the Blairs and to the Tory leader last week to apologise for what she had said. Compounding the embarrassment was the fact that she was speaking in her capacity as a director of her private public relations company, R-JH, which she set up in 1997, two years before she married the prince.

As an experienced PR executive, the countess might have been expected to be more discreet. Officials and other PR practitioners described her as naive, and it was clear that she had fallen for the oldest trick in the book: a tabloid sting.

What made the tale even more bizarre, however, was that it did not appear in the publication which obtained the original story. The News of the World published an anodyne, authorised interview with the countess, but the explosive material, obtained by its undercover reporter Mazher Mahmood, was splashed across its principal rivals, the Mail on Sunday and the Sunday Mirror.

The Mail suggested that the Queen was outraged by the alleged remarks, and that Prince Edward was "absolutely furious" with his wife for making them. The tale appeared under the banner headline: "Queen's Outrage at Sophie Insults". A similar story appeared in the Mirror.

Sexuality

The News of the World, apparently as a reward for its discretion, had to make do with a formal interview at Buckingham Palace by the countess last week in which the she was obliged to answer questions about the sexuality of her husband and her difficulty in conceiving children.

Palace officials thought that the fluffy revelations would do the job. But they reckoned without the wrath of the PR guru, Max Clifford. For it was Clifford who had first set the story in chain after an employee of R-JH had approached him with concerns about the way Sophie Wessex (as she prefers to be professionally known) was running her business.

Clifford was furious that the NoW had been cowed into burying the story. Even though the countess had secured an injunction preventing her employee from discussing her business, he is understood to believe that the paper was not legally prevented from running any comments made by the countess, which Mahmood had taped. However, it is thought that the NoW editor, Rebekah Wade, decided not to run the original story on legal advice. Determined to see the story in print, Clifford tipped off the Mail and the Mirror.

It emerged yesterday that Mahmood - who appears to possess an entire wardrobe of Arab get-ups - had met the countess three times over champagne at the Dorchester Hotel. She had attended the meetings with her business partner, Murray Harkin, but her police bodyguard had remained outside the room.

R-JH has a number of blue-chip clients including the Lanesborough Hotel, JCB and the British Luxury Council and last year had a turnover of more than £660,000. As chairman, the countess's stake in the company was estimated by the Mail on Sunday as being worth £900,000 and she was said to have received a salary last year of £47,763 with an additional £18,000 bonus. It would have been plausible that a Middle Eastern businessman would have wanted to engage her firm - and although Sophie Wessex has insisted in public that she is sensitive to her relationship to the royal family, the fact of her position as wife of the Queen's youngest son would have been attractive.

It was only when the NoW contacted the palace with details of what the countess is alleged to have said that horror of the situation dawned. The countess alerted the press complaints commission, and her lawyers obtained the injunction against her employee at R-JH. Press chiefs at the palace, which has recently made something of a practice of appeasing potential tabloid tormenters, offered the exclusive interview to the NoW. But the strategy was a disaster: the countess was humiliated in the Sunday papers twice over.

In an attempt to regain the upper hand, the palace issued a strong statement in which it insisted that none of the quotes attributed to the countess by the Mail on Sunday was true. "The story is riddled with inaccuracies and fictions ... the claim that the Countess has deeply upset the Queen is untrue and to run a speculative story under that headline is particularly offensive. Suggestions that she was in any way disrespectful to the Queen or the Queen Mother are untrue.

"The claim that the countess told the bogus sheikh that Prince Charles and Camilla Parker-Bowles would marry is untrue. The suggestion that her marriage is imperilled or that Prince Edward is furious with her are untrue. The remarks attributed to the Countess about political figures are selective, distorted and in several cases flatly untrue. Not one of the quotes in the Mail on Sunday is accurate."

The palace declined to say which parts of her remarks might have been accurate, even if later regretted. The royal family, it was said yesterday, was entirely supportive of her. A member of the royal family, who is trying to pursue her own career, is obviously vulnerable to set-ups such as this, and all members of the royal family risk tittle-tattle, misinformations and from time to time wholesale inaccuracy."

Meanwhile palace insiders said there was no public interest defence in persuading the countess to speak about her views of prominent figures. "This is not like the Guardian exposing the activities of Neil Hamilton or Jonathan Aitken," one said. The couple, who live at Bagshot Park in Surrey, do not receive a stipend from the civil list but the prince is given at least £140,000 a year by his mother as an allowance.

When Sophie Rhys-Jones, 36, first emerged as the fiancee of the Queen's youngest son, it was said that her PR experience would stand her in good stead. But, whatever she may have said, her colleagues in the business were united in their opinion yesterday that her judgment had been seriously undermined.
