fields.headline: Private lives?
fields.standfirst: How can you reconcile each individual's right to privacy with the media's right to publicise the truth?  Tessa Mayes  argues that the meaning of freedom of expression is changing in the modern world
fields.trailText: How can you reconcile each individual's right to privacy with the media's right to publicise the truth? Tessa Mayes argues that the meaning of freedom of expression is changing in the modern world
fields.body:
What's happened to the way we talk about freedom of expression? Today, free expression is viewed as if it automatically requires to be weighed against privacy. Under the new Human Rights Act, judges are already deciding how a right to privacy (article 8) will impact on the right to freedom of expression (article 10). Appeal court judges in the case of Michael Douglas, Catherine Zeta-Jones and OK! magazine against Hello!'s publication of unofficial photographs of the couple's wedding say they have "a powerful case" for a right to privacy.

The danger is that privacy regulation will create a new chilling effect on what we discuss in the future. Privacy protection is talked about as if there is a consensus on what "privacy" means. Celebrities argue they have a right of privacy to stop other people taking photos of them. The royal family argues that Prince William needs protecting from newspapers publishing details of his private life. Claiming "privacy intrusion" is the latest way to control unwanted publicity and stop the investigation of your life.

Yet in 1972, when the Younger Committee on Privacy was set up to look at the press, it concluded that privacy was too fluid a concept to define. An individual's private life can be of no public interest in one situation and of immense public interest in another. Should privacy mean that a public figure's life is only discussed between the hours of 9am-5pm? Is it right that professional photographers and camera crews require a Greater London Authority permit to take photos in a public place such as Trafalgar Square? If Guardian journalists had accepted that Jonathan Aitken was on a private holiday in France, for example, would they ever have discovered that he had lied about who paid for a hotel bill?

To resolve such dilemmas, the Human Rights Act offers a new framework: what are presented as competing rights on privacy and free expression can be "balanced", depending on the specifics of a case. But should free expression be treated on a par with privacy in the first place? After all, nobody is arguing for the right of journalists to physically enter people's bedrooms, but simply the right to use words and images.

These days, however, the meaning of "privacy" has changed. It used to be about protecting data from intrusion by the state. Now it means protecting individuals from intrusion by anyone. "Privacy" has become such a subjective concept that it can be applied whenever anybody feels they don't like what is said about them. Above all, free expression is argued to cause emotional harm.

For instance, Naomi Campbell's case against the Mirror - following its publication of a photo of the supermodel emerging from a Narcotics Anonymous clinic a few months ago - is not that no details should be published about her private life. Instead, she says the revelation of details should be under celebrities' control during sensitive times in their lives.

It's not only celebrities who say they don't like comment on their private lives on certain occasions. Some people who are not normally in the public eye have complained about the effects of intrusion by a "media scrum" in the aftermath of tragedies. Last year, Tony Blair warned British photographers not to take photographs of his new-born son Leo. Several years ago, newspaper executives complained when reporters from ITV's The Big Story series erected a 60-foot crane to film on the public pavements outside their houses following the Mirror Group's publication of photographs of Princess Diana inside her gym. The fact that different types of people want privacy from public scrutiny is used to argue that privacy is an essential need for all human beings.

Yet why should what is freely expressed be decided according to what the object of expression feels is bad for him or her? If society is becoming more sensitive to words and images, shouldn't we debate why this is, rather than automatically draw up more regulations?

Not everyone is more sensitive to words and images; plenty of people invite the media to invade their privacy. Celebrities confess their drink binges (Caroline Aherne), drug habits (Robbie Williams) or relationship problems (Denise Van Outen) quite happily in interviews. Thousands have sent showreels to Channel 4's 2001 Big Brother series, content that their intimate moments could be under 24-hour surveillance. One could argue that in this confessional age, people's feelings about public scrutiny are becoming more robust.

It depends on who is doing the privacy-invading, of course. We may feel content to tell all when it suits us, and aggrieved when somebody else reveals details. But can free expression ever be stopped? For all the laws that attempt to restrict the media, there is always someone else who may gossip or write an email about you if a story is worth talking about.

Journalists who argue in favour of free expression and invade people's privacy are told - often by other journalists - "Well, you would say that, wouldn't you?" Whether it's an investigative journalist arguing about the need to expose the corrupt and the cruel or a tabloid editor wanting to publish photos of semi-naked celebrities, they are dismissed as merely wanting a licence to make money from snooping, prying and other people's misery.

There is more at stake in defending free expression, however, than the ability of journalists to make a living. The right to freedom of expression means that everyone can have their say and judge what others say. It's not a privilege reserved for billionaire media moguls. But it's not surprising that some journalists no longer support a right to expression free from the constraints of privacy safeguards. Not everyone wishes to be associated with the expression of trivia or unpalatable material. Acceptable free expression is said to be by responsible journalists on matters in the public interest; indefensible expression involves salacious stories that lower the standards of journalism.

Yet this begs a question about freedom itself: should judges, laws, self-regulatory codes or anyone else decide what counts as free expression, or the individual who is speaking, writing, or publicising an image in the first place?

Freedom of expression may be discussed far more, especially by those in positions to decide what everyone else can say. But if our idea of free expression is constantly bound up with a notion of privacy, we're not hearing the full debate.

 Tessa Mayes is a journalist and director of the LIRE media group. Her interactive report, Restraint or Revelation? Free Speech and Privacy in a Confessional Age, will be published by spiked, the new online magazine

fields.headline: Media firms urged to exploit sports market
fields.trailText: 10.15am: Media companies should buy stakes in sports governing bodies, according to PricewaterhouseCoopers, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
European media companies should buy stakes in sports governing bodies, according to a report published today.

The study by management consultancy PricewaterhouseCoopers urges media companies to be more "ambitious and vigilant" in the lucrative sports market and take a leading role in organisations such as European football body Uefa.

Using the example of Formula One governing body FIA, which has been forced to split its regulatory and commercial operations, the report argues that "individualistic sports" such as tennis and golf are ripe for exploitation.

"Investing directly in the governing body might be a move as they [global sports bodies] grapple with becoming more commercial, transparent and popular in a multichannel environment," says the report.

The authors hope the EU ruling on the FIA - which allows media companies to buy into the commercial arm of the organisation - will "accentuate the distinction between regulatory and commercial functions".

"The soaring value and high level of public interests in rights negotiations means sports governing bodies are coming under greater pressure than ever before to be open and transparent in their commercial negotiations," the report adds.

The report cites a recent investigation by the European Commission, which argued sports federations should give their commercial operations "balanced access to the market" - a clear hint at letting in media companies.

But the PricewaterhouseCoopers advisers warn against other pitfalls in sports investment, including riding roughshod over fans' views and navigating the regulatory maze.

"Sports investment is not as cut and dried as some people might think - a strategic approach to manage this complex landscape will open up untapped opportunities in new geographic markets and sports, and mitigate risks from regulators and politicians," said David Lancefield, author of the report.

Mr Lancefield added that investment in governing bodies was more of a "medium-term opportunity" for media companies.

"They are trying to become more open and that represents an opportunity not only for investment but also for taking advisory roles," he said.

webTitle: Arcadia starts its clearance sale of unwanted brands

fields.headline: Arcadia starts its clearance sale of unwanted brands
fields.trailText: Arcadia's new boss will begin his promised clear-out this week by declaring that Hawkshead, Racing Green and Wade Smith are up for sale. By Andrew Clark.
fields.body:
Arcadia's new boss, Stuart Rose, will begin his promised clear-out of the retail group's clothes brands this week, by officially declaring that Hawkshead, Racing Green and Wade Smith are up for sale.

The announcement comes as pressure intensifies on the poorly performing company - an Icelandic retail consortium has snapped up a 20.1% stake, and is urging the firm to expand internationally.

Mr Rose, who was appointed in November, wants to focus on a handful of Arcadia's better known high street chains. He has identified Burton, Top Shop and Dorothy Perkins as the "core" of the company.

He will set out his strategy in detail on Thursday, when the firm announces interim results, which are expected to show profits of £20m to £23m.

Despite hints from Arcadia that it wants to sell its "fringe" businesses, the level of interest from buyers has been modest. Former Arcadia director Richard Maney has been trying to put together a bid for one brand, while Tesco has been tipped to be interested in Racing Green as a rival for Asda's popular George clothes range.

Arcadia is hoping a formal announcement that some brands are on the block will encourage bidders to come forward. Principles is also under review, and Arcadia is likely to clarify the future of Miss Selfridge - which Mr Rose was quoted as dismissing recently, asking: "Why the hell did we buy it? Good question."

Hawkshead is positioned as an affordable brand "inspired by the great outdoors", while Racing Green largely comprises primary coloured sweaters and blouses. Wade Smith, the Liverpool-based designer retailer, is likely to be sold back to its founder, Robert Wade-Smith, for around £10m.

Arcadia is set to exit Dial, its home shopping joint venture with Littlewoods, which has so far proved disappointing.

Mr Rose was poached from the supermarket chain Iceland to replace Arcadia's long-serving boss, John Hoerner. He faces pressure to expand the firm's presence overseas from a consortium led by Baugur, Iceland's biggest retailer.

Baugur last week stressed that it had no plans to attempt a bid for Arcadia. However, it wants to work with the company on overseas expansion, particularly of Top Shop and Miss Selfridge.

fields.headline: Rivers of newsprint...
fields.standfirst: In the wake of Tory MP John Townend's attack on 'coloured immigrants', Roy Greenslade asks how far the press has come since Enoch Powell's 1968 'rivers of blood' speech
fields.trailText: April 2 How far has the press come since Enoch Powell's 1968 'rivers of blood' speech, asks Roy Greenslade.
fields.body:
Newspapers have come a long way since 1968, haven't they? That was the year Enoch Powell delivered his infamous "rivers of blood" speech advocating a virtual end to black and commonwealth immigration along with a policy of assisted repatriation.

He was immediately sacked from the shadow cabinet by Tory leader Ted Heath. This decision outraged the Daily Telegraph at the time. "Whatever the deficiencies of his statistics and the exaggerations of his language... he was expressing anxieties felt by millions of people... His congenital disposition to push an argument to its logical and linguistic extremes was not sufficient ground for dismissing him."

Last week another Tory MP, John Townend, decided to pick up Powell's baton, claiming that "coloured immigrants" had ruined "our homogeneous Anglo-Saxon society" and were responsible for rising crime.

He also complained about "a great political correctness" which inhibits people from talking about the subject. Immigration had changed "the character of Britain... It is a fact."

So what did the Telegraph say this time? It agreed with Townend: We have been changed by immigration and discussion about that "fact" should not be taboo. It took him to task for disparaging immigrants because "politicians have a duty to avoid comments that are likely to make their fellow citizens feel stigmatised on account of their race."

Having tapped Townend on the knuckles, the editorial writer then defied logic by launching into a rant about the commission for racial equality for ensuring that politicians stick to their "duty". In other words, the Telegraph of 2001 broadly agrees with the Telegraph of 1968: immigrants are unwelcome, but please do not use "linguistic extremes" to say so.

The Daily Mail, which said little about Powell in 1968 but was tacitly in agreement, was very critical of Townend. He is an "undistinguished" MP who "at last manages to achieve a blip on the radar-screen with his offensive rant" and who has been rightly repudiated by William Hague.

But the Mail echoed the Telegraph's concern about the "political atmosphere in which crucial questions [about immigration and asylum seekers] can't be properly addressed". It believed "voters have a right to open, honest debate."

I had to swallow hard on reading that. Does the Mail honestly believe that its one-sided, wholly negative, xenophobic coverage of the plight of asylum seekers has contributed to an "open, honest debate"? More likely, it has fed the prejudices of Townend and his ilk.

The Sun was having none of this. It came up trumps on Friday with a stinging little leader and a commentary by the Tory party's only black parliamentarian, Lord Taylor.

In 1968, when the Sun was not owned by Rupert Murdoch and was a bastion of liberalism, it tore into Powell. It did the same to Townend: "An odious speech from an odious man."

The Mirror, which broke the Townend story and therefore scooped the rest of the press by 24 hours, also showed a commendable consistency. Powell was condemned 33 years ago, and so was Townend this time.

One paper that has gone through a sea-change since 1968, well, several sea-changes, is the Daily Express. It thought Heath "foolish" for having sacked Powell, because he "reflected the feelings of a vast number of people". In Townend's case the paper didn't think it important enough for a leading article, presumably because he has never once been pictured in OK! magazine. But the angle of the Express news story, that Hague was under fire for failing to banish his errant MP, hinted at where its new sympathies might lie if it was allowed to express them.

The real surprise was the absence of anything on the Townend episode in the Times. In fact, a report on Townend's speech was in the paper's first edition but was dumped in favour of a later story about the Tory defector to Labour, Ceri Evans.

I can imagine the dropping jaws of production executives who never have any trouble changing pages to accommodate two good stories at the same time. The Times back bench clearly needs a little technical instruction. Or did the night editor think the Townend story of little consequence? (The editor, Peter Stothard, must be absolved because he was in court all week fighting an important libel action).

It's true that Townend's career, to borrow the Sun's winning phrase, "has been an utter failure", but the implications of his speech, not to mention Hague's repudiation of it, deserved proper coverage. It was a page lead in every other broadsheet.

The Times's slip-up compared badly to 1968, when William Rees-Mogg wrote a superb, unequivocal leader, denouncing Powell's speech as "shameful" and "evil". It was "calculated to inflame hatred between races" and made "a deliberate appeal to racial prejudice", he wrote.

For the record, by the way, the Guardian was altogether less critical of Powell. It regarded his speech as inflammatory but did not think his intention was to fan the flames of "racialism", and noted rather tamely that his call for repatriation was "quite contrary to the official policy of the Conservative party."

This time around, the Guardian was not only certain of Townend's intentions but pointed to the double standards of Hague.

One paper which, despite what people might think, has changed some of its views is the News of the World. In 1968, in praise of Powell, it concluded its editorial: "WE CAN TAKE NO MORE COLOURED PEOPLE. TO DO SO, AS MR POWELL SAYS, IS MADNESS".

Yesterday, it didn't mention Townend. If it had, I happen to know it would have said no such thing.

fields.headline: Lost track
fields.standfirst:
Last year's Hatfield train crash killed four men, paralysed Britain and shattered confidence in rail transport. The culprit was a simple broken rail. In the first of two extracts from his definitive book on the disaster, Ian Jack asks how a technology dating back to Babylonian times could be so fragile

Special report: the Hatfield train crash
fields.trailText: Last year's Hatfield train crash killed four men, paralysed Britain and shattered confidence in rail transport. The culprit was a simple broken rail. In the first of two extracts from his definitive book on the disaster,  Ian Jack  asks how a technology dating back to Babylonian times could be so fragile
fields.body:
About 16 miles north of central London, just before the town of Hatfield, Hertfordshire, there is a small, wooded valley with a stream and a pond at the bottom: Howe Dell. A sign declares that the dell is "a valuable urban wildlife site". Hornbeam, ash, oak and willow grow in the valley; also carpets of bluebells and dog's mercury - though, of course, no flowers were visible when I went there last December, nor any of the wrens, chaffinches or blue tits which the sign says haunt Howe Dell. It was a grey afternoon of bare trees and earth sodden from the wettest English autumn since 1727, the year records began. Men from the local housing estates walked their dogs through clinging mud. Electric trains passed close by with their windows lit - dinky little reading lights in the first-class carriages of the expresses - but they travelled slowly.

The railway forms the fourth side of Howe Dell, its eastern and most definite boundary, with a high, steel fence to keep out people who might damage the railway or get themselves killed. The tracks of the main line from London King's Cross to the north of England and Scotland curve here, perhaps because the engineers who surveyed the route in the late 1840s wanted to avoid the cost of embankments and bridges over Howe Dell, or because the landowner was stubborn, or because the Great Northern Railway wanted Hatfield's station to be located in the village rather than an inconvenient mile outside it. Whatever the cause, the four tracks coming down from London bend to the right and east - a gentle enough curve which trains had safely negotiated for 150 years, until October 17 2000.

On that day at 12.23pm, the 12.10 King's Cross to Leeds express entered the curve at 115mph - the maximum permitted speed for this stretch of track - and came off the rails. Four people died. They were: Robert Alcorn, 37, a pilot from New Zealand who was travelling to Leeds to fly a Learjet from there to Jersey; Steve Arthur, 46, Alcorn's employer as the owner of the Atlantic Gulf Aviation Company, married with two children, of Pease Pottage, West Sussex; Leslie Gray, 43, a solicitor, of Tuxford, Nottinghamshire; Peter Monkhouse, 50, managing director of an advertising company, married with three children, of Headingley, Leeds.

All four men had been in the buffet car when its roof was ripped off as it struck one of the steel stanchions placed regularly at the side of the track to support the line's overhead electric wires. It threatened no record in recent British railway crashes (Southall, 1997, seven dead; Ladbroke Grove, 1999, 31 dead). But no other railway accident in British history has led to the degree of public anger, managerial panic, political confusion, blame and counter-blame that came in the wake of the Hatfield crash. In fact, outside wars and nuclear accidents, it is hard to think of any technological failure which has had such lasting and widespread effects (to those not directly involved, not struggling for life in the Atlantic or bereaved on land, the Titanic was simply a very thrilling story, a chilling entertainment).

A week or so later, when overfilled rivers began to flood low-lying England and the first people were emptied from their sandbagged homes into boats, the unsettling impression grew of Britain as an unsound country, weakly equipped, underskilled, easily made chaotic and only superficially modern; an incompetent society. "We must be the laughing stock of Europe," people said. The reason was elementary: movement. People could not move, in an economy - the world's fourth or fifth largest - which depended on millions of everyday, necessary journeys. Few trains ran; those that did ran unreliably, even to the revised schedules that sometimes doubled or trebled the normal journey times. Travellers tried other methods; motorways became impassable, domestic flights overbooked. At railway stations, even aboard a train itself, would-be passengers were advised to travel "only if your journey is really necessary"; the train may depart, but it may not arrive - nothing could be guaranteed. In any case, what was necessity? Arriving at the office? Reaching a funeral? Getting home? People old enough to remember then - long trains packed with troops crawling through blackouts and air raids - compared that period favourably with the present. Then, there was an enemy; Britain was a more capable nation.

Every day the newspapers reported a new crisis of trust and confidence in the railways and the businesses which own them (new rail horror: my journey to hell). What was the cause of this crash and these deaths? On the night of October 17, various theories were aired - a terrorist bomb, vandalism, some fault with the train, driver error, signal error. In a 1937 leaflet on the evolution of rail transport, Charles E Lee wrote that a railway "is merely a specialised form of road designed to meet limited needs". According to Lee, the earliest evidence of railways by this definition occurs in the Babylonian empire ruled by Belus, about 2245 BC. Around this time - not much after middle stone age families were sitting around Howe Dell, chipping flints - Babylonian stonemasons were instructed to build certain imperial roads as two parallel lines of stone, 5ft (or three cubits) apart, so that vehicles of the same 5ft axle-width could be pulled along by mules and horses which walked down the centre of the track. This system made haulage easier, but it seems to have contained no means of making sure that a vehicle stayed on the track.

Railways by their more exact definition, as prepared tracks which by their construction keep the vehicle in place and guide it independently of human or animal interference, were probably first known in Greece. Around 400 BC, Greek ships were pulled across the isthmus at Corinth on wheeled cradles which travelled along grooves cut into the rock. A prolonged and rail-less interval followed the collapse of Greek and Roman civilisations, until, around the 12th century, German miners began to spread across central Europe in the search for exploitable seams of metal ore: iron, lead, silver, copper and gold. Illustrated books published in Germany in the 16th century have lively woodcuts of bearded men in pointed woollen headwear pushing small trucks from the mine's mouth on wooden rails.

But keeping the trucks on the wooden track remained a large problem when both wheel and rail were flat at their point of contact, with nothing to prevent the one leaving the other. Various methods evolved, but the breakthrough was the flange, the edge which extends beyond the wheel's running surface and prevents it going astray. The first documented railway in England (Wollaton, near Nottingham, 1603) probably had trucks with flanged wheels. Like almost every railway built in Britain over the next two centuries, the Wollaton line transported coal from a pithead; and as the coal industry grew so railways and flanged wheels proliferated. Continental Europe, when it came to import the technology of flanged wheels and iron rails from Britain in the last quarter of the 18th century, knew it as the voie anglaise or the englischer Schienenweg - the English railway.

In 1821, when George Stephenson was appointed engineer on the world's first public railway, the Stockton and Darlington line, the width between the rails was 4ft 8in. And this became one of the world's most ubiquitous measurements. Of the 750,000 route miles of railway that exist in the world today, 60% measure 4ft 8 in from rail to rail. Trains followed this gauge to the battlefields of the American Civil War and the Somme, into the Vatican City, to the tragic little terminus under the gate at Auschwitz. On this gauge, Buster Keaton outwitted the Union army. Across it, many silent heroines were tied. And, of course, on October 17 last year it was also the gauge that carried the 12.10 north from London, with 170 passengers, including four men of middle age named Alcorn, Arthur, Monkhouse and Gray. Five minutes out of King's Cross, somewhere between Finsbury Park and Hornsey, if my frequent experience is any guide, an announcement was made from the buffet car. It was open and selling "traditional and gourmet sandwiches, hot toasties, pastries, and hot and cold drinks". The four men rose from their first-class seats and swayed up the train. Alexandra Palace went by on its green hill. The train accelerated and bore on through the tunnels and stations of the north London suburbs: New Southgate, Oakleigh Park, New Barnet, Potters Bar. The names of the stations became too blurred by speed to read, the tunnels no more than a momentary darkness and a change of noise and pressure that shuddered the carriage windows.

Thirteen miles out: the first countryside - cows, woods, what might still be a farmhouse. The four men were by now sitting before white tablecloths and waiting for lunch. Alcorn sat across from Arthur at one table, Monkhouse and Gray at another over the aisle. Behind the bar, small bottles of Merlot Cabernet jiggled in a glass cabinet. Steam hissed from the tea and coffee machine. Fourteen miles out, Brookmans Park. A mile and 30 seconds later, Welham Green. Some flat modern factories and warehouses appeared on the left with large and legible signs: Soundcraft, Tesco, Falcon for games, puzzles and playing cards, Mitsubishi. If any of the four men looked out of the window at this point, Mitsubishi would be the last word he ever read.

The first rails to be made completely of metal came out of the Dowlais ironworks in South Wales in 1791. They were cast iron, much more durable than wood, but also brittle; they broke. The great quest in the 210-year history of rails since then has been to find a rail that will not break. The answer, for a time, was wrought iron, which is what Stephenson used on the Stockton and Darlington line, and again later on the world's first passenger railway, the Liverpool and Manchester. They also broke. By 1832, only two years after the railway opened, it was noticed that fragments of iron littered the track. By 1839, every one of the line's original rails had been replaced.

Eleven years later, when the Great Northern Railway opened its main line between London and Peterborough via Hatfield, the pattern was repeated. The rails there also soon began to chip and fragment under the weight of heavy coal traffic. By 1865, the entire line had been re-railed and so railways began to experiment with steel.

British engineers followed European practice and welded the lengths of rail together. The tiny gap between each rail length disappeared. Then, in 1967, 49 passengers died when a train derailed on unwelded track at Hither Green in south London. The cause was a rail which had fractured at its weakest point, the bolt-holes at the join. This became the standard British rail, specification BS11-113A. In 1995, as part of regular repair and maintenance work, new rails of this kind were laid at Howe Dell. Like most rails in Britain, they were made by British Steel (now part of an Anglo-Dutch company, Corus) at its plant in Workington, Cumbria. They weren't quite standard. When rails are expected to carry an extra stress, they are especially hardened at the factory by quenching them with water as soon as they leave the rollers, a process called "mill heat treatment". These were mill heat treated (MHT) rails; they were to be laid on the curve. And curves bring their own problems.

Engineering is often easier to depict than to describe. One striking thing about engineers is how often they want to draw things; words not being up to the work of describing the technical reality. During the research for this piece, I was handed several instant drawings. In a phenomenon known as "the dynamics of the wheel/rail interface", drawing is especially useful. One day in November I took the train from London to Peterborough - a very slow train that moved gingerly over the crash site - to meet a young engineer, Philip Haigh. "Give us a pen," he said at one point, and then: "Do you have a 5p piece?" He drew round the circumference of the coin to produce a circle with a diameter of about in or 2cm. That was the size of the contact area between a wheel and a rail when train and track were in perfect equilibrium. Perfection requires the straightest rail and the truest wheel; but if these ideal conditions were met, Haigh said, then only a in strip would wear along the rail top (which is 2in wide). In an electric locomotive, 100 tons of vehicle and machinery could be shared among eight wheels and eight of these 5p contact spots. Each 5p would support a weight of 12.5 tons. Given a powerful engine, the friction caused by turning all eight wheels against two rails would easily haul a train of 1,000 tons at 115 miles an hour.

And when the train reaches a curve? "The contact spot shifts for both wheel and rail," Haigh said. What happens is this: the wheels are asked to obey a new direction by the rail. That instruction, combined with centrifugal force, pushes the wheel against the rail on the outside of a curve. The shoulder between flange and wheel hits the corner of the rail. At low speed, that hardly matters, the train will scrape round. At high speed, say 125mph, the train needs some corrective to try to restore its equilibrium. Therefore the track is "canted" - tilted like the racing track in a velodrome, with the outside rail the higher of the two. But different kinds of train travel at different speeds and would need different levels of cant if their equilibrium was always to be perfect. Engineers reach a compromise: a cant that will work at different speeds, though not perfectly for all of them. At high speed, the wheels still shift position and put an extra stress on the higher rail, attacking its inner corner, the corner from which the gauge is measured: the gauge corner.

Rails are made to take pressure from the top. Exposed to this different, sideways pressure from, say, 60 fast trains a day, seven days a week, they can begin to crack: gauge corner cracking. Curves are by no means the only cause of damaged rails. The steel may contain flaws, little voids that are difficult and sometimes impossible to detect with the human eye. Wheels that are out of shape and not perfectly circular can batter and dent the rail. The ground beneath can subside by an inch and twist the rail. The railhead can flake. The more engineers I talked to, the more I saw rails in a new light; not as simple and indestructible - the Iron Road - but as complicated and vulnerable. Railway engineers have always seen them as a technology that needs constant vigilance.

At a railway engineering exhibition in Birmingham, I met a retired engineer, Bill Armstrong, who spoke about the track as "a living thing". Rails were always shifting, settling, creeping this way or that. As the chief permanent way engineer for a large part of Yorkshire, he'd been required to walk every mile of his track twice a year - many dozens of miles on foot, twice a year, peering at the rails. The inspectors under him walked every mile of track in their care at least once a month; in turn, the sub-inspectors under them walked it at least once a fortnight. In this way, every mile of line was patrolled not less than twice a week. Passenger lines were inspected no fewer than three times, usually on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays. "We had a saying," Armstrong said. "The uninspected inevitably deteriorates."

We were talking inside one of the bleak halls of Birmingham's National Exhibition Centre. The Hatfield crash had cast a gloom over this year's fair. At a couple of seminars in side rooms I'd heard speakers despair of the national culture: "a dearth of engineers . . . a basic lack of engineering competence . . . not enough people who understand how the infrastructure works or behaves."

Armstrong said: "How many folk in this country, even the ones who're interested in railways, know what happens below the wheel? With them, it's always the wheel upwards. Below the wheel matters. You know the trouble with England? We've never had the guts to rip things down and start again. It's all make do and mend." He had an analogy. "It's like having a wife who keeps asking you to paint the front door when the more important job is to get the damp seen to in the cellar."

He spoke about an everyday garden nuisance: the weed. "In the old days you'd never see a weed on the line. That was when you had six chaps working from the same hut, looking after their bit of track. Weeds are evidence of neglect, they clog the drainage in the ballast, the ballast becomes uneven, the tracks sink or twist."

And now? "The days of a line being patrolled by a man every day have gone. But it's worse than that. Not only have the maintenance structures disappeared, but the knowledge of what the structures did has disappeared."

The great change happened in the middle years of the 90s, its centrepiece the Railways Act, which was passed by the Conservative government under John Major in 1993. Seven years later, at 12.23 pm last October 17, the 12.10 to Leeds came off the tracks. The two events are connected.

There was a fracture on the outer high rail at the Hatfield curve. The locomotive and the train's first two coaches passed over it safely, but the shock and pressure ran through the rail like a lightning bolt. The pressure found other cracks. Instantly, more than a 100ft of rail shattered into 300 pieces. The other eight vehicles came off the track. Passengers fell over each other, necks hit the backs of seats. Scalding water exploded in the buffet car. Apart from the dead, two buffet attendants and two other passengers were seriously injured, another 66 passengers slightly so. Inside a length of 600yds and a time of 17 seconds, a train travelling at 115mph had broken apart and shuddered to a halt.

Ambulances came. Howe Dell flickered with flashing lights and the arcing sparks of acetylene torches. By 2.30pm, the first officers had arrived from government agencies: the Health and Safety Executive, its quaintly named subdivision Her Majesty's Railway Inspectorate, and the British Transport Police. For the next four days they bent among the ballast and the grass and picked up pieces of steel. Eventually, they reconstructed the assassin, the rail, and named the assassin's weapon, gauge corner cracking. A remote technical term entered the common language. But if rail and cracks were Gavrilo Princip and his pistol, who was the Kaiser in the case? The truth is that there were several kaisers - stubborn men in love with a political idea. One of them lived just down the track at Huntingdon: the former prime minister, John Major.

"Give us a pen," he said at one point, and then: "Do you have a 5p piece?" He drew round the circumference of the coin to produce a circle with a diameter of about in or 2cm. That was the size of the contact area between a wheel and a rail when train and track were in perfect equilibrium. Perfection requires the straightest rail and the truest wheel; but if these ideal conditions were met, Haigh said, then only a in strip would wear along the rail top (which is 2in wide). In an electric locomotive, 100 tons of vehicle and machinery could be shared among eight wheels and eight of these 5p contact spots. Each 5p would support a weight of 12.5 tons. Given a powerful engine, the friction caused by turning all eight wheels against two rails would easily haul a train of 1,000 tons at 115 miles an hour. And when the train reaches a curve? "The contact spot shifts for both wheel and rail," Haigh said. What happens is this: the wheels are asked to obey a new direction by the rail. That instruction, combined with centrifugal force, pushes the wheel against the rail on the outside of a curve. The shoulder between flange and wheel hits the corner of the rail. At low speed, that hardly matters, the train will scrape round. At high speed, say 125mph, the train needs some corrective to try to restore its equilibrium. Therefore the track is "canted" - tilted like the racing track in a velodrome, with the outside rail the higher of the two. But different kinds of train travel at different speeds and would need different levels of cant if their equilibrium was always to be perfect. Engineers reach a compromise: a cant that will work at different speeds, though not perfectly for all of them. At high speed, the wheels still shift position and put an extra stress on the higher rail, attacking its inner corner, the corner from which the gauge is measured: the gauge corner. Rails are made to take pressure from the top. Exposed to this different, sideways pressure from, say, 60 fast trains a day, seven days a week, they can begin to crack: gauge corner cracking. Curves are by no means the only cause of damaged rails. The steel may contain flaws, little voids that are difficult and sometimes impossible to detect with the human eye. Wheels that are out of shape and not perfectly circular can batter and dent the rail. The ground beneath can subside by an inch and twist the rail. The railhead can flake. The more engineers I talked to, the more I saw rails in a new light; not as simple and indestructible - the Iron Road - but as complicated and vulnerable. Railway engineers have always seen them as a technology that needs constant vigilance. At a railway engineering exhibition in Birmingham, I met a retired engineer, Bill Armstrong, who spoke about the track as "a living thing". Rails were always shifting, settling, creeping this way or that. As the chief permanent way engineer for a large part of Yorkshire, he'd been required to walk every mile of his track twice a year - many dozens of miles on foot, twice a year, peering at the rails. The inspectors under him walked every mile of track in their care at least once a month; in turn, the sub-inspectors under them walked it at least once a fortnight. In this way, every mile of line was patrolled not less than twice a week. Passenger lines were inspected no fewer than three times, usually on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays. "We had a saying," Armstrong said. "The uninspected inevitably deteriorates." We were talking inside one of the bleak halls of Birmingham's National Exhibition Centre. The Hatfield crash had cast a gloom over this year's fair. At a couple of seminars in side rooms I'd heard speakers despair of the national culture: "a dearth of engineers . . . a basic lack of engineering competence . . . not enough people who understand how the infrastructure works or behaves." Armstrong said: "How many folk in this country, even the ones who're interested in railways, know what happens below the wheel? With them, it's always the wheel upwards. Below the wheel matters. You know the trouble with England? We've never had the guts to rip things down and start again. It's all make do and mend." He had an analogy. "It's like having a wife who keeps asking you to paint the front door when the more important job is to get the damp seen to in the cellar." He spoke about an everyday garden nuisance: the weed. "In the old days you'd never see a weed on the line. That was when you had six chaps working from the same hut, looking after their bit of track. Weeds are evidence of neglect, they clog the drainage in the ballast, the ballast becomes uneven, the tracks sink or twist." And now? "The days of a line being patrolled by a man every day have gone. But it's worse than that. Not only have the maintenance structures disappeared, but the knowledge of what the structures did has disappeared." The great change happened in the middle years of the 90s, its centrepiece the Railways Act, which was passed by the Conservative government under John Major in 1993. Seven years later, at 12.23 pm last October 17, the 12.10 to Leeds came off the tracks. The two events are connected. There was a fracture on the outer high rail at the Hatfield curve. The locomotive and the train's first two coaches passed over it safely, but the shock and pressure ran through the rail like a lightning bolt. The pressure found other cracks. Instantly, more than a 100ft of rail shattered into 300 pieces. The other eight vehicles came off the track. Passengers fell over each other, necks hit the backs of seats. Scalding water exploded in the buffet car. Apart from the dead, two buffet attendants and two other passengers were seriously injured, another 66 passengers slightly so. Inside a length of 600yds and a time of 17 seconds, a train travelling at 115mph had broken apart and shuddered to a halt. Ambulances came. Howe Dell flickered with flashing lights and the arcing sparks of acetylene torches. By 2.30pm, the first officers had arrived from government agencies: the Health and Safety Executive, its quaintly named subdivision Her Majesty's Railway Inspectorate, and the British Transport Police. For the next four days they bent among the ballast and the grass and picked up pieces of steel. Eventually, they reconstructed the assassin, the rail, and named the assassin's weapon, gauge corner cracking. A remote technical term entered the common language. But if rail and cracks were Gavrilo Princip and his pistol, who was the Kaiser in the case? The truth is that there were several kaisers - stubborn men in love with a political idea. One of them lived just down the track at Huntingdon: the former prime minister, John Major.  This is an edited extract from The Crash that Stopped Britain, published by Granta. fields.headline: Saddlers slip in final furlong
fields.trailText: Who wants entertainment when there are points to be won? A competitive game in a buzzing atmosphere did nobody here any favours with the other teams in the top six all stockpiling three points.
fields.body:
Who wants entertainment when there are points to be won? A competitive game in a buzzing atmosphere did nobody here any favours with the other teams in the top six all stockpiling three points.

It left Walsall, who made most of the running, off the pace for automatic promotion. "The hill's getting pushed a bit steeper," conceded the manager Ray Graydon. "But I won't give it up until it's mathematically impossible for us to do it."

The maths are that Walsall now sit seven points behind second-placed Millwall, about one point for every chance they sent into the crowd behind Tony Warner's goal here. The locals groaned time after time as set pieces were overhit and shots skied, and to complete a torturous afternoon Millwall almost nicked it at the death through Paul Moody and Christophe Kinet.

Millwall must be glad to see the back of March, a month that brought them only one win in six matches, but April will hardly come as a relief: sixth-placed Stoke visit the New Den tomorrow night and the leaders Rotherham follow them on Saturday.

Yet Don Goodman, Walsall's lively acquisition from Motherwell, labelled Millwall "the best team in the division" and by that definition a point was not to be sniffed at. With the Saddlers' hopes unseated, Millwall enter a three-horse promotion race with Rotherham and Reading. A fretful springtime starts here.

fields.headline: Now Karadzic must be jailed
fields.standfirst: Special report: war crimes in the former Yugoslavia
fields.trailText: Mr Milosevic's imprisonment should speed up the arrest on war crimes charges of his former henchmen, senior Western envoys in Bosnia said.
fields.body:
Mr Milosevic's imprisonment should speed up the arrest on war crimes charges of his former henchmen, senior Western envoys in Bosnia said.

The Bosnian Serb leader Radovan Karadzic and his military commander, Ratko Mladic, have been indicted by the Hague tribunal but have evaded arrest.

"I think Milosevic was the key one, the key perpetrator in all of this, and the signal to all of them now is: 'It's time to give yourself up. If you don't, we are coming after you because people deserve justice,' " Jacques Klein, head of the UN mission, said.
Reuters

fields.headline: Sheffield fancy deserves dandier
fields.trailText: The biggest First Division crowd of the season turned out for the 100th Sheffield derby as Carl Asaba sealed victory for United.
fields.body:
This may have been parochial. It was hardly irrelevant. At 38,433 the biggest First Division crowd of the season at the league's 100th Sheffield derby yesterday could never be that. Eventually support on this scale will get a team worthy of its backing.

"To think some people have talked about mergers," snorted United's manager Neil Warnock. "If Wednesday were in the Premiership they'd get 38,500 every week; if we were we'd get at least 25,000."

That may be so but it is not going to be tested next season. At the moment these are two average teams, though 10 games ago, anchored at the bottom of the table, Wednesday supporters would have grasped happily at that description. Since then Peter Shreeves, having taken over from Paul Jewell on a caretaker basis, has overseen six wins to make the Owls safe.

Under Warnock's stewardship United are having their best season for years but, though this win takes them within five points of the play-off places, they are surely not good enough to go up.

Stranger things have happened, though, as Warnock pointed out. "All we can do is keep up the pressure on the Prestons and Forests. We've nothing to lose."

The game's first goal came six minutes into the second half. Des Walker allowed a hefty clearance by the United goalkeeper Simon Tracey to bounce and was then beaten to the ball by Carl Asaba.

The big Londoner, immense throughout, held the ball, then laid it off perfectly for his hitherto anonymous partner Laurent D'Jaffo to shoot unchallenged past Kevin Pressman.

Having made one, Asaba scored another as Wednesday, pressing for the equaliser, were caught on the break. Bobby Ford found Paul Devlin unmarked on the right wing and Asaba did wonderfully well to guide his header from the resulting cross beyond the scrambling Pressman.

It looked like game over but the awkward looking Sibon's touch in pulling down a bouncing cross was superb and the insouciance with which he then turned and volleyed into the corner wonderful to behold.

Again Wednesday pressed but, having already used all three substitutes, one of whom replaced the winger Alan Quinn, whose broken left leg will keep him out until next season, they were reduced to 10 men when Ashley West wood pulled a hamstring. With the visitors prepared to pull every man back behind the ball, it was a disadvantage Wednesday never looked likely to overcome.

In fact United should have added to their lead but David Kelly, his hair turned grey during a long career of never quite fulfilling early promise, shot feebly wide of goal after being set up by Asaba and Devlin.

"I said there'd be some setbacks but it's a temporary one," said Shreeves. "The main thing is we can still get out of trouble." Once Wednesday's survival is confirmed, the club have promised to offer him the job on a permanent basis.

fields.headline: Robins remain on song
fields.trailText: The Cheltenham Festival may have been cancelled, but the spa town's football club look the form horses to make the play-offs after moving into the top seven thanks to a hat-trick either side of half-time by the veteran striker Neil Grayson.
fields.body:
The Cheltenham Festival may have been cancelled, but the spa town's football club look the form horses to make the play-offs after moving into the top seven thanks to a hat-trick either side of half-time by the veteran striker Neil Grayson.

Cheltenham extended their unbeaten run to nine matches, but there was only one team in it in the opening 30 minutes as City created space and chances at will. Cheltenham left the 36-year old Grayson operating on his own up front and looked negligible as an attacking force until the striker turned the game on its head.

Cardiff were a goal up after only five minutes, Scott Young heading in Andy Legg's hanging free-kick after taking advantage of some slack marking. The turning point came after 36 minutes. Grayson had been booked for a foul on Young and, fired up by what he saw as an injustice, brought his side back into contention after hitting home a rebound after Michael Duff's cross had been met by Mark Yates's right foot.

Five minutes later no one followed Grayson to the near post where he enjoyed a free header and he turned Rhys Weston inside out before sliding in his third three minutes after the restart.

"I was not happy with the early kick-off on a Sunday, but the police insisted," the Cheltenham manager Steve Cotterill said. "After a per- formance like that, perhaps we should have more of them."

webTitle: Leader: Milosevic now accountable to justice

fields.headline: Milosevic in the dock
fields.standfirst:
Now there is a chance for a full accounting

Special report: Serbia
Special report: war crimes in the former Yugoslavia
fields.trailText: It is a pity that it took six months. But yesterday's arrest of Slobodan Milosevic is hugely welcome for all that.
fields.body:
It is a pity that it took six months. But yesterday's arrest of Slobodan Milosevic is hugely welcome for all that. His threat to kill himself rather than surrender turned out to be a characteristic bluff, a final act of cowardice by a man who has spent his political life hiding behind others. Milosevic seems to have a particular talent for self-delusion, a genius for denial. Now, confined in a solitary prison cell in Belgrade, all pretence and bluster are stripped away. All the toadies and cronies, the thugs and fixers who surrounded him have slipped off into the shadows one by one.

As a prisoner, he will have no special privileges, the Serb authorities say. As an arraigned $100m fraudster, he in any case faces years of lonely reckoning. But alone with himself, and with nobody to bolster his self-justifying illusions, perhaps Milosevic will also finally begin to confront his responsibility for the epic destruction and misery of his years in power: for his many crimes not just against his own people, but against common humanity.

He is not alone in being called to account. That the leadership in Belgrade was not of one mind in ordering Milosevic's detention last Friday is only too evident. Zoran Djindjic, Serbia's reformist prime minister elected last December, gambled with the loyalty of the army when he sent the police to the old dictator's mansion. It was a risk that almost failed to pay off. He gambled, too, that there would be no sudden, mass rush of hardline support from Milosevic's Socialists. In this he calculated correctly.

But in acting as he did, presumably to secure continued US financial aid and support for Serbia's economic regeneration, Mr Djindjic directly confronted Vojislav Kostunica. The popular Yugoslav president has resisted a purge of the Milosevic old guard and fiercely rebuffed the claims of the Hague international tribunal for the extradition of suspects. That Mr Kostunica, after a fraught few hours, was grudgingly brought onside was both an advance and a narrow squeak for Mr Djindjic and his backers.

But Mr Djindjic did, thankfully, prevail - and from that success must now proceed Serbia's far too long postponed inquiry into its collective recent past. The president, in particular, should understand that a full accounting for the Milosevic years, at last a practicable possibility, will ultimately produce a stronger, healthier Serbian nation. Humiliation of the Serbs is not on the west's agenda, especially after the recent reminder in Macedonia and Presevo of what potentially valuable allies they can be.

What the rest of Europe wants and expects is a Serbia that, no longer threatening its neighbours and at peace with itself, can become in time a full, productive member of the EU and other institutions. From this will flow the essential reassurance that is a precondition for settlements with Kosovo and Montenegro and for lasting peace in Bosnia. One antidote to ethnic Albanian extremism, for example, is a democratic Serbia thoroughly purged of all its guilty men.

It is vital that Serbs be given the full facts about the way in which Milosevic deceived, divided, betrayed and ruined their country. This activity extended well beyond fraud to assassination at home and abroad. But it is equally vital that Milosevic's many war-crime victims, in Bosnia and elsewhere, also see justice done. These claims overlap. To avoid further wrangling over extradition, why not convene a court in Belgrade under the joint auspices of the Hague and the Serbian state? Lay out Milosevic's lies for all to see. Televise it round the Balkans. Tell it how it was. And then send him down.

webTitle: Iffy decision keeps Preston on course

fields.headline: Iffy decision keeps Preston on course
fields.trailText: With five of their remaining eight games at home and clear water between them and the chasing pack, Preston can claim to be favourites for the final play-off spot and can view life amongst the Premiership elite as a realistic possibility.
fields.body:
With five of their remaining eight games at home and clear water between them and the chasing pack, Preston can claim to be favourites for the final play-off spot and can view life amongst the Premiership elite as a realistic possibility.

Not that their manager David Moyes would permit such thoughts to circulate too loudly. Moyes is in the apprentice stage of an already successful career but he is wise enough to stamp on any premature back-slapping.

After a 19-year hiatus in the League's lower reaches, Preston's progress has been as consistent as it is impressive. The 37-year-old Glaswegian has kept faith with the bulk of the squad that claimed the Second Division title, adding talents such as the young strikers David Healy and Richard Cresswell.

If good fortune has a part to play, Preston appear destined to find themselves in the end-of-season shake-up. They survived against a committed Gillingham side thanks in no small part to the generosity of the referee Uriah Rennie, who viewed the Gills striker Iffy Onoura's tumble over Teuvo Moilanen as bad balance rather than bad goalkeeping.

Having escaped a penalty Preston assumed territorial advantage but struggled to make inroads against the well-organised visitors. Moyes was satisfied with the points, however, in the context of a run that has seen only one defeat in 10 games.Similar progress before the end of May could well see his team emerge as surprise visitors to Anfield and Old Trafford next season.

fields.headline: Egil eyes look on the bright side for Taylor
fields.trailText: West Brom enhance their promotion chances as Egil Olsen pays tribute to Graham Taylor, "one of the greatest managers ever".
fields.body:
Graham Taylor's managerial career has invariably hit more peaks than troughs. However, it was ironic that the man most responsible for the criticism of his disastrous spell in charge of England, the former Norway manager Egil Olsen, was here to witness the beginning of the end of Taylor's Watford odyssey.

This latest defeat, Watford's 14th in 23 games, shattered their play-off hopes and surely snuffed out any chance that Taylor had of signing off his 29-year coaching career with yet another promotion.

However, there was no disguising the professional respect held by Olsen for him: "He's made a big impact in English football and is one of the greatest managers ever. He is much better and much more pleasant than the English press who tried to kill him."

Olsen, who retired from football after a disappointing spell in charge of Wimbledon last season, believes that Taylor, aged 56, could return to the game: "He will be a huge loss to English football but he could come back. He's still young enough to continue - younger than me anyway."

But despite such platitudes there is no disguising the fact that Watford were woefully inept against a West Bromwich side who look likely themselves to land a play-off place.

Taylor's side conceded two quick goals at the start of the second half: James Quinn neatly scored his first of the season and then a hopeful punt by Neil Clement was misjudged by Watford's goalkeeper Espen Baardsen, who saw the ball loop over his right hand on the edge of the area. webTitle: Comment: Milosevic's arrest not end of troubles

fields.headline: A beginning, not an end
fields.standfirst:
Milosevic may be behind bars, but the forces he unleashed are still at large

Special report: Serbia
Special report: war crimes in the former Yugoslavia
fields.trailText: Milosevic may be behind bars, but the forces he unleashed are still at large.
fields.body:
The arrest of Slobodan Milosevic is the second act in a three-part drama. The first was his fall from power, the second act is his disgrace in Serbia and the third act will begin when and if he is dispatched to the Hague. But it is a drama which is being watched in rather different ways by western governments and by the peoples of the region to which Milosevic brought so much suffering.

Western governments see mainly the progressive humiliation of the leader they blame for involving them in conflicts they wished to avoid, a man who challenged them and tricked them and made them look alternately craven and stupid. People in the region, on the other hand, had already consigned Milosevic, as a man, to history. Naturally he has his supporters in Serbia, Montenegro and the Bosnian Serb entity, Republika Srpska, but most are less true supporters than people who have been trying to keep him out of court because they do not want to go down with him.

Then there are those, whether from the Milosevic camp or from outside it, who want to inherit some of the assets he once controlled and inherit some of the influence he once exercised. They care for or about him only because they are looking out for themselves. Just as his supporters see him only as an instrument, his more principled enemies are less interested in his judgment and punishment in itself than in the fact that such a judgment should open the way to judgment on many others. More important still, they hope that it could lead to the definitive isolation of the dark political forces that Milosevic was able to concentrate.

Given the normal stereotype of Balkan characteristics, it is curious that the west may be more vengeful in its attitude towards Milosevic as an individual than those who were his local opponents. The critical question in Serbia is not whether Milosevic is going to pay the price for his crimes, but whether the continuity, partial but real, between the attitudes of the Milosevic years and those prevailing now can be broken.

"Half of the present government should be in the courtroom at the Hague," one Serb human rights worker snapped, when talking about Milosevic. President Vojislav Kostunica may not be one of those who should be there, but he has set himself up, since overthrowing Milosevic, as a kind of nationalist beacon. "I see a new phase of folklore beginning to develop," a worker for an international agency said, "in which both Milosevic and Nato are the villains, and Serbia once again the victim."

The Milosevic arrest is an important moment in the Serbian political struggle, which is between those who want a limited and essentially fraudulent settlement of the accounts of the last 10 years and those who want the process taken through to a proper end. But it is not yet a victory for the latter, because groups with very different ideas about Serbian renewal are trying to use Milosevic for different ends. A continued failure to arrest him would have been a clear signal that the wrong people were in charge in Serbia or that nationalist forces, whether of the old or the new kind, were too strong for the more realistic and liberal elements in the government to risk confrontation. But his arrest is not a clear signal that the opposite is true.

Serbia's political orientation is important throughout former Yugoslavia, particularly in Bosnia, Montenegro and Kosovo. In these places, it is not so much that, after the brief excitement of the siege of Milosevic's home, it is back to business as usual. It is back, rather, to unfinished business as usual. In Bosnia, especially, there is disinterest in the civil charges Milosevic faces. "This issue will only come alive here if he goes to the Hague," says the journalist Amra Kebo, "because we could not see how the international community could have Milosevic at the Hague and not have Radovan Karadzic and Ratko Mladic there as well."

The international troops in Bosnia, notably slow in picking up men indicted by the Hague, would have to start work in earnest. But the most pressing problems with Serbia now are obviously not to do with Milosevic but with Kostunica, who has encouraged and helped the unreconstructed nationalists in Republika Srpska. How the Milosevic arrest and the political and legal manoeuvring that follows will ultimately affect Kostunica's standing, and therefore the behaviour of political leaders in Republika Srpska, is a key question for Bosnia.

In Montenegro, those advocating independence hope that the arrest will dishearten the opponents of independence led by the Montenegro branch of Milosevic's party. The blow for them comes as the campaigning begins for elections next month in which the pro-independence parties could well win a victory big enough to proceed swiftly to a successful referendum on pulling out of the federation. Again, the question is whether Kostunica has already replaced Milosevic as a factor in the morale of the so-called Yugoslav bloc of Montenegro parties.

The interest of Kosovans in the Montenegrin elections is that formal separation from Serbia would strengthen the case for Kosovo's independence, and hence their more distant interest in the Milosevic case is in whether it might help push Montenegro one way or another. In Macedonia, even more distant from the impact of the arrest, the interest is in how the outcome in Kosovo, after a Montenegrin separation, might affect the troubled border region. "Everything in former Yugoslavia, unfortunately, is connected to everything else," observed a diplomat in Belgrade. The connections mainly lead outward from Serbia, whose political condition can still have an important effect on events elsewhere, even though the wars of the 90s are over, and it is now impoverished and desperate for aid.

The broad picture in the region is that nationalist extremism, Serbian and other, has a considerable capacity to regroup and to reinvent itself. In spite of the military victories, and in spite of the international occupation of substantial areas and extensive international interference elsewhere, there is no simple transition from bad to good.

The interferers waver and prevaricate, or decide, without consultation, to disengage. Old nationalists are replaced by new ones with less chequered pasts and "moderates" often disappoint those who voted for them or turn out to be opportunists. Although the number who do so may be falling, insecurity, real or imagined, still leads many ordinary people to vote on an ethnic nationalist ticket. Even in Croatia, furthest out of the woods, rightwing forces are still substantial, and help sustain Croat extremism in Bosnia.

The arrest of Milosevic was imposed on Serbia by the United States, which may now go on to impose an early transfer to the Hague. The west's once wily and infuriating antagonist is being brought down, but the forces that he helped let loose are still to be finally defeated.

fields.headline: Bolton pay for lack of penalties
fields.trailText: Bolton's hopes of claiming an automatic promotion place are in danger. This latest demonstration of how to throw away two valuable points in the dying stages of a game has left Sam Allardyce's team in an increasingly vulnerable position in second place.
fields.byline: Mark Ogden at the Reebok stadium
fields.body:
Bolton's hopes of claiming an automatic promotion place are in danger. This latest demonstration of how to throw away two valuable points in the dying stages of a game has left Sam Allardyce's team in an increasingly vulnerable position in second place.

If their promotion challenge does eventually falter and Bolton fail to return to the Premiership after a three-year absence, two damning statistics will surely haunt Allardyce and his team.

This draw with Wimbledon left Bolton without a league victory at the Reebok stadium since a 2-0 win against Tranmere on January 13. Hardly the form of a team chasing promotion to the Premiership. And Bolton have not been awarded a penalty in the league since the opening day of the season. Their meagre tally could have been boosted against Wimbledon but three appeals were turned down by the referee Bill Jordan.

The most blatant, an 89th-minute bear-hug by Mark Williams on the Bolton substitute Ian Marshall left Allardyce furious. "Williams had his arms all around Ian Marshall, but we are not getting what we deserve at the moment and the man in the middle is the culprit for that," he said. "There is no question in my mind that the referee refused a blatant penalty."

Honesty may be forced to take a back seat in the push for promotion. "The gaffer has told us he's sick to death of telling us to go down in box," the Bolton defender Simon Charlton revealed. "It's part of the game nowadays."

"Not getting the win is a massive blow," Allardyce added. "The longer we go without a home win, the harder it gets for us."

fields.headline: Talking to Leonardo
fields.standfirst:
As usual, Britain is missing the real debate about the future of Europe - just ask my two-year-old grandson

Special report: what is Britain?
Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: As usual, Britain is missing the real debate about the future of Europe - just ask my two-year-old grandson.
fields.body:
This is a personal column, in the sense that it begins with my Spanish grandson. But it also encompasses Penelope Cruz, Time magazine, Tony Blair, John Townend and an amazing Belfast hotel owner. More of all of them in a moment.

Meanwhile, here's Leonardo. He is two-years-and-four-months-old. He chatters away in English like any tiny, bouncy scrap. ("That's a very big ship," he said gravely when we went to the Cutty Sark the other day, "it's enormous.") He talks Castilian Spanish almost as fluently to his dad, and Catalan with his playschool mates. When he goes to visit his paternal grandma, they speak Gallego.

He is in no sense a Barcelona prodigy or exception. His father needs all three Spanish languages - plus a little English - to work. So does my daughter, though she throttles back a bit on the Gallego. And there goes little Leonardo, switching unthinkingly between tongues, asking me for a lollipop in English and the shop girl for the big red one in Catalan.

What, you wonder, will he be 20 years on? Will he be what John Townend would call "Anglo-Saxon", welcome in some snug bar supping Yorkshire bitter? Or Castilian, Catalan, Galician? Which is where Penelope Cruz and Time magazine come in.

Miss Cruz (from Madrid) is currently the hottest thing around Hollywood. You probably saw her looking lustrous at the Oscars. When Time, this week, runs a cover story on "Generation Europe" (the 21- to 35-year-olds), then of course she has to be on the cover. I'm a "citizen of the world", she says, "I like to work in different languages." She is, interestingly, not alone. Antonio Banderas and Javier Bardem are stars on the same global movie beat as Spanish becomes the other American.

What Time has done, via a Mori poll, is ask this generation who they are. Are you German, French, British, Italian - or are you European? And it's a balance: 31% of French, 36% of Germans, 42% of Italians say "European". To be sure, only 21% of young Britons say the same, but is the glass four-fifths empty or one-fifth full? Which political party, this coming election, speaks for the 21% - or even acknowledges that they exist?

The point here, the point the British non-debate always misses, has nothing much to do with Brussels and its grey men in suits winding up the Daily Mail. There's no need to pin "ever deeper union" on your lapel, because what's happening is happening by osmosis, not decree, in the way young Europeans behave and think and act. They recognise their roots, their homes, their ties - but they are also citizens of a wider world. Have skills and languages: can travel. From the Ramblas to the Fulham Road and back.

This isn't yet the mobility of labour that Tony Blair thinks so vital to what we used to call the American economic miracle (and which Gordon Brown does so little to encourage); perhaps only 2 or 3% of Generation E are on the move as yet. But there are still hundreds of thousands of them, young professionals, and their numbers swell year by year. They are one definition of the future.

So to that Belfast hotel owner. Dr Diljit Rana MBE JP. I met him a few weeks ago on a plane from New Delhi. He had come to Britain from India in the 60s and found his way to Northern Ireland, and stayed. Was there a large Indian community in the province? No, very small. Did he like the people? Yes, very much. And religion? "Sometimes at checkpoints they say "Protestant or Catholic?" and I say "Hindu" - and they ask "Is that a Protestant Hindu or a Catholic Hindu?"

We talked, inevitably, about the peace and the non-process. I was familiarly gloomy. He was surprisingly upbeat. Why? I said. "Because of Europe. It makes everything different." Look, what did "being British" or "being Irish" mean any longer? It didn't mean wafting off into some nationalist sunset, proud and alone. It meant sitting together in the same Brussels committee rooms, sharing the same open borders, the same jobs, observing the same rules and regulations. And because they, who would see the peace process through, knew this, they also knew they must settle for less - because the absolutes of the struggle had perished.

Score one for a wise, tolerant Hindu: a Generation E founder member three decades back. While Penelope Cruz sends money she earns to charities in Calcutta, Diljit Rana earns his money in Belfast. They are part of the same future, and they deserve to be heard.

It will, I guess, be a thoroughly depressing election. William Hague will bang on about asylum hordes from eastern Europe arriving to drink our bitter. Jack Straw will offer to lock them up more securely or dump them off Calais. The same cards played from the same mouldy deck. There'll be a pother about Britishness and roast beef and alien pigswill: and an absence of light or joined-up argument.

Meanwhile, just off stage in real foreign countries, ethnic Albanians will be shooting Macedonians, ETA will be bombing Spanish holiday towns and George W will be cancelling treaties that don't suit his stinking Texas. Narrow little, selfish little worlds - worlds that shrink as decisions have to be made. Is that the best horizon we have?

We used, long ago, to think that internationalism was some dotty, vaguely lefty ideal, lodged in a corner of history where Woodrow Wilson sat with the Noel-Bakers pere et fils. They were men of great goodwill, speaking peace from nation to nation. But so much of that has died with the cold war. Now the words are hollow and what's left of the vision thing seems mostly sour, anxious introspection.

Welcome to Generation Europe (a fine sub-section of Generation Globalisation). Their views, on the Mori scale, are liberal and free-thinking. They look forward with keen anticipation. They care, deeply, about the things that matter - like the environment - and have no time for fear and jealousy.

They are not yet the only Europe. The wife of the chief minister here in Catalonia has just disgraced herself with a rant about mosques driving out the Catholic churches. The Balkans don't end at Vienna. One step forward can swiftly turn to two steps back. Yet we can now live side by side across a fluid, shifting continent and many of us - the young, the ambitious - are choosing that way. And when I look at Leonardo, changing tongues as naturally as he changes T-shirts, I get a glimpse of hope; and of what, 20 years on, he might be.

fields.headline: But has he done the right thing?
fields.trailText: John Curtice, deputy director, ESRC centre for research into elections and social trends
fields.body:
John Curtice, deputy director, ESRC centre for research into elections and social trends

Yesterday's Mori poll showed that, although the percentage of people who think the government is handling foot and mouth well has almost doubled since a week ago, they don't think Tony Blair can run an election campaign and deal with foot and mouth at the same time.

Delaying the election until June is the decision I'd have made. But there's a risk that foot and mouth won't be better by then, and that will have wider implications for agriculture and tourism and mean economic confidence declines. Blair made a decision against the advice of the majority of his party, so the stakes are raised. If he doesn't get a large majority, he can forget commanding the party in the way he has for seven years.

Paul Stinchcombe, Labour MP for Wellingborough, the party's most marginal seat (majority 187)

Delaying until June 7 was difficult. I think it's right that Blair has been listening carefully to the farmers and tourist industry. He's had to make a decision that's right for the country rather than the party. I think they have made the right policy decisions on foot and mouth; the army is doing the right things, Maff is doing the right things, and clearly it's coming under control. He was in a position to run an election but if he decided the crisis was on such a scale it would be inappropriate, that's a courageous decision.

Patrick Nicholls, Tory MP for Teignbridge, the Conservatives' least secure seat (majority 281)

Deciding not to hold the election on May 3 was the right thing to do. It would have been unseemly to have an election going on with the foot and mouth crisis at its height. I can understand that if you've been in opposition for 18 years, it's politics, politics, politics, but, after four years, he should have been able to think beyond that. Delaying the election is recognition that this is a national crisis. I simply don't know whether this delay's good, bad or indifferent for the Tories or for me personally. A reasonable presumption is we're going to do considerably better than we did last time. But while the farmers may come out to support us, they may stay at home in misery and despair.

The Right Rev Michael Turnbull, Bishop of Durham

I don't see how the crisis in the countryside is going to have changed very much by June. Even if the disease is seen to be under control, the repercussions are not going to go away. There will still be enormous pain and it may well have knock-on effects on the tourist industry. I doubt whether delaying it for a month gets us anywhere except to extend uncertainty.

[With] modern media communications and postal votes, I don't think it disenfranchises people. The prime minister has had a lot of firsthand contact with the farming community and I respect his judgment.

Andrew Spence, north-east coordinator for Farmers for Action

I'm standing against Tony Blair in Sedgefield for the UK Independence Party. For me the election can't come soon enough. But I thought it should be postponed until there was a conclusion over the foot and mouth outbreak. That would have been the only way forward and the only way that he'd have secured the confidence of the people.

And we're seeing the tip of the iceberg; they've just opened a tip near my farm to dump 100,000 lambs and now they're saying cattle will go in there too.

If you're going to hold an election you want 100% of people who are prepared to vote to be able to do so. At the moment the countryside is basically blocked off.
