webTitle: Comment: Socialism is the best religion

fields.headline: Socialism is the best religion
fields.standfirst: And RH Tawney beats the Bible when it comes to doing good
fields.trailText: And RH Tawney beats the Bible when it comes to doing good.
fields.body:
That, as we used to say in Sheffield 50 years ago, "will learn him". No sooner had Tony Blair addressed the Christian Socialist Movement on the close relationship between faith and politics than the Archbishop of York intensified the prime minister's election date agony by echoing William Hague's call for the proposed May poll to be postponed.

Let us hope that the primate - who has never before said much of note on any social issue - will continue to demonstrate that religious authority can be used to justify anything. I have heard the Bible quoted to prove that homosexuality is intrinsically evil, that capital punishment is just retribution and that eating animal flesh is ordained by God.

Between us, the prime minister and I make up the two halves of the Christian socialist equation. He is one and I am the other. But, back in the days when I could not distinguish between the verbs to learn and teach, I was regularly in the congregation of the Sheffield Socialist Sunday School. It was held in what I now regard as a comment on the relationship between religion and politics - the old cobblers' shop of our local Co-op store. We expressed views which, although I support them still, are not likely to attract Tony Blair's support.

Services always began with our version of the national anthem. "When will thou save the people, Oh God of mercy, when? The people, Lord, the people! Not crowns or thrones, but men." We then considered the application of Biblical texts to modern life and decided that holy writ was timeless. It was, we agreed, still as difficult for a rich man to enter into the kingdom of heaven as it was for a camel to pass through the eye of a needle. Our advice to such people was to take all they had and give it to the poor. I am not sure that the prime minister - who has called for the creation of more millionaires - endorses that recommendation.

As I approached the age of discretion, I began to suspect that somewhere in Sheffield, the Christian faction of the Young Conservatives were also quoting the Bible in support of their beliefs. I assumed that they began with Matthew 25 as proof that anyone who makes 100% profit on an investment is a "good and faithful servant". And I imagined that they then moved on to condemnation of those foolish virgins - an allegory of the undeserving poor - who made no provisions for hard times. I took it for granted that no reference was made to the moneylenders being driven from the temple.

I am not suggesting that the ideological right is not entitled to quote the Bible in its support. Indeed, my objection to the confusion of religion and politics is that they have and they will. Christians in my experience - admittedly limited to the Salvation Army - do wondrous works on behalf of their fellow men and women. That is because they choose to live according to the Bible's more compassionate verses. But equally the ghastly television evangelists of the southern states of America will argue that their opposition to state-financed welfare is justified by the Bible's emphasis on individual responsibility. I think I am my brother's keeper. They do not.

When, in the Socialist Sunday School, we discovered that the Bible justifies everything and anything, we began to discuss Christian issues rather than the Christian gospels. I vividly recall the debate about St Martin, the Roman centurion who cut his cloak in half so that he should share it with a beggar. We agreed that he was to be condemned for not giving the whole thing away. We had moved from St Paul to Proudhon and in our innocence believed that all property was theft.

However, thanks to the Socialist Sunday School, I did find a sensible moral philosopher in whom I could believe. I believe in him still. Until I read RH Tawney's Equality, I was a Labour supporter because that is what I was brought up to be. He made me a socialist because it offered the hope of a better society. I read the book again recently in preparation for a radio programme and was, once more, left breathless by the brilliance with which he destroyed the arguments for an unequal society.

Christian charity ought to prompt someone to send a copy to No 10. It should be accompanied by a note which explains that the Bible's conflicting assertions illustrate the absurdity of pretending that men and women of goodwill - freed from political prejudice - can work together to solve common problems. We cannot even agree about what the problems and their solutions are. It is ideology which provides answers, and we should abandon the nonsensical notion that ecumenical politics can elevate government to new heights of public service. For politicians the important text is "render unto Caesar the things which are Caesar's".

webTitle: Business: Blair should be more enterprising

fields.headline: It is about time Blair had a big idea
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Larry Elliott: Tony Blair's opinion poll lead over William Hague is so commanding it probably makes no difference when he calls the election. But delaying it to June, let alone October, does involve economic risks.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's opinion poll lead over William Hague is so commanding it probably makes no difference when he calls the election. But delaying it to June, let alone October, does involve economic risks and upsets the carefully calibrated timing designed to maximise the feelgood factor for early May.

Last month's Budget was supposed to be the final piece of the jigsaw, but memories of the chancellor's package have already faded as the media's agenda has turned to foot and mouth. Unemployment will go back up, if only temporarily, this spring as a result of the loss of jobs in the tourist industry, and economic growth will slow. The one crumb of economic comfort for a government with one wary eye on the febrile global stock markets is that the Bank of England may cut interest rates this week. It should.

Despite the desperate attempts by the opposition to call this Blair's spring of discontent, Labour's biggest problem will be getting its supporters out to vote on election day. It is not that voters believe the government has screwed up, rather that having Labour in power with a 179-seat majority has made precious little difference. Britain now is remarkably similar to Britain on May 1, 1997.

Perhaps the single most depressing statistic is that spending on the nation's infrastructure has been lower in each of Labour's four years than in the final 12 months of John Major's administration and only 25% of what it was in the dying months of Jim Callaghan's luckless government. To be spending less than 0.5% of the economy's annual output on restoring the tattered remnants of the public realm is scandalous. Gordon Brown blames spending departments for this, but the chancellor cannot shuffle off responsibility so easily. He holds the purse strings. He imposed the cuts in Labour's first two years. The buck stops with him.

Labour's response to the charge that it has been a do-nothing government is two-fold. First, it points to some solid achievements - the minimum wage, extra money for low-income earners through a host of tax credits, help to some pensioners, extra billions for health and education - as evidence of work in progress.

There are good things delivered by Blair that would not have been delivered by Hague. Any Labour supporters toying with the idea that there is no difference between left and right in the modern world should have been speedily disabused last week when George Bush decided that America's right to go on polluting the planet took precedence over the Kyoto agreement to cut CO-2 emissions. In retrospect, voting for Ralph Nader in Florida was not such a good idea after all.

The second strand of the argument is that Labour's first term was all about showing competence and that things will get a lot better in a second term, honest. Only then will we see a full flowering of the government's progressive vision. Margaret Thatcher's radical phase was her second term between 1983 and 1987, which saw her take on and defeat the miners, sell off chunks of state-owned industry, and abolish the GLC and the metropolitan councils.

Before that she had enough on her plate bringing down inflation from 20%, coping with mass unemployment and fighting the Falklands war, without heeding those in her government and in the free-market think-tanks peddling the ideas that would lay the foundations for the second term revolution. With Labour a demoralised rump of a party in 1983, she had the ideas and the opportunity to get radical.

It is possible that Blair has merely been biding his time, storing up all his radical ideas for a second term. Did you see a pink, four-legged creature with wings and trotters float past your window?

The reality is that politics now is more like the 1950s than the 1980s. In the 50s, the Conservatives were in power but did not do very much. They took over from Labour in 1951 at a time when the economic climate turned benign, when inflationary pressure was minimal and world demand strong. They accepted the status quo inherited from the Attlee government - that large chunks of the economy should be in state hands, that full employment should be the centrepiece of economic policy, that capital should shoulder some of the responsibility for building up the welfare state - and stayed in charge for 13 years, making only incremental changes.

In some respects, the Conservatives did some of the things that Labour had never quite got round to doing; the mass expansion of council housing, for example, took place only after 1951. There were regular periods of breast-beating when it became clear that Britain, despite the favourable economic background, was performing far less well than Germany or France, but for the most part it was a time when the Conservative party thought that the point of politics was for it to stay in power rather than to change things.

Like the Conservatives, this Labour government took over when the economic climate was set fair. For the first time in decades it is possible to run the economy at about 3% growth without stoking up inflation. Full employment, if not yet a reality, is a definite possibility. Of the four big macroeconomic indicators, only the balance of payments, the Achilles' heel of the British economy, gives cause for concern.

Moreover, Labour accepts the traditional consensus. It believes low inflation is the prime objective of economic policy, that the balance of power in the workplace is just about right, that the industries privatised by the Conservatives should remain privatised, with a couple of new ones thrown in for good measure, it idolises business (the bigger the better). It seems to have no trouble, either, with 50s-style social authoritarianism. This is not a government that, even were it to be in power for 50 years, looks interested in rocking the boat. It just wants to change course by a couple of degrees.

Such an approach may be justified. It may be that much of what happened in the final quarter of the 20th century was necessary, right and irreversible. It may be that capitalism has now reached a point of near perfection so tinkering with the machine is all that is necessary. Labour's pollsters would argue that anything more radical would risk alienating the contented masses of Middle England, driving them back into the arms of the Conservatives.

But there is a different way of looking at things. Despite the good macro-economic numbers, Labour is so cocooned in its micro-management of the country that it fails to see the bigger picture. The global economy spends its time veering from one crisis to another, with the bursting of the hi-tech bubble only the latest in a series of disturbances.

As those people in southern England who have spent the past 12 months on flood alert could testify, something weird is happening to the world's weather. When people die in train crashes because the private sector has skimped on safety, there are legitimate questions to ask about ownership.

But there's the rub. Where Thatcher had both the opportunity and the ideas, Labour just has the opportunity. Yet the challenges are real and urgent. If the democratic left is not willing to provide a lead, history suggests there will be plenty of others with crackpot panaceas who will. George Bush for one.

The buck stops with him. Labour's response to the charge that it has been a do-nothing government is two-fold. First, it points to some solid achievements - the minimum wage, extra money for low-income earners through a host of tax credits, help to some pensioners, extra billions for health and education - as evidence of work in progress. There are good things delivered by Blair that would not have been delivered by Hague. Any Labour supporters toying with the idea that there is no difference between left and right in the modern world should have been speedily disabused last week when George Bush decided that America's right to go on polluting the planet took precedence over the Kyoto agreement to cut CO-2 emissions. In retrospect, voting for Ralph Nader in Florida was not such a good idea after all. The second strand of the argument is that Labour's first term was all about showing competence and that things will get a lot better in a second term, honest. Only then will we see a full flowering of the government's progressive vision. Margaret Thatcher's radical phase was her second term between 1983 and 1987, which saw her take on and defeat the miners, sell off chunks of state-owned industry, and abolish the GLC and the metropolitan councils. Before that she had enough on her plate bringing down inflation from 20%, coping with mass unemployment and fighting the Falklands war, without heeding those in her government and in the free-market think-tanks peddling the ideas that would lay the foundations for the second term revolution. With Labour a demoralised rump of a party in 1983, she had the ideas and the opportunity to get radical. It is possible that Blair has merely been biding his time, storing up all his radical ideas for a second term. Did you see a pink, four-legged creature with wings and trotters float past your window? The reality is that politics now is more like the 1950s than the 1980s. In the 50s, the Conservatives were in power but did not do very much. They took over from Labour in 1951 at a time when the economic climate turned benign, when inflationary pressure was minimal and world demand strong. They accepted the status quo inherited from the Attlee government - that large chunks of the economy should be in state hands, that full employment should be the centrepiece of economic policy, that capital should shoulder some of the responsibility for building up the welfare state - and stayed in charge for 13 years, making only incremental changes. In some respects, the Conservatives did some of the things that Labour had never quite got round to doing; the mass expansion of council housing, for example, took place only after 1951. There were regular periods of breast-beating when it became clear that Britain, despite the favourable economic background, was performing far less well than Germany or France, but for the most part it was a time when the Conservative party thought that the point of politics was for it to stay in power rather than to change things. Like the Conservatives, this Labour government took over when the economic climate was set fair. For the first time in decades it is possible to run the economy at about 3% growth without stoking up inflation. Full employment, if not yet a reality, is a definite possibility. Of the four big macroeconomic indicators, only the balance of payments, the Achilles' heel of the British economy, gives cause for concern. Moreover, Labour accepts the traditional consensus. It believes low inflation is the prime objective of economic policy, that the balance of power in the workplace is just about right, that the industries privatised by the Conservatives should remain privatised, with a couple of new ones thrown in for good measure, it idolises business (the bigger the better). It seems to have no trouble, either, with 50s-style social authoritarianism. This is not a government that, even were it to be in power for 50 years, looks interested in rocking the boat. It just wants to change course by a couple of degrees. Such an approach may be justified. It may be that much of what happened in the final quarter of the 20th century was necessary, right and irreversible. It may be that capitalism has now reached a point of near perfection so tinkering with the machine is all that is necessary. Labour's pollsters would argue that anything more radical would risk alienating the contented masses of Middle England, driving them back into the arms of the Conservatives. But there is a different way of looking at things. Despite the good macro-economic numbers, Labour is so cocooned in its micro-management of the country that it fails to see the bigger picture. The global economy spends its time veering from one crisis to another, with the bursting of the hi-tech bubble only the latest in a series of disturbances. As those people in southern England who have spent the past 12 months on flood alert could testify, something weird is happening to the world's weather. When people die in train crashes because the private sector has skimped on safety, there are legitimate questions to ask about ownership. But there's the rub. Where Thatcher had both the opportunity and the ideas, Labour just has the opportunity. Yet the challenges are real and urgent. If the democratic left is not willing to provide a lead, history suggests there will be plenty of others with crackpot panaceas who will. George Bush for one. larry.elliott@theguardian.com

fields.headline: The mane man
fields.standfirst:
The hair is no longer golden, and he never became prime minister. But Michael Heseltine has no regrets. He's too busy running a multi-million pound publishing empire - and talking to his trees

Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: The hair is no longer golden, and he never became prime minister. But Michael Heseltine has no regrets. He's too busy running a multi-million pound publishing empire - and talking to his trees
fields.body:
My mum's all of a tremble. " Ooooooh! Michael Heseltine." She's not often impressed by interviewees. But Hezza's always had a way with the ladies. Big, broad Tarzan, with his golden mane and Palladian mansion, his fierce oratory, the 270 self-made millions, the lovely family, his 50 acres, the eight gardeners to nurse his arboretum, his butler and chauffeur, and the woman who does his toast to perfection every morning 10 minutes after he hits the morning room. Michael Heseltine has always seemed to have everything. Except the Tory leadership, of course. He will retire from politics come the next election.

The security man at his publishing empire, Haymarket, in Hammersmith, west London, invites us into the car park when we mention we're here to see the gaffer. Which car belongs to Hezza? He points to the Jag, of course. "But it's got a scratch on it. He's getting a new one."

Haymarket is a funny old company. Hugely profitable, with its 100 smart, laminated magazines - the majority of them deadly dull corporate affairs - it's also built on the cheap. Journalists start out at Haymarket, get paid next to nothing, learn the trade, and often move on to jobs on national papers. The executives pay themselves kings' salaries. None more kingly than Heseltine. For decades he was virtually a sleeping partner, but since since 1997 he has returned full-time as chairman. Haymarket has expanded considerably, and he has seen his own fortune swell by 50 odd million.

The building is typically Haymarket. OK on the outside, trashy and cramped on the inside. Even his top-floor office looks as if it's made of cardboard and asbestos. I've never seen such a spartan executive pad. No pictures of friends or family, no trinkets, no trophies. I ask him whether he's just moved in. He looks surprised. "Oh no, no, no. I've been here since 1997. It's called minimalism isn't it? Hahahohoho!"

We stop for a photograph. The mane is no longer wild and gold. Yellow-grey and flat, but still very long. He makes love to the camera like a supermodel. There's hair sprouting everywhere these days - from the nose, the back of his shirt. Meanwhile, those extraordinary eyebrows stand at 45 degree angles like fencing swords. It is only his little boy's mouth that disappoints, with its receding lips and tiny teeth.

It's strange that Heseltine ended up in publishing. He was mildly dyslexic as a child and says he still doesn't like reading. But he says he's always been the entrepreneur, and tells me a practised anecdote about his public school days. "The first known example of my entrepreneurial activities is when I was 13. I wasn't any good at games, so when all these very energetic fellows spent the afternoon exhausting themselves on the soccer playing fields of Shrewsbury, I used to carry lemonade up the hill and sell it at a significant mark-up." He ho-ho-hos. Actually, you can see it in the early photos of the little boy. He looks rather precious and over-preened.

There's a famous story about how at Oxford Michael Ray Dibdin Heseltine mapped out his career on the back of an envelope - Fifties: millionaire. Sixties: MP. Seventies: minister. Eighties: Cabinet. Nineties: Downing Street.

Who would have thought that the former defence secretary, energy secretary, president of the board of trade and deputy prime minister would bow out of politics with a whimper? Does he now think of himself simply as a businessman? "Well that is my life, that is perfectly fair. That's what I do and what I think about. Psychologically, I think I left the House of Commons in '97." Better not tell his constituents that. "I think it's extremely difficult to have had the extraordinarily privileged career I've had and then go back into being in opposition. It's a young man's game, opposition. So I came back here." He holds his empire in his hands. "And it's been enormously fortunate in the sense that so often people in politics . . . it's like going over a cliff. There isn't any letdown, there's a nasty bump at the bottom."

Is that what Thatcher found? "I've no idea," he says tersely. They can't stand each other. Never have been able to since they fell out over the Westland affair. Few people can remember, or care about, the details of the European v American helicopter row. But Heseltine does.

I ask him why he found it so much easier to work with Major. "Well John Major was erm erm, erm, a reasonable and decent fellow." His brain seems to be fighting an internal battle. "Why I hesitated was that I don't accept, it just isn't true that I didn't find it possible to work with Mrs Thatcher. I worked with her for seven years."

But in the end he couldn't work with her? "Ah yes, well, she tried to cheat, and I won't have that. And I left. It was the most appalling waste of my life." She betrayed him? "Well she tried to cheat," he repeats. Heseltine has an effortless sense of moral superiority. At the same time, though, he sounds like a petulant lad.

Does he ever look back on Westland and wish he'd kept quiet? "No, I don't . . . The whole idea that one should have kept just a little quiet over what I believed to be a scandal - the world is full of people who kept a little quiet."

Thatcher did for him, and a few years later he did for her. When Heseltine challenged for the leadership, she won the vote but lost the party's confidence. She stood down. It may have been a satisfying short-term revenge for him, but she had the last laugh. Thatcher loyalists never forgave him.

I ask him what he is most proud of in his political life. "Oh council house sales, the defeat of CND, the final rationalisation of the Ministry of Defence, and Liverpool." After the riots in the 80s, he spent a deal of time in the city and devised a policy to revamp it. "In Liverpool I had an opportunity to put into practice a philosophy I had all my political life, in other words good enlightened capitalism - paternalism if you like. Noblesse oblige. I believe strongly that those with power and privilege have responsibilities . . . what we did has now become the consensus inner city policy; a constructive partnership between the public and private sectors."

The strange thing is, I say, most people will probably remember you as Tarzan swinging the mace in parliament and destroying Thatcher. He chuckles modestly. Was the mace-swinging spontaneous? " Yeaasssss , the Labour party had cheated. They got legislation through by cheating." His political career seems to have been plagued by cheats.

What does he think he will be best remembered for? "My trees," he answers instantly. Heseltine loves his arboretum. He and his eight gardeners have planted 3,500 trees and shrubs over the past quarter of a century, and he spends about 20 hours a week in it. "It's a therapy. As one walks out of the house into garden everything is left behind."

Does he talk to the trees? "Oh yes. Underperformers are very severely castigated." He abuses his trees? "Oh yes, I do abuse my trees. I had a thorn tree that was very much underperforming and I had a conversation with it and I said, 'Look, the game's over, if you don't do better than this you're on the way out.' The next year it flowered like you've never seen such flowers. Absolutely covered in flowers, as if to say, well OK, sod you. It died the year after."

He's looking me straight in the eye for a change, talking with animation and passion for the first time. There's no stopping him.

Does he finds it easier to talk to the trees than to his political colleagues? "Noooooah. No, no no, no." I think that's a yes. "I mean I could never talk to people in parliament with the same rough edge of the tongue that I talk to the trees."

Perhaps that was the problem. Great with the trees, but not so good at shmoozing fellow Tories. The charisma lay more in your image than soul, I suggest. And as a politician he never quite had the drive or devilry of Thatcher. "Well you must decide on the characteristics. I'm perfectly capable of doing this gladhanding," he grumbles. He says he did loads of it in the 80s, charmed the pants off any number of Tories.

But he does have the reputation of being a loner, detached? "Yeh, yeh, that's true, that's true. I don't run away from that. I'm not good at small talk." Does he find it difficult to make friends? "I have close good friends, but not many. I'm not the life and soul of the party."

He insists he was always good at keeping in touch with those he worked closely with. But not very good at keeping on side with those he had to? "Yes, yes, yes, I think that's probably right." There's a long pause, as he struggles with his words. "Difficult . . . the party became very divided in the 80s. They had a view about who was 'One of us' as the phrase was, and I never was." The assassin sounds rather hurt.

He must at times wish he hadn't stood against her. "I don't have any regrets," he says. But it's only human to have regrets. "I had a wonderful time, huge privilege," he chants. "I cast the dice, and I knew what I was doing." He equates regret with failure, and he doesn't do failure.

But he desperately wanted to be prime minister? "I would like to have been prime minster, yes. Desperate is not the word I'd use. If I had really been that preoccupied, would I have stayed away from the House of Commons all those years?" He says he didn't shmooze because it wasn't his way. "But if I was this scheming monkey that everyone would like to portray me as, the fact that it wasn't my natural way wouldn't have stopped me." I don't think he could have been the scheming monkey either - he's too proud, and too cold.

Anyway, these days, Heseltine wants to accentuate the positive. He is even willing to be generous about Hague - yes, slightly dodgy on Europe, but such a young man, so clever, terrific speaker, and it was only the once he supped those 14 pints. Most people, he says, think things were always better in their day, but he's not so small-minded. He smiles. Big handsome hairy Tarzan with his milk teeth.

Someone told me that his father, an army colonel, had been called Haircut Heseltine. Is that true? He looks astonished, "Yes, how did you discover that? No he wasn't called Haircut Heseltine. No, no. where did you get that from out of curiosity?" Must protect my sources, I say. He's virtually pleading for the information. "Oh yes, but it could only be someone who was a contemporary of his. Give me a clue. I think he was called Half-inch Heseltine. I think he was. Because he was meticulous about the appearance of his soldiers. And in those days everyone had short hair. And he had a big mirror put outside the barracks gates in Clitheroe in Lancashire, so his troops going in and out could see whether they were smart enough to represent the regiment."

So you've spent the past 40 years rebelling against Half-inch Heseltine? "No, no, I'm devoted to my father." If you push your hair forward, how far would it go, I ask. My bet is that it would hang off his chin. "I haven't the first idea." Go on, try it. "No, I shan't. I certainly won't try it." Go on. "No, not at all.

"I didn't always want long hair. I just had long hair. There was no conscious decision." Come off it, hair length is a choice! "You can have a passive choice." Laziness? "Yeeeeaassss. Indifference." Indifference!

Did Half-inch disapprove? "Well I don't think, to be honest, he lived that long. I don't think I did have that long hair. I can think of pictures at Oxford when I was president of the union and I had quite short hair. My father was dead two years later."

On the way out, Heseltine puts his hand out, and I don't see the man in front of me. Instead I shake hands with a little boy in shorts and a blazer with cropped blond hair.

fields.headline: Talking to Leonardo
fields.standfirst: As usual, Britain is missing the real debate about the future of Europe - just ask my two-year-old grandson
fields.trailText: As usual, Britain is missing the real debate about the future of Europe - just ask my two-year-old grandson.
fields.body:
This is a personal column, in the sense that it begins with my Spanish grandson. But it also encompasses Penelope Cruz, Time magazine, Tony Blair, John Townend and an amazing Belfast hotel owner. More of all of them in a moment.

Meanwhile, here's Leonardo. He is two-years-and-four-months-old. He chatters away in English like any tiny, bouncy scrap. ("That's a very big ship," he said gravely when we went to the Cutty Sark the other day, "it's enormous.") He talks Castilian Spanish almost as fluently to his dad, and Catalan with his playschool mates. When he goes to visit his paternal grandma, they speak Gallego.

He is in no sense a Barcelona prodigy or exception. His father needs all three Spanish languages - plus a little English - to work. So does my daughter, though she throttles back a bit on the Gallego. And there goes little Leonardo, switching unthinkingly between tongues, asking me for a lollipop in English and the shop girl for the big red one in Catalan.

What, you wonder, will he be 20 years on? Will he be what John Townend would call "Anglo-Saxon", welcome in some snug bar supping Yorkshire bitter? Or Castilian, Catalan, Galician? Which is where Penelope Cruz and Time magazine come in.

Miss Cruz (from Madrid) is currently the hottest thing around Hollywood. You probably saw her looking lustrous at the Oscars. When Time, this week, runs a cover story on "Generation Europe" (the 21- to 35-year-olds), then of course she has to be on the cover. I'm a "citizen of the world", she says, "I like to work in different languages." She is, interestingly, not alone. Antonio Banderas and Javier Bardem are stars on the same global movie beat as Spanish becomes the other American.

What Time has done, via a Mori poll, is ask this generation who they are. Are you German, French, British, Italian - or are you European? And it's a balance: 31% of French, 36% of Germans, 42% of Italians say "European". To be sure, only 21% of young Britons say the same, but is the glass four-fifths empty or one-fifth full? Which political party, this coming election, speaks for the 21% - or even acknowledges that they exist?

The point here, the point the British non-debate always misses, has nothing much to do with Brussels and its grey men in suits winding up the Daily Mail. There's no need to pin "ever deeper union" on your lapel, because what's happening is happening by osmosis, not decree, in the way young Europeans behave and think and act. They recognise their roots, their homes, their ties - but they are also citizens of a wider world. Have skills and languages: can travel. From the Ramblas to the Fulham Road and back.

This isn't yet the mobility of labour that Tony Blair thinks so vital to what we used to call the American economic miracle (and which Gordon Brown does so little to encourage); perhaps only 2 or 3% of Generation E are on the move as yet. But there are still hundreds of thousands of them, young professionals, and their numbers swell year by year. They are one definition of the future.

So to that Belfast hotel owner. Dr Diljit Rana MBE JP. I met him a few weeks ago on a plane from New Delhi. He had come to Britain from India in the 60s and found his way to Northern Ireland, and stayed. Was there a large Indian community in the province? No, very small. Did he like the people? Yes, very much. And religion? "Sometimes at checkpoints they say "Protestant or Catholic?" and I say "Hindu" - and they ask "Is that a Protestant Hindu or a Catholic Hindu?"

We talked, inevitably, about the peace and the non-process. I was familiarly gloomy. He was surprisingly upbeat. Why? I said. "Because of Europe. It makes everything different." Look, what did "being British" or "being Irish" mean any longer? It didn't mean wafting off into some nationalist sunset, proud and alone. It meant sitting together in the same Brussels committee rooms, sharing the same open borders, the same jobs, observing the same rules and regulations. And because they, who would see the peace process through, knew this, they also knew they must settle for less - because the absolutes of the struggle had perished.

Score one for a wise, tolerant Hindu: a Generation E founder member three decades back. While Penelope Cruz sends money she earns to charities in Calcutta, Diljit Rana earns his money in Belfast. They are part of the same future, and they deserve to be heard.

It will, I guess, be a thoroughly depressing election. William Hague will bang on about asylum hordes from eastern Europe arriving to drink our bitter. Jack Straw will offer to lock them up more securely or dump them off Calais. The same cards played from the same mouldy deck. There'll be a pother about Britishness and roast beef and alien pigswill: and an absence of light or joined-up argument.

Meanwhile, just off stage in real foreign countries, ethnic Albanians will be shooting Macedonians, ETA will be bombing Spanish holiday towns and George W will be cancelling treaties that don't suit his stinking Texas. Narrow little, selfish little worlds - worlds that shrink as decisions have to be made. Is that the best horizon we have?

We used, long ago, to think that internationalism was some dotty, vaguely lefty ideal, lodged in a corner of history where Woodrow Wilson sat with the Noel-Bakers pere et fils. They were men of great goodwill, speaking peace from nation to nation. But so much of that has died with the cold war. Now the words are hollow and what's left of the vision thing seems mostly sour, anxious introspection.

They are not yet the only Europe. The wife of the chief minister here in Catalonia has just disgraced herself with a rant about mosques driving out the Catholic churches. webTitle: Bill could turn MoD police into a paramilitary force, Tories warn

fields.headline: Bill could turn MoD police into a paramilitary force, Tories warn
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Tories in opposition
Special report: human rights in the UK
fields.trailText: A bill expected to be passed by the Commons today will give the Ministry of Defence police extensive powers allowing officers to arrest civilians anywhere in the country - akin, opponents say, to a national paramilitary force.
fields.body:
A bill expected to be passed by the Commons today will give the Ministry of Defence police extensive powers allowing officers to arrest civilians anywhere in the country - akin, opponents say, to a national paramilitary force.

The move, prompted in part by the force's inability under existing law to intervene in last year's fuel protests, is also opposed by MPs because the force is significantly less accountable than local police forces.

"There may be a role for an armed gendarmerie but this is not what the government is saying," said Robert Key MP, a Conservative defence spokesman. The government simply describes the armed forces bill, which contains provisions giving the MoD police more power, as a "tidying up process", he said.

The MoD argues that the bill is merely designed to allow its police to act in public order situations, or when a serious crime is being committed, without first having to get the permission of the local police.

However, opponents believe the government wants to use the 3,700 officers in the MoD police to help make up the shortfall in local police forces and deploy them, in particular, during demonstrations.

Up to now, the authority of the MoD police is restricted to MoD property and bases and military or civilian personnel living or working there. All MoD police can carry firearms.

Despite assurances given to MPs by Geoff Honn, the defence secretary, during the committee stage of the bill, the MoD police are not formally subject to police complaints authority investigations, to the inspectorate of constabulary, or to the same disciplinary procedures as civilian police.

Nor is the force accountable to an elected police authority. It is an MoD agency controlled by a senior civil servant and the defence secretary without outside scrutiny.

The MoD recently agreed to appoint three civilians to its police board but its police officers will still not be democratically accountable, Mr Key said.

It may be sensible to have an armed gendarmerie along the lines of paramilitary forces on the continent. It could also have a role in peacekeeping, he added, noting that 50 MoD police were operating in Kosovo. But that was not what the government was arguing for.

The MoD police is being sued by Tony Geraghty, the journalist arrested under the Official Secrets Act for writing a book, The Irish War. Charges against him and his alleged contact, Lieutenant Colonel Nigel Wilde, a retired army bomb disposal officer, were dropped.

Colonel Wilde and his wife, Monika, also plan to sue the force.

fields.headline: Railway monitor to join board
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Railtrack will today have its scope limited by the government in a move which could eventually result in it being returned to public ownership.
fields.body:
Railtrack will today have its scope limited by the government in a move which could eventually result in it being returned to public ownership.

It has agreed to a new "public watchdog" being appointed to its board when the government announces a £1.5bn package of rail measures designed to bolster the company.

Following intense pressure by the government, Railtrack has conceded that it will have to appoint a new non-executive director charged solely with looking after the interests of passengers. The appointment will be made over the next few months.

This is the first clear step by ministers to turn Railtrack away from a company being solely answerable to its board and shareholders into one which uniquely must take the wider public interest into account.

Railtrack sources insisted last night that it alone would be responsible for choosing the candidate, and that the company hoped to combine the appointment with that of the announcement of a new chairman.

The government will also announce that it is to assume responsibility for completing the £5.2bn Channel tunnel rail link from Folkestone to central London by 2006.

Railtrack might complete the first section of the 68-mile route on time by 2003, but the project will be completed by Bechtel, the American construction company.

Rail observers last night saw the government's announcement as being the first stage of a gradual return of the railway industry to public ownership. Railtrack will now only in the main have control of track maintenance while the private sector will be responsible for enhancing and improving the network.

webTitle: 'Mass affluents' get richer as the poor get poorer

fields.headline: 'Mass affluents' get richer as the poor get poorer
fields.trailText: The millionaires club in Britain is growing at a rate of 17% a year and now has 74,000 members. But it is not just the super-rich who have been getting richer: another club is emerging made up of those who have liquid assets of between £30,000 and £200,000.
fields.body:
The millionaires club in Britain is growing at a rate of 17% a year and now has 74,000 members. But it is not just the super-rich who have been getting richer: another club is emerging made up of those who have liquid assets of between £30,000 and £200,000.

Nearly 4m people, or 8% of the population over 16 years of age, can now claim membership of this group of "mass affluents", according to research from Datamonitor, the independent market analysis experts - and its numbers have been growing by 12% a year for the past five years.

These new rich are mostly white, male, over 35, and living in the south east. They win inclusion in the £30-200k club by virtue of money in cash and shares, before the value of any property or pension funds they hold is taken into account.

Soaring property prices in the south have created many new paper millionaires, as did the dot.com bubble. But the "mass affluents" do not just hold paper fortunes.

"A lot of the growth has come out of the finance industry, where the numbers employed have grown by 2.3% between 1999 and 2000," said Antony Kelsey, Datamonitor analyst. "These are people who work in banks, on mergers and acquisitions, they are very well paid industries, and it is these types who are fuelling growth." New technologies have also created new wealth.

But another factor is fear that traditional sources of pensions will not provide for retirement and many members of the club are those who have been building up a pool of assets for their old age.

However, the younger members may be wealthy but are not necessarily wise.

Mr Kelsey said: "Seventeen per cent of them hold no investments at all, and although 62% of them have equity holdings, only 40% have ISAs."

While the rich get richer, the poor get poorer - and the regional gaps become more stark.

The mass affluent are concentrated in London (19%), the south east (a further 19%), East Anglia (12%), and Yorkshire and Humberside (11%). Only 1% of people with assets of £30-200k live in Merseyside, 5% in Scotland, and 4% in Wales.

A survey based on fieldwork from the Office for National Statistics last September by Bristol, York, Loughborough and Herriot-Watt universities found that by the end of 1999, a quarter (26%) of the British population was living in poverty, measured in terms of low income and multiple deprivation of necessities.

The survey confirmed that poverty rates have risen sharply. In 1983, 14% of households lacked three or more necessities because they could not afford them.

That proportion had increased to 21% in 1990 and to over 24% by 1999.

About 8m people cannot afford one or more essential household goods. Almost 7.5m people are too poor to engage in common social activities such as are considered necessary by the majority of the population.

fields.headline: Eye-catching initiatives urged on ministers to prevent sense of limbo
fields.standfirst:
Show of activity ordered in run-up to poll

Special report: New Labour in power
Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: Tony Blair has ordered government departments to fill April with eye-catching announcements, in a bid to show the government is not in limbo or the victim of events.
fields.body:
Tony Blair has ordered government departments to fill April with eye-catching announcements, in a bid to show the government is not in limbo or the victim of events.

A full grid of announcements was drafted last week across Whitehall for the next seven days as a precaution against the prime minister delaying the general election from May 3 to June 7.

However, ministers and Millbank will be scrambling to fill April, and are likely to bring forward initiatives that had been destined for the campaign itself.

Moreover, the decision to prolong the pre-election period will require a big psychological shift in Whitehall which had long been working on the assumption of a May 3 election.

It has even been reported that David Blunkett, the education secretary, had hosted what amounted to a farewell drinks party for his civil servants last week.

Another education minister last week was gasping for May, saying the budget had run out of cash for further announcements.

Other ministers, such as Peter Hain (industry), had rushed forward as much cash as possible to placate the families of miners still waiting compensation for ill-health from the government.

A third minister claimed there had been an end of term spirit inside the private offices of many ministers with talk of holidays and campaign trails.

Although ministers remain ministers during a general election campaign, they in practice do little governing. Whitehall civil servants go on holiday, or enjoy a slower pace.

However, the precaution of preparing the usual announcement grid for the coming week will mean civil service need not return to work today in search of ditched, delayed or incomplete announcements.

Ministers, for instance, will try to give a "business as usual" feel by making announcements on the future of Railtrack and drug rehabilitation, as well as on the science budget.

Other announcements had been postponed anyway because of the media dominance by the foot and mouth outbreak.

Nevertheless, the carefully crafted slow build-up to the election launch has been damaged. The budget has been published and most of the big benefit increases will go into voters' pockets this week, earlier than Gordon Brown, the chancellor, would have wanted for in terms of a June election.

Ministers had already published green papers setting out plans for the future of criminal justice, the health service, education, transport, adult skills, and the future of the new deal.

The situation leaves the government in danger of treading water in April. But April could be a politically cruel month for the government.

There are controversial reviews due shortly from the Home Office - one on the future of criminal sentencing and another on the future of the court system.

The deadline for decommissioning in the Northern Ireland peace process is June, putting extra pressure on ministers to prove the IRA is acting in good faith.

The unemployment, new deal and inflation figures should remain buoyant.

However, if the tourist industry is hit as hard as some predict, Britain could be pushed towards far slower growth than expected. Hotel bookings were down 7% in London last week, and Easter generally represents 10% of the tourist trade.

Two further interest rate decisions from the Bank of England are due before June 7, including one on June 6.

Big summits also loom for the G8 and for the EU in June, including a possible clash with George Bush over Kyoto. Sleaze will continue to raise its head. Keith Vaz, the Foreign Office minister, has retired from the front line of politics for eight weeks after his collapse.

But Elizabeth Filkin, the parliamentary commissioner for standards, will continue with her inquiry into further aspects of his finances.

She will also start to pursue aspects of Geoffrey Robinson's business empire after the industry secretary, Stephen Byers, gave the go ahead for her to seek information from Arthur Andersen.

fields.headline: Jobless may rise over 1m again
fields.standfirst:
Impact on economy is worse than forecast
New Labour in power
Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: One million is proving to be a symbolic figure for Labour. Sometime this week, the number of livestock earmarked for slaughter will pass the seven figure mark as foot and mouth tightens its grip on the countryside.
fields.body:
One million is proving to be a symbolic figure for Labour. Sometime this week, the number of livestock earmarked for slaughter will pass the seven figure mark as foot and mouth tightens its grip on the countryside.

For Millbank strategists, however, the number was meant to symbolise another milestone - the news last month that unemployment had dropped below 1m for first time in 25 years.

Now economists fear the job losses from foot and mouth may send unemployment back above the million mark. The foundations of Labour's carefully crafted election strategy - Gordon Brown's successful handling of the economy - are looking increasingly vulnerable.

City forecasters at first were inclined to dismiss the economic impact of foot and mouth. Although lost sales are costing farmers around £50m a week, agriculture today is a tiny part of the economy - 1.2% of output - and livestock farming makes up just a third of that.

If the crisis were to wipe out livestock and dairy farming, the rest of the economy would feel the impact but would not be thrown into recession.

But what the first forecasts missed was the damage being inflicted on other parts of the economy by the virtual shutdown of large parts of the countryside. Cancelled sporting fixtures, empty hotels, and lost haulage contracts all add up to a much bigger impact.

Tourism has been the biggest loser. The industry esimates the epidemic will have cost it £2bn in lost sales by Easter. Mr Blair declared last week that Britain was still open for business, and embassies have been instructed to spread the word. But the damage has already been done: the British Tourist Authority in New York says half its calls are about foot and mouth.

At home, families are ignoring the government's advice and cancelling or changing holiday plans. Seaside resorts are reporting lower Easter bookings.

Hotels and resorts are already cutting jobs, raising a nightmare possibility for the government. By mid-May when the April unemployment figures are published, the jobless total may have crept back above the 1m figure.

The crisis is also expected to increase Britain's trade gap with rest of the world, which is already the widest since records began 300 years ago.

Again the hit on tourism is the main reason - livestock exports accounted for just £615m last year - just under half a percent of total exports. Tourism, though, is a big earner: foreign visitors spent about £13bn in Britain last year.

Not only are foreigners cancelling trips, but UK residents are also choosing to take holidays abroad rather than at home, which increases the trade deficit.

When Labour strategists long ago pencilled in May 2001 as their preferred election date, no one foresaw that a global recession would be clouding the horizon.

The US and Japan, the world's number one and num ber two economies, are in deep trouble, and big European and American companies are announcing layoffs daily.

A recent analysis suggested that the epidemic and the global slide into recession could shave 1% off growth this year, the equivalent of £9bn in lost output.

However, most City analysts think this estimate is too high. Not all the losses the tourist industry is suffering are a direct cost to the economy - people are diverting spending to other leisure industries such as bookshops and shopping.

And some businesses are making money cleaning up after the epidemic: the government has spent £100m on disinfecting the affected farms and abattoirs, and £40m on lorries and transport.

Luckily for the chancellor, the economy was in robust health before the epidemic started and the slowdown will only really start to bite in the autumn, after the likely election date in June.

For Millbank strategists, however, the number was meant to symbolise another milestone - the news last month that unemployment had dropped below 1m for first time in 25 years. Now economists fear the job losses from foot and mouth may send unemployment back above the million mark. The foundations of Labour's carefully crafted election strategy - Gordon Brown's successful handling of the economy - are looking increasingly vulnerable. City forecasters at first were inclined to dismiss the economic impact of foot and mouth. Cancelled sporting fixtures, empty hotels, and lost haulage contracts all add up to a much bigger impact. Tourism has been the biggest loser. The industry esimates the epidemic will have cost it £2bn in lost sales by Easter. fields.headline: Boom time for Bob?
fields.standfirst: He has been transmogrified from Bob of Boomtown Rats via Sir Bob of Band Aid to Bob the Businessman. So where will Bob Geldof's trajectory take him now?
fields.trailText: April 2: He has been transformed from Bob of Boomtown Rats via Sir Bob of Band Aid to Bob the Businessman. What next, asks Maggie Hyde?
fields.body:
With last week's sale of deckchair.com, Bob Geldof earned himself £500,000 and a three-year contract at £100,000 a year to stay involved.

Two years ago, when he sold his production company, Planet 24, to Carlton, he bagged a cool £5m.

He has been transmogrified from Bob of Boomtown Rats via Sir Bob of Bandaid to Bob the Businessman. So where will his trajectory take him now?

As an airy Libran (October 5 1951, 2.20pm, Dublin) Geldof gets a buzz from ideas, always moving the goalposts in the light of his latest notion.

The Libran Scales weigh the pros and cons and, if he is like most Librans, he'll usually have some big scheme or other pending. His life is probably one (in)decision after another, which could be rather wearing to live with.

He says of himself "everything I do is because I'm frightened of being bored", and his restless energy shows in the lack of fixity in his horoscope. It is all cardinal and mutable signs, forever moving and doing but lacking the patient ability to see things through over the long term.

Popular astrology often gets Libra wrong and confuses its balancing act with acquiescence, but Geldof is no more a sit-on-the-fence dreamer than fellow Librans Margaret Thatcher, Genghis Khan and John Lennon. Once this air sign gets the wind in its sails it can become a gale.

In common with all Librans, Geldof's angry power blazes away when in his eyes the playing field isn't level or an injustice is being done.

Way back in 1985, Geldof used this marvellous force to galvanise the music industry into Live Aid, and this is where the great Libran gift of persuasion came fully into play, persuading musicians to work as a team and persuading the public to cough up.

But don't be fooled into thinking Libra persuasion has to be gentle - its logic can be so demanding that, if you don't agree with Librans, they show complete disdain.

Librans come under the planet Venus and, with both Venus and Mars in the critical sign of Virgo, Geldof does not tolerate fools gladly: "You can take people apart, but you're not too hot at putting them together again. They sense that you're rating them on a scale of one to 10 in a dozen different categories. Learn to describe a thing without the windy criticism." (Debbi Kempton-Smith)

It is not a very "personal" horoscope, nor is it introspective yet, like all Librans, Geldof's life is defined in terms of his relationships.

His high-profile marriage to Paula Yates and the tragic ending for Paula and her lover Michael Hutchence, is shown by poignant symbolism in Geldof's horoscope as the melancholy weight of Saturn progressed onto his Libra Sun.

As well as a marriage partner, Librans need business partners too. It is an astrological truism they should never do anything alone because they need someone earthy and practical who can make ideas work in the real world of bricks, cash and mortar.

In recent years, Geldof's business partners - Waheed Alli and Charlie Parsons at Planet 24, James Page at Eidos - have proved fruitful, and his contribution to the success of these ventures has been through his initiative and his ability to play the charismatic frontman.

Currently, with 10 Alps Broadcasting, he is still wearing his businessman's hat but what happened to the music?

With the personal tragedies behind him, selling deckchair.com is Geldof's way of starting to clear the decks. It is a signal that he is about to move into a new horizon.

We can only speculate on what this might be but with Mars progressing into Libra this June and his partner point coming to Mars in August, a significant new business relationship could be forged.

Since Mars was prominent, too, at the time of Live Aid, more good things are still to come from Geldof's Martian anger and Libran outrage.

fields.headline: BBC Choice chief shows 45 Minutes red card
fields.trailText: 45 Minutes, the celebrity-driven football show, has been axed after two series, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
45 Minutes the cult BBC football show that revealed Les Ferdinand's involvement in the infamous trashing of the Blue Peter garden.

The show made national headlines when spurs star Ferdinand revealed in an interview that as a 15-year-old he had helped his mates get over the wall before the notorious incident, which took place in 1983.

But now Stuart Murphy, controller of BBC Choice, has decided to call time.

He has dropped the show - which aimed to bring a more celebrity-driven, showbiz approach to coverage of football - after just two series.

Instead, Liquid News, BBC Choice's showbiz news show, will cover more sport as part of its brief.

"BBC Sport will continue to look to make a wider range of programmes, bringing sport and entertainment together in new formats," said a BBC Choice spokesman.

"We will be widening the scope of Liquid News to cover sport and its interaction with the world of entertainment."

"A new daily strand is planned to give new focus to sport on the channel, including the celebrity side and news issues."

45 Minutes was presented by former Big Breakfast host Lisa Rogers and Joe Mace, while Shovell, the M People drummer, interviewed the footballers.

The show attracted a procession of big-name soccer stars, including Edgar Davids and Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink.

As well as solving the 17-year-old mystery of who trashed the Blue Peter garden, 45 Minutes's other scoops included getting Frank Lampard to reveal that his West Ham team-mate Paolo Di Canio shaves his entire body in the shower after training.

But the show will not be missed by other members of the BBC Sport department.

Mr Murphy gave the producers of 45 Minutes licence to throw far more money at football stars than other programmes were allowed.

The axing of 45 Minutes comes as Mr Murphy is preparing to change the mix of programming on BBC Choice as it transforms into the youth-orientated BBC3.

fields.headline: First text message lottery to launch
fields.trailText:
8.30am: A new service will offer consumers the chance to win a daily prize of £50,000, writes Amy Vickers.

Nov 14: Retailers on riot alert
Nov 8: Lakeside hosts text message ads trial
fields.body:
The world's first lottery to be played over mobile phones is set to launch in the the UK offering cash prizes of up to £50,000.

Players can simply play by keying in their seven numbers and sending them to a special lottery telephone number.

The company behind the novel venture is expecting the game will be a huge hit with younger players, cutting out the trip to a newsagent for lottery tickets.

Daily prizes of £50,000 will be up for grabs with smaller pay outs also expected.

SpotFlash, the company behind the service, is drafting in sponsors to help out with costs for its ZagLotto service.

"It will work like the lottery - with rollovers - so it's hard to say how many payments we may have to make. It all depends on how many people enter," said Bill Green, chief executive officer of the company.

The lottery is the second service from SpotFlash. It recently introduced ZagMe, a shopping centre experiment that sent teenagers text messages giving them details of special offers.

The service has already been launched at the Lakeside and Bluewater shopping centres and has been such a success it is being expanded.

More than 50,000 people signed up to the ZagMe trials, giving SpotFlash access to an estimated 20% of the under-25s that visit the two shopping centres. This was double the number the company had expected.

Unsurprisingly, 18 to 24-year-olds were the heaviest users, 25 to 34-year-olds were the biggest spenders and sports goods carried the highest transaction value.

Related stories

Nov 8: Lakeside hosts text message ads trial

webTitle: Leader: Blair, stop our election  misery

fields.headline: Blairism at its worst
fields.standfirst:
Please put us out of our election misery

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: If the government's generalship in the foot and mouth campaign had been matched by the way ministers mobilised around the broadcasting studios yesterday, the outbreak would now be well past its peak.
fields.body:
If the government's generalship in the foot and mouth campaign had been matched by the way ministers mobilised around the broadcasting studios yesterday, the outbreak would now be well past its peak. It was an operation to make Marlborough proud. All together now: delay ... a few weeks ... no great harm done to the tourist trade.

As for the hapless Chris Smith, who had spent most of the previous day saying the contrary, Jack Straw abandoned the roast beef of middle England - are ministers still under injunction to ingest the stuff? - to go on the radio at lunchtime and bury him as effectively as a Cumbrian JCB.

The past few days have displayed all the well-known deformations of the Blair era. Decisions are weighed in the scales of polls and focus groups and spun in mass-circulation newspapers. The cabinet is sidelined and the parliamentary Labour party ignored. Excited, ill-considered language about crisis and nationhood inflates public expectations and comes to dictate policy.

The prime minister, unable to trust the capacity of his colleagues but unwilling to sack them, bounds to the front of the stage to take personal charge. The upshot is that foot and mouth, a regional and sectoral problem fundamentally to do with the small-scale economics of pastoral farming, is allowed to preoccupy the whole government as if indeed it were a national and general question.

The casualties of that diversion of political attention are easy to see. Not by chance are they policies affecting the urban majority. Mr Blair's lack of focus has allowed London transport to become a political and probably also now a financial disaster. Railtrack is foundering. The huge administrative reorganisation that may be necessary if Labour is to deliver its spending promises is put on hold because the prime minister is busy elsewhere. Gus Macdonald, who seems to have taken to the Rottweiler role with enthusiasm, tells us the prime minister's decision on election timing will be "informed by what is best for the country".

But which country, Gus? Only a prime minister with some misty-eyed Baldwinian aspiration to unite us all in happy-ever-after land could fail to see that what has happened in livestock farming exhibits deep conflicts of interest between producers and consumers, tax-eaters and tax-payers, animal-lovers and those to whom sheep and pigs are mere industrial materials.

Michael Portillo's charge that the government is dithering is hard to rebut, hypocritical though the Tories are to make it. Ministers' diaries have emptied. The machinery of state is stalled. A deathly calm hangs over the corridors of power - and this situation of stasis looks like it will last even longer now. Conservatives believe less government is better government. Social democrats ought to spend their waking hours thinking of ways in which the power of the state can be harnessed to national improvement and the pursuit of social justice. To govern is to legislate. Yet from mid-January until, it now appears, mid-June there will have been little or no effective policy-making. Within 48 hours Mr Blair must put us out of our misery. We have given up on dancing round the Maypole. Mustering enthusiasm for a canter round a June poll is not going to be easy.

The past few days have displayed all the well-known deformations of the Blair era. Decisions are weighed in the scales of polls and focus groups and spun in mass-circulation newspapers. The cabinet is sidelined and the parliamentary Labour party ignored. Excited, ill-considered language about crisis and nationhood inflates public expectations and comes to dictate policy. The prime minister, unable to trust the capacity of his colleagues but unwilling to sack them, bounds to the front of the stage to take personal charge. The upshot is that foot and mouth, a regional and sectoral problem fundamentally to do with the small-scale economics of pastoral farming, is allowed to preoccupy the whole government as if indeed it were a national and general question. The casualties of that diversion of political attention are easy to see. Not by chance are they policies affecting the urban majority. Mr Blair's lack of focus has allowed London transport to become a political and probably also now a financial disaster. Railtrack is foundering. The huge administrative reorganisation that may be necessary if Labour is to deliver its spending promises is put on hold because the prime minister is busy elsewhere. Gus Macdonald, who seems to have taken to the Rottweiler role with enthusiasm, tells us the prime minister's decision on election timing will be "informed by what is best for the country". But which country, Gus? Only a prime minister with some misty-eyed Baldwinian aspiration to unite us all in happy-ever-after land could fail to see that what has happened in livestock farming exhibits deep conflicts of interest between producers and consumers, tax-eaters and tax-payers, animal-lovers and those to whom sheep and pigs are mere industrial materials. Michael Portillo's charge that the government is dithering is hard to rebut, hypocritical though the Tories are to make it. Ministers' diaries have emptied. The machinery of state is stalled. A deathly calm hangs over the corridors of power - and this situation of stasis looks like it will last even longer now. Conservatives believe less government is better government. Social democrats ought to spend their waking hours thinking of ways in which the power of the state can be harnessed to national improvement and the pursuit of social justice. To govern is to legislate. Yet from mid-January until, it now appears, mid-June there will have been little or no effective policy-making. Within 48 hours Mr Blair must put us out of our misery. We have given up on dancing round the Maypole. Mustering enthusiasm for a canter round a June poll is not going to be easy.

Prime minister to delay election until June 7

Special report: New Labour in power

fields.trailText: Tony Blair will today announce that he has abandoned plans for a general election on May 3 in deference to the foot and mouth crisis, but his aides insisted that he would not let the polling date slide beyond his new target date of June 7.
fields.body:
Tony Blair will today announce that he has abandoned plans for a general election on May 3 in deference to the foot and mouth crisis, but his aides insisted that he would not let the polling date slide beyond his new target date of June 7.

No formal announcement of the new date will be made today, because civil service rules would interpret such an announcement as the start of the election campaign and require ministers to go into a form of purdah.

Instead, Jack Straw, the home secretary, will tell the Commons that he intends to table emergency legislation to delay the county council elections, planned for May 3, until June 7.

Mr Blair telephoned cabinet members on Saturday to tell them that he had finally come down in favour of delay. The mood switched in his camp on Thursday and Friday. Cabinet members and union leaders were willing to accept the risks inherent in his one-month delay, but only on the proviso that the prime minister gives a private commitment not to postpone again.

No one in the Labour movement is willing to countenance an autumn poll during a possible economic downturn. "We have shown the farmers we are listening, but we are not going to do this again," said one cabinet minister.

The deferral to June, the subject of heartsearching in Downing Street all last week, means parliament need not be dissolved until Tuesday May 15, giving exhausted ministers nearly another four weeks of parliament, including the difficult Easter season when the teaching union conferences meet. But it also gives the army, the vets and the embattled Ministry of Agriculture six weeks to produce clear signs that the foot and mouth epidemic is under control.

Mr Blair made the decision against the fluctuating advice of some cabinet ministers after accepting that foot and mouth would still dominate his and the media's attention for the foreseeable future. A majority of the public, the farming unions, bishops, the Tory leader William Hague and the Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy had all supported delay.

The only serious countervailing force had been the beleaguered tourist industry and some senior cabinet ministers, including Gordon Brown and John Prescott. Neither was in the mood to condemn Mr Blair in private or public, although some claimed that Mr Blair's unelected advisers had en joyed undue influence. All sides accept that the choice of the election date is the prerogative of the prime minister, but some Labour aides fear that Mr Blair will take a short-term knock for looking weak and no longer in control of events.

Michael Portillo, the shadow chancellor, accused him of dithering and other Tories called for a delay until the autumn when the rural crisis should be cleared.

There were more than 40 new cases on Saturday, and the total number reached 891 by yesterday afternoon.

Nick Brown, the minister of agriculture, will today again delay the decision on whether to vaccinate dairy cattle in Cumbria, despite promising on Friday to make a decision within 48 hours.

The deferral reflects continuing opposition from farming unions. Mr Blair will again meet scientific experts today aware that a vacinnation go-ahead could lead to a year long ban on British meat exports and damage to the Cumbrian milk industry.

More than 940,000 animals have been earmarked for slaughter, with 353,000 waiting to be killed and 166,000 carcasses awaiting disposal.

Tim Yeo, Mr Brown's Tory shadow, said the number of animals waiting to be killed was more than double the number than when Tony Blair took personal charge. But the army hopes to have 180 trucks shifting cattle and sheep for burial by today taking them closer to their target of 24 hours from diagnosis to slaughter.

Despite the lack of a formal announcement,ministers went out in a phalanx yesterday to explain Mr Blair's thinking. John Reid, the Northern Ireland secretary, said on GMTV: "The prime minister is someone who by instinct believes in unity rather than division, somone who wants to be inclusive rather than exclusive." A slight delay in the elections would, he said, be a sign of sensitivity.

Mr Straw stressed that the delay was likely to be a one-off show of support to rural communities. He said the decision had not been governed "in terms of the practicalities of running polls but it's much more to do with sensitivity about the issue and the countryside, taking account of the national mood".

Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, said: "I can well understand why he may well come to the view that we need some more time to make sure we have got in place the methods, the mechanisms, the resources to cope with the foot and mouth outbreak before we go to the country."

Nevertheless, ministers will be forced to eat their words over claims that delay of the county council elections will seriously damage the tourist industry. Industry chiefs claim they are losing £200m a week in lost revenue and expressed deep disappointment at the decision.

John Redwood, the Tory campaigns chief, said local elections should be postponed in the worst affected areas and Mr Blair should announce when the council polls would be held in other areas.

The disease continued to affect sporting events with yesterday's decision to cancel the Cheltenham festival race meeting, which had been rearranged from March to later this month, after officials confirmed that it was within the foot and mouth exclusion zone. The meeting, which was postponed because of the livestock movement restrictions, was doomed after a new case was confirmed yesterday in Woolstone, a village five miles from the track.

What happens now?

April 2

Prime minister and home secretary to confirm local council elections will be held on June 7.

April 3

Party managers will seek advice from the electoral commission on new spending limits. Expect to be told they can spend an extra £800,000 each.

April 6

Class size and pupil teacher ratio figures released.

April 15

Easter Sunday and teaching union conferences.

April 26

New Deal figures released.

May 14

Last date for dissolution of parliament.

June 6

Monetary policy committee to give interest rate decision.

June 7

General and county council elections.
