fields.headline: How protests, polls and political instinct convinced Blair to move election day
fields.standfirst:
Party hierarchy favoured May but farmers helped sway PM
Election 2001: Foot and mouth
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is not a man to make a decision before he feels politically compelled to, but in the case of the May 3 election he must have felt like a man prematurely committed. For weeks he and his aides had insisted any delay in the council elections would send a desperate message to overseas visitors and cripple the British tourist industry.
fields.body:
Tony Blair is not a man to make a decision before he feels politically compelled to, but in the case of the May 3 election he must have felt like a man prematurely committed. For weeks he and his aides had insisted any delay in the council elections would send a desperate message to overseas visitors and cripple the British tourist industry.

The Sun, on the personal advice of Alastair Campbell, Mr Blair's press secretary, had reported that May 3 was the official election date - news that was a present from Downing Street to the paper for its backing of Labour. The Sun in turn praised Mr Blair for sticking to his guns.

Yet privately there had always been more doubts that the foot and mouth epidemic might destroy the planning. By Thursday Mr Blair, Mr Campbell and the inner circle had come to believe delay was unavoidable.

The final decision appears to have been made by Mr Blair on Friday, when the news started to seep through the higher echelons of the party. The prime minister's decision was resolved after meetings with farmers in Dumfries and Galloway. Cabinet members were not individually told until Saturday, by phone by Mr Blair.

Straining at the leash

Many of the big figures in the cabinet and at the party's headquarters at Millbank had favoured May, but with one or two exceptions everyone accepted the final judgment on date to be finely balanced. The only proviso was that if Mr Blair plumped for June there could be no further slippage - he would not only look weak but be prey to rightwing interests.

One ministerial source said: "It would be wrong to characterise this as a united cabinet defied by the prime minister. We all have the same political instincts and are subject to the same pressures as [Mr Blair]. A lot of people were shifting last week to June and ultimately everyone accepted that anyway this was a decision for the prime minister."

The first indications of a serious wobble came on Thursday when Mr Blair met the chancellor Gordon Brown - who is also the party election coordinator - after some gruelling meetings with the National Farmers' Union. He also had a meeting with his inner circle, which included Pat MacFadden, Anji Hunter, Mr Campbell and his pollster Philip Gould.

Mr Brown, like John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, had favoured May. Close to the Millbank machine, Mr Prescott and Mr Brown were straining at the leash.

But Mr Blair felt that the Ministry of Agriculture figures were showing no clear sign that the foot and mouth epidemic could be credibly described as under control. New cases were running at 40 a day, requiring the culling not just of these animals but those on neighbouring farms. The logistical exercise was massive.

In Cumbria the proposed 24 hours target from detection of the virus to slaughter was nowhere near being met and the number of animals to be buried was rising. Protests were rising over plans to open up new burial sites. And the farmers' union could not be persuaded to vaccinate dairy cattle in Cumbria.

Mr Blair feared he could not credibly promise to make foot and mouth his top priority, then call an election. In conversation with cabinet ministers he set out the case for delay, including his belief that he did not want to win the election on the basis of a split in the country and bitter arguments over the campaign's timing.

One cabinet source said Mr Blair seemed to see himself not just as a one nation leader but almost as father to the nation.

Mr Blair was strongly supported at that time by some of his closest Downing Street confidantes, including the Cabinet Office minister Lord Falconer, his personal assistant Ms Hunter, and Mr Gould.

According to Mr Gould, 25 seats were likely to be lost due to public anger if the poll occurred in May; he felt strengthened by his own private poll for the party last weekend and the Mori poll in the Times showing a rock solid 18-19 point lead that was unlikely to evaporate. A Telegraph poll at the weekend confirmed the view at Downing Street that the public opposed an early poll. The Gallup poll showed 13% thought that in a May poll they would be less likely to vote Labour.

Throughout, Blair was canvassing opinion. Supposedly in exile, Peter Mandelson, the former Northern Ireland secretary, had persistently advised Mr Blair of the necessity of delay to make a credible one nation appeal. However some cabinet members, including Alan Milburn, the health secretary, also favoured June, warning that the first two weeks of the election would be about foot and mouth rather than Labour's agenda of jobs, public services and the Tory threat.

Knife-edge decision

Mr Milburn was sure that delay from May did not raise the threat of being knocked off course in June. David Blunkett, the education secretary, favoured May but told Blair it was a knife-edge decision. Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, wanted May but by the end of the week had swung to June. Jack Straw, the home secretary, was for May but in the past few days realised the virtue of delay. He did not see a practical case against May - such as rural areas being unable to vote - but accepted the case for sensitivity.

The strongest opposition came from Mr Prescott and Mr Brown, the two most closely associated with the Millbank campaign machine. Mr Prescott's people on Wednesday claimed no one favoured June. But neither of these men fought Mr Blair to the death over it.

On Thursday Mr Brown met his closest electoral advisers in a private room at a Soho restaurant - some present, including advisers linked to US Democrats, warned that the first two weeks would be dominated by the foot and mouth outbreak. Those who wanted to press ahead pointed out that only the rightwing press, the farmers and the Tories championed delay. Less than 1% of farms had suffered an outbreak of the disease. One cabinet member even blamed the BBC, saying it was "run by youngsters running a vegetarian agenda; the coverage ... totally out of proportion".

The party general secretary, Margaret McDonagh, advised that Labour had set aside millions for poster spending in April linked to good economic news, and these billboards could not be cancelled. Equally the party and unions had published a lot of election literature. The GMB union had printed 500,000 leaflets - but little, or none of it, said "Vote Labour on May 3".

The prime minister knows his decision is not one by which he is likely to benefit partywise. Whatever the result on June 7 there will be voices claiming that if he had gone earlier he would saved more seats.

Doubtless by now he will be seeing the great virtue of fixed term parliaments.

webTitle: Comment: Election date should have been May

fields.headline: With apologies to the sheep, it should have been May
fields.standfirst: The prime minister has nothing to gain by delaying the election
fields.trailText: The prime minister has nothing to gain by delaying the election.
fields.body:
From beneath his familiar black fedora Kenneth Clarke ventured a cheerful mid-week prediction about the date of the general election. "It's decision time for Tony Blair, isn't it? And he's not very good at taking decisions."

So would the election be on May 3 or June 7? "He'd be mad to postpone it," said Clarke without a moment's hesitation. I thought that too. So did the Labour MP who excitedly reported that he'd just seen General Sir Mike Jackson on TV - in camouflage and red beret - taking on all those unarmed cattle.

"That means it must be May 3," the MP explained. Until they read Saturday morning's Sun - New Labour's equivalent of the Official Gazette - most cabinet ministers thought so too, though those with long memories will remember that 10 days earlier the Sun had said with equally self-important certainty that it would not be June. The editor had virtually been to the Palace to tell the Queen. Equally unembarrassable, ministers have also been coming round fast since learning that the prime minister had changed his mind at the end of a week of intermittent wobbling. The party machine at Millbank - and in the constituencies - will be less easily placated.

This was not an aircraft taxiing down the runway, only to be called back by air traffic control. The election plane was airborne somewhere over the Irish Sea when the drinks were spilled in first class and the peanuts scattered in economy on Friday night. The result: an emergency landing, burned rubber, money leaking like fuel, adrenalin gone to waste. And for what, activists and officials will be asking each other today when postponement of the county council elections obliquely confirms the larger delay.

To appease the farmers who don't like Labour anyway ? To impress the Countryside Alliance and the editor of the Daily Telegraph, who don't vote for Blair either? To please the bishops whom Mrs Thatcher spent 11 largely-successful years taking no notice of whatsoever?

I must admit I had a wobble myself long before Downing Street appeared to cotton on to just how grim things were in much of the countryside. It would obviously be logistically possible to stage the elections. Telephone canvassing, postal votes, Millbank had all the answers. But would it be appropriate amid so much rural distress? Or a bit like going to a party straight after granny's funeral?

It did not take much to unwobble me. As the scale of the traffic in infected animals emerged from the agri-economy and the logistics of slaughter/burial/vaccination loomed ever larger, it became obvious that Britain will not be out of this crisis in a hurry. Certainly not by June 7, this year or next.

As the story was spread around the world by our efficient (and hysterical) media, the growing damage to tourism - a far more important industry by any test - could only be compounded by delay. Americans already think our feet and hands are dropping off.

So, delay will benefit no one and may add to the financial burdens in already hard-pressed regions. With lanes closed and hungry sheep on the Ridgeway, prosperous west Berkshire looked disease-free but quietly miserable yesterday. Cumbria - and it is mainly Cumbria - must be awful. But not many of us live or work there. Life goes on, except in Whitehall where the decision-making process, never hyperactive, remains grid-locked until the election is won or lost.

There is also the question of will. If Mr Blair is seen in four weeks' time to have got on top of the crisis and earned well-deserved plaudits after an admittedly slow start, he may well claim to have "put country before party" and re-earned his laurels as a One Nation leader. A handsome second term majority will be his just reward. That is what cabinet loyalists say. "Tony's great strength is his One Nation instinct," says one of the pro-June 7 minority. "The decision will undermine the claims that Labour is anti-countryside. It will also make it awkward for William Hague to conduct an election campaign over the next 10 weeks after what he's said."

That is the sort of upbeat spin I expect Alastair Campbell to put on events when he feeds the vultures at this morning's 11 o'clock briefing in the basement of No 10, albeit, I suspect, with more enthusiasm than he privately feels. Yet the same result could have been achieved by Blair devoting the first half of the campaign - until after Easter - to the rural crisis, leaving the vulgar electioneering to Gordon Brown. He would not have minded!

As things stand, Blair-bashers, Ken Clarke for instance, will crow that the prime minister has again been pushed off course by his own lack of inner certainty and belief, or by his desire to be liked. "The minute you say 'Why don't the electorate love us?' you're on the road to ruin," a senior No 10 adviser admitted recently.

Quite. Yet the chancellor's March 7 budget quietly paid £1.9bn worth of Danegeld to the road protest lobby, despite the No Surrender rhetoric. But, as with the fuel protest, Blair will today again look like a leader who is more concerned to appease his natural enemies than reward his friends, more concerned to listen to his unelected kitchen cabinet - Philip Gould, the Eeyore of pollsters, is likely to have had a hand in this - than to his elected cabinet colleagues.

Delay must have irritated the Sun, but has it pleased the Daily Mail? We shall see. There remains the niggling doubt that this delay has something to do with our muddled sentimentality towards animals, whom we seem happy to battery-farm and kill in huge numbers provided no one reminds us what is happening.

fields.headline: Peers compromise over hunting bill
fields.standfirst: Special report: the hunting debate
fields.trailText: Hopes of a pre-election compromise on fox hunting will rise today when Countryside Alliance peers give their support to an independent statutory body to oversee the future of the sport.
fields.body:
Hopes of a pre-election compromise on fox hunting will rise today when Countryside Alliance peers give their support to an independent statutory body to oversee the future of the sport.

The body would have powers to fine hunts and individuals if they breach an agreed code, as well as a duty to investigate any complaint against a hunt or individuals. The proposals have the backing of the Countryside Alliance and represent a shift in its thinking.

The alliance hopes that the amendments to the hunting bill tabled by the Labour peer Baroness Mallalieu - combined with support for a review of the law on animal cruelty - will be seen by the government as a significant concession.

Downing Street wants a deal on fox hunting, but was dismayed when peers last week threw out not just a ban on hunting, but also any form of independent regulation, the so-called middle-way option. Peers voted for total self-regulation by 249 votes to 108.

A majority of Labour MPs support an outright ban and want the commitment included again in the party's manifesto. But some could be persuaded into a manifesto compromise if they saw hunting subject to a credible regulatory framework which has the support of hunters.

Along with Baroness Mallalieu, who is president of the Countryside Alliance, the amendments are supported by the Conservative peer Lord Mancroft, and Lord Allenby.

The amendments propose that the home secretary establish an independent, statutory eight-strong supervisory body for hunting. Its chairman would be appointed by the home secretary and a report to parliament would be published annually.

Members would be chosen by a selection committee and should at least include a vet, someone experienced in wildlife management, farmers and land managers. Hunting organisations would not be given a direct seat, but would be entitled to give advice.

John Jackson, chairman of the Countryside Alliance, said the body would be independent and have powers to impose sanctions if a code on cruelty was broken. He said hunters were likely to follow a good quality code, but added "there is no question there would have to be a means of ensuring that the hunts complied with the code".

Baroness Mallalieu said her proposals were less bureaucratic than those of the "middle way", did not require licensing of all hunters and hunts, and did not include draconian sanctions of stop and search, as well as forfeiture of hounds.

The alliance admitted that the current independent supervisory authority for hunting suffered from a lack of public confidence, even though it is chaired by a high court judge. No member of the public has made a complaint to the body since it was established by hunting groups.

Mr Jackson said the proposals to be tabled today were better conceived than the ideas put forward by the "middle way" group and roundly rejected by peers last week.

He insisted the Burns inquiry into the future of hunting had demonstrated that there was insufficient evidence to show that hunting was any worse than other forms of animal culling.

Mr Jackson said: "The law on cruelty to animals was in an incredible mess. If someone stamped a fox to death, a criminal offence would have been committed. But if he shot a fox in the gut leaving him to die over three days, no law has been broken."

"Because of past history, there is undoubtedly a problem of public confidence and that leads one in the direction of tidying up the law on cruelty to animals, and setting up an open and publicly accountable system of supervision of hunting."

He added that he would like a wider review of animal welfare in Britain, covering scientific experiments, animal husbandry, wildlife management and the treatment of pets.

If the election is delayed, there is only a small chance that peers will hold a further committee stage in the Lords for bill. However, Baroness Mallalieu, said she welcomed the chance to discuss the amendments in committee to show how far the alliance has moved to find a compromise.

"The minute you say 'Why don't the electorate love us?' you're on the road to ruin," a senior No 10 adviser admitted recently. Quite. Yet the chancellor's March 7 budget quietly paid £1.9bn worth of Danegeld to the road protest lobby, despite the No Surrender rhetoric. Sensible politics in the circumstances, and it was good to see the Daily Mail advocating European tax harmonisation on fuel duties. But, as with the fuel protest, Blair will today again look like a leader who is more concerned to appease his natural enemies than reward his friends, more concerned to listen to his unelected kitchen cabinet - Philip Gould, the Eeyore of pollsters, is likely to have had a hand in this - than to his elected cabinet colleagues. Delay must have irritated the Sun, but has it pleased the Daily Mail? We shall see. There remains the niggling doubt that this delay has something to do with our muddled sentimentality towards animals, whom we seem happy to battery-farm and kill in huge numbers provided no one reminds us what is happening. So, in these sentimental and credulous times, we weep for both lambs and foxes, but not for steel workers. And Mr Blair is a man of his time, more so perhaps than the rational Ken Clarke. michael.white@theguardian.com Email update Sign up for our free daily foot and mouth round-up More on the election and foot and mouth Politics: foot and mouth What's going on? Special report: New Labour in power
Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is not a man to make a decision before he feels politically compelled to, but in the case of the May 3 election he must have felt like a man prematurely committed. For weeks he and his aides had insisted any delay in the council elections would send a desperate message to overseas visitors and cripple the British tourist industry.
fields.body:
Tony Blair is not a man to make a decision before he feels politically compelled to, but in the case of the May 3 election he must have felt like a man prematurely committed. For weeks he and his aides had insisted any delay in the council elections would send a desperate message to overseas visitors and cripple the British tourist industry.

The Sun, on the personal advice of Alastair Campbell, Mr Blair's press secretary, had reported that May 3 was the official election date - news that was a present from Downing Street to the paper for its backing of Labour. The Sun in turn praised Mr Blair for sticking to his guns.

Yet privately there had always been more doubts that the foot and mouth epidemic might destroy the planning. By Thursday Mr Blair, Mr Campbell and the inner circle had come to believe delay was unavoidable.

The final decision appears to have been made by Mr Blair on Friday, when the news started to seep through the higher echelons of the party. The prime minister's decision was resolved after meetings with farmers in Dumfries and Galloway. Cabinet members were not individually told until Saturday, by phone by Mr Blair.

Straining at the leash

Many of the big figures in the cabinet and at the party's headquarters at Millbank had favoured May, but with one or two exceptions everyone accepted the final judgment on date to be finely balanced. The only proviso was that if Mr Blair plumped for June there could be no further slippage - he would not only look weak but be prey to rightwing interests.

One ministerial source said: "It would be wrong to characterise this as a united cabinet defied by the prime minister. We all have the same political instincts and are subject to the same pressures as [Mr Blair]. A lot of people were shifting last week to June and ultimately everyone accepted that anyway this was a decision for the prime minister."

The first indications of a serious wobble came on Thursday when Mr Blair met the chancellor Gordon Brown - who is also the party election coordinator - after some gruelling meetings with the National Farmers' Union. He also had a meeting with his inner circle, which included Pat MacFadden, Anji Hunter, Mr Campbell and his pollster Philip Gould.

Mr Brown, like John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, had favoured May. Close to the Millbank machine, Mr Prescott and Mr Brown were straining at the leash.

But Mr Blair felt that the Ministry of Agriculture figures were showing no clear sign that the foot and mouth epidemic could be credibly described as under control. New cases were running at 40 a day, requiring the culling not just of these animals but those on neighbouring farms. The logistical exercise was massive.

In Cumbria the proposed 24 hours target from detection of the virus to slaughter was nowhere near being met and the number of animals to be buried was rising. Protests were rising over plans to open up new burial sites. And the farmers' union could not be persuaded to vaccinate dairy cattle in Cumbria.

Mr Blair feared he could not credibly promise to make foot and mouth his top priority, then call an election. In conversation with cabinet ministers he set out the case for delay, including his belief that he did not want to win the election on the basis of a split in the country and bitter arguments over the campaign's timing.

One cabinet source said Mr Blair seemed to see himself not just as a one nation leader but almost as father to the nation.

Mr Blair was strongly supported at that time by some of his closest Downing Street confidantes, including the Cabinet Office minister Lord Falconer, his personal assistant Ms Hunter, and Mr Gould.

According to Mr Gould, 25 seats were likely to be lost due to public anger if the poll occurred in May; he felt strengthened by his own private poll for the party last weekend and the Mori poll in the Times showing a rock solid 18-19 point lead that was unlikely to evaporate. A Telegraph poll at the weekend confirmed the view at Downing Street that the public opposed an early poll. The Gallup poll showed 13% thought that in a May poll they would be less likely to vote Labour.

Throughout, Blair was canvassing opinion. Supposedly in exile, Peter Mandelson, the former Northern Ireland secretary, had persistently advised Mr Blair of the necessity of delay to make a credible one nation appeal. However some cabinet members, including Alan Milburn, the health secretary, also favoured June, warning that the first two weeks of the election would be about foot and mouth rather than Labour's agenda of jobs, public services and the Tory threat.

Knife-edge decision

Mr Milburn was sure that delay from May did not raise the threat of being knocked off course in June. David Blunkett, the education secretary, favoured May but told Blair it was a knife-edge decision. Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, wanted May but by the end of the week had swung to June. Jack Straw, the home secretary, was for May but in the past few days realised the virtue of delay. He did not see a practical case against May - such as rural areas being unable to vote - but accepted the case for sensitivity.

The strongest opposition came from Mr Prescott and Mr Brown, the two most closely associated with the Millbank campaign machine. Mr Prescott's people on Wednesday claimed no one favoured June. But neither of these men fought Mr Blair to the death over it.

On Thursday Mr Brown met his closest electoral advisers in a private room at a Soho restaurant - some present, including advisers linked to US Democrats, warned that the first two weeks would be dominated by the foot and mouth outbreak. Those who wanted to press ahead pointed out that only the rightwing press, the farmers and the Tories championed delay. Less than 1% of farms had suffered an outbreak of the disease. One cabinet member even blamed the BBC, saying it was "run by youngsters running a vegetarian agenda; the coverage ... totally out of proportion".

The party general secretary, Margaret McDonagh, advised that Labour had set aside millions for poster spending in April linked to good economic news, and these billboards could not be cancelled. Equally the party and unions had published a lot of election literature. The GMB union had printed 500,000 leaflets - but little, or none of it, said "Vote Labour on May 3".

The prime minister knows his decision is not one by which he is likely to benefit partywise. Whatever the result on June 7 there will be voices claiming that if he had gone earlier he would saved more seats.

Doubtless by now he will be seeing the great virtue of fixed term parliaments.

fields.headline: But has he done the right thing?
fields.standfirst:
Special report: New Labour in power
Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: John Curtice, deputy director, ESRC centre for research into elections and social trends
fields.body:
John Curtice, deputy director, ESRC centre for research into elections and social trends

Yesterday's Mori poll showed that, although the percentage of people who think the government is handling foot and mouth well has almost doubled since a week ago, they don't think Tony Blair can run an election campaign and deal with foot and mouth at the same time.

Delaying the election until June is the decision I'd have made. But there's a risk that foot and mouth won't be better by then, and that will have wider implications for agriculture and tourism and mean economic confidence declines. Blair made a decision against the advice of the majority of his party, so the stakes are raised. If he doesn't get a large majority, he can forget commanding the party in the way he has for seven years.

Paul Stinchcombe, Labour MP for Wellingborough, the party's most marginal seat (majority 187)

Delaying until June 7 was difficult. I think it's right that Blair has been listening carefully to the farmers and tourist industry. He's had to make a decision that's right for the country rather than the party. I think they have made the right policy decisions on foot and mouth; the army is doing the right things, Maff is doing the right things, and clearly it's coming under control. He was in a position to run an election but if he decided the crisis was on such a scale it would be inappropriate, that's a courageous decision.

Patrick Nicholls, Tory MP for Teignbridge, the Conservatives' least secure seat (majority 281)

Deciding not to hold the election on May 3 was the right thing to do. It would have been unseemly to have an election going on with the foot and mouth crisis at its height. I can understand that if you've been in opposition for 18 years, it's politics, politics, politics, but, after four years, he should have been able to think beyond that. Delaying the election is recognition that this is a national crisis. I simply don't know whether this delay's good, bad or indifferent for the Tories or for me personally. A reasonable presumption is we're going to do considerably better than we did last time. But while the farmers may come out to support us, they may stay at home in misery and despair.

The Right Rev Michael Turnbull, Bishop of Durham

I don't see how the crisis in the countryside is going to have changed very much by June. Even if the disease is seen to be under control, the repercussions are not going to go away. There will still be enormous pain and it may well have knock-on effects on the tourist industry. I doubt whether delaying it for a month gets us anywhere except to extend uncertainty.

[With] modern media communications and postal votes, I don't think it disenfranchises people. The prime minister has had a lot of firsthand contact with the farming community and I respect his judgment.

Andrew Spence, north-east coordinator for Farmers for Action

I'm standing against Tony Blair in Sedgefield for the UK Independence Party. For me the election can't come soon enough. But I thought it should be postponed until there was a conclusion over the foot and mouth outbreak. That would have been the only way forward and the only way that he'd have secured the confidence of the people.

And we're seeing the tip of the iceberg; they've just opened a tip near my farm to dump 100,000 lambs and now they're saying cattle will go in there too.

If you're going to hold an election you want 100% of people who are prepared to vote to be able to do so. At the moment the countryside is basically blocked off.

webTitle: Cook blames press for Vaz's collapse

fields.headline: Cook blames press for Vaz's collapse
fields.trailText: Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, yesterday blamed the press for provoking the collapse that left Keith Vaz, the Europe minister, in hospital.
fields.body:
Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, yesterday blamed the press for provoking the collapse that left Keith Vaz, the Europe minister, in hospital.

Mr Vaz collapsed on Thursday after recording a television interview and has been advised not to work for eight weeks. He had been under intense pressure after the Commons standards watchdog accused him of frustrating its investigation into his affairs.

Mr Cook called for the "hounding" of Mr Vaz to stop in an interview on ITV's Jonathan Dimbleby programme. He said: "This is a man who is entitled to rest and I wish the press, who have been pursuing him mercilessly over the last two months, would sometimes respect that their victims are human and that what they do can have - as it has in this case - a human consequence."

He continued: "I do think it would be helpful if at this present time the media were to understand that this man is hu man ... This is a man who is seriously ill and has been ordered to take time off and I don't think he should be badgered and harried and harassed."

Mr Cook stressed that Mr Vaz had been cleared by the standards and privileges committee of 14 out of 15 allegations levelled against him.

Mr Cook confirmed there would be no direct replacement appointed to cover Mr Vaz during his convalescence.

Despite Mr Vaz's acquittal by the committee of all but one complaint, the Tories demanded his resignation after he was criticised for refusing to cooperate with the inquiry by Elizabeth Filkin, the parliamentary commissioner for standards.

Since then Ms Filkin has announced that she is to open a fresh investigation into his links with the wealthy Hinduja brothers and he has been criticised by another committee of MPs for his handling of Balkans issues.

webTitle: Let's establish a fair rate for care

fields.headline: Let's establish a fair rate for care
fields.standfirst: As the new national care standards commission gets under way, Les Bright calls for the commission or a new care homes regulator to set the minimum fee that councils should pay for places
fields.trailText: As the new national care standards commission gets under way, Les Bright calls for the commission or a new care homes regulator to set the minimum fee that councils should pay for places.
fields.body:
A year ago, Counsel and Care called for a care homes regulator. We were convinced that pressures being exerted by local authorities, in their role as purchasers, were having a bad effect on the care sector. Nothing we have seen since has changed our mind.

Then, homes were under-occupied, leading to business failure, closures and high levels of anxiety for older people living in them. Yet, some older people remained "trapped in hospital beds", either because of a shortage of money to purchase places or the unwillingness of proprietors to take on new residents at clearly uneconomic prices.

The range of homes available to prospective new residents has since decreased, and in some cases homes have refused to accept residents placed by local authority social workers. Of course, if the resident's family can top up the fee paid by social services, then a place can be found. But often close relatives are on low incomes or pensions themselves, with little scope for finding up to £50 pounds a week.

Major service purchasers have as much power to influence the market as monopoly providers - and the public sector buys around 70% of care home places. As a result of local authorities performing their role "managing the market" in care, there has been a contraction in the number of places and homes, and in the number of homes still prepared to take publicly funded residents.

For a number of years, care home owners in many parts of the country have received increases less than inflation. In extreme cases they have even faced reductions to the fees paid. What this means in practice is that homes are expected to provide full board and personal care for less than most readers would pay to stay in modest bed and breakfast accommodation.

Some councils think there is scope for reducing the amount paid per client, because people are making good profits from their businesses. While that may have been the case in the past, recent economic jitters, a rash of mergers to avoid businesses collapsing, and the lure of selling a large house and grounds for its development potential, rather than as a going concern, suggests that those days are long since over.

It is time for action to set up a body capable of setting and monitoring a fair rate for care. In other industries, such as gas and telecoms, where private companies now provide services which were once public monopolies, privatisation has been accompanied by the creation of a consumer protection body. This has the power to fine or place other sanctions on providers whose services do not meet the agreed standards.

Individual consumers can often shop around. But older residents have few options, assuming their needs even fit with councils' eligibility criteria for admission to care homes and financial support. A further narrowing of that choice should be avoided by setting a minimum price that local authorities should pay for care. Such a price would need to reflect the real cost of providing care to the level soon to be demanded by the implementation of the new national minimum standards for the conduct of care homes.

The brand new national care standards commission, formally established this month, takes full responsibility for registering and inspecting care services from next April. It will make the inspections process more consistent but it will not be able to direct the market as other industry regulators.

There is a strong link between the price paid for goods, and the quality and usefulness of the goods supplied. To ensure that some of our most vulnerable citizens don't end up with "shoddy goods", there needs to be a way of setting fees at a level which will cover decent care. Either the commission or a new care homes regulator should take up this role. Prescriptive? Yes. But logical - and definitely worth a try.

We were convinced that pressures being exerted by local authorities, in their role as purchasers, were having a bad effect on the care sector. Nothing we have seen since has changed our mind. Then, homes were under-occupied, leading to business failure, closures and high levels of anxiety for older people living in them. Yet, some older people remained "trapped in hospital beds", either because of a shortage of money to purchase places or the unwillingness of proprietors to take on new residents at clearly uneconomic prices. The range of homes available to prospective new residents has since decreased, and in some cases homes have refused to accept residents placed by local authority social workers. Of course, if the resident's family can top up the fee paid by social services, then a place can be found. But often close relatives are on low incomes or pensions themselves, with little scope for finding up to £50 pounds a week. Major service purchasers have as much power to influence the market as monopoly providers - and the public sector buys around 70% of care home places. As a result of local authorities performing their role "managing the market" in care, there has been a contraction in the number of places and homes, and in the number of homes still prepared to take publicly funded residents. For a number of years, care home owners in many parts of the country have received increases less than inflation. In extreme cases they have even faced reductions to the fees paid. What this means in practice is that homes are expected to provide full board and personal care for less than most readers would pay to stay in modest bed and breakfast accommodation. Some councils think there is scope for reducing the amount paid per client, because people are making good profits from their businesses. While that may have been the case in the past, recent economic jitters, a rash of mergers to avoid businesses collapsing, and the lure of selling a large house and grounds for its development potential, rather than as a going concern, suggests that those days are long since over. It is time for action to set up a body capable of setting and monitoring a fair rate for care. In other industries, such as gas and telecoms, where private companies now provide services which were once public monopolies, privatisation has been accompanied by the creation of a consumer protection body. This has the power to fine or place other sanctions on providers whose services do not meet the agreed standards. Individual consumers can often shop around. fields.headline: Finance marketeers relish UK's rising affluence
fields.trailText: 8.30pm: Finance companies are targeting a growing group of consumers known as the 'mass affluent', reports Julia Day.
fields.body:
Financial services marketeers will be rubbing their hands with glee - the rich are getting richer and they are in desperate need of advice about what to do with their money.

Banks, building societies and independent financial advisers have all started targeting a new group of consumers, the "mass affluent" - people who have substantial sums of money but are not millionaires.

There are 3.7m people in the UK who fall into the mass affluent category, according to a report from the research company Datamonitor.

The report says 7.9% of the population of the UK has liquid assets of between £30,000 and £200,000.

But it predicts this group is set to soar to 4.9m people by 2004.

As 17% of the current mass affluent market do not have any investments and only 40% hold ISAs, they are rich pickings for the financial services industry.

"There has been a huge surge of interest in the mass affluent sector - financial service providers have rushed in to take advantage of a growing market," said Michele Gorman, lead financial services analyst at Datamonitor.

The majority of mass affluents are white, male, over 35 years old and living in the south-east of England. But over-55s account for 38% of the market.

The research also revealed the number of millionaires in the UK has grown at a rate of more than 17% a year since 1995 - reaching 73,990 in 2000.

Datamonitor is launching a research and consultancy service dedicated to looking at the mass affluent market.

fields.headline: ITN slammed for recycling material
fields.trailText: 8.30am: ITN has been criticised for putting material from its TV channel straight onto News Direct 97.3FM, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
ITN has had its wrists slapped by the Radio Authority after it recycled material from its TV news channel and used it on the News Direct radio station.

In its quarterly programme and advertising bulletin, the Radio Authority has given ITN a yellow card.

A spokeswoman said the authority was concerned about the amount of national and international news from ITN's News Channel being broadcast on News Direct 97.3FM, which is licensed as a London-based station.

The Radio Authority was concerned that News Direct 97.3FM was failing to provide a high enough level of news coverage relevant to London, a spokeswoman confirmed.

The spokeswoman said there were also "technical problems" with the sound quality broadcast over the radio.

She said parts of the soundtrack had been lifted straight from ITN's News Channel TV station without any adaptation for radio.

In some cases, references were made that were irrelevant on the radio.

"In some cases, news bulletins indicated things visually that were not audible over the radio," she said.

The warning follows reports earlier in the year that ITN was forced to tone down a revamp of the station's output after objections from the Radio Authority.

ITN is understood to have abandoned plans to stream all its overnight radio material from News Channel in the wake of the Radio Authority's objections.

"We had some technical difficulties after the relaunch of ITN News Direct but these were resolved some weeks ago," said an ITN spokesman.

He added that the Radio Authority had allowed some selective reuse of television material.

The Radio Authority said it was confident the problem would be resolved after discussions with ITN.

webTitle: C4 to overhaul Smash Hits awards

fields.headline: C4 to overhaul Smash Hits awards
fields.trailText: 8.30pm: Channel 4 is taking over the Smash Hits poll winners party from the BBC, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Channel 4 is taking over the Smash Hits poll winners party from the BBC, after the corporation decided to launch its own Top of the Pops-branded awards last year.

The Smash Hits poll winners party has been running for more than ten years.

It is "the most important event in the UK pop music calendar", according to Trevor Dann, Emap Performance's managing director of pop, who joined last year from the BBC.

The awards show will be shown on Channel 4's youth strand T4 and will undergo a major overhaul.

T4 commissioning editor Jo Wallace said the collaboration was "an extraordinary opportunity to build on this reputation and give T4 viewers this year's hottest pop ticket".

The TV show is to be produced by Done and Dusted, the music production venture that emerged from the ashes of the doomed music portal Switch2.

The deal is the culmination of an agreement signed early last year between Emap and Channel 4, which has so far failed to generate any significant successes.

Emap last week slashed jobs across its digital operations and Channel 4's joint venture Slam is thought to be under review.

webTitle: Sheikh rattles and rolls out star victims

fields.headline: Sheikh rattles and rolls out star victims
fields.standfirst:
As an experienced publicist, Sophie Wessex should really have seen it coming. With the arms trade off its peak, when a Middle Eastern sheikh offers you champagne in a plush London hotel it can only be Mazher Mahmood, writes Matt Wells.

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: As an experienced publicist, Sophie Wessex should really have seen it coming. With the arms trade off its peak, when a Middle Eastern sheikh offers you champagne in a plush London hotel it can only be Mazher Mahmood, writes Matt Wells.
fields.body:
As an experienced publicist, Sophie Wessex should really have seen it coming. With the arms trade off its peak, when a Middle Eastern sheikh offers you champagne in a plush London hotel it can only be Mazher Mahmood, writes Matt Wells.

Mahmood, investigations editor at the News of the World, seems to have a penchant for dressing up as an Arab. The get-up caught out two Newcastle United football club directors, Freddie Shepherd and Douglas Hall, whose disparaging comments about football fans and local women were caught on tape. The DJ Johnnie Walker was jailed for cocaine possession after being snared by Mahmood, again dressed as an Arab.

Mahmood posed as Sheikh Mohammed al-Kareem when he approached London's Burning actor John Alford with the lure of £100,000 to help launch a nightclub in Dubai. Alford claimed he was pressurised into supplying the "sheikh" with cocaine.

Mahmood's methods are legendary. He works secretively, rarely coming into the News of the World office, and employs minders. From the Midlands and the son of a magistrate, his identity is closely guarded and his picture is never printed in the newspaper.

A Mahmood sting is expensive and often complex, including booking suites in top London hotels such as the Savoy or the Ritz.

But although his methods have not been without controversy, Mahmood claims to have secured over 100 convictions.

webTitle: Buyers line up to relieve Scoot of Loot

fields.headline: Buyers line up to relieve Scoot of Loot
fields.standfirst:
More net news
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Scoot, the struggling online directories business, has received a number of approaches for Loot, the classified advertising newspaper it bought last year. by David Teather.
fields.body:
Scoot, the struggling online directories business, has received a number approaches for Loot, the classified advertising newspaper it bought last year.

The company's adviser, investment bank Merrill Lynch, is understood to have entered into discussions with potential buyers of various parts of the business, though Loot is viewed as the prime asset. Interested parties include Trader, a French rival to Scoot which lost out in the bidding for the newspaper last summer.

The approaches come after Merrill was given the mandate 10 days ago to "conduct a review of all strategic options" for Scoot, interpreted by many as hanging a "for sale" sign over the business. The review was announced alongside a widening of the group's losses last year to £71.5m. Scoot was worth £2.5bn at its peak last year during the dot.com boom, but is now valued by the market at £89m.

There is some suggestion that there may have also been an approach for the entire group. Scoot disclosed at its recent results that it has only £31m left in the bank, which would last for less than a year if losses are not stemmed.

Scoot paid £190m for Loot, which also has an online division, nine months ago. If a deal were struck with Trader.com it is understood Scoot would still have access to Loot content in Britain for its websites.

The disposal of Loot would see the loss of the only part of the company making any money - about £100,000 since the acquisition. Reports yesterday said Loot would fetch £75m.

The acquisition of Loot last June resulted in a £40m windfall for the newspaper's founder David Landau. The takeover was funded by Vivendi Universal which increased its shareholding in Scoot to 22.4% as part of the deal.

Scoot though has so far proved to be a poor investment for Vivendi which bought into the company at 230p a share.

The shares are worth 12p and one of the few things to enliven the price over the past 12 months has been persistent rumours that Vivendi would snap up the rest of the company.

Trader.com is listed on Nasdaq and owns a number of classified advertising titles including La Centrale in France and the Melbourne Trading Post.

fields.headline: New media diary
fields.trailText: • A survey of national daily newspaper websites causes much mirth. The rather dubious inclusion is Express.co.uk, the relic of a website that features the ground-breaking device of a scanned front page of the paper (updated daily no less). For this feat of web ingenuity, the site scored 5.3 points (from a total of 20) for "delivery of proposition" and a remarkable 4 for "content". As a barometer, independent.co.uk recorded 9.7 for "proposition", mirror.co.uk 10 for "content" and dailymail.co.uk (a brochure site) 5 for "content". Top of the charts was the Guardian, closely followed by thesun.co.uk and then telegraph.co.uk. But pity ft.com, which came a lowly fourth despite the £100m thrown at it last year. Obviously money well spent.

 A survey of national daily newspaper websites causes much mirth. The rather dubious inclusion is Express.co.uk, the relic of a website that features the ground-breaking device of a scanned front page of the paper (updated daily no less). For this feat of web ingenuity, the site scored 5.3 points (from a total of 20) for "delivery of proposition" and a remarkable 4 for "content". As a barometer, independent.co.uk recorded 9.7 for "proposition", mirror.co.uk 10 for "content" and dailymail.co.uk (a brochure site) 5 for "content". Top of the charts was theguardian.com, closely followed by thesun.co.uk and then telegraph.co.uk. But pity ft.com, which came a lowly fourth despite the £100m thrown at it last year. Obviously money well spent.

 The curse of boo.com struck at Emap Digital last week when it undid a year's worth of painstaking recruitment. The job of axing the 100 staff was divvied up between senior management, but the job of firing two former boo employees fell to former boo chief development officer Luke Alvarez, now Emap Digital's chief operating officer. Oh the irony. The seasoned redundantees took it in their stride and went to the pub, but not the pour souls in Peterborough, who ripped into the strategy director. Cries of disbelief were met with, "Sorry, you've never even been to this office before and now you're going to close us?" Lesson learnt? You have to handle the regions with care.

 As the nation listlessly awaits the general election, it was only a matter of time before the Tory party jumped on the "berate BT" bandwagon. It seems that the Tories reckon a sure-fire election winner is to lynch BT for the slow roll-out of broadband and promise to shake up the auction of broadband fixed wireless if, and this is the important bit, the nation picks the baldy funny-voiced bloke. But there's just so much wrong with that political platitude that it's impossible to know where to start.

 Knock the net all you will, but you have to give it credit for providing disgruntled individuals with a chance to rant. Profiting from this is opinions website DooYoo.co.uk, which this week carries an eye-opening account from a disgruntled BT SurfTime customer who uncovers a nasty catch in the flat-rate internet service. Despite connecting to a freephone number and paying £14.99 a month, users have found they get billed for phone charges when the service is busy (apparently the service automatically connects them to a paid-for number). Ouch.

Amy Vickers is new media editor of mediatheguardian.com

 amy.vickers@theguardian.com

webTitle: Leader: Sophie Wessex duped by tabloid

fields.headline: Sophie's sheikh down
fields.standfirst:
She fell for News of the World's arabesque

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: There is something about a sheikh, as Sophie Wessex (née Rhys-Jones) has just shown. Appear with a burnous and the promise of dosh, and reason flies out the window.
fields.body:
In a Jonathan Miller production of Cosi fan tutte a few years ago Ferrando and Guglielmo pretended to be the Albanian suitors by dressing up as Arabs - a device so transparent that Dorabella and Fiordiligi became an even more stupid pair than the libretto makes them.

But there is something about a sheikh, as Sophie Wessex (née Rhys-Jones) has just shown. Appear with a burnous and the promise of dosh, and reason flies out the window. The News of the World could not care less for Press Complaints Commission rulings on subterfuge, but getting a reporter to pretend to be an Arab sheikh - even a gullible PR person ought to be able to spot this one a mile off.

It cannot just be the fancy dress. Or the scent of money (real enough in the Aitken case, of course). Most of the world's wealthiest live in the United States, and among the Arab members of the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries, the leaders of Algeria or Iraq do not quite fit the Lawrentian stereotype. Yet it seems desert prince imagery - Rudolph Valentino crossed with Frank Herbert and that old ad for Fry's Turkish (sic) Delight - has burned itself into the collective consciousness.

webTitle: 'Now we have to show where the money is'

fields.headline: 'Now we have to show where the money is'
fields.standfirst: Bringing interactivity to television takes on a whole new meaning when you are talking about getting hands-on with Temptation Island.  David Teather meets Jim Rudder, the man charged with making Sky's new services sexy
fields.trailText: Bringing interactivity to television takes on a whole new meaning when you are talking about getting hands-on with Temptation Island. David Teather meets Jim Rudder, the man charged with making Sky's new services sexy
fields.body:
Jim Rudder is getting excited about Temptation Island, the trashy US show on Sky One where couples try to resist the scantily clad charms of single contestants. The show, he says straight-faced, is ripe for interactivity. A demonstration on his laptop shrinks the broadcast stream to a quarter of the screen and a series of options appear.

The mock-up includes voting on contestants online, betting on who will crack first, profiles of the players and the "island shop" - although what that might sell is a little bewildering. BSkyB is holding talks with the producers of the show which could see these ideas becoming reality in the coming months.

Rudder, 42, took the newly created job of director of interactive broadcasting at BSkyB at the end of last year to exploit the opportunities provided by digital television. Apart from a brief spell in Sydney in the mid-90s, he is a BSkyB lifer, joining at launch in 1988.

"It is hard not to sound cocky about what Sky is doing with interactivity," he says in a broad Australian accent. "Other platforms may argue that they are superior or that they are better suited for interactivity, but where the hell are they and what are they doing? Show us."

The broadcaster has made interactivity a key priority in the coming year. Partly for "stickiness", to keep churn figures for Sky Digital low at a time when the cable industry is finally showing signs of getting its act together.

But there is also a more black-and-white commercial rationale. At the company's financial results presentation in February, chief executive Tony Ball outlined ambitious targets to increase the average revenue per subscriber from the current £286 to £400 a year by 2005. Of that increase, Ball expects almost half to come from new interactive services. "We have had a big growth period. Now we have to show where the money is," he said. Temptation Island would include a slice of revenues from the shop and the premium rate line used for voting.

A look back to some of the services launched in the past two years and at some of the corporate deals shows that BSkyB has been putting the blocks in place for some time. Sky Sports Active has demonstrated the appetite for viewers to interact with their televisions - around 40% of subscribers watch football using the enhanced service which gives text information and allows camera angle choice. Sky News Active was the second to launch, again combining text and broadcast, enabling viewers to dip in to video streamed headlines, entertainment, sports or business news.

On the corporate side, BSkyB bought Surrey Sports Group to begin offering online betting. But perhaps the most significant step change has been the integration of Open, the successful retail service which BSkyB now has full control of. The integration has presented Rudder with a large resource of technical expertise while the robust systems in place for Open will allow secure e-commerce (or t-commerce to use the proper term) across the Sky Digital platform.

Crucially, taking control of Open also removed a no-competition clause which was hampering BSkyB from offering interactive services such as shopping or online betting on its other channels.

fields.headline: My New Media
fields.standfirst: Alexander Broich
fields.trailText: Alexander Broich
fields.body:
Favourite websites?

atomfilms.com where you can see various movie trailers but most importantly I check it to watch Angry Kids. I also really like madaboutwine.com. The UK approach towards wine is much less biased than in Europe and it's a whole new world here. The site guides you to specific vintages, say in northern Australia, which is great because I like my red wine.

Last online purchase?

Two things. An Easter vacation to Hamburg to visit my family and a couple of books for my wife.

Last technological faux pas?

Accidentally sending out emails to the wrong person while using Microsoft Outlook. The system recognises a name and finishes off the address but doesn't always pick the name you want.

News sources on the web?

I'm a news junkie so I regularly check ft.com, CNN.com and spiegel.de to get UK, US and German news.

Time spent on the web?

I'm online all day, two hours of which are strictly business related.

Site least likely to succeed?

Concept wise there are hundreds of sites which are not clearly targeted towards a defined group of people. The sites may have a bit of music, some shopping and entertainment but they don't have any concept at all. What is the value? Zero. These sites without focus and quality will disappear because they won't generate any significant revenue.

Most useful site?

Sites which offer a full range of downloads of products. If you want to see a video clip but your PC tells you you don't have the latest version, historically you'd have to call your IT department and then wait three days for them to sort it out. Now you just click on the download button and it takes a few minutes.

Most irritating thing about the web?

The problems being reported on the web are primarily to do with human psychology - like people's need for security. I understand people's worries but it's not rational - there's no safer place for a credit card than the web. I understand that the web is anonymous and you don't know what's going on but if you go to a proper website then it's safe.

Ever been in a chat room?

Yes. I joined a travel-related one about an area in North Carolina as it was difficult to find a guide book. It was quite good and people came up with ideas and recommendations.

Do you still bother with old media?

Very much so. I still read newspapers in the physical form as well as online.

 Alexander Broich is the managing director of bol.com in the UK

webTitle: Take a gamble on digital betting

fields.headline: Take a gamble on digital betting
fields.trailText: Two hundred years after Napoleon called us "a nation of shopkeepers", digital media moguls are banking on us being a nation of gamblers, unable to go five minutes without having a flutter on the horses, the dogs, or the colour of Judy Finnigan's bra.
fields.body:
Two hundred years after Napoleon called us "a nation of shopkeepers", digital media moguls are banking on us being a nation of gamblers, unable to go five minutes without having a flutter on the horses, the dogs, or the colour of Judy Finnigan's bra.

New technology has certainly made it easier for us to place a bet than ever before. At the bookies, on the racecourse (foot and mouth permitting), through the TV set-top box, mobile phone or PC. We can throw away money (which is the point of gambling) to our heart's content. But just because we can bet any time, any place, anywhere, does that mean we all will?

At first glance, the going looks good for the UK runners. BSkyB generated £33m in gambling revenues between July and December 2000. An aggressive and expensive roll-out of set-top boxes boosted this early lead and has got everyone in the new media industry jumping up and down with excitement. When the digital cable and terrestrial platforms join the race for the interactive gambling pound, through their own betting platform, the market dynamic will change.

According to media buying and research company Optimedia, the share of digital homes in 2005 will cross the line at 25.3% BSkyB, 23.6% cable and 7.6% DTT, with almost a third of the country remaining analogue until the latter half of the decade. That's a total of 14.1m digital customers paying an average of £5 each to take a 10% share of the UK's £7bn gambling market.

Gamcare, an organisation which analyses the social impact of gambling in the UK, conducted a survey of 7,680 people in June 2000. The results described a nation of people who like to flutter in the company of other people, playing the National Lottery and bingo for instance, but who don't much care for solitary gambling. Of the 72% who had gambled in the last year 35% bet on the lottery. It's only when you get down to what the survey calls "problem" gamblers, mostly men between the ages of 24 and 35, that the probability of taking a bigger slice of their wallet looks more likely to happen through the set-top box.

Enhanced TV does not necessarily produce enhanced viewers. Interactive evangelists will argue that viewers will bet on the outcome of an (exclusive) game or event as it happens on the screen, therefore generating "live" revenues. All I can say to that is, imagine a group of English football fans betting against David Batty on the spot in 1998. Imagine that. Exactly.

As a mass medium, TV can no doubt take the process of gambling into new areas of the social psyche. If successful, TV betting may well make both men and women consider having a flutter more often, but channelling this new tendency may prove more difficult than its promotion. Betting online is quicker and open to offshore competition. Mobile betting between friends is more socially stimulating and accessible than the set-top box. So while no one will question the ability of the TV to change perception, in reality, it cannot control the way we live our lives.

Globally, however, the market for online betting looks huge. Investment bank Merrill Lynch says that the sector will be worth £125bn by 2015. Remember, though, 12 months ago the same bank also said Amazon would be worth $47.5bn. Today it is worth $3.5bn. So, while investment banks are not expected to be 100% right about their market valuations, we should at least expect them not to be 92.5% wrong.

I n Las Vegas, the Mecca of the gambling world, the MGM Grand hotel has an entire floor of coin-operated Family Feud machines, immersing the Pearson TV brand into the heart of a real gambling community. Special cameras "film" the gamblers and make them part of the game as they pay to play. How this would translate online is immaterial. The point is that no one else can work that hotel floor with that brand and make that money from that community.

Using this as an analogy for the online gambling market in the UK, BSkyB, NTL, Telewest and OnDigital are the new hotels on the block. Their business is only as valuable as the number of new customers they attract through their doors in the next 10 years. The older hotels in this equation are the betting shops, the National Lottery and the bingo halls, who already have an established clientele.

In the battle for viewers and shareholder value, it seems that the digital players are unable to think outside the box when it comes to the promise of easy revenues from gambling. After building the multichannel market on exclusive access to sporting events, they are backing a horse with several riders in a field wide open to outsiders.

Today, in a fragmented media universe, the need for togetherness and communication has never been stronger - witness the popularity of messaging and mobile phones. The pleasure of gambling in groups is communal, tribal even. Its appeal goes deeper into the collective national character than a coin-operated slot machine or a button on the remote control. The British enjoy doing things together. They are also impossible to predict - as Napoleon once found to his cost.

 RIchard Kilgarriff is managing director of iballs Media

fields.headline: Media monitor
fields.trailText: John Kampfner
fields.body:
I was in the Strangers bar of the House of Commons one night last week talking about the election date with a group of MPs. "It will be hard for him to delay the election," said one, "given that so many papers, especially the Sun, have invested so much in May."

I spluttered over my beer. This is surely the ultimate case of a hall of mirrors: a prime minister apparently worried about upsetting newspapers that have been encouraged to propose a course of action that he, in his heart of hearts, would like to pursue but isn't sure he can.

Leading the pack, as it has throughout, has been Murdoch's best-selling red-top. Day after day "the Sun says" has screamed: May 3 or bust. Sometimes it's been on the front, sometimes in its usual spot inside. There have been variations on the theme - a delay would play into William Hague's hands; a delay would make the prime minister look weak and, Number 10's favourite, a delay would damage Britain's image abroad.

Friendly newspapers have been relied on to produce a climate of inevitability. If the tactic works, they in return will be able to say that they're ahead of the game. And the more the government wobbled at the end of the week before last, as the extent of the crisis dawned, the more important it became for public opinion to be massaged into accepting the logic of May.

Last Monday, the calls for May 3 reached a peak. Among other papers, the FT had a leader calling for an early poll; the Evening Standard did the same, along with a column from Peter Kellner; Sion Simon in the Telegraph weighed in, as, naturally, did the Sun. The only paper to buck the trend that day, in news terms if not in comment, was the Independent, which played up "contingency plans" for June 7.

On Tuesday, the Mirror provided more help, with a telephone poll suggesting 58% in favour and 42% against an early election. This contradicted a 42-45 finding by Channel 4's Powerhouse programme. As for its rival, the Sun's "pollometer" showed, naturally enough, support for May 3; on Wednesday, in a first hint of doubt, it said the government must do everything it can to avoid calling off the election (to save tourism), while on Thursday it said May was back "on target".

But among many journalists, ministers and special advisers, opinions have fluctuated. They have been taking on new roles as bookies, exchanging odds. "I was 60:40 yesterday, now I'm a bit more 50:50", was one typical exchange. Another was: "I'm still a May man. Are you really set on June?" For some of those correspondents and commentators who have stuck their neck out from early on, and who have written the same piece up to half-a-dozen times, the strains were beginning to show.

Sometimes news editors never tire of stories, sometimes they tire too easily. The saga of Ken Livingstone versus New Labour falls into both categories. During the mayoral contest, it was rarely off the front pages or the radio and TV bulletins; since he actually took over the running of London, he has lost much of his news impact.

The decision this week of Bob Kiley, his transport commissioner, to seek judicial review against the government over its plan for the tube, did grab headlines, but not nearly as many as might have been expected. In the middle markets and pops, it barely got a mention.

Part of the reason lies in Livingstone's team crying wolf once too often (they first threatened to take ministers to court early in December, only to pull back at the last minute); part of it is news organisations' now-manic fear of of sounding too London-centric. They obviously forgot that a decrepit transport system in the capital might actually affect more people than foot and mouth.

fields.headline: In next week's Radio Times...
fields.standfirst: At nearly 80 years old, the Radio Times has been knocked off its top spot in the listings league by a young contender. Editor Nicholas Brett talks to  Meg Carter  about how a £7m facelift will bring the BBC back fighting
fields.trailText: At nearly 80 years old, the Radio Times has been knocked off its top spot in the listings league by a young contender. Editor Nicholas Brett talks to Meg Carter about how a £7m facelift will bring the BBC back fighting
fields.body:
At 78, the grand old lady of TV listings is undergoing a costly make-over you could easily mistake for a late-life crisis. Recent press speculation suggests the Radio Times could soon be up for sale, and the BBC-owned weekly has already been relegated to second position in the fiercely competitive listings sector by What's On TV. But next week's relaunch, following £7m new investment, is designed to convince readers and advertisers the magazine with the olde worlde title is neither fuddy-duddy nor out of touch.

The make-over, including a re-styled front cover and masthead, is accompanied by an editorial shift - from covers restricted to publicising BBC programmes to regularly putting other broadcasters' output on the front - which will undoubtedly surprise those who still see the title as Auntie's listings lapdog. But insiders insist it is a "natural next step". Radio Times has already moved with the times to sharpen its editorial teeth, broaden and deepen its multichannel coverage and diversify into e-publishing. Now it is responding to the latest shifts in digital media - and pressures in the TV listings marketplace.

Three publishing groups dominate the paid-for TV listings sector - IPC, publisher of market-leading What's On TV and TV Times; Bauer, publisher of TV Choice and TV Quick; and the BBC. Competition is intense, and overall the sector is seeing a decline in sales - by 10% over the past year, one estimate suggests (see box).

Yet despite losing its No 1 spot to IPC, Radio Times, now in second position, still sells 1.26m copies a week and prides itself on a more upmarket readership profile than its rivals, which enables it to retain a higher cover price - at 79p almost twice that of What's On TV. Radio Times remains Britain's most profitable consumer magazine, turning over an estimated £80m - more than £50m from the cover price alone, with the balance from advertising. Small wonder then if, as last week's reports suggested, Greg Dyke is lining up Radio Times to be part of a planned £1bn flotation.

"If the BBC needs money an obvious place to go for it would be Radio Times," its acting editor Nicholas Brett admits. "When ITV sold TV Times in 1998 it went for around £250m. Given our turnover, we would certainly be worth a lot." Even so, he quickly adds: "I'm unaware of any current plans. In fact in the 12 years I've been at Radio Times I can't remember a time when the story has not been doing the rounds."

One thing, however, is for sure. With two years to go until her 80th birthday, the old lady is working hard to prove she's not ready for retirement yet. To prove the point, out goes the familiar curly Radio Times logo and in comes a decidedly more contemporary look courtesy of a cover design using the Gill typeface, which now becomes the standard font throughout.

While the look is described by some media buyers as "radical", Brett insists the rationale behind it is anything but. Aesthetics aside, the choice of Gill is historically apt, he points out. Eric Gill, the originator of the Gill font back in the 1920s and a one-time Radio Times illustrator, was also responsible for producing the Prospero and Ariel sculptures that still adorn the entrance to Broadcasting House. "Gill may look totally contemporary," he says, "but it is also truly in tune with Radio Times's heritage and core values."

Readers are hardly likely to appreciate such nuances, of course, but the key is that they see the redesign as signalling change, says Radio Times publisher Ashley Munday. For this is more than a cosmetic face-lift. The rethink has been shaped by analysis of channel output and demographics, he explains, which have been assessed against Radio Times's own readership profile to cut the magazine's multichannel focus down from 21 to 18 services. The magazine's core readership is younger than many assume - typically aged in their mid-40s, dynamic and discerning. More space will now be allocated to fewer channels and listings pagination will increase by an extra double-page spread per day.

"We may be covering fewer multichannels, but those featured will be more relevant to Radio Times readers - to reflect changes in the TV landscape," says Brett. "Look at what has happened amongst our 3m readership. Currently one third are in multichannel homes, either courtesy of Sky or digital - less than the national average of 40%. But in the past 12 to 18 months our readers' rate of switch has been quicker [than average] - 23% compared with 11%."

There is a growing role for Radio Times to scout a wider territory to highlight the best programming for its readers, Brett believes: "Part of our job is to promote multichannel TV. We get a lot of readers wanting to know if now is the right time to change. Channels like Artsworld, Performance and E4 will enjoy billing unlike that provided by any other British magazine or newspaper - brilliant for the channel and a real point of distinction for us."

Another point of difference will be what Brett calls "voice": "Radio Times has for a long time been a magazine led by sub-editors, features editors and commissioning editors. Now we are saying our critics and writers are our voice - they must say what's best on radio or TV this week. The rest of us will take our lead from them." So responsibility for selecting what's best on TV and radio for the Radio Times audience - highlighted in its listings pages' Choices section - is shifting from the editors to the staff writers in a bid to strengthen the title's personality.

It's quite a cultural change, Brett says with a knowing look - and no little understatement. Not so long ago Radio Times, which was launched by Lord Reith in 1923, was managed by BBC mandarins. Content was agreed by committee and producers had copy clearance - including which image went on the front cover. While much has changed since TV listings deregulation 10 years ago, Radio Times's emphasis on all things BBC has remained a constant.

From now on, however, programmes deemed by Radio Times writers to be the best will become the focus for features coverage, and likely candidates for cover stories. Readers' tastes may still favour BBC fare but the BBC cover story will no longer be a foregone conclusion.

Refining and deepening Radio Times's coverage will strengthen its reader promise of "the best of the best" and more clearly differentiate different Radio Times products, Munday hopes. "Listings themselves are more a commodity these days, and comprehensive listings more appropriate for other platforms, such as our Radio Times webzine," he says. "What sets magazines apart now is guidance."

The growth of digital media presents opportunities, not threats, he claims: "It increases demand for listings and raises the value of guidance." Radio Times already provides viewing recommendations for ONdigital's electronic programme guide and recently struck a similar deal with personal video technology manufacturer TiVo. "Our future success will depend on more than branded listings for electronic programme guides," says Munday. "It will be about developing credible navigation systems - signposts to say where is the 'best' programming for different types of viewer, and directing them between programmes."

The Radio Times brand is already being wooed by digital services - latest discussions focus on how its extensive editorial resources can be used to enhance interactive programming. "This is because the brand is seen to offer value as an adviser on quality programming and where it can be found," Munday claims. "This must be the way ahead for us: helping platform operators to get the best frequency from electronic platforms, and helping viewers - our readers - to make the most of their time." Whether Radio Times will achieve this within BBC Worldwide's stable of consumer magazines or outside, however, remains to be seen.

TV listings - the hit list

 Sales in the TV listings magazine sector are declining, partly because "paid-for" mags must compete against titles sent by satellite/cable operators to subscribers and information viewers get free - around 30m free listings sections or supplements are available in the UK each week.

 The growth of digital media is also bad news for print-based listings guides, as digital TV provides comprehensive listings in electronic form. Magazines have responded by placing more emphasis on advice than sheer amount of information, recognising what Andrew Roberts of media specialist Starcom Motive calls "the growing importance of being a simplifier of choice".

 All listings titles bar Radio Times are viewed both by owners and media buyers as mass-market. RT prides itself on its upmarket readership, on giving less coverage to soaps and celebs, and on retaining a high cover price - at 79p almost twice that of What's On TV, and expected to rise next week. RT sales have fallen from more than 10m pre-deregulation to a latest ABC figure of 1,264,315.

 Media specialists broadly back the thinking behind its relaunch, but warn that in seeking to be seen as slicker and more modern, it risks scaring off core readers. Claudine Collins, press director at Mediacom: "While Radio Times may think it can afford a new look and increased cover price, alienating existing readers and attracting insufficient new ones to fill the potential shortfall is always a danger."
