fields.headline: Hungry reporter  is now fulfilled
fields.standfirst:
Described by the editor as one of the great newspapermen of our times, David McKie, who has held most editorial positions on the Guardian, retired on Friday after 35 years. He shares his experiences with young journalist of the year Emma Brockes

Hear the interview
fields.trailText: Described by the editor as one of the great newspapermen of our times, David McKie, who has held most editorial positions on the Guardian, retired on Friday after 35 years. He shares his experiences with young journalist of the year Emma Brockes
fields.body:
When David McKie was growing up in Leeds, what mattered in life was reported in the Yorkshire Post. The Guardian, then Manchester-based, existed for him as a right-thinking paper on the wrong side of the Pennines. "The Post had lots about Yorkshire cricket in it," he says, "which I knew to be the most important subject in the world."

It wasn't until he was studying at Oxford in 1957 that his priorities changed. It was the time of the Suez crisis and McKie and his fellow students turned to the Guardian to articulate their unease. "It told us that we were quite right in thinking that this was an immense wickedness and a huge piece of incompetence. From then, I always wanted to work for the Guardian."

David McKie retires this week after working for the paper for 35 years and occupying every position from junior reporter to assistant news editor to Peter Preston's deputy during some of the paper's toughest times. He is known presently to readers as a political columnist and the author of the devilish weekly dispatch, Smallweed.

"He is amazingly knowledgeable on a huge range of subjects," says Alan Rusbridger, the editor. "He is painstakingly fair to people. He is fantastically punctilious about details and accuracy and he writes like a dream. There is no job in journalism he can't do better than anyone else. He has never won a prize, but he is one of the great journalists of our time."

McKie's first day in the newsroom was on October 4 1965. The paper was 16 pages thick, cost five old pence and if you found a photograph you had reason to celebrate. McKie, whose first news editor was John Cole later political editor of the BBC, was given an underwhelming salary of £1,750 a year.

"They rather took the view, that if you worked for the Guardian, it was a terrific privilege and did you really expect to be paid as well? So they paid starvation rates. But if you wanted to work for a paper that was left of centre and cherished writing, then there was nowhere else you wanted to go."

His ambition was to become a political reporter and he eventually achieved it after serving time on the news and features desks. To McKie, politics comprised the exact mix of the serious and the wacky that made his own writing so powerful.

"Having employed the term 'bog standard' last week," he wrote recently, in a needle-sharp column, "I am now assailed with requests to explain what it means. I shall answer this in one brusque and immaculate sentence: I haven't the slightest idea."

To staff, he represents everything that justifies the peculiar loyalty that the Guardian inspires. While political reporter, McKie was mindful not to grow too fond of his subjects, although he inevitably developed friendships with politicians on both sides of the House. "My two closest friends in the Labour party were Neil Kinnock and Roy Hattersley. That caused difficulties, particularly when Neil became leader, because I was writing leaders condemning him. One of the politicians I most revere is John Biffen, a really good, honest, decent man. Some of the anti-Thatcher Tories became good mates. When people condemn politicians, I say, wait a minute, what about Jack Ashley, a man with no ambitions to rise up the tree, but only to serve his constituents and do the best he can for the party."

In retirement, McKie will continue to do what he has loved but not always found time for, to write for the paper. What he will miss most, he says, are those chance encounters with colleagues and readers which excite his ever-renewing interests. "It is those conversations," he says, "when you talk about something not particularly relevant to anything and suddenly you think, that's jolly interesting. That will be a terrible loss."

The biggest challenge of his career, says McKie, came in the early 80s with the formation of the SDP and the subsequent split, in the Guardian office, between those in support of it and those loyal to the ailing Labour party.

"David Owen came up to me at a party conference and denounced the Guardian. 'Say what you like about the Daily Mail,' he said, 'at least it knows what side it's on.' And I said: "We know what side we're on, we're on our side. We're not here to be on the Labour party's side, we're not here to be on the SDP's side, we're here to define our own terms, approve those parties that come close and disapprove the rest.'"

He is the standard to which we all aspire.

fields.headline: Media Monkey's diary
fields.trailText: • Cheering signs of a united front within the BBC's business and economics team. Business editor Jeff Randall, speaking on Friday morning about Robert Maxwell, quipped: "I had the great misfortune to be offered a job by Robert Maxwell just before he died. Thank God I didn't take it . . ." Monkey is sure that his witticism was in no way meant as an implied criticism of his revered colleague Peter ("Maxwell's chief of staff") Jay.

 Cheering signs of a united front within the BBC's business and economics team. Business editor Jeff Randall, speaking on Friday morning about Robert Maxwell, quipped: "I had the great misfortune to be offered a job by Robert Maxwell just before he died. Thank God I didn't take it . . ." Monkey is sure that his witticism was in no way meant as an implied criticism of his revered colleague Peter ("Maxwell's chief of staff") Jay.

 The restoration of the show formerly known as the Late Review to its rightful place in the middle of the night - it's now part of Newsnight on Fridays - has led to some interesting interaction between the arty types and the politicos. Tom Paulin has revealed that he stayed up to 2am with Jeremy Vine after one recent edition discovering hidden cultural depths. Not only is JV a nifty ballroom dancer, according to Paulin, he's also an aficionado of WH Auden. Whatever next, Ekow Eshun on macro-economics?

Better luck next time, Greg.

fields.headline: Brand Aid
fields.standfirst: Avon
fields.trailText: Avon
fields.body:
What is it?

The US cosmetics giant whose team of sales ladies became a suburban institution among bored housewives in search of cheap glamour.

What's the problem?

The last ten years have been tough. With more women going out to work, no one is home to the Avon lady. And Avon's reputation - not so much hip as hip replacement - makes finding new customers tricky.

What are they up to?

Avon is having a makeover of its own. The company has just hired a new UK marketing director to oversee its corporate facelift on this side of the Atlantic, but in the US the reinvention of Avon is already well advanced: lipsticks will be in department stores for the first time.

Will it work?

Avon's US transformation was complete when even style bible Vogue waxed lyrical about its new beauty centre in New York's Trump Tower.

Marketing:

Avon's stated ambition is to become the Coca-Cola of the beauty industry, with its snappy new slogan: "Dare to change your mind about Avon".

History:

Avon ladies have been ringing our doorbells since 1886, when door-to-door book salesman David McConnell found sales increased when he gave away perfume to customers. Realising the perfume was more popular than the books, he hired an all-female sales force and set up the California Perfume Company. In 1939 he came to England and was so impressed by Stratford-upon-Avon that he decided to rename his company after the Warwickshire town.

The future:

A new team of virtual Avon ladies sell you lippy via your laptop.

The last ten years have been tough. With more women going out to work, no one is home to the Avon lady. And Avon's reputation - not so much hip as hip replacement - makes finding new customers tricky. What are they up to? Avon is having a makeover of its own. The company has just hired a new UK marketing director to oversee its corporate facelift on this side of the Atlantic, but in the US the reinvention of Avon is already well advanced: lipsticks will be in department stores for the first time. Will it work? Avon's US transformation was complete when even style bible Vogue waxed lyrical about its new beauty centre in New York's Trump Tower. Marketing: Avon's stated ambition is to become the Coca-Cola of the beauty industry, with its snappy new slogan: "Dare to change your mind about Avon". History: Avon ladies have been ringing our doorbells since 1886, when door-to-door book salesman David McConnell found sales increased when he gave away perfume to customers. Realising the perfume was more popular than the books, he hired an all-female sales force and set up the California Perfume Company. In 1939 he came to England and was so impressed by Stratford-upon-Avon that he decided to rename his company after the Warwickshire town. The future: A new team of virtual Avon ladies sell you lippy via your laptop.

fields.headline: My beef with news naivety
fields.standfirst: While the media dithered in Devon, Cumberland News editor,  Keith Sutton  was awash in disinfectant in Cumbria. He explains how the world's press finally arrived on his patch
fields.trailText: While the media dithered in Devon, Cumberland News editor, Keith Sutton was awash in disinfectant in Cumbria. He explains how the world's press finally arrived on his patch
fields.body:
Week one of the foot and mouth outbreak and our newsdesk gets an angry call from a Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food (Maff) press officer in Whitehall: "Stop pestering our Carlisle offices with this bloody question about which farms are contaminated. We're not telling you, we can't tell you - because of the Data Protection Act," he boomed, and added loftily: "Don't you realise we're in the middle of a national crisis?"

Outside my office door, I could hear the sobs of my disinfected PA as she read the evening News & Star. The toll of affected farmers read like her Christmas card list: "Claire and William, Alison and Ian, Les and Margaret, Uncle Tucker..."

Despite Maff, we knew what was going on. Every morning my PA left her mother and brother on their farm, carefully dipped her shoes into a bowl of disinfectant and headed off to her office. In fear of spreading the virus, she had given up socialising, going to church, and shopping for anything other than essentials. Many others did the same, passing the burning funeral pyres and rotting carcasses left in the fields as they drove in and out of our offices.

Three of the directors of my company were to lose their herds in the weeks to come. Eight members of staff were to be placed in quarantine, either unable to go out of their homes or unable to return to them. "Spreading like the Plague", screamed the front page of the Cumberland News, our weekly paper whose circulation area - throughout north Cumbria across to the edge of Northumberland and over the border into south-west Scotland - eerily mirrored the spread of the disease from its epicentre at Longtown mart.

Yes, Minister. We did realise this was a national crisis. But did you? Did anybody in London? The sense of betrayal and isolation in Cumbria was almost as tangible as the rancid smell and roaring flames of livelihoods going up in smoke. The stench of stereotypes wafted up from the capital. Farmers come from Devon, don't they, with sweet, soft accents borrowed from the Archers? And anyway, Devon's down the road, isn't it? Television showed the west country, it seemed, non-stop. The papers followed suit. You could rent-a-rant from David Handley, fighting farmer of fuel crisis fame, but you couldn't hear the crying farmers of Cumbria for weeks to come.

We were at the centre of a world exclusive that nobody told the world about. Our 27,000 circulation evening and 40,000 circulation weekly papers were the first by about a week to report that foot and mouth was not under control in Cumbria when Nick Brown was telling the country differently. We were first to report demands for the army to be brought in. First to point out that farmers were waiting as long as 10 days for vets to arrive and their animals to be subsequently slaughtered and disposed of. First to warn that the whole ecology of the Lake District national park was at risk.

We stayed ahead of the media - and the politicians - not because we were doing anything clever. (In fact my recent policy decision to dispense with a full-time farming editor began to look distinctly shaky). The anger, heartbreak and frustration at the lack of urgency exhibited by "Naff", aggravated by the sense that nobody outside the county was listening, boiled over into five weekly broadsheet pages of foot-and-mouth news, features, and letters and six daily tabloid pages of the same.

I privately appointed myself farming editor. Every day I was opening around 30 letters. Most of them along the lines of "Blair fiddles while Cumbria burns". We revolutionised our website with up-to-the-minute news of which farms were contaminated and how many beasts were to be slaughtered. We did our best to read the minds of Maff and Brown on when and where and on which animals the dreaded preventive cull was going to fall. We reported that the countryside was indeed closed, though not in the way London understood: we said that darts and dominoes, church tabletop and car boot sales were off; boy scouts stopped meeting; playgroups were cancelled; and farm children stayed off school.

This was our news agenda. It was a story in which information was sensation every day. Circulations soared, most gratifyingly on our urban-based evening paper which in one week saw sales go up by an average 12 % per night. On the day we warned of the threat to the Lake District, our sales were up 16%.

The first significant media awakening from London began with the Today programme. Radio 4 had spotted our story about the delay in burning carcasses. On Friday March 9, John Humphrys interviewed me. By the time the rest of the media followed up, I was a well-informed and informative farming editor. I took Jon Snow's Channel 4 film crew to buy disinfectant, and spoke knowledgably to Danish, French, Australian and Canadian news teams about Virus-O and Borax 30c. The reporter from the Paris-based Libération seemed to know more about Cumbrian farming than some of the London journalists. In one memorable background interview with a southern media person, I felt I almost had to spell out the difference between pigs, sheep and cattle.

Snow's live broadcast from Carlisle city centre on Monday, March 19 was typically informed, incisive and involving. It set down a marker for the rest and in retrospect seems to have been a turning point in media coverage. Snow's programme, ranging through the rotting carcasses to the economic despair in the Lake District, confirmed everything we had been saying for the past two weeks.

The politicians followed in the wake of the media: the chief vet, Joyce Quin, Tony Blair, the army and, finally, Nick Brown. We were now nearing the end of week four. Over the border in Scotland, they seemed to have got their act together more quickly, more decisively, more democratically. Devolution, regional government... no longer will these issues seem quite so academic to Cumbrians. Our papers have now joined the effort to rebuild out of this disaster. The Cumberland News Farmers Fund is attracting thousands of pounds in donations. Some heads appear to have rolled or, at least, been pushed sideways within Maff. A full-scale inquiry would be useful when it's all over.

As Mr Blair rushed through Carlisle, visiting Maff officials, farmers and soldiers on his way to Stockholm, another Whitehall press officer - this time from No 10 itself - phoned me. "Mr Blair has your number and will ring you personally this evening if he has time," she said.

Sadly, I am still waiting for the call. I was tempted to replay to the prime minister the words of the London Maff man of three weeks earlier: "Don't you realise we're in the middle of a national crisis?"

 Keith Sutton is editor of the weekly Cumberland News and the evening News and Star www.news-and-star.co.uk

fields.headline: My media
fields.standfirst: Gurbux Singh
fields.trailText: Gurbux Singh
fields.body:
Newspapers:

The Guardian before I leave for work and then all press cuts from all national and local newspapers which deal with race or related matters. The CRE has an agency which monitors race stories. I read the ethnic press, or at least skim them. At weekends I read the Sunday Times, Mirror and the Observer.

Magazines:

New Statesman, Management Today, the Economist and Cricket Monthly, I'm a cricket fanatic and a big fan of India.

Books:

Just finished Father and Son by Edmund Gosse and tried several times to read White Teeth by Zadie Smith but couldn't get into it. About to read Death of Raju written by an American science professor. I have three young children so it's difficult finding the time to read.

Television:

BBC2 and Sky news are good. Also watch ZeeTV which is a mixture of Bollywood films, news from the sub-continent and cricket. If I'm free on a Sunday I'll watch the omnibus EastEnders.

Radio:

Occasionally Today and Radio 5 Live when I'm on the treadmill at home.

Film:

I've taken my two eldest sons to watch some daft kids' movie which they enjoyed but I thought were dreadful. Cultural activities in London are tremendous but I may as well live elsewhere because I don't use many of the facilities.

Adverts:

I have a big interest in adverts because of how they present different communities. One in every five ads has a Caribbean person in it which is great because it presents people in a normal way. For Asians, though, it's one in every 100 - something the media needs to look at.

New Media:

The dangers of the internet in terms of racist material is something I should be more concerned about. The opportunity of using different medium to communicate a message is powerful and is something the CRE needs to exploit much more.

 Gurbux Singh is chair of the commission for racial equality and will host the Race In Media Awards. He will be live online on Wednesday at 2pm at www.societytheguardian.com

fields.headline: Bitch's brew
fields.standfirst: The interactive website where music-biz insiders swap cheeky gossip is short of cash. Kate Burt reports
fields.trailText: The interactive website where music-biz insiders swap cheeky gossip is short of cash. Kate Burt reports
fields.body:
All celebrity-based scandal in this feature is fictitious and any resemblance to any genuine celebrity-based scandal, fresh or stale, is entirely coincidental. OK, now we've got that out of the way - have you heard the one about the famous designer who, at a much more famous friend's wedding, drunkenly confessed that her best sex ever was a lesbian incident with a famous model? How about the revelation that a seemingly demure Irish pop band are, in fact, "quite horrible" and were re-named Sticky, Shouty, Fiddly and Ken by the road crew on their last tour? Oh, and a personal favourite: which former teatime TV actor was said to favour starting the sex act with: "Tom's coming in now"?

Welcome to the world of Popbitch.com. It's not hard to warm to the naughty and not-generally-so-nice weekly online slander-mail and its associated messageboard. The non-profit-making venture, which started as a 1,000-strong virtual clique swapping scurrilous music-industry rumour, now has more than 30,000 subscribers.

Popbitch emerged quietly in December 1999 and, through word of mouth alone, is now so overrun with web traffic that it needs a new server, at a cost of £2,500. Enter "Bitchaid", the site's official begging campaign, launched a fortnight ago. "It's been very depressing," sighs Popbitch's officially anonymous creator (whose identity is not really that big a secret, but whom I promised to call Nigel). Nigel, who somehow manages to juggle his payment-free, part-time web hobby with a hectic media day job, sounds knackered. "The weird thing about websites," he says, "is that they're only cheap to run when hardly anyone uses them. It's a shame - you start something for fun; it becomes really popular and then you have to take a decision about whether to turn it into a business." But - he is adamant - that's something Popbitch will never become.

The site's celebrity assault is two-pronged: there's the weekly newsletter, packed with highly improbable yet absorbing revelations - a sort of Private Eye meets the National Enquirer. Then there's the chatroom - a sort of Private Eye meets the school common-room - where guests are known only by their noms des plume. Nigel got the idea for Popbitch at the height of the "get rich quick" dot.com goldrush.

"We got bored and wanted to do something different," he says. "Something that didn't look like it was trying to make money. After the whole Geri Halliwell/Chris Evans, Chris Evans/Billie, Geri/Robbie thing, people have become cynical about celebrity journalism." And the minute you go down the business route, he says, you play into the hands of PRs. The fact that Popbitch has always refused to do that is its strength - but might also be its downfall.

Nigel maintains that the stories on the newsletter are picked when they're believed to be true. Well, true-ish. Or at least funny. "One of my messages made it onto the newsletter once," says a music PR who wishes, in true Popbitch style, to remain anonymous. "I made up a story about Nicole Appleton being born with a tail, invented a bogus medical term for it, and they put it on. It was one of the proudest days of my life."

Even for those the site has offended, Popbitch is still held in great affection. Everyone loves a juicy urban myth and Popbitch's made-up tales have become legendary. Remember the one about Anais Gallagher being kept out of the public eye because she was, in fact, black - and Meg Mathews's love child with drum and bass big-wig, Goldie? And what about the alleged incident combining a former boyband member, a teenager popstar's breasts and several lines of cocaine? All Popbitch. They've even spawned commemorative T-shirts (reading "Goldie's my dad" and "Chazbaps" respectively), created by and sold - at a loss - via the site.

Despite complaints that outsiders are ruining the quality of the gossip ("I went on it today," says one former regular snootily, "and all they were talking about was Jamie Oliver and the sexual prowess of one of S Club 7. You don't get the A-list stuff you used to"), the message board retains a certain cosiness.

Logging on is like eavesdropping on a bunch of old friends down at the pub. Prudish Belinda is whispered to be Popbitch himself in transsexual disguise, while Goatboy is the message board stud: "Everyone fancies Goatboy," says a showbiz journalist and regular Popbitcher, "he's lovely, but he's probably a horrible 16-year-old student from Wolverhampton." Ironically, these anonymous mates would probably rather pull their own eyelashes out than actually be seen conversing with one another in real life.

Not everything on the messageboard has been a bundle of laughs, however. One posting on the board is said to have provoked a - fruitless - witchhunt for a mole at Radio 1. The subject? The minutes of a confidential playlist meeting which, with its alarming judgments (such as "no longer relevant", "priority act with label, but station think they're rubbish" to "a good image - a band R1 wants to be associated with"), embarrassingly read more like a marketing report than the sentiments of people who claim to love music.

Another, more damaging, incident involved an innocent TV presenter and some extremely unpleasant allegations of illegal sexual preferences. It got the site closed down for three weeks. The ensuing legal action from the presenter's camp, Nigel says, still hangs over him. It is the reason for the introduction of compulsory registration for those using the chatroom. "We felt people were posting this kind of thing just to get a reaction. I don't want the site to be dealing with issues that affect people's lives like that. It's supposed to be entertaining."

But celebrities and large corporations are not the only victims. The harsh spotlight of defamation has also shone on the obscure: "A friend called one day to say there were some messages on Popbitch about me," recalls one music PR. "They suggested that I had had extra-marital affairs. At the time, I'd only been married three months. What's disconcerting is that while those who know me know it was utter rubbish, people I only know professionally, may believe it." Another journalist, however, was pleasantly surprised when she heard she'd been given the Popbitch treatment: "I totally panicked, thinking I was being slagged off, but it turned out that I was on the Top 10 Journalists You Want To Shag list." Still, apart from the tricky TV presenter situation, Popbitch has surprisingly few enemies. One PR company, the Outside Organisation, whose clients, the Spice Girls, had some - sadly unrepeatable - stories posted about them, asked Popbitch to remove the comments. "We actually all found the things hilarious," says Outside's Stuart Bell, "but they were so far from the truth that our clients may have found them offensive." Even Radio 1 didn't take its fury out on Popbitch. "It was more how the information got out that worried us," says a BBC source, "but I don't think any of us want to see Popbitch die."

Many former fans still feel the quality of the website's slander is waning, though. "It's lost its initial underground charm and appeal," says the manager of a high-profile indie act, echoing almost everyone quoted in this piece. It's perhaps just another urban myth, but Madonna is rumoured to have logged on briefly, using MLVC (her initials) as her guise. Perhaps coincidentally, on stage the following day she dedicated a song to all the popbitches out there.

"That was when the site peaked," the manager says. "At that moment, a lot of non-industry people became part of Popbitch and that's made it far more trivial." A music writer agrees: "A friend actually met up with someone from the board, and he turned out not to be in the industry," she shrieks. "He was a city trader!"

Despite all that, the site has enough loyal aficionados to have raised more than half the required rescue money in the first week of its appeal. Especially impressive when you consider that lack of technology meant that people have had to send in cheques by old-fashioned snail mail. "Those who donate do get a gold star by their name on the board, though," says Nigel, who is confident of keeping Popbitch fuelled for at least a year on the new server.

The appeal's fast-track success has nipped in the bud the dubious idea of a fundraising party. "A lot of people were looking forward to it," says the showbiz journalist. "They want to meet each other. But it would have been a nightmare - you imagine it's all going to be glamorous media people but you know if you turned up it'd just be a bunch of spotty students."

And that's the spirit that might just keep Popbitch's unique underground charm alive. "Everyone knows who's behind Popbitch," she continues, "but none of us will ever mention his name because we don't want it ever to stop."

"We felt people were posting this kind of thing just to get a reaction. I don't want the site to be dealing with issues that affect people's lives like that. It's supposed to be entertaining." But celebrities and large corporations are not the only victims. The harsh spotlight of defamation has also shone on the obscure: "A friend called one day to say there were some messages on Popbitch about me," recalls one music PR. "They suggested that I had had extra-marital affairs. At the time, I'd only been married three months. What's disconcerting is that while those who know me know it was utter rubbish, people I only know professionally, may believe it." Another journalist, however, was pleasantly surprised when she heard she'd been given the Popbitch treatment: "I totally panicked, thinking I was being slagged off, but it turned out that I was on the Top 10 Journalists You Want To Shag list." Still, apart from the tricky TV presenter situation, Popbitch has surprisingly few enemies. One PR company, the Outside Organisation, whose clients, the Spice Girls, had some - sadly unrepeatable - stories posted about them, asked Popbitch to remove the comments. "We actually all found the things hilarious," says Outside's Stuart Bell, "but they were so far from the truth that our clients may have found them offensive." Even Radio 1 didn't take its fury out on Popbitch. "It was more how the information got out that worried us," says a BBC source, "but I don't think any of us want to see Popbitch die." Many former fans still feel the quality of the website's slander is waning, though. "It's lost its initial underground charm and appeal," says the manager of a high-profile indie act, echoing almost everyone quoted in this piece. It's perhaps just another urban myth, but Madonna is rumoured to have logged on briefly, using MLVC (her initials) as her guise. Perhaps coincidentally, on stage the following day she dedicated a song to all the popbitches out there. "That was when the site peaked," the manager says. "At that moment, a lot of non-industry people became part of Popbitch and that's made it far more trivial." A music writer agrees: "A friend actually met up with someone from the board, and he turned out not to be in the industry," she shrieks. "He was a city trader!" Despite all that, the site has enough loyal aficionados to have raised more than half the required rescue money in the first week of its appeal. Especially impressive when you consider that lack of technology meant that people have had to send in cheques by old-fashioned snail mail. "Those who donate do get a gold star by their name on the board, though," says Nigel, who is confident of keeping Popbitch fuelled for at least a year on the new server. The appeal's fast-track success has nipped in the bud the dubious idea of a fundraising party. "A lot of people were looking forward to it," says the showbiz journalist. "They want to meet each other. But it would have been a nightmare - you imagine it's all going to be glamorous media people but you know if you turned up it'd just be a bunch of spotty students." And that's the spirit that might just keep Popbitch's unique underground charm alive. "Everyone knows who's behind Popbitch," she continues, "but none of us will ever mention his name because we don't want it ever to stop."

fields.headline: Don't call me worthy
fields.standfirst: Marie Claire's high-profile editor, Liz Jones, has edited her last issue: but what was her crime? Some say she was too serious for an increasingly trivial market and had to go for the sake of sales.  Jessica Hodgson  reports on the perilous and ever-expanding world of women's glossies
fields.trailText: Marie Claire's high-profile editor, Liz Jones, has edited her last issue: but what was her crime? Some say she was too serious for an increasingly trivial market and had to go for the sake of sales. Jessica Hodgson reports on the perilous and ever-expanding world of women's glossies
fields.body:
More than a few delicately pencilled eyebrows were raised this week after news of Liz Jones's departure from the editor's chair at Marie Claire started to leak out from IPC. The company is still sticking to the party line about Jones's departure, saying that she has left to pursue other interests and write a book. But her departure, shortly after ABC figures showed the magazine had lost 11% of its sales, prompted widespread speculation that the company was unhappy with her performance.

Once described as "the politically correct Cosmopolitan", Marie Claire's star has waned over the past year, its sales slumping from a high of 450,000 for the end of 1999 to just above 400,000. After a high-profile launch in 1988 under editor Glenda Bailey, it established itself as the only magazine capable of successfully combining gloss with grit, famously covering issues such as female circumcision. By the mid-1990s it was catching Cosmo.

Despite the fact that there's now clear blue water between the two titles, observers don't believe the gap is big enough to warrant the treatment of Jones. Marcelle d'Argy Smith, a former Cosmopolitan editor, is shocked. "It's ruthless," she says. "A good company would have gone, 'Hang on, what does this editor need?' I may not have liked everything that Liz Jones wrote, but she was very bright and got them lots of publicity. It's a bit like a holiday company having a single complaint and then firing the manager."

Ian Birch, editor-in-chief of Emap Elan women's titles, believes there's more pressure on women's magazine editors than ever before. "In a celebrity dominated world, an editor experiences a small glimmer of what it's like to be a true celebrity," he says. "In the same way American Vogue is Anna Wintour and Anna Wintour is American Vogue, the editors have to be spokespeople for their magazines." For d'Argy Smith, Jones's departure is symptomatic of editors' increasing impotence in relation to publishers and advertisers. "The editors are now simply weathergirls," she says.

Jones, who joined the magazine in 1999 from the Sunday Times Style section, got Marie Claire noticed. Her tenure will be remembered chiefly (although probably unfairly) for her Sunday Times Single File column, which chronicled the neuroses of the pampered western female in lurid technicolour. The columns became an apocalyptic, media-will-eat-itself vision of what happens to the single professional woman when you read too many women's magazines.

Jones's descriptions of her military-style preparation for a date prompted disgust and sympathy in equal measure. "I go into training," she wrote. "I run and work out every single day. I buy new clothes. I get the cleaner in to do a special spring-clean of my house and wax the floorboards. The gardener will come. I get the window-cleaner to do the windows."

The columns were all the more compelling because of Jones's apparent failure to make any connection between her cosmetic self-flagellation and her romantic problems. However much we were repelled by the neurosis (not to mention the spare cash), we responded to the candour. Jones's interest in body dysmorphia culminated in the decision to put large-size model Sophie Dahl on the cover of the magazine alongside the slimline Pamela Anderson.

Insiders say Groupe Marie Claire, the owner of the Marie Claire international brand, did not share Jones's editorial vision, and there are unconfirmed reports that her resignation was precipitated by an argument over the use of Victoria Beckham as a cover model. Both IPC and Groupe Marie Claire began to feel that Jones was beginning to bring too much of her personality into the magazine and that it was becoming "worthy".

Marie Claire's award-winning Reportage section has always been controversial. For everyone who thinks the reports from far-flung corners of the globe are a valuable window onto a misrepresented world, there are others who see them as a figleaf for the lack of serious reporting in women's magazines. Others believe "worthy" content has no place in a glossy.

Recent rumours that the section was to be axed have been staunchly denied by IPC, but insiders now say that under new editor Marie O'Riordan, "pendulous breasts in the Kalahari" articles may go the way of all flesh. O'Riordan has indicated that she wants the magazine to be more "fun".

Jones is the second women's magazine editor to quit in six months amid reports that her work was too serious. In October, Sally Brampton, the former Elle editor, quit Red. Like Jones, Brampton was an editor who believed women's magazines should try to broaden their focus beyond the staples of celebrity, sex and fashion, and when her resignation is discussed among publishing executives the dreaded "worthy" tag has stuck.

The ghost of Wagadon's Frank - the high-profile "intelligent" glossy canned indecently quickly - now hangs like an albatross over any mag azine covering anything more intellectually challenging than a new lipstick. D'Argy Smith believes that broader social affairs coverage has been deliberately marginalised.

"When I was editing Cosmo we had Lesley Abdela as a political editor," she says. "This would be unthinkable today." She blames her successor, Mandi Norwood, for a fundamental shift in the concept of "accessibility" in the woman's magazine. "Mandi Norwood introduced the concept of the Essex girl into the women's magazine market. She captured a kind of zeitgeist, which is dumbing down," she says. Gill Hudson, editor of the BBC's rival intelligent glossy Eve, will not be drawn into a discussion on Jones's editing style, but thinks that, if anything, Marie Claire had gone too tabloid for her liking.

Pendulous breasts in the Kalahari are struggling against skeletal stars in designer frocks as women's magazine publishers dive into the celebrity market. And so far, the punters seem to like it. The success of Emap's Heat, whose circulation bulged by 140% in the last ABCs, is testimony to this. Perhaps more significant for the established glossies such as Marie Claire and Cosmo are the recent launches of Time Inc's In Style and Condé Nast's Glamour, which is reported to have sold 500,000 copies in its first month.

In Style's editor Dee Nolan believes that far from being an escapist fantasy, the cult of celebrity is a "reality check" after magazines' previous fixation with supermodels. "Models are so far removed from our lives," she says, "while celebrities, although they are at the gorgeous end of real, are nevertheless real people to whom we can aspire." Nolan believes that the interest in celebrity also reflects the growing influence of female producers and stars in the Hollywood system and the media in general.

The new magazines have given the established glossies a shock to the system, according to Mindshare's press buying director Paul Thomas. "There's more competition in the marketplace than ever before. Glamour and In Style have launched very strongly and there's a danger that some of the really traditional brands could be damaged." In this kind of climate, the 11% drop in circulation of the kind experienced by Marie Claire in the last ABCs is bound to have given IPC pause, and the pressure is on the publishers to deliver numbers.

Ian Birch of Emap Elan thinks that "to divide the market into celebrity versus grittiness is an oversimplification". He claims that the proliferation of media means that it's no longer appropriate for a woman's magazine to aspire to a one-size-fits-all read. "If the Elle reader wants to know about politics, she will log on to CNN.com or watch Channel 4 News or Sky. If she wants to read about style, she will pick up a magazine like Elle."

D'Argy Smith puts it more succinctly. "We all know that 10 years ago newspapers discovered women. Magazines always used to be able to do what newspapers can't. Now there's not a lot newspapers can't do and you have to ask yourself what magazines can."

Lorraine Candy, editor of Cosmpolitan, makes the point that in periods of tough competition or even recession, women are less likely to buy more than one magazine. Glossies will win or lose the battle for readers on eye-grabbing coverlines, she says. And in an aggressive battle for jaded consumers, magazine publishers will be falling over themselves to lose the worthy tag.

Meanwhile, globalisation means that magazines have to answer more and more to global masters. "Increasingly, magazine brands are part of an international strategy," says Birch. "It's understood that the local editor has a local knowledge and understanding. But if editors misinterpret that brand, then clearly that needs to be looked at."

For d'Argy Smith, there is little room for editors to manoeuvre within these international templates. "None of the magazines have the balls to deviate from the formula. When, occasionally, you do get one, all the publishers lose their cool. It's like all the girls wanting to have exactly the same hairstyle."

Focus on real people

"I was going to quote the Dalai Lama, but all my friends will take the piss," quips Janice Turner when asked whether she's nervous about launch editing Real, the new women's fortnightly from H Bauer. "Great achievement and great love always require great risk," she says. "What's the alternative? Not jumping?"

H Bauer is really jumping with Real, which launches this week with a hugely ambitious print run of 900,000, and has a £10m marketing budget. "We're confident that we've got a good product and we can make it work," says Turner, unblinking.

It's a bit of a hairy time to be launching a magazine, particularly a women's magazine - as Liz Jones's resignation underlined. Women's titles in general made a fairly undistinguished showing in the recent ABC figures.

At first glance there's a bit of a "so what" factor about any new women's magazine. At least seven glossies have launched in the past two years. Cosmopolitan editor, Lorraine Candy is bemused. "In a declining, fragmenting market it seems odd that publishers are still clinging to the holy grail that all that's needed is a brand-new woman's magazine."

Real must avoid the curse of Riva, a mid-market women's fortnightly "intel ligent glossy" launched in the early 1990s by Sally O'Sullivan, which bombed, taking an estimated £7m of IPC's money with it.

Real's pitch is to bring glossy production values and intelligence into an accessible women's weekly format. "We have the pace and vitality and relevance of a weekly but the glossiness, design and intelligence of a monthly," says Turner. It's a more upmarket and older demographic than the staple women's weeklies, promising articles by, among others, Julie Burchill and Channel 4 News's Kirsty Lang.

Turner turns up her nose at suggestions that it's a Woman's Weekly for Guardian readers. "We're not worthy," she says. God forbid. The first issue is promisingly seductive, with echoes of You magazine in the sumptuous design.

Real also rejects the current love affair with celebrity. "I have always passionately believed that real people are more interesting than celebrities. I know it's against the climate to say this, but I think there's a saturation factor with '16 clutch bags Julia Roberts wants to wear to the Oscars'." Instead there's a feature on real life gigolos, an interview with the "real life" DCI Tennison, and an emphasis on practical advice, in features like "how to have sex with the same man for the rest of your life".

A lot of onlookers are hoping Real does work. Eve magazine's editor Gill Hudson says it's an opportunity to revitalise the "fantastically homogeneous" women's market. "If the fortnightly format does work, it could potentially open up a whole new market," she says.

Maire Fahey, editor of Prima, agrees. "If you can break people's reading habits, you can really change the market. The evidence from the celebrity magazines is that people are crying out for new formats."

The history of H Bauer, which launched several successful new titles into a recession at the end of the 80s, suggests that if anyone can pull it off, they can. Fahey notes that "they don't take prisoners". And Turner, at least, is in it for the long haul.

webTitle: New start for welfare of children in court

fields.headline: New start for welfare of children in court
fields.trailText: The new children and family court welfare service in England and Wales begins its first working day today amid growing controversy.
fields.body:
The new children and family court welfare service in England and Wales begins its first working day today amid growing controversy.

Even before the launch of the Children and Family Court Advisory and Support Service (Cafcass), the complexities of creating a unified body to work in the best interests of the child were already becoming apparent.

The challenge of combining family court welfare functions that were formerly provided by the probation service, the children's branch of the official solicitor's department, and guardian ad litem and reporting officer services into one integrated system means the embryonic service has been experiencing some uncomfortable birth pangs.

Guardians ad litem, who represent vulnerable children in public law cases, are concerned about the way they will be paid in future. Before Cafcass came into being the guardians were mostly self employed, worked for councils and were paid an hourly rate. Under new arrangements there are plans to pay them under banding systems of fixed fees.

Representatives of the National Association of Guardians ad Litem and Reporting Officers (Nagalro) are arguing that the new arrangements for fixed fees may fundamentally change the way they work and, as a consequence, undermine the vital work they do in representing and safeguarding children.

As a result, the association is challenging the proposed pay structure and threatening a judicial review if no acceptable way forward can be found. A six-week moratorium has been agreed to find a solution, and Nagalro has taken legal advice, although it is said to be cautiously optimistic that a more reasonable agreement can be negotiated with Cafcass.

Susan Bindman, chairwoman of Nagalro said: "The work that we do is highly complex and demands flexibility. Gathering together all the appropriate information that is required to safeguard a vulnerable child can be extremely time consuming. Our fear is that under the proposed pay structure many of the fundamental tenets underpinning the work that we do may be lost.

"We regret the attempt to reframe the issue of quality in public services. That is a disservice to the guardians ad litem and to the children they represent."

Anthony Hewson, chairman of Cafcass says part of the agency's responsibility is to make sure the public purse is being properly used.

"We have a six-week period where we will have to examine the issues. And there are two very different positions. On the one hand we have the Inland Revenue telling us that guardians ad litem cannot be employed under their current terms. But Nagalro does not agree, and the answer is to talk and try to reach an agreement," he said.

A short-term measure means that guardians ad litem will continue to be paid under existing arrangements.

The Association of Family Court Welfare Officers (AFCWO) is among those that have broadly welcomed the new service.

Chairman Jim Lawson said: "There are a number of potential benefits from an integrated advisory and support service for family courts, not least the fact that there can now be agreed national standards with practitioners.

"In the past, family court welfare was formerly part of the probation service and had become extremely marginalised within the service. Guardian panels were administered by the local authority and that meant the authorities were effectively paying for the guardians."

Most guardians ad litem are involved in disputes between local authorities and parents, but because of this financial link with council there were fears they would be seen as less independent than they really were.

Mr Lawson sees the challenge for Cafcass as providing a new organisation that will encourage the exchange of skills and contribute to the professional development of all the participants.

"But there may be problems with vested interests if professionals attempt to cling to the past rather than embracing the future," he warned.

Mr Hewson says delays in the family court system were leading to some children having to wait up to 40 weeks to get into the system: "In future we will be able to analyse the areas where children are facing unacceptable waiting times and effectively address the problems with a unified approach."

He believes the main task is to listen to the views of children to create a truly child-focused system: "Over the next 12-months we are going to be asking children what it is that they would like to see in terms of a service. There are many ways we can do this. We have already begun talks with agencies like the NSPCC and that is crucial to the future."

Anthony Hewson, chairman of Cafcass says part of the agency's responsibility is to make sure the public purse is being properly used. "We have a six-week period where we will have to examine the issues. And there are two very different positions. On the one hand we have the Inland Revenue telling us that guardians ad litem cannot be employed under their current terms. But Nagalro does not agree, and the answer is to talk and try to reach an agreement," he said. A short-term measure means that guardians ad litem will continue to be paid under existing arrangements. The Association of Family Court Welfare Officers (AFCWO) is among those that have broadly welcomed the new service. Chairman Jim Lawson said: "There are a number of potential benefits from an integrated advisory and support service for family courts, not least the fact that there can now be agreed national standards with practitioners. "In the past, family court welfare was formerly part of the probation service and had become extremely marginalised within the service. Guardian panels were administered by the local authority and that meant the authorities were effectively paying for the guardians." Most guardians ad litem are involved in disputes between local authorities and parents, but because of this financial link with council there were fears they would be seen as less independent than they really were. Mr Lawson sees the challenge for Cafcass as providing a new organisation that will encourage the exchange of skills and contribute to the professional development of all the participants. "But there may be problems with vested interests if professionals attempt to cling to the past rather than embracing the future," he warned. Mr Hewson says delays in the family court system were leading to some children having to wait up to 40 weeks to get into the system: "In future we will be able to analyse the areas where children are facing unacceptable waiting times and effectively address the problems with a unified approach." He believes the main task is to listen to the views of children to create a truly child-focused system: "Over the next 12-months we are going to be asking children what it is that they would like to see in terms of a service. There are many ways we can do this. We have already begun talks with agencies like the NSPCC and that is crucial to the future."

webTitle: The need for craftsmen in a hi-tech age

fields.headline: You need hands
fields.standfirst: In an age of hi-tech architecture, we still need craftsmen who can build with skill and care, says Jonathan Glancey.
fields.trailText: In an age of hi-tech architecture, we still need craftsmen who can build with skill and care, says Jonathan Glancey
fields.body:
It would be part of my scheme of physical education," John Ruskin wrote in 1867, "that every youth in the state - from the King's son downwards - should learn to do something finely and thoroughly with his hand, so as to let him know what touch meant and what craftsmanship meant. Let him once learn to take a straight shaving off a plank, or draw a fine curve without faltering, or lay a brick level in its mortar, and he has learned a multitude of other matters which no lips of man could ever teach him."

Ruskin is quoted by the architect Hugh Pople in the catalogue for Making Buildings, a touring exhibition about the craft of architecture. Pople believes that craft skills in modern British building and architecture have all too often been lacking, because "the UK not only under-invested in its built environment during the 20th century, but also under-invested in its most valuable asset: its people".

Given that British industry has treated labour, even highly skilled labour, like cannon-fodder, it is easy to see why today's building industry and architects have had difficulty finding craftsmanship of a high standard. Housebuilders are turning to new concrete techniques even in the construction of traditional-looking new homes; facades are increasingly pasted on like wallpaper.

This, though, is not the whole story. There are many highly skilled craftspeople working at the arts- inspired end of the building industry, and there has also been a new wave of craft workers emerging over the past 25 years alongside Britain's hi-tech architects.

Making Buildings has been organised by the Crafts Council with the New Art Gallery, Walsall, and the Buckinghamshire Chilterns University College, where curator Greg Votolato is professor of design. Votolato's show concentrates on the overtly environmentally friendly end of modern craft-inspired construction, taking in abstract artworks whose theme is architecture. Yet some of the latest talent is in the craftsmanship required by architects of the hi-tech school of Norman Foster and Richard Rogers.

The fact is that many new buildings are crafted - but in ways that we have learned only slowly to appreciate. Foster's Hongkong & Shanghai Bank in Hong Kong, for example, is a superb example of custom-made architecture, a building crafted using the skills of welders, glaziers and steel-makers. It has about it the mix of computer-age technology and handmaking that is the glue of the aerospace industry. Architects are recovering at least a part of their role in the craft and building process. But what about the workers? On display in Making Buildings are examples of the work of architectural practices such as Edward Cullinan's, which, although utterly modern in concept, require a high degree of craft skill. Cullinan's upcoming New Conservation Centre for the Weald and Downland Open Air Museum at Singleton, Sussex, is an inspiring example. The Crafts Council show displays a section of the building; a thing of almost boundless curves, it is built of layers of green oak. It is clad in cedar, has spruce floors and has the air of an ultra-modern parish church. It is a fine mix of modern boat-building and even aircraft technology, crafted by hands, aided by computer design.

There are also examples of the work of the Walter Segal Self Build Trust, which enables communities to construct their own practical and modern homes. This is like a translation to Britain, via the Bauhaus aesthetic of the late Walter Segal, of Shaker or Amish communal building methods. Here, the process of building is as important as the finished product - as it is in the case of Amish barns. No one who saw the film Witness can forget the scene in which an Amish village raises a clapboard barn in what seems like one dreamy day.

Elsewhere there are more lighthearted, unorthodox and experimental uses of new craft skills and materials. Ushida Findlay Architects, from Tokyo, have collaborated with the basket-maker Lee Dalby on the design of a curious vortex of bamboo - it makes a lovely sound - intended, in part, to connect new architectural ideas with sensual and responsive building materials. A similar theme is pursued by the Japanese architect Tono Mirai, who shows lovely "nests" of mud and straw - dreamy structures hovering happily between the worlds of practical building and architectural dreaming.

Building and dreaming have been fused together several times by Jim Partridge, a craftsman who works mainly with unseasoned green timber; the shelter and information centre he made with Liz Walmsley from thuya and larch logs for the Chilterns Sculpture Trail is one of the most delightful buildings I've seen in recent years. Sadly, it has been taken down because children like to play on it. It would be good to see other structures like this, and even to allow children to play on them.

This may seem an unfocused show, but it's not: it sets out to show the diverse range of craft skills required for and emerging from new forms of architecture and new materials. It's dangerous to be over- optimistic, given the fact that most of the trashy buildings we spend our working and domestic lives in are about as finely crafted as an MDF bookcase from a budget DIY warehouse. Yet the desire to build beautifully is unlikely to go away as long as there is someone around who appreciates taking a straight shaving off a plank, drawing a fine curve without faltering or laying a brick level in its mortar. And, as the great architect Ludwig Mies van der Rohe liked to say, architecture began "when two bricks were put together well".

webTitle: Food for thought on charity trek

fields.headline: Food for thought on charity trek
fields.standfirst: In the latest posting from an adoption supporters' charity walk in China, student Emma Summerfield describes an experience of a lifetime walking on the great wall, although the spam and egg sandwiches were almost as memorable
fields.trailText: In the latest posting from an adoption supporters' charity walk in China, student Emma Summerfield describes an experience of a lifetime walking on the great wall, although the spam and egg sandwiches were almost as memorable.
fields.body:
The sponsorship details that were sent out by BAAF several months ago stated that this trip would be "a challenge of a lifetime". Today I think everyone's expectations were surpassed!

We left the hotel early this morning, some still suffering from the previous night's entertainment (myself included). We arrived at Jinshangling, one of the lesser visited parts of the wall. It looked impressive from the bottom, after climbing some steep steps, we were on our first watchtower. The view was magnificent.

Fortunately, the sun was up, although it was fairly cold until we started walking. For about two hours, we weaved our way along the wall with our local guides. The walk was amazing and covered some difficult conditions - crumbling walls and more steep steps up and down. Some parts were 90 degree angles and we had to practically crawl up - not for the faint hearted.

There are 20 people participating, ranging in age from 23 to 64, and of several different professions. Some people are directly involved in adoption and fostering in both England and China. The rest of us just wanted to raise awareness and money for this issue. I am a student at City University, in London, studying psychology. I worked for nine years in an American bank but two years ago decided on a career change. My aim is to become a child psychologist and become more involved in adoption and fostering issues.

Today, I have had some great conversations with people about their experiences. Robert Glover and I discussed the Chinese perspective on adoption and fostering. He works for Care for Children in Shanghai. A personal sponsorship of £100 per year keeps a child in a foster family in Kunming (I've already signed up).

Lunch was on a watchtower. Those fried egg and spam sandwiches are not going down well. The rest of the walk en route to Simatai was as challenging as the morning's. At our final destination we had passed 32 watchtowers and more than 12kms. We brought some souvenirs from our guides as a gesture of our gratitude.

The journey back to the hotel was buzzing with adrenaline. Everyone was exhilarated and proud of our achievements. Everyone on this trip is here to raise money for child welfare in England and China, which we couldn't have done without the companies, the family members and friends who have given so generously.

It was a truly amazing day. The landscape was spectacular, the walk challenging and the company great.

webTitle: Italian authors sue in plagarism row

fields.headline: Answer me with damages, Italian author tells rival
fields.standfirst: Former friends fall out as they sue and counter-sue in plagiarism row
fields.trailText: Former friends fall out as they sue and counter-sue in plagiarism row.
fields.body:
In both stories a girl has a traumatic coming of age in northern Italy, rebels, escapes on a bicycle, runs into a man with a drooping moustache, and has a baby.

What happens next is up to the courts, for the similarities between the stories have lobbed a grenade into Italy's usually placid publishing world.

Ippolita Avalli, an acclaimed novelist, is suing her bestselling former friend Susanna Tamaro for plagiarism.

Accusations of betrayal and deceit, themes common to their fiction, are being flung in an increasingly dirty fight.

Ms Avalli is seeking £1.7m damages and wants Ms Tamaro's book, Answer Me, removed from bookshops. Ms Tamaro has responded with a £1m counter-claim.

Ms Avalli's autobiographical 1997 novel The Goddess of Kisses was hailed for its bleak depiction of growing up. Narrated in the first-person in curt prose, it was shortlisted for the Strega prize.

She claims that its plot, structure and vocabulary were ripped off in the title story of Answer Me, a short-story collection which has sold 200,000 copies since its publication earlier this year, making Ms Tamaro one of Italy's most successful authors.

"It was clearly and blatantly plagiarised," Ms Avelli's lawyer Nicola Rocchett, told Panorama magazine.

His court case lists 35 points of similarity. "The plot, characters, style, atmosphere, natural and socio-cultural setting, as well as the premises and conclusions, are nearly identical," he said

In The Goddess of Kisses, published by Baldini & Castoldi, the narrator Giovanna throws a tantrum during mass, condemns the Catholic church and calls the congregation "whitewashed tombs".

In Answer Me, published by Rizzoli, the narrator Rosa smashes a statue of Jesus during mass and calls the congregation "whitewashed tombs".

Rosa, like Giovanna, flees her house on a bicycle and crashes into a man whose moustache is "drooping".

Ms Avalli said there was no doubt about her former friend's guilt. "She and her editor are people who know me very well. There's no way they couldn't have realised it."

She was especially affronted that her character's pregnancy - drawn from her own experience - was replicated, an alleged theft of her private life as well as fiction.

Ms Tamaro denies the accusations and has retaliated in a series of newspaper interviews, claiming to be the victim of pure terrorism.

"I must make an embarrassing confession. I've always copied. I've ransacked St Augustine, Montaigne, Pascal. I've always thought this was called culture," she said.

"And as for the moustache, how many ways can it be? Long, short, curly, or maybe drooping, like my father's?"

If the counter-suit succeeds, the damages will join Ms Tamaro's royalties in funding a charitable foundation. A Milan court will hear the case next month.

The feud is made all the more bitter by the fact that they were introduced by Ms Tamaro's companion, Roberta Mazzoni, an editor at Baldini & Castoldi, who helped to get The Goddess of Kisses published.

Ms Tamaro denied being influenced by her partner when it came to writing her own book. "Absolutely not. I don't have that kind of relationship with Roberta."

webTitle: Macedonia prepares for talks with its Albanians

fields.headline: With one eye on the EU, Macedonia prepares for talks with its Albanians
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Macedonia
Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Macedonia is to begin a broad political dialogue with the leaders of its Albanian community in response to the European Union's attempt to defuse the country's crisis, it emerged at the weekend.
fields.body:
Macedonia is to begin a broad political dialogue with the leaders of its Albanian community in response to the European Union's attempt to defuse the country's crisis, it emerged at the weekend.

The EU's foreign policy chief, Javier Solana, who is holding talks in Skopje today, is expecting to see a "Europe committee" or "round table" designed to resolve the country's bitter inter-ethnic differences and pave the way for a EU-Macedonian agreement next week.

Mr Solana and the EU's commissioner for external relations, Chris Patten, are due to meet President Boris Trajkovski, opposition leaders and leaders of the Albanian parties.

President Trajkovski is said to be ready to join an all-party dialogue and to revise parts of the constitution to take into account Albanian sensitivities, after the weeks of fighting between Macedonian forces and ethnic Albanian guerrillas.

In return Brussels is offering a "stabilisation and association agreement", to be signed by foreign ministers in Luxembourg a week today, the first step towards EU membership for the tiny former Yugoslav republic.

Croatia is the only other Balkan state promised such a deal, at last November's Zagreb summit.

EU leaders, well placed sources said, bluntly told President Trajkovski in Stockholm last weekend to exercise restraint while fighting the ethnic Albanian UCK (national liberation army) rebels in the hills above the northern city of Tetovo.

"You have to keep the moderate Albanians on board and isolate the extremists," he was warned. "Any action which could undermine this goal would be a mistake."

Macedonia says it has now completed the military operation to drive the insurgents out of their mountain hideouts and across the border into UN-governed Kosovo.

"We have accomplished the goal of driving out the terrorists with minimum casualties," the prime minister, Ljubco Georgievski, said on Saturday.

"It was a text-book operation and was praised by the international community for its precision and efficiency."

The EU sees the successful resolution of the Macedonian military operation as due in part to the coherence of its foreign policy and a close working relationship with Nato, despite anger in Skopje that Nato has been lax in policing the Kosovo border.

Mr Solana also coordinated policy with the US secretary of state, Colin Powell, and is urging him to visit Skopje.

But the feeling is that, at a time of disarray in Washington, this is a Balkan crisis in which Europe can finally take the lead.

Lord Roberston, the Nato secretary general, will meet Mr Solana this morning in Brussels to discuss the issue.

A peaceful solution is far from assured, however. Macedonian opposition groups have angrily criticised the government's readiness to meet EU demands. The main ethnic Albanian leader, Arben Xhaferi, a key partner in the fragile coalition government, has threatened to quit if his community's demands are not met within a month - leaving men with guns to fight for Albanian rights.

Mr Georgievski and other politicians of the ethnic majority are wary of a nationalist backlash from their own constituencies if they concede too much.

For this reason Brussels has presented inter-ethnic dialogue as an integral part of the path to EU membership rather than a concession to violence.

Ethnic Albanians form as much as a third of Macedonia's 2.2m population and say they are discriminated against in education, employment and politics.

EU sources say that rewriting the country's constitution is a key demand, but it is not clear whether the parties are prepared to do that.

Under pressure from the EU, the two sides are being asked to achieve within a few weeks what they have failed to do in the 10 years since independence from socialist Yugoslavia in 1991.

Mistrust runs deep and ethnic Albanian politicians accuse their Slav colleagues of repeatedly failing to keep their promises.

The Slavs, however, say the Albanians keep shifting the goalposts.

On Friday, Nato-led peacekeepers detained 30 men of "military age", some of them armed, along the hilly and wooded border between Kosovo and Macedonia.

fields.headline: Chinese restaurants feel the pinch
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Chinese restaurants across the UK have reported a downturn in trade of as much as 40% after reports that meat from Asia destined for the Chinese catering trade could be responsible for the foot and mouth outbreak.
fields.body:
Chinese restaurants across the UK have reported a downturn in trade of as much as 40% after reports that meat from Asia destined for the Chinese catering trade could be responsible for the foot and mouth outbreak.

Restaurateurs in infected regions of Yorkshire and Devon, as well as Chinatown in London, have contacted community leaders to report a slowdown in custom and express their dismay at the "scapegoating" for the outbreak.

Jabez Lam, a Chinese community leader in London and a member of the National Civil Rights Monitoring Group, said widespread reporting of an unsubstantiated link between foot and mouth and the Chinese food industry was irresponsible and had the potential to incite hate crime.

"Since these stories appeared in the press and on television, restaurants have been extremely quiet. I have reports of establishments in Leeds which have not had a single customer since, and in Chinatown many are reporting a 40% decrease in business," he said. "In a time like this, with an internal crisis, it is easy to label a foreign community as responsible, but these allegations are extremely serious. The Chinese food industry is already subject to racial attacks and hatred.

"Nick Brown [the agriculture minister] and the media forget that the Chinese catering business in this country is suffering too. To offer the Chinese community as a sacrifice is despicable."

Mr Lam said the allegations could devastate an industry that employs 80% of Chinese workers in the UK. A protest petition calling on Tony Blair to condemn the "irresponsible" remarks was delivered to Downing Street on Thursday.

The allegations claimed that smuggled meat served in a Chinese restaurant and then sold as pigswill was being investigated as the most likely source of the foot and mouth epidemic. A concealed container of smuggled meat "clearly labelled for a Chinese restaurant" had been found.

Last night, Downing Street and Maff denied responsibility for the initial allegation. But both Maff and Northumberland trading standards officers confirmed that an investigation into the possible illegal importation of infected meat from Asia was under way.

webTitle: Foot and mouth: Festival and Six Nations give up the fight

fields.headline: Festival and Six Nations give up the fight
fields.trailText: This month's rearranged Cheltenham National Hunt Festival was abandoned last night after a new outbreak of foot and mouth disease five miles from the Gloucestershire course. Its insurers now face a claim of £8m for the loss of the showcase meeting.
fields.body:
This month's rearranged Cheltenham National Hunt Festival was abandoned last night after a new outbreak of foot and mouth disease five miles from the Gloucestershire course. Its insurers now face a claim of £8m for the loss of the showcase meeting.

The seemingly unabated spread of the virus also put paid to the conclusion of rugby's Six Nations yesterday, when the organising committee announced that Ireland's three outstanding matches, at home to England and away to Scotland and Wales, will be postponed until an unspecified date next season. Next weekend's games, England v France and Italy v Wales, will go ahead.

The Cheltenham cancellation will cost the betting industry an estimated £100m. The festival attracts 200,000 spectators to Prestbury Park and is worth £10m to the local economy. Hotels are facing heavy losses, which some have tried to limit by withholding racegoers' deposits.

The meeting, originally planned for March 13-15, was first rescheduled for April 17-19 after the course failed to comply with British Horseracing Board and Ministry of Agriculture guidelines concerning the grazing of sheep on the track. The new foot and mouth case, confirmed on Saturday, is in the village of Woolstone, putting the Cheltenham course inside an exclusion zone.

Bookmakers last night said that contingency plans to run the meeting's four main champion races at Sandown Park would do virtually nothing to replace their lost income. The Gold Cup, Champion Hurdle, Queen Mother Champion Chase and Stayers' Hurdle will all be transferred to Sandown, not in name but as new Grade One races over similar distances at the Whitbread Gold Cup fixture on April 27 and 28.

"With the original dates going," said David Hood of William Hill, "the betting industry lost about £100m - and us about £20m. If they run these championship races at Sandown's Whitbread meeting that would boost the turnover, but you are talking peanuts. All that you would be talking about there are feature races on an attractive day.

"The unique nature of the festival and its position in the racing calendar make it one of the strongest betting fixtures of the year and the damage to betting turnover cannot be underestimated."

In addition to the rescheduled championship events four races at this week's Grand National fixture at Aintree have been upgraded in status and been granted extra prize money. Cheltenham's managing director, Edward Gillespie, said it was now vital for racing to rally behind the three-day National meeting which starts on Thursday.

"It is bad news, but we must now all try and support the big meeting at Aintree. I know that I'm very much looking forward to my day out on Saturday. We are disappointed for everyone concerned that the 2001 Cheltenham Festival won't go ahead, but we must now look forward to next year," he said.

Sixty-one meetings have now been lost to foot and mouth and Cheltenham is the 14th racecourse to fall within an exclusion zone. The BHB indicated at the weekend that it will consider allowing racecourses within infected areas to stage fixtures again.

Speaking before the annoucement of Cheltenham's cancellation, Paul Greeves, the BHB's racing director, said: "If perhaps in two weeks' time we feel the situation is coming under control we will be ready to act. The ministry has already said it is OK and at some point racing itself will question our policy. Some racecourses are already asking and others will certainly follow."
