webTitle: Officer hurt by stolen digger at protest over cull

fields.headline: Officer hurt by stolen digger at protest over cull
fields.standfirst:
Protester in custody after bulldozer crushes police van
 Future of Ministry of Agriculture is questioned
Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText:
Protester in custody after bulldozer crushes police van
 Future of Ministry of Agriculture is questioned
fields.body:
Anxieties over the slaughter and burial of livestock sparked violence early yesterday when a mechanical digger stolen from the site of a new grave was used to crush a police van, injuring an officer inside it.

Up to 100 protesters have been demonstrating against burials at an army firing range in Eppynt, Powys, which is due to begin receiving carcasses tomorrow. They fear that the dead animals will bring foot and mouth to the area.

A 50-tonne vehicle being used to excavate the pit was driven at speed towards the crowd, sending up to 60 officers and more than 50 protesters fleeing "in absolute horror", said Terrence Grange, chief constable of Dyfed Powys.

The digger went through an army checkpoint and hit a protester's car before driving over the police van. It took ambulance staff two hours to release the injured officer and he was said to be "badly bruised and traumatised" following the 1am incident.

It is not yet clear precisely what caused the incident. The driver of the vehicle was in custody following his arrest on suspicion of attempted murder and three other people were being held in connection with the incident.

The rising death toll has caused many to question the appropriateness of the mass cull. So far 940,000 animals have been condemned, with 353,000 still awaiting slaughter and 166,000 carcasses awaiting disposal. The number of cases rose to 891 yesterday, with at least 75 new cases over the weekend.

It has also raised speculation over the future of the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food, which is under fire for its handling of the outbreak. Rumours that it faces restructuring when the crisis is over drew strength yesterday when Stephen Byers, the trade secretary, failed to reject suggestions that it might eventually be absorbed into his own department.

As Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, visited a new disease control centre in Newcastle on Tyne, he admitted Maff did not have the resources to tackle the outbreak alone, but said that his staff had been working flat out and that the situation remained under control.

Despite concerns about animal welfare, the RSPCA's chief vet yesterday praised slaughterers and said they were doing their job "carefully and with great compassion" as he visited the former airfield in Cumbria where 10,000 sheep are being slaughtered each day.

"This is an amazing operation and it is absolutely dreadful to see so many animals being killed," said Chris Laurence, who had made a special 300-mile trip to Great Orton, near Carlisle, from the RSPCA's headquarters in Horsham, Sussex. "They are being killed by people with skill who are doing an excellent job."

More than 20 slaughtermen working 12-hour shifts and supervised by seven vets have now killed more than 125,000 sheep. An army armourer has been brought in to maintain their captive bolt guns which are showing signs of wear.

Animal lovers have placed flowers at the site in memory of the slaughtered livestock. By the security gate Heather Davison from Jedburgh in the Scottish borders had left a bouquet of flowers with a card reading: "We will never forget all the innocent animals who have been murdered." Another anonymous visitor had left daffodils with the message: "Never forget the slaughter."

But Mr Laurence said he was happy with how animals were held at the site before slaughter. "I have not seen any animal held here for longer than half an hour."

Replying to Prince Charles's claim that the culling of healthy animals was mindless, Mr Laurence added: "It is a little incorrect to say these animals are healthy because very many of them will be incubating the disease although they are not showing symptoms yet. Within reason, this is the right thing to do."

He dismissed vaccination as a "last desperate measure", warning: "It is not a question of simply vaccinating an animal and it then being immune and never getting the disease.

"After they have been vaccinated, they are likely to end up as carriers, excrete the virus for many months afterwards and infect every other animal they come into contact with."

There was some positive news for farmers in Northern Ireland, where movement restrictions are likely to be eased today, allowing them to apply for licences to move their animals short distances on welfare grounds. The area has seen only one case of the disease - in a sheep farm at Meigh in South Armagh more than a month ago - and the cull in the control zone around it is almost complete.

In Scotland, the tourism industry learned that the actor Sir Sean Connery will lead a campaign to attract American tourists back to the country.

In England a tourism "cabinet" will work out a recovery plan for the industry. It will include representatives from the English Tourism Council, the Cabinet Office, the British Tourist Authority, and other industry bodies.

webTitle: Carter urges Bush to act on global warming

fields.headline: Carter urges Bush to act on global warming
fields.standfirst:
Special report: global warming
Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: The United States must develop an urgent plan to reduce its emissions of greenhouse gases, which account for a quarter of the world's total, former president Jimmy Carter told the Bush administration yesterday.
fields.body:
The United States must develop an urgent plan to reduce its emissions of greenhouse gases, which account for a quarter of the world's total, former president Jimmy Carter told the Bush administration yesterday.

Along with nine other influential US and international figures, Mr Carter has signed a letter to President George Bush pressing for "consensus and action", just days after his government announced that it was ditching the Kyoto protocol on global climate change, signed in 1997.

Mr Carter acted as an opinion poll showed that three-quarters of Americans regard global warming as a serious problem and two-thirds want the administration to develop a plan to deal with it.

Mr Bush's announcement that the US would not abide by the Kyoto agreements to cut emissions by 5.2% from the 1990 levels by 2012 caused a worldwide outburst of anger against US energy policies, making the first big dent in the administration's international standing, especially in Europe.

European Union officials, headed by the environment commissioner, Margot Wallstrom, are due to meet the head of the US environmental protection agency, Christine Todd Whitman, in Washington today to protest against the decision.

Mr Carter's statement does not align itself precisely with European protests, since it stops short of calling on the White House to abide by Kyoto, but it mirrors the alarm which the president's pay-off to the Republican party's big corporate backers has created, even in the US.

"No challenge we face is more momentous than the threat of global climate change," the open letter says.

"The current provisions of the Kyoto protocol are a matter of legitimate debate. But the situation is becoming urgent and it is time for consensus and action.

"There are many strategies for curbing greenhouse gas emissions without slowing economic growth. In fact the spread of advanced cleaner technology is more of an economic opportunity than a peril.

"We urge you to develop a plan to reduce US production of greenhouse gases. The future of our children - and their children - depends on the resolve that you and other world leaders show."

The letter, which is published in the new issue of Time magazine, is signed by Mr Carter and the former Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev.

Other signatories include the film star Harrison Ford, the Cambridge University cosmologist Professor Stephen Hawking, the former astronaut John Glenn, the financier George Soros, and the doyen of American television news, Walter Cronkite.

The new poll shows that Americans are more supportive than their government of action to cut emissions, but the closeness of some of its findings is a reminder that Americans are less environmentalist than Europeans, especially about their cars and trucks.

Just over half of of them think the US should take measures to control global warming, even if other countries do not - the reverse of the position adopted by Mr Bush.

Nearly two-thirds, including half of Mr Bush's Republican voters, identify carbon dioxide as a cause of climate change, which is a position Mr Bush explicitly rejects.

And 55% say that the administration should require improvements in the fuel efficiency of cars and trucks, even if the result is more expensive and smaller vehicles.

Against that, more than 40% disagree with the fuel efficiency proposal, and only 48% are willing to pay an extra 25 cents a gallon for petrol - which costs about $1.60 (about £1.12) a gallon in most of the US - to help reduce pollution.

Ten years ago, when petrol was cheaper, just over 60% were willing to pay extra.

webTitle: Rools website's founders  on starting up

fields.headline: Starting up
fields.standfirst:
Now it comes down to generating real money

More net news
fields.trailText: Now it comes down to generating real money, say Adam Hamdy and Guy Mallison, the co-founders of rools, an online payments service for teenagers.
fields.body:
Our financial position at the moment is healthy but we always have an eye on the next round of funding. The lengthy lead times that can be involved in securing funds - we estimate five months from start to finish - mean that the current turbulence is causing us to re-examine fundamentally our strategy.

A critical challenge is to start generating some serious revenue, to demonstrate to investors that the business does have potential. To date, our revenue has been limited to the small transaction fees that we derive from the trial of our service. It is not clear when we will be able to launch the full service, for which we are relying on a banking partner, so we probably have to look elsewhere for more immediate returns.

One opportunity lies in using our core system in other applications. We have developed a fairly heavyweight online transaction processing and account management system that has already attracted the attention of an ISP and market broking firm - and this has been without any active marketing. We could focus on developing business-to-business applications of the system, but that might be at the expense of effort in the teen payments space. Finding an appropriate balance between the two will be important.

A solution may be to partner with another player in the teen payments industry. We have a bank-based business model that may be complementary with some of the pre-pay card services. It is a difficult direction to open up, but one we are considering.

Once potential revenue streams have been explored, attention quickly focuses on cost. We have been prudent from the start. To date, the business has been under-budget every month of its existence. There is not a huge amount more we can squeeze but we do have enough cash to last us into next year.

The lead times in our industry, from preparing for a full launch to securing next-round funding, mean that these issues have to be resolved now. In the current environment we might have to be radical in order to ensure our survival but by planning ahead we are confident of minimising the risks.

 Adam Hamdy and Guy Mallison are the co-founders of rools, an online payments service for teenagers.

fields.headline: Chris McGreal @ Harare
fields.standfirst: Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: Harare's robots are no longer flashing, and many of its streets have suddenly become a maze for the uninformed. But it hardly matters to most of the city's motorists. They are more likely to be found sitting behind the wheel of a car that is going nowhere.
fields.body:
Harare's robots are no longer flashing, and many of its streets have suddenly become a maze for the uninformed. But it hardly matters to most of the city's motorists. They are more likely to be found sitting behind the wheel of a car that is going nowhere.

In recent weeks, many of the Zimbabwe capital's traffic lights - robots as they are known in southern Africa - have been plundered for their bulbs. City officials say the stolen lamps are turning up in discos, which can no longer obtain lights through the regular channels because Zimbabwe's economic crisis has left no foreign currency for such trivial imports. Harare's street name signs are also quietly disappearing in the middle of the night, but for a darker use. The aluminium is bent to shape coffin handles to cope with the endless stream of Zimbabweans killed by Aids.

In the scheme of what Harare's residents have to put up with, the dysfunctional robots and disappearing street signs are small irritants. For a start, people do not spend so much time in their cars any more. At least, not on the move. The foreign exchange crisis has robbed the country of regular fuel supplies. These days motorists congregate at petrol stations in a seemingly perpetual hunt for fuel. It only takes a whisper of a rumour that a delivery is imminent and cars flock to the garage. Frequently their drivers are disappointed, but even when they are not they still spend most of the day waiting.

For all the government's fevered attempts to whip up racial confrontation to distract Zimbabweans from the real causes of their problems, petrol queues on the whole remain fairly placid as whites and blacks alike bemoan the events that have brought Zimbabwe the worst economic crisis since independence. There is not usually much disagreement over whose fault it is. When fights do break out it is usually over queue hopping. And it's not just petrol that is scarce. A diesel shortage has brought every train in the country to a halt. A lack of aviation fuel has all but grounded Air Zimbabwe, although it does not like to admit as much until passengers get to the airport and discover there is no plane. The government was so desperate to get fuel into Zimbabwe last month that it stole 16m litres from BP tanks in Mozambique after a cheque to pay the Kuwaiti owners bounced.

As Zimbabwe's crisis grows, the government talks as if an intergalactic British conspiracy is responsible and its own actions have no bearing on the fuel shortage. fields.bodyText: Harare's robots are no longer flashing, and many of its streets have suddenly become a maze for the uninformed. But it hardly matters to most of the city's motorists. They are more likely to be found sitting behind the wheel of a car that is going nowhere. In recent weeks, many of the Zimbabwe capital's traffic lights - robots as they are known in southern Africa - have been plundered for their bulbs. City officials say the stolen lamps are turning up in discos, which can no longer obtain lights through the regular channels because Zimbabwe's economic crisis has left no foreign currency for such trivial imports. Harare's street name signs are also quietly disappearing in the middle of the night, but for a darker use. The aluminium is bent to shape coffin handles to cope with the endless stream of Zimbabweans killed by Aids. In the scheme of what Harare's residents have to put up with, the dysfunctional robots and disappearing street signs are small irritants. For a start, people do not spend so much time in their cars any more. At least, not on the move. The foreign exchange crisis has robbed the country of regular fuel supplies. fields.headline: Secs in the City
fields.trailText: The phrase "office romance" has never made much sense to me. Be honest: is your office romantic? Strip-lighting, functional furniture and that strange office smell - a mixture of instant coffee and recycled air - have never really got me in the mood for love.
fields.body:
The phrase "office romance" has never made much sense to me. Be honest: is your office romantic? Strip-lighting, functional furniture and that strange office smell - a mixture of instant coffee and recycled air - have never really got me in the mood for love.

Don't get me wrong, I am blessed with male colleagues of above average intelligence, looks and good humour. If I came across them in a drinking establishment I might even be tempted to ask them their star sign and buy them a lager. But there are elements to every fledgling romance - mystique, allure, that certain je ne sais quoi - that are killed stone dead by working together. I see them at 9am every morning. It's not a pretty sight.

So it's safe to say that all the relationships in our office are peacefully platonic. Or, at least, they were. All that changed last week with the arrival of The Temp.

You know how it is, there's a bit of extra typing and filing to do, you give the agency a ring, hoping for someone who can at least walk and think at the same time, and then a 6ft 2in Adonis turns up in reception. And that was Jason, just off the plane from Australia, bronzed, blonde and blue-eyed. Well, fair dinkum, I almost choked on my almond croissant.

It was like a permanent Diet Coke break. When Jase was in the vicinity, the girls flushed, fluttered and fawned. Suddenly we were turning up to work in new outfits, with immaculate hair and perfect make-up. Just because we felt like it, you understand. Just for a change.

The boys were less impressed. After a couple of days they began to make pointed remarks about all Australians being criminals and trading email jokes about Outback sheep farmers.

It couldn't last, of course. The filing was well and truly finished and we had to say goodbye. The girls were bereft, but the boys were positively beaming. Mark and Tom even bought cakes to cheer us up. And it struck me that Jason might have looks that put Jude Law in the shade, but he would never have known - much less cared - that Sara will only eat carrot cake and Chloe can't stand dark chocolate.

There might not be any romance in our office, but when you've got colleagues who will buy you eclairs and not care that you look like Miss Piggy while you eat them, who needs it?

fields.headline: WPM
fields.trailText: As usual, WPM is all over the shop. Sometimes she wonders whether she might have been born 15 minutes too late, so making her 15 minutes late for every appointment in her entire life.
fields.body:
* As usual, WPM is all over the shop. Sometimes she wonders whether she might have been born 15 minutes too late, so making her 15 minutes late for every appointment in her entire life. She's got umpteen letters to write, the phone bill to pay and toenails to paint, and when will she ever find the time to decorate her boudoir?

What she needs is an Alexandra Fontaine. Alexandra may sound like a hypnotist, or maybe an exclusive range of designer footwear, but in actual fact Alexandra (and we're not calling her Alex, folks, we're keeping this strictly professional here) is a Personal Time Saver, shaving off valuable minutes like parmesan and handing them to you in a small sprinkly container so you can distribute them at your leisure.

Alex has sent WPM a picture of herself, inexplicably lodged inside a clock, with her hands at quarter past twelve. Or is that three o'clock? Alex will sort all the itty-bitty bits of your day, like collecting your dry-cleaning and contacting the Kennel Club to see about that litter of Yorkshire Terriers you ordered, so that you can get on with your job and go to your aerobics class (although WPM is thinking about asking Alexandra to go her aerobics class for her). You can contact the marvellous Ms Fontaine at alex.fontaine@virgin.net . Soon, your life will be calm, and your sock drawer tidy.

*WPM expects she doesn't need to tell you about the hpofficejet g85. You've got your finger on the pulse; in fact that's what we call you behind your back, "Pulsefinger". You know that the hpofficejet g85 is all the kids are talking about nowadays, it's like the Pokémon of the office world.

The cats at Hewlett-Packard are saying it's "an all-in-one fax, colour printer, copier and scanner, which literally does everything but make the coffee". Yes, because that would be WPM's job, wouldn't it? And heaven only knows, if they went and invented a contraption which could fax, print, photocopy, scan and make coffee to boot, WPM would be hard put to find things to make it look as though she were working. I mean, a girl can only riffle through the papers on her desk looking exasperated and sighing dramatically so many times, before management gets suspicious.

And sooner or later WPM is certain they'll even invent robots to do that. Their little pincer-like hands shuffling through that paperwork so much more efficiently, and their sighs, their sighs, sounding like Jane Birkin, je t'aime-ing across the office. Anyway, the point of all this, is that Hewlett-Packard and Office World have joined forces, much like Westlife and Mariah Carey, or Elton John and Kiki Dee, to give us a a real humdinger of an offer.

Until April 6 2001 AD, with every single hpofficejet g85 you purchase, you'll be getting - and I do hope you're sitting down as you read this - a brand new kettle to take home with you, too. Yes! A KETTLE! Just imagine the endless hours of fun instore for you. Wow your colleagues as you make them cup of tea after cup of tea after cup of tea. And it needn't stop there. With so many instant beverages on the market, not to mention Pot Noodles and custard, you'll soon show the boss that you're an innovative and creative worker, who can get a refreshment job done fast. Bugger the faxing; let's leave that to the robots.

*There isn't a day goes by when WPM doesn't wish there were a monthly magazine aimed specifically at secretaries and PAs. I mean what is it with all this quarterly nonsense? WPM wants secretarial information and fast. She doesn't want to hang around waiting for news of the latest Regus survey, like some nervous, gap-toothed 15-year-old, standing alone outside McDonald's on a Saturday afternoon, waiting for her date to show up. Praise the lord, then, for Executary News, a brand new magazine for secretaries and PAs. With lots of news and features and boasting amazing competitions and amazing promotions, with amazing prizes, like kettles, you can bet your ass, Executary News is going to be pretty amazing.

So why not send a cheque for £19.50 (payable to Executary International Magazine Ltd) to Subscriptions, Executary News, Groves Business Centre, Milton Under Wychwood, Oxon OX7 6JF. C'mon, what else were you going to do with that twenty quid? Blow it on hard drugs, and photocopying ink?

fields.headline: Apple of your iMac
fields.standfirst: In the first of a series of must-haves, Laura Barton finds that spots before the eyes are a jolly good thing
fields.trailText: In the first of a series of must-haves, Laura Barton finds that spots before the eyes are a jolly good thing
fields.body:
As a girl, I of course love flowers. And dalmations. So imagine my recent joy, nay euphoria, at finding that Apple has devised iMacs that blend seamlessly into the rural setting of a beautiful summer meadow. Or Battersea Dogs' Home. The iMac's Flower Power and Dalmation designs, shown right here, on these very pages, enable you to remember all the lovely things in life while stuck behind your computer terminal on a dank Wednesday afternoon.

But they're not just a pretty face. Oh no. These babies boast all manner of technical wizardry and flippertyjibbets to make your life sweeter still.

Wonder, at the magic of iTunes, which allows you to craft your own MP3 files and burn music CDs in its built-in CD burner, when you should be doing some work. The real beauty is that it'll just get on with it, quietly, in the background, like a small and diligent seamstress. You won't even know you're wearing it. What's more, the mighty Harman Kardon Odyssey sound system (which sounds an adventure and a half) will ensure that when Mr Snodgrass goes out for his business luncheon, you can all dance around to Bryan Adams on your desktops. There isn't even a cooler fan to make that unnerving droning sound while Bryan is belting out Summer of 69, because the iMac cools itself calmly and quietly and without any fuss.

Marvel at the genius of iMovie 2, an invention that gives you the power to edit your home movies, adding a swish soundtrack and wowing effects such as sepia tones, water ripples and, of course, soft-focus, for those fuzzy-edged on-screen snogging moments. Then you can download it onto a video cassette and bore the whole office to tears with the film you made of your second cousin's wedding. Alternatively, you may want to email it to your chums, or broadcast it on the internet for the whole bleeding world to admire.

The iMac also has the advantage of the Apple Pro Mouse. With her "high-precision optical sensor", she needs no cleaning, so say adios to all that scratching off the grey scummy bits on the inside of your mouse, 'cause this little cutie glides like Torville and Dean. And there's more. None of this nancying around with internet service providers, with the iMac you're up an' at 'em in minutes. Just as soon as you've figured out how to plug in the power cord and the keyboard and the mouse and the telephone cable. And worked out where the power button is. And maybe stopped for a nice cup of tea, because it's thirsty work, this computer lark.

And it doesn't end there. There's even some kind of magic AirPort Base Station contraption, which will allow you to use your pretty little iMac without even plugging her in. I know, I can hardly believe it either. And what with those delicious new designs, it won't be long until offices everywhere will be looking like the pick'n'mix counter in Woolies. Now I, like all ladies, can only dream of the day when Apple will create for us iMacs complete with fluffy bunny rabbit ears drooping over my screen, and the sweet, sweet smell of parma violets wafting towards me from a small vent in my keyboard. It is only a matter of time.

fields.headline: The inside track
fields.standfirst: Job security
fields.trailText: Job security
fields.body:
We are close to full employment, yet many people are still frightened of losing their jobs. Why? Well, evidence shows that, despite a raft of legislation introduced in the past four years to improve the quality of working life, employers are brushing new and even old laws aside, and employees are colluding with them for fear of jeopardising their careers.

The working time directive is the regulation that most frequently goes by the board. Introduced as a health and safety measure, it attempts to limit the working week to 48 hours. Research conducted by the Institute for Public Policy Research (IPPR) found that pressure is being put on employees to waive their rights, and it is becoming common for such waivers to appear in standard contracts. Fear of losing overtime is an incentive to sign.

Such waivers are of questionable legality, but unambiguously illegal practices are also widespread. Birth Rights, a report from the National Association of Citizens Advice Bureau (Nacab) claims that tens of thousands of women are being dismissed for becoming pregnant. Sometimes this is done subtly through demotion after women return from maternity leave, sometimes it is done blatantly - Nacab cites a shop assistant fired because it was thought that customers would find her condition physically unappealing.

Either way is illegal. Yet, according to Nacab, women put up with it, to hold on to their jobs at any cost. When they are finally forced out, they are afraid of taking their cases to an employment tribunal.

Nacab suggests that such behaviour is due to employees' ignorance of the law. Many of the cases they examined were found among the low-paid, but this may reflect Nacab's client base. Better paid women probably resort to a solicitor.

IPPR, on the other hand, found that employees were well aware of their rights, but are reluctant to pursue them, and even dismissive of the possibility of legislation improving their conditions.

webTitle: Pity the poor temp who would rather work than take time off

fields.headline: Pity the poor temp who would rather work than take time off
fields.trailText: This Easter, while many workers will choose to indulge in a spot of DIY, hundreds of work-hungry temps will yearn to top-up their time-sheets.
fields.body:
This Easter, while many workers will choose to indulge in a spot of DIY, hundreds of work-hungry temps will yearn to top-up their time-sheets. As the bank holidays kick in, with Good Friday and Easter Monday hotly pursued by May Day and the spring holiday, temps who have not yet scraped together enough work to qualify for paid holiday (by putting in 13 consecutive weeks with one agency) are likely to see these breaks as a huge financial inconvenience.

Tanya, who temps as a PA in advertising, says: "It's nice not to work on public holidays, but I work to make money, in order to travel. If I don't work, I don't get paid, so I don't benefit from the break."

At recruitment agency Tate Appointments, sales and marketing specialist David Joseph empathises: "The thing with temping is that there is never a guarantee that you will find work, so there is a risk element. Although many temps feel that holiday pay is a bonus, if you are a career temp it is going to be something that is really important to you."

Of course, there are also holiday periods, such as those sandwiched between Christmas and New Year, when you want to take time off, but are compelled to work. Keeping busy at the office when your permanent colleagues are at home polishing off the Quality Street is a challenge. Elizabeth, a secretarial temp, recalls working during this time: "It was so quiet, there was no point being there. But I didn't have a choice."

It was a glorious day for temps when it was announced that, from October 1 1998, they would have the right to holiday pay. Until then, they had no choice but to slave away all year, in the hope that, somehow, they could steal two weeks in Majorca while still managing to cover the council tax and cat-sitter for the weeks they were absent.

Thankfully times have changed. And if recent rumblings in Europe are anything to go by, things could soon tip even further in temps' favour. On the topic of eliminating the qualifying period for temps' holiday pay, Andrew Fielding, spokesman for employment and social affairs at the European Commission, explains: "There is no detail on paper yet, but two sides of industry will be trying to reach an agreement."

In view of this, coupled with the quiet optimism emanating from the recruitment industry, DIY temps look set to be on the increase. Skip-hire suppliers, brace yourselves.

Survival tips

* Register with other agencies that specialise in industries which typically employ staff in holiday periods, for example, hotel and catering, exhibition and conference centres and retail. Some flexibility is needed, so you may have to forego your Monday-to-Friday routine over this time. The Recruitment and Employment Confederation website www.rec.uk.com offers a search facility of specialist agencies in any selected region.

* Once you qualify for paid-holiday, tell your agency when you want to take a bank holiday as part of your entitlement, otherwise you could loose out on a day's pay.

* The Department of Trade and Industry's employment agency standards inspectorate produces a leaflet called Know Your Rights. For a free copy of this and for advice on any aspect of your work for an agency, call its helpline on 0645 555105.

fields.headline: That old chestnut
fields.standfirst: Pensions. Who cares? Not many people, it seems. But temps are being discriminated against, warns Dolly Dhingra
fields.trailText: Pensions. Who cares? Not many people, it seems. But temps are being discriminated against, warns Dolly Dhingra
fields.body:
There seems no respite from the drudgery of responsibility. No sooner are you out of school than society expects you to look for a decent job . . . then it's the obligatory mortgage. If by your 30s you haven't sorted out your pension, well frankly, you are just so not ahead of the game. So worried is the government about Britain's ageing population that everyone, including temps, is being called on to save for their retirement.

About 19m people in Britain claim the basic state pension, but the present state scheme will have to treble to provide for baby-boomers in their old age. Medical advancement means people are living longer, which adds up to a huge greying population. Worse, thirtysomethings just aren't pulling their weight. In fact, only one in seven people over the age of 30 has any pension provision. What a bunch of slackers.

Pensions, however, remain an unsexy topic that few relish thinking about. "I know I'm supposed to do something, but I'm only 31. If I do have any extra savings, I want to use them on holidays or on my flat. I'll do something about my pension when I've done everything else," says temp Sarah Hall.

Diane Taylor, 27, has been temping for two years. "I'm still recovering from paying off my student loan," she says. "I'm loath to start thinking about what state I'll be in at 60 just yet."

Under current legislation, employers with four or more employees earning above £70 a week have to designate a pension provider to enable employees to contribute to a pension. Recruitment agencies, however, seem to have gone unnoticed by such law and in strict terms the employer of temp workers remains a grey area.

"Temps are in no-man's land - they are not legally employed by the agency or the employer," explains Martin Green, financial planner for Pertemps recruitment.

Forward-thinking enough to realise that it's only a matter of time before the government compels recruitment agencies to act, Pertemps is the first recruitment agency to set up a pension scheme. The gesture is not as generous as it sounds: Pertemps doesn't contribute to pensions, but has simply carried out the administration that allows its temps to make contributions.

"It's just a simple adjustment that has to be knocked off a person's pay. Anyone in payroll can do it. Most companies have the technology to set it up," explains Green.

Others recruitment agencies are quick to follow Pertemps' lead. Reed is finalising research into its own scheme. "The flexible workforce is often cited by the government as key to Britain's economic success. Through schemes like these, the benefits to the economy can be balanced by better provision of long-term support to the individual temporary worker," says Derek Beal, finance director of Reed.

Pension provisions, it seems, will fast become another perk that recruitment agencies will use to win over temps.

webTitle: President and Serbian PM at odds on policy

fields.headline: Raids expose rifts between the reformist leaders
fields.standfirst:
President and Serbian PM at odds on policy

Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Slobodan Milosevic's foolhardy last hurrah exposed deep divisions in the new democratic order in Belgrade between the Yugoslav president, Vojislav Kostunica, and the Serbian prime minister Zoran Djindjic's government.
fields.body:
Slobodan Milosevic's foolhardy last hurrah exposed deep divisions in the new democratic order in Belgrade between the Yugoslav president, Vojislav Kostunica, and the Serbian prime minister Zoran Djindjic's government.

Constitutionally, it is the Serbian government which is in charge of investigating, arresting and prosecuting Mr Milosevic for his alleged offences at home, while Mr Kostunica is responsible for foreign policy and carries the can for any decision to transfer the former Yugoslav president to the international war crimes tribunal in the Hague.

At the crack of dawn yesterday a reportedly deranged Mr Milosevic gave himself up after Mr Kostunica went to his luxury villa in the Belgrade suburb of Dedinje.

He was escorted by one of Mr Milosevic's crony, the indicted war criminal Milan Milutinovic, who still formally remains president of Serbia.

All's well that ends well. But it was an agonising two days for the hesitant Mr Kostunica, who has been increasingly exasperating Mr Djindjic and his colleagues.

They are in a hurry to start rebuilding Serbia, integrating it with the rest of Europe, and gaining the unqualified support of the west, and in their quest they increasingly see Mr Kostunica, an ardent Serbian nationalist and slow-moving stickler for the letter of the law, as a liability rather than an asset, even though he enjoys immense popularity at home.

Vladan Batic, the Serbian justice minister, maintained yesterday that the Yugoslav and Serbian governments were "100% united" behind the operation to seize Mr Milosevic, but there was scant evidence of that on Friday night or Saturday morning.

The president and the prime minister had to knock heads together at an emergency meeting with security and military chiefs on Saturday afternoon before tackling yesterday's dawn arrest.

All the signs are that Mr Kostunica was kept in the dark about Friday night's preparations to pounce, however amateurishly, on the Milosevic fortress.

For most of Friday the president was in Geneva, making a speech about the perils of secessionism in what remains of Yugoslavia.

Mr Djindjic, meanwhile, affected nonchalance, declaring that the action in Dedinje was routine police work while he was at home watching a video of the Oscar-garlanded Gladiator with his son.

The initial bungling in seizing Mr Milosevic was in no small measure due to the conflicting loyalties exhibited by the Serbian commandos who were ordered to go into the villa and the Yugoslav army units guarding the residence.

As Yugoslav president, Mr Kostunica is the commander in chief of the armed forces and it was only later that the army stood aside, on his orders. When the police tried to raid the villa and seize Mr Milosevic in the early hours of Saturday, the army guards reportedly handed the keys to the gates to Mr Milosevic's private bodyguards.

The army chief of staff, Lieutenant General Nebojsa Pavkovic, a controversial figure who was appointed to his post by Mr Milosevic after commanding the 1998-99 campaign against ethnic Albanians in Kosovo, said bluntly that his men were doing their duty by guarding the government villa, formally a military installation.

The result was that the frontpage of Saturday morning's Politika newspaper, reflecting the Djindjic camp's views, accused Gen Pavkovic of sabotaging the abortive arrest, and suggested that he was operating at the behest of Mr Kostunica. Senior Djindjic officials said Gen Pavkovic had attempted a "mini military coup", and justice ministry officials also blamed him.

Although Mr Batic insisted that there was agreement, the justice minister has been discreetly criticising Mr Kostunica for weeks.

A similar, if more minor, conflict erupted in Belgrade a week ago when the Djindjic camp quietly arrested the former mayor of the Bosnian town of Prijedor and put him on a plane to the Hague, where he is on a secret list of accused war criminals. It was the first time that Belgrade had arrested and transferred an indicted person to the Hague. Again, Mr Kostunica was kept in the dark and he was livid. He denounced the action as illegal.

With Mr Milosevic in jail, the conflict between the camps is likely to intensify. The Djindjic coterie will be emboldened to rid the army and security forces of their remaining Milosevic loyalists, who have been counting on the tacit support of Mr Kostunica. They could also arrest serving army officers indicted by the Hague for war crimes at the Croatian town of Vukovar in 1991.

The Americans were hugely instrumental in ushering Mr Kostunica into office last October as the best hope for displacing Mr Milosevic while retaining domestic support.

But Washington could now transfer its backing to Mr Djindjic as a pragmatic liberal who acted more decisively to put the ousted leader in Belgrade's central prison.

fields.trailText: Online fraud is not costing UK retailers £190m a year as we suggested in an article headed Hackers hold sway for now, page 3, Small business solutions, March 29. That is the figure for all credit card fraud in the UK in 1999, of which fraud costing just £9m happened over the internet, according to the Association for Payment Clearing Services.
fields.body:
Online fraud is not costing UK retailers £190m a year as we suggested in an article headed Hackers hold sway for now, page 3, Small business solutions, March 29. That is the figure for all credit card fraud in the UK in 1999, of which fraud costing just £9m happened over the internet, according to the Association for Payment Clearing Services.

In a report about the "euthanasia drug", pentobarbitone sodium, page 4, March 30, we made several references to 100 millimetre bottles. We meant to refer to millilitres.

In the obituary of the television presenter and producer Muriel Young, page 24, March 29, her date of birth was given as June 19, 1928. It was in fact June 19, 1923, which explains how it was possible for her to join the ATS in 1943.

The words that Bessie Smith sang (page 16, G2, March 28) were "Give me [or Gimme] a pigfoot and a bottle of beer..." not the terser "Gimme a pigfoot and a beer ..."

The character in the children's tale is Rumpelstiltskin, a column, page 5, G2, March 30, not the unrulier "Rumplestiltskin". The miller's daughter (queen) has to guess his name to save her child.

Due to an editing slip we gave the year of death of Sviatoslav Richter as 1995 instead of 1997 in a piece by Bruno Monsaingeon, Friday Review, page 8, March 16.

Homophone corner, from Notes & queries, page18, G2, March 29: "To avoid hypothermia [Captain Bligh] had everyone soak their clothing in the seawater, ring them out and put them on." (No calls about the other mistakes in that please).

The cover of the Friday Review, March 30, "The six tribes of pop" should have carried a credit for Steve Caplin.

webTitle: French say M&S closure may have been illegal

fields.headline: French say M&S closure may have been illegal
fields.standfirst: Jospin says that the employees who enriched Marks & Spencer shareholders deserved better than to be dismissed by email
fields.trailText: Jospin says that the employees who enriched Marks & Spencer shareholders deserved better than to be dismissed by email.
fields.byline: Jon Henley  in Paris and  Andrew Clark
fields.body:
The French government is considering legal action against Marks & Spencer over the "unacceptable" and possibly illegal way the struggling retailer announced plans to close down all of its stores in France.

The French prime minister, Lionel Jospin, said this weekend that M&S might have broken French law, which requires companies to inform employee representatives before announcing large scale restructuring. He asked the employment ministry for a full inquiry.

"The case of Marks & Spencer is particularly unacceptable," a visibly angry Mr Jospin said after an informal cabinet meeting. "It appears that the employees and, seemingly, the managers of the French outlets were advised by the British management at the same time as the press and the stock exchange - by email."

The prime minister continued: "The employees who enriched Marks & Spencer's shareholders deserve better treatment. Such behaviour should be punished."

Marks & Spencer's sudden announcement last Thursday of its plans to close down its continental European operations with the loss of 3,350 jobs, including 1,700 in France, was met with incredulity and outrage.

The French finance minister, Laurent Fabius, said he was shocked by the company's "exceptionally brutal" behaviour. M&S opened its first French store, on the Boulevard Haussman in Paris, in 1975, and many employees have 20 years or more of service behind them.

An M&S spokeswoman yesterday defended the way the decision was communicated, saying: "We're convinced that we complied with all the legal requirements."

She said staff representatives on the company's central committee were summoned to Paris to be told of the closures in person, and managers received emails allowing them to break the news to staff verbally. "We're surprised by the reaction from the authorities," she said.

To adjust for its shrinking workforce, the firm is considering moving out of its 450,000sq ft head office in Baker Street, London. Chairman Luc Vandevelde has asked the company's property division to scour the country for replacement sites.

The spokeswoman said: "It's an option - we've got a restructured business and we've got to look at what our needs are, going forward."

Staff numbers at Baker Street have fallen sharply. Eighteen months ago, 4,300 people worked in the building; some 3,400 remain, but the company announced another 350 head office redundancies this week. One site under consideration is in Paddington Basin, west London.

Baker Street has been home to Marks & Spencer since the late 1950s. The E-shaped premises contain some prized assets, including a Monet painting, Bras de Seine, in one of the company's private dining rooms.

Not-so des. res.

When the going gets tough, the tough move offices... Shell moved out of its riverside "cathedral of commerce", Shell-Mex House, in 1998 after warning of falling oil prices and the worst trading conditions for five years. Located next to the Savoy hotel, Shell-Mex House boasted 1,486 windows, 22 miles of water pipes and executive offices made of Queensland walnut.

Allied Domecq axed its grade II-listed headquarters in Portland Place, Belgravia, after selling its poorly performing pub estate two years ago. The 25,000 sq ft of offices contained a collection of 70 works of modern art. The company moved to more modest premises in Bristol.

Whitbread last year quit The Brewery, its ornate 250-year-old base in the Square Mile, in a cost-cutting measure after exiting beer and pubs. The complex, which houses coaches for the Lord Mayor's show each year, is to become Marriott apartments. Whitbread's executives moved to an office block round the corner.

Smith & Nephew sold Astor House, its neo-gothic mansion bordering the Thames, for £15m as part of a reorganisation in 1999 following plunging profits.

fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.trailText: Observer
fields.body:
Observer

A big increase in Britain's capacity to generate electricity from wind power will be signalled next week when the Crown Estate grants leases to 17 new offshore projects.

Cash-strapped British Telecom wants to team up with Vodafone in a move that would see the two companies build their next-generation mobile networks together.

Big drugs firms including Bayer, Novartis and Roche are to be targeted by animal rights campaigners protesting against Huntingdon Life Sciences.

Sunday Times

American engineering group Bechtel is to take control of building the second phase of the Channel tunnel rail link from Railtrack. The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, is expected to give approval for the £4.3bn project today.

Macdonald Hotels is close to winning the auction of Forte's Heritage Hotels for £350m.

BOC, the world's second largest industrial gas maker, is expected to announce wide ranging disposals in in the next month to combat potential bid approaches and drive up its share price.

Sunday Telegraph

The government is to appoint its own director to the board of Railtrack and reduce the company's responsibility for growing the nation's network.

Vivendi Universal, the media group, has put its 246-strong chain of Oddbins off-licences up for sale for about £65m. Potential bidders include First Quench, the business owned by Nomura.

Foreign currency and payments business Travelex plans a £1bn stock market flotation, but will wait until the government's position on the single currency is known.

Mail on Sunday

Railtrack has been forced to look for an overseas chairman because of a shortage of willing candidates at home.

Retailer Kingfisher is in advanced talks to sell VCI, its video and publishing offshoot, in a deal that would raise £40m-50m. The move is part of Kingfisher's plans for a full demerger, announced last September.

Sunday Express

Sir Peter Davis earned almost £2.5m in his last three months in charge of insurance group Prudential, according to the company's latest annual report.

Sunday Business

British Telecom's finance director, Philip Hampton, has turned down the opportunity of replacing Sir Peter Bonfield as the company's chief executive. He is said to have balked at taking on what has been described as "a poison chalice".

Cazenove, the blue chip stockbroker, is reviewing its plan to place 10% of its share capital with institutions by the end of the month as part of a move towards incorporation. It had hoped to raise £150m from the exercise, but is believed to be rethinking its capital needs in the light of the turmoil in financial markets.

Pubmaster is poised to give the green light to a formal £500m bid for Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries.

IoS

The Ministry of Defence is planning a £1bn public-private partnership to redevelop its barracks, many of which are considered to be little more than slums. The proposal is expected to be rubber-stamped in two weeks.

Bargain-hungry buy-out firms are circling Cable & Wireless, the telecommunications company, as its cash pile mounts but its share price falls. It is understood that Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the US leveraged buyout specialist, is one company looking at C&W with a view to a possible break-up.

Great Universal Stores is poised to defy the gloom surrounding internet shopping and Wap phones by launching a mobile internet shopping site for its Argos subsidiary.

fields.headline: Dresdner accepts Allianz merger terms
fields.trailText: Directors of Germany's Dresdner Bank last night emerged from a specially convened board meeting to announce they had accepted a 110bn euros (£68bn) merger proposal from insurance group Allianz, creating the world's fourth largest financial services group.
fields.body:
Directors of Germany's Dresdner Bank last night emerged from a specially convened board meeting to announce they had accepted a 110bn euros (£68bn) merger proposal from insurance group Allianz, creating the world's fourth largest financial services group.

The merged business will have more than 20m clients in Germany, opening up enormous opportunities for cross-selling of banking and insurance.

Dresdner board spokesman Bernd Fahrholz said: "Clients expect access to a comprehensive range of financial services. They need the best possible advice on all issues relating to banking and insurance products."

Combining the two organisations would create "one new entity that is stronger than the sum of its two parts".

The combined corporation will rank second in Europe, behind HSBC which has a market value of €123bn. Elsewhere, its only bigger rivals are US groups Citigroup and AIG.

Investment banking arm Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein would be spun off through a stock market flotation "in the next two to four years", Mr Fahrholz said. This follows pressure for autonomy from the business's chairman, Bruce Wasserstein.

The merger will be executed through an offer by Allianz of €53.1 for each Dresdner share, in a mixture of cash and paper, valuing Dresdner at €29.7bn.

Critics suggest Allianz is overpaying, pointing out that half of Dresdner's value comes from a portfolio of industrial investments worth an estimated €15bn. They therefore suggest that Allianz is paying a steep bid premium of €4bn in comparison to Dresdner's underlying operations.

Mr Fahrholz brushed aside fears of redundancies: "Job cuts have not been discussed but I can tell you that there will be no jobs cuts for the foreseeable future."

Allianz and Dresdner believe there is a large untapped market of wealthy, elderly Germans who could be persuaded to buy insurance and asset management products. They hope the country's ageing population and reforms to pensions legislation will fuel demand.

Complicated cross-share holdings have traditionally made mergers difficult between big German financial institutions. This structure has begun disintegrating. Dresdner attempted a merger with rival Deutsche Bank last year but the deal collapsed over disagreements about the future of Dresdner Kleinwort Benson.

Deutsche is now holding exploratory talks with French insurer Axa, while Munich Re is planning a tie-up with HypoVereinsbank.

fields.headline: Going Dutch
fields.standfirst: First homosexual weddings in Amsterdam
fields.trailText: The gay community in the Netherlands rejoiced with whoops of joy yesterday at the first celebration of same-sex marriages recognised by any country.
fields.body:
The gay community in the Netherlands rejoiced with whoops of joy yesterday at the first celebration of same-sex marriages recognised by any country.

The mayor of Amsterdam married four gay couples just after the stroke of midnight, when the new law granting homosexuals equal rights to marry and adopt children came into force.

The couples - three male and one female - nervously exchanged their vows.

"There are two reasons to rejoice: you are celebrating your marriage and you are also celebrating your right to be married," the mayor, Job Cohen, told the newly weds in the city hall. Pink cake and pink champagne were served at a reception, and then the party moved to several of the city's gay clubs.

"I'm proud to be Dutch," said Dolf Pasker, who married his partner of six years Geert Kasteel. "This makes it all real."

The group ceremony was the culmination of a 15-year crusade in the Netherlands. Gay couples are now able to apply for court permission to adopt children after living together for three years. The law also eliminates legal ambiguities on inheritance, pension rights, taxes and divorce.
AP

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Pilgrims die in shrine stampede | Rebel ceasefire in Philippines | Protest at Vatican Radio | 13 die in South African crash
fields.body:
Pilgrims die in shrine stampede

Pakistani authorities said yesterday that at least 32 pilgrims had been killed in a late night stampede at a Muslim shrine in the central province of Punjab.

The stampede took place just before midnight on Saturday when thousands of pilgrims rushed forward after the Behishti Darwaza, or Paradise Gate, was opened to inaugurate the annual feast known as urs at the shrine of a 13th century saint in Pak Pattan.
Reuters, Pak Pattan

Rebel ceasefire in Philippines

The Philippines' biggest Muslim rebel group ordered its forces to halt all attacks against government troops yesterday ahead of peace talks with Manila.

The Moro Islamic Liberation Front (Milf) has told its guerrilla units on the southern island of Mindanao to start the ceasefire tomorrow. The front is the biggest group fighting for an Islamic state in the south of the mainly Roman Catholic country.
Reuters, Manila

Protest at Vatican Radio

Several hundred people demonstrated yesterday outside Vatican Radio, accusing it of polluting the air with electromagnetic waves. At issue is the station's transmitter in the town of Santa Maria di Galeria, near Rome. Residents fear leukaemia cases in the area may be linked to the radio station's electromagnetic output.
AP, Vatican City

13 die in South African crash

Thirteen people were killed in a vehicle pile-up in Johannesburg yesterday. South Africa's roads are among the world's most dangerous.
Reuters, Johannesburg

webTitle: Israelis vow vengeance at baby's funeral

fields.headline: Israelis vow vengeance at baby's funeral
fields.standfirst:
Settlers and Palestinians each bury a child, but hatred is stronger than common grief

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Settlers and Palestinians each bury a child, but hatred is stronger than common grief.
fields.body:
Thousands of Jewish settlers, bristling with sophisticated weapons and swearing revenge, gathered yesterday for the funeral of a baby girl, whose killing by a Palestinian sniper led to a grotesque battle over her corpse.

As Yitzhak Pass was handed the tiny blue-shrouded figure of his 10-month-old daughter Shalhevet among the olive trees at the disputed Tomb of the Patriarchs, the voice over the loudspeaker leading the prayers choked with grief, and girls sobbed into their prayer books.

The tomb, where the biblical Abraham, Isaac and Jacob are reputedly buried, lies in the heart of this city, where an enclave of 400 Jewish settlers live in open voiced hatred with 120,000 Palestinians.

"It is not the first time our people have suffered since coming to Hebron," said a rabbi. "But there never was a killing like this - a girl less than a year old falling in a holy place like a soldier."

In Gaza, the Palestinian security chief, Mohammed Dahlan, demanded the return of five members of Force 17, Yasser Arafat's personal bodyguard, who were arrested by the Israeli army early yester day. Force 17 is accused by the Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, of the drive-by shooting of Jewish motorists.

The army said six men were seized at a roadblock north of the West Bank city of Ramallah. The Palestinians described it as a kidnapping and also accused Israel of detaining 35 members of their security forces.

The 400 settlers of Hebron refused to bury Shalhevet, despite Jewish requirements for a speedy funeral, until Mr Sharon, invaded the Palestinian-ruled hills of Abu Sneineh, from where the fatal shot is believed to have been fired. Yesterday, a week after she was killed, many of the settlers still urged him to retake the ridge.

"The only way we can live in peace here is if we retake Abu Sneineh and all high places in the West Bank," Yael Ami-El said.

Despite being guarded by two helicopter gunships and hundreds of soldiers, many of the men in the funeral procession carried M-16s with telescopic sights, mini-Uzis and handguns.

Dozens wore T-shirts reading: "No Arabs, no terror," and a few lobbed stones through the windows of Palestinian houses along the route. A small cascade of stones fell on the mourners in return.

Few Palestinians shed tears for Shalhevet. About 130 of the 455 people who have been killed in the uprising were Palestinians under the age of 18, the latest an 11-year-old Ramallah boy who was also buried yesterday, after being shot in the head by an Israeli soldier.

Once again the 40,000 Palestinians of Hebron's old city were under curfew, and many said they dared not look out of their windows for fear of attracting the settlers' wrath. "We have been unable to move for ages, and they can go wherever they want," Muktasseb Metsub said through the coils of barbed wire behind her home.

webTitle: Astronauts look on the sunny side

fields.headline: Astronauts look on the sunny side
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: Almost 40 years after Yuri Gagarin made the first human orbit of the Earth, and almost 20 years since the US launched its first reusable spacecraft, the shuttle, two men and a woman are engaged in the down-to-earth business of normal housekeeping and gardening in space.
fields.body:
Almost 40 years after Yuri Gagarin made the first human orbit of the Earth, and almost 20 years since the US launched its first reusable spacecraft, the shuttle, two men and a woman are engaged in the down-to-earth business of normal housekeeping and gardening in space.

Commander Yuri Usachev, 43, a Russian, and James Voss, 52, and Susan Helms, 43, his two American flight engineers, are the latest tenants in a three-roomed flat circling the planet at five miles a second, at an altitude of about 220 miles.

The housekeeping is simple: they have to keep alive in a neighbourhood that forgives no mistakes.

On the sunny side of their home - an international space station slowly being built in orbit - the temperature rises to 121C. On the shady side, it falls to minus 157C. So the trio occupy three cylindrical chambers of aluminium sheathed by four inches of Kevlar, the stuff of bulletproof vests, ceramic fabrics, and sheets of aluminised Mylar, the stuff used for survival bags, to keep themselves at room temperature and to protect them from direct collisions with space dust and bits of splinters of old satellites.

The air they breathe is a precious commodity. The oxygen arrives freshly split from water by electrolysis. The carbon dioxide they exhale is scrubbed by a chemical sieve and piped into space. The methane from the intestines is collected by a charcoal filter, along with ammonia from sweat, and acetone from the breath.

The water they drink is recycled from their breath, and the humidity in the air. Later it will be reclaimed from their urine, and from the washbasin.

One day, there will be a shower on the ISS but the tenants still have to clean themselves with a damp cloth and about 2oz of water. And when they eat, they make do with bags or tins of food heated in a convection oven the size of a suitcase. There is no refrigerator, so hot drinks are possible, but cold ones are not.

They can read and they can listen to music. Or they can look out of the quadruple-glazed windows, where they can watch a sunrise and sunset every 45 minutes, because the space station sails around the earth about 18 times a day.

But they must also exercise. The first tenants, who moved in late last year, brought a treadmill, and ran on it before lunch and before dinner to offset bone loss and muscle wastage that goes with life in microgravity. The second crew added an exercise bicycle. But most of their time will be spent at work.

Some of this work involves gardening: tending seedlings of a tiny weed called Arabidopsis growing in a compost in the ISS equivalent of the potting shed. This is partly to see how genes control growth in space when there is no "up" in which to grow up, and partly to prepare for the gardens that will be necessary to provide food and recycle air and water on some future human flight to Mars in around 30 years.

They will monitor dangerous radiation during solar flares, when the sun hurls billions of tons of matter at Earth at millions of miles an hour. They will photograph the planet below them to keep up the 35-year-old record of the growth of cities and the expansion of agriculture, first begun during the Apollo programme. They will be monitored by psychologists and doctors on the ground and they will monitor each other's reflexes and attitudes to see how each reacts to life in a world filled with floating ballpoint pens and tortilla crumbs, and in which the mere flick of a finger against the wall can send one of them flying across the room.

And they will do all these things while Nasa cuts its plans for the space station, because of cost overruns, and knowing that 60% of astronomers and physicists think that the questions they solve could be solved on Earth. And they have the usual stress of dealing with head office back on Earth. "They plan an activity to take one hour and we all know it will take five hours," complained one of the first tenants.

Next stop Mars

Yuri Gagarin made just one circuit of the planet in a Soviet spacecraft called Vostok 1 on April 12 1961. Coincidentally, the US space shuttle Columbia took to the skies for the first time on April 12 1981. On Thursday, to mark the anniversaries, British scientists will gather for the national astronomy meeting in Cambridge to discuss the case for the human exploration of Mars.

For the first time, the European Space Agency has begun to look to the distant planets. A package of British instruments is already on its way to Saturn's moon Titan aboard a joint Nasa-European mission called Cassini-Huygens. A British probe called Beagle 2 will drop to the surface of Mars from a European orbiter called Mars Express on Boxing Day, 2003.

European space chiefs are also thinking about grabbing rock from the surface of Mars and bringing it back. A robot lander would bounce down on to the Red Planet, scoop up 1kg of whatever it landed on, seal it, and pack it into a tiny rocket. This would take off, rendezvous with a robot orbiter, and then return to circle the Earth months later, to be collected by the space station team, or a shuttle crew.

"You get roughly 1kg of sand, the grains of which have been blown about from every part of Mars. You've got the whole history of Mars, provided you can sort it out," says Paul Murdin, of Britain's National Space Centre.

fields.headline: No 1851 Tony Hall
fields.trailText: Age: He turned 50 a few days ago.
fields.body:
Age: He turned 50 a few days ago.

Is that significant? Of course.

Why? Because when he reached that ripe old age, he became eligible for his big fat BBC pension.

Old BBC hand, is he? Man and boy. Joined as a trainee after Oxford in the early 70s, worked in the newsroom in Belfast, became editor of the Nine O'Clock News at 34, caught the eye of John Birt and was appointed head of BBC News.

Destined for the top? Not quite. When Birt stepped down as director-general, he was one of the Birtists (dubbed "head prefect" by one foreign correspondent) beaten to the job by Greg Dyke. His days were numbered.

It happens to us all. And now he is beginning a well-earned retirement? Not exactly. Today he starts as chief executive of the Royal Opera House.

Decent salary? Somewhere between £150,000 and £250,000. Covent Garden is cagey about it.

Does he know a lot about opera? Not much, though he does go to the Verona opera festival every year.

fields.headline: Country Diary
fields.standfirst: The end of the pier
fields.trailText: The end of the pier
fields.body:
The Grand, Brighton

An upper balcony in this famous hotel gave me a perfect view over the old pier, a structure now in a terminal state of decline. The windows of the pavilions were smashed, the railings buckled and the planking sagged heavily as if just about to collapse into the sea. Yet the council seems to wish to jollify the wreck with a scattering of neon. Thirty minutes before sundown the lights came on to announce in bold capitals, "WEST PIER". Unfortunately the bulbs on the "R" weren't working so it actually read "WEST PIE". The failure of even these adornments seemed only to intensify the pier's air of decay, like decorations on a dead Christmas tree.

But dusk masked the dereliction and triggered a spectacular display as a large starling flock swirled over the pier while gathering for their night-time roost. Thousands of birds eddied down until they were just above roof height. Repeatedly a part of the amorphous swarm riffled down through a cavity that gave them access to the pavilion. The best way I can think to convey this mesmerising sight is to ask you to imagine film footage of a great smoke cloud emerging from a chimney, but picture the film running in reverse so that the fluid, billowing mass of steam funnelled downwards into its brick home.

Further along the beach one could also see the flashy display on Brighton's other working pier, where the light show terminated at the neon-bedecked cylinder of a helter-skelter and a cascade of other illuminations. Yet it struck me that there was nothing there half so beautiful as the vision just presented by its derelict predecessor.

webTitle: Interview: Margaret McCauley on a life of tragedy

fields.headline: Why I had to let my brother die
fields.standfirst:
Twenty years ago Margaret McCauley watched as her brother - an Irish republican prisoner - starved to death on hunger strike. Then, in 1997, her only son and most of his family were killed in a fire. She talks to Rosie Cowan about a life defined by tragedy

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Twenty years ago Margaret McCauley watched as her brother - an Irish republican prisoner - starved to death on hunger strike. Then, in 1997, her only son and most of his family were killed in a fire. She talks to  Rosie  Cowan about a life defined by tragedy.
fields.body:
Smell is perhaps the most evocative sense. Even now, surrounded by family photographs in the cosy living room of her small, terraced house in the Creggan estate in Derry, Margaret McCauley will never forget the terrible, sickening odour of human decay.

It transports her back 20 years, to a white hospital room with bars on the tiny window and two guards by the end of a bed, where she sat waiting for her brother to die. She wasn't helpless in the face of his death. In fact, she had the ultimate power over the 27-year-old, her only sibling, who was seven years younger and whom she had brought up after the death of their parents. With a word, she could call in the doctors and save his life.

But Mickey Devine was an Irish National Liberation Army (INLA) gunman, and had decided to starve himself to death. It was part of a concerted campaign by republican prisoners in the Maze prison's notorious H-blocks to challenge their categorisation by prison authorities as "ordinary criminals". They believed that they should have "political" status - and they were prepared to die unless given special rights.

It was an agonising situation for the families of those who had embarked on the protest. "I was his sister, I'd had to be his mammy, and now I was being asked to play God," says McCauley, a vivacious woman in her 50s. "I was 34 years old and all I wanted to do was run away.

"He told me if I took him off hunger strike, he would simply go back on it as soon as he was able, and prolong my agony. When he died I had so many mixed emotions. I did what he wanted but I still wonder whether I did the right thing."

Bobby Sands was the first hunger striker to die, on May 5, 1981, after 66 days without food. Mickey Devine became the 10th and last when he died on August 20, after 60 days. Those were dark days for Northern Ireland - during the six-month period of the protests, 64 people, 34 of them civilians, were killed in violent incidents outside the prison. Margaret Thatcher, then prime minister, refused to give in to the prisoners' demands, saying that she would not be blackmailed by terrorists. In fact, their requests were quietly granted in the ensuing months and while never officially designated as such, paramilitary prisoners were effectively given the special status they had sought. The hunger strikes changed the course of history, setting Sinn Fein on the road to political success and ultimately, many would argue, the peace process.

Devine's death elevated him to republican martyrdom. But to McCauley, he was just her baby brother. "He was an ordinary fella. He didn't have his fate written on his forehead. He had red hair and glasses, and when he was wee he was always fighting. It was a sort of self-defence against being teased," she says. "Daddy died when [Mickey] was 12 in 1966 - the year I got married - and when Mammy died six years later, Mickey moved in with us. To be honest, he was a bit of a nuisance.

"Bloody Sunday [when British paratroopers shot dead 13 unarmed men on a civil rights march in Derry in 1972] made a huge impact on him. Afterwards, I knew he'd got involved. He was going out at odd hours of the night. His politics were not my politics, but I asked no questions."

Even so, it was a shock for McCauley when her brother was arrested in 1976 and jailed for 12 years for armed robbery. He was sent to the Maze prison outside Belfast, which republicans still call by its former name of Long Kesh, and joined the "dirty protest", in which inmates refused to wear prison uniform, wrapped themselves in blankets and smeared their excrement on the walls.

Devine took part in the brief hunger strike of 1980, which was called off without fatalities. But by the time he told his sister he would be joining the second campaign, three weeks before he started refusing food, four men were already dead. "I held his hands and my eyes just filled up and there were knots in my stomach, but no words came."

Each time she made the four-hour round-trip from Derry for weekly visits, they would talk about everything but his impending death. As he grew weaker, she stayed with friends in Belfast, visiting him every day.

Devine married at 18 but prison had broken up the marriage, a common situation. But McCauley was determined that his two children, Michael, seven, and Louise, five, would remain close to their father, and she took them to see him regularly.

"When the time came for them to say goodbye, I lifted one on either side of his bed. I put his hands on their heads and told him which was which, as he could no longer see. He stroked their hair and their little faces and he whispered how much he loved them. As I led them out of the room, I turned back and he was just lying there, a skeleton, the tears running down his face."

The night before her brother died, McCauley went to a small chapel in Belfast and prayed that he would die quickly. He lapsed into unconsciousness at 5am next morning and died in her arms at 7.50am. It was a time of conflict with the Roman Catholic church, and many priests would not allow paramilitary trappings into their chapels, so McCauley complied with her brother's last wishes, leaving his flag-draped coffin in her house while mourners attended the funeral mass. "I felt so alone," she says. "Even though the other hunger strikers' families have been so good to me, I just couldn't talk to friends about how I felt."

Twenty years on, McCauley is still close to her nephew and niece. Michael, 27, works with computers, and Louise, 25, is expecting her fifth child. But the intervening years have also been shadowed by tragedy. Three years ago, as she prepared to attend the funeral of the mother of another hunger striker, Kevin Lynch, McCauley received a phone call telling her there had been a chip pan fire at the home of her only son, Jody. He, his wife, and two of their children died. Only the youngest, four- year-old Jade, survived, but only after months in hospital with third-degree burns.

"I had been known for years as Mickey Devine's sister. Now I was Jade McCauley's granny. I was defined by these two tragedies, and yet I am one of the happiest, most positive people I know. God makes the back to bear the burden."

A few yards from McCauley's home is a windswept graveyard, with a panoramic view of Derry and the river Foyle. Her brother is buried at the republican memorial, a masked paramilitary figure at the top of the hill. Several rows down is the headstone she designed for her son and his family. "Sometimes, when I meet a man about the age Mickey would be now - 46 - and he says 'I knew your brother, I was in the Kesh with him', I wonder, what would our Mickey look like now?

"And I wish all the people in those photos could come down from my walls and see each other, just for one hour, so that Mickey could meet his grandchildren and my grandchildren. I wish I could hear them all laugh together, just once."

fields.headline: Ulster murder case faces collapse
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The case against a loyalist paramilitary double agent accused of the murder of the Belfast solicitor, Pat Finucane, could collapse after a key prosecution witness withdrew crucial evidence, the Guardian learned yesterday.
fields.body:
The case against a loyalist paramilitary double agent accused of the murder of the Belfast solicitor, Pat Finucane, could collapse after a key prosecution witness withdrew crucial evidence, the Guardian learned yesterday.

William Stobie, an Ulster Defence Association member who secretly worked for the Royal Ulster Constabulary special branch, was to appear in court again on April 24 in connection with the killing of the Catholic lawyer who was shot dead at his home in February 1989.

The victim's brother, Martin Finucane, has said that Neil Mulholland, a former journalist who later became a Northern Ireland Office press officer, informed the director of public prosecutions that he was withdrawing three statements implicating Mr Stobie in the murder.

Mr Stobie was a senior UDA officer when fellow members asked him to provide weapons for an attack against someone they alleged was a top republican target. He claims he told his special branch minders about the plot but that they ignored him, and, after the killing, missed the chance to arrest the man who masterminded it. Mr Mulholland's evidence, based on interviews with Mr Stobie, is central to the crown's case.

The matter has serious consequences for the entire peace process, as the unresolved issues surrounding the murder are pivotal to the lack of nationalist and republican confidence in the revamped RUC.

The Finucane family and their supporters believe the RUC and the army colluded in his murder, and are demanding a full, independent inquiry.

The government has maintained that the proceedings against Mr Stobie would render such an inquiry sub judice, but if the Stobie case falls it would be hard to sustain this argument. A full inquiry could throw up highly damaging questions for the entire British establishment, including the extent of suspected cooperation between the army's shadowy force research unit and loyalist terrorists at the time of the murder, and whether there was collusion.

The Finucane family has no confidence that a current investigation into alleged security force collusion, spearheaded by John Stevens, the Metropolitan police commander, will uncover the truth.

"Neil Mulholland's lawyers have told Stobie's lawyers that he is not going to testify for health reasons," said Martin Finucane. "The DPP and British attorney general will now have to decide if the case goes ahead. We have always pointed out the limitations of relying on Mulholland's evidence, and the Stevens inquiry.

"We're not just interested in who pulled the trigger but who pulled the strings, and we think a lot of people have gone to great lengths to stop the truth getting out."

The Stevens team recently informed Brian Nelson, another UDA double agent, who also worked undercover for the army, and who is now in hiding in England, that he would not face charges over the Finucane murder.
