fields.headline: Screen grabs
fields.standfirst: Coming to a box near you
fields.trailText: Coming to a box near you
fields.body:
Had you been troubled by Channel 4's apparent sobriety in recent weeks, the good news is the nation's raciest broadcasters are returning to form with a fearless dissection of the world of hardcore pornography. Trailed in 4's publicity materials with a photograph of an anonymous crotch, the imaginatively titled Hardcore will follow a single mother from Canvey Island as she tries to launch a career in the US porn business - where, remarkably, she and the programme-makers uncover habitual sleaze, abuse and misogyny. All credit to 4 (the channel, of course, that routinely paraded the late porn-star Lolo Ferrari on Eurotrash) for lifting the lid on this seemingly innocuous industry, and for their decision to screen the show in a time slot ideally suited to hard-edged investigative journalism - 10.35pm next Saturday night.

The BBC, meanwhile, are also poised to begin their own exposé series - albeit exposés from the late 19th century - with The People Detective, in which dapper curator Daru Rooke transports six people around the murky back alleys of their genetic history. And oh, the horrors they discover, as murderers, witches and cannibal victims pile up under hitherto respectable family trees. Just in case anyone plans snooping round our ancestry, Screen Grabs would like to make it clear that we come from a long line of law-abiding cultural pundits, dating back to the original family patriarch who eked out a living making glib remarks about cave paintings.

fields.headline: Escape from Ballykissangel
fields.standfirst: She doesn't lie about her age, admits that money matters, and has no regrets over leaving her best-known show. As Gareth McLean finds out, Dervla Kirwan is anything but the average actress
fields.trailText: She doesn't lie about her age, admits that money matters, and has no regrets over leaving her best-known show. As Gareth McLean finds out, Dervla Kirwan is anything but the average actress
fields.body:
Dervla Kirwan is quite the unique actress. For a start, when we meet for our interview over lunch, she actually orders something to eat. When her monkfish kebab thing and medley of vegetables arrive, she actually eats them. And then she orders dessert and eats that too. (Admittedly, the dessert is fruit salad and she has peppermint tea and a glass of still water to accompany her meal, but gin and monkfish don't really go, do they?)

Then there's her candour. In a business where actors trot out "I loved the writing" and "I took this part because it was such a challenge" as their rationale for working, when really they did it for the dosh, Kirwan is refreshingly frank. The actress, whose name was made by playing Assumpta Fitzgerald in Ballykissangel, embarked upon her latest project with no illusions.

"Graham Theakston, with whom I worked on The Dark Room [a BBC1 adaptation of the Minette Walters novel], was directing The Bombmaker and asked me if I was interested. I could see all the pitfalls in the script, but female characters who dominate like Andrea are few and far between. Whatever flaws there are, you owe it to yourself to do it. I've made a lot of mistakes in my career but the biggest mistake I've made is to turn down work. And I read Stephen Leather's book on which it was based, knew it was a bestseller and I think my commercial head took over."

Kirwan isn't daft. In The Bombmaker, she has found a very commercial vehicle. In it, she plays Andrea Hayes, a Dublin wife and mother whose past - as an IRA bombsmith - comes back to haunt her when her daughter is kidnapped. As a ransom, the abductors demand Andrea's services in the creation of a giant bomb which they plan to detonate in the City of London. If Andrea refuses, she will never see her daughter - an impossibly cute munchkin named Katie, complete with blonde ringlets - again. Thus she has to choose between the life of her daughter and the lives of thousands of people who could be caught in the bomb blast. Much handwringing and racing against time ensues.

The Bombmaker isn't gritty, cutting edge drama but then, it's not supposed to be. Mark Freeland, controller of drama and comedy at Sky One, describes it in terms of the ripping novel you would read on a transatlantic flight. "You're not going to read Jane Austen, you're going to read stuff that's genuinely going to grip you right from the off."

And that sums up The Bomb maker. It is a fairly gripping, reasonably high-octane thriller, which wouldn't look at all out of place on BBC1 or ITV. (Of course, on the BBC, it would have been ruined by having Amanda Burton in the title role.) While ably supported by Mark Womack as her husband, and Samantha Bond as a Special Branch/British intelligence type, The Bombmaker is undoubtedly Kirwan's show, proving she is a bankable star who can carry a drama. As Andrea, she provides real emotional ballast to what otherwise might have been a terrorist-of-the-week, made-for-TV movie. Kirwan's achievement is particularly impressive since she manages all this in a boilersuit, while around her people are madly overacting in balaclavas.

Were that not enough to test her mettle, one of Boyzone turns up as a policeman and haunting Irish music strikes up at poignant moments, leading you to wonder whether Clannad are perched just out of shot, fingers poised on fiddles. And as the star of Sky One's flagship homegrown drama for the spring/summer season, she stares out intently from the cover of the channel's glossy promo brochure. She says she didn't think twice about doing work for the satellite broadcaster.

"If Sky approach you and ask you to work for them, it'd be stupid not to say yes. As an actress who has been on BBC1 and BBC2, ITV and Channel 4, it's good to be involved in another network, and one which sells its products all round the world. You do have to think of the business side. I am all for high art but I owe it to myself to be clever about it and do commercial things too."

So far, she's not doing too badly. Since Assumpta left Ballykissangel - dead - Kirwan has made some interesting, calculated choices. As well as The Dark Room, for which she shaved her head and screamed a lot, she has done political satire (Mr White Goes To Westminster), cuddly Christmas drama (The Greatest Store In The World and The Flint Street Nativity) and complex, well- writ ten relationship dramas (Eureka Street and Hearts And Bones). With The Bombmaker, Kirwan says she wants to attract a different audience to her work. "It's about international terrorism and the New World Order, and those are things you wouldn't normally associate with a drama with Dervla Kirwan in it."

But behind all this businesslike bombast, Kirwan just wants to act. "Ballykissangel made me a household name, and I am enormously grateful for that, but I don't feel it would ever have developed me into a better actress had I stayed. I'll be 30 this year and now, I feel so much more confident with so much more to give as an actress. You can ask a 24-year-old actress to play a 30-year-old woman and she can, but she can't possibly bring to it the wealth of experience a woman of that age has."

Kirwan attributes some of her sanguine reflection to her upcoming birthday, which she admits in a most un-actressy way. "A lot of actresses say they are 24 when they are 34 but I find that ridiculous. I wish we didn't succumb to the youth-is-all ideology in this industry, because there is a huge audience out there who want to relate to characters of their own age played by actors of their own age. If you're ever going to get rid of that youth-centric attitude, there have to be people out there who will say, 'Hey, I'm whatever age and I'm a better actress for it.'"

She is equally forthright about fame, having become almost as famous for her private life as for her work on Ballykissangel, when she and co-star Stephen Tompkinson became an item. The pair are no longer together and Kirwan is in a new relationship with actor Darren Boyd.

"Looking back on that, I can understand why the machine around the show turned our relationship into a fairy tale for the media. If I was then the woman I am now, I would have put a stop to it, but I was a 23-year-old girl. I don't think I would be the person I am now without having had that experience. However, I haven't made the mistake of being a celebrity to get work. I think I am an actress first and foremost, but I am aware of the celebrity side of the business."

So aware, in fact, she is dismissive of her peers who have faux-disdain for what she calls "the fame game". "I buy celebrity magazines and I enjoy reading them. It doesn't make me less of an intellectual, it makes me human. I love asinine interviews with people. I've done them. And I've done photoshoots wearing flimsy dresses. It's a laugh. I've never been so famous that I've walked down the street and people have hassled me, or I've had the paparazzi outside my door. That on a continuous basis would be terrible, but if you're going to live by the sword, you die by the sword. You have to come to terms with that."

Kirwan has had 15 years to get used to the limelight. Born in Churchtown, Dublin, the youngest of three sisters, she inherited her mother's love of theatre and was 15 when she landed her first role in the BBC drama Troubles. A year later, she starred in Wexford Trilogy by Billy Roche at The Bush Theatre, reprising the roles when the plays were adapted for television. Then came stints at the Royal Court, the Cockpit Theatre, the Globe and the Tricycle. In 1992, she played opposite Ronald Pickup in Melvyn Bragg's A Time To Dance before playing Phoebe in Goodnight Sweetheart. She has returned to comedy lately, guest-starring in Randall And Hopkirk (Deceased) just before starting rehearsals for a new series of Hearts And Bones. In the next 18 months, she says she'd like to do some theatre.

"I have spent half my life in the business and I want longevity. I want to produce [she has just acquired the rights to a novel] as well as act. I hope that in the future, I can strike a balance between doing great, interesting TV and unashamedly commercial stuff. And why not? We are here to entertain. This is a job which demands leaps of faith. Why play safe all the time?"

 The Bombmaker, Sky One, Sunday 8th April, 9pm

fields.headline: Mark Lawson
fields.standfirst: Moral complexity, sophisticated psychology, and plain good writing - Paul Abbot's Clocking Off proves why its creator is seen as such a remarkable talent
fields.trailText: Moral complexity, sophisticated psychology, and plain good writing - Paul Abbot's Clocking Off proves why its creator is seen as such a remarkable talent
fields.body:
When critics say that a work contains impressive "set pieces", it's generally a sneer, suggesting achievement in moments rather than the whole. But writing for the screen depends on key scenes. As viewers, we remember the jobless Yosser Hughes banging his head against the wall in The Boys From The Blackstuff, the sinister CIA man singing as he drinks late at night with Bob Peck's cop in Edge Of Darkness, the long speech by the head of the claims tribunal in Alan Bennett's Kafka drama The Insurance Man - about people's desire to be compensated for loss of happiness. Played as a taster at awards ceremonies, they instantly show those who didn't see the series why the prize is being given.

There are three scenes in the opening episode of the second series of Clocking Off (BBC1) which, though only amounting to a minute or so in the hour of action, establish why Paul Abbot is regarded as one of TV's most remarkable new dramatists. As a general rule, playwrights have their heads filled with speeches, while TV and movie writers have imaginations teeming with scenes. It would surprise me if Abbot hadn't built the story around this trio of set-pieces.

Set in a Manchester factory which makes bed linen, Clocking Off is unusual in TV fiction terms for operating a shift pattern: a different employee is the central character each week. In this episode, the dramatic foreman is Kev Leach (Jack Deam), a laddish fabric cutter whose life centres on beer and Man U, but who is wandering into marriage with his girlfriend. As the opening credits run, Kev notices that a work-mate, Brian Pringle (Paul Oldham), has moved into the house across the road.

A fiction-writer needs, among other things, to be a smuggler, disguising explosive material to look like something else, so we cheerfully wave it through and are then amazed to hear a bang. This meeting on the street looks like a piece of script-writing putty - setting up, perhaps, competition over Kev's hairdresser girlfriend, Babs Fisher (Ashley Jensen) - but is actually dynamite.

The fuse is lit in the first of the three crucial scenes. Kev and Babs have just made love. She's post-coitally painting her toe-nails - "I've got to wear sandals tomorrow" - and he can't stand the smell, so gets out of bed. The nail varnish, and Bab's rationale, are typically original Abbot touches; a lesser writer would have used a cigarette. Kev reaches for a video camera. Babs says she isn't staying and, anyway, he's out of tape. At least some of the audience is surely supposed to think ill of Kev here, using his lover in private porn, but Abbot is declaring the crate of whisky at Customs in the hope that we won't look under the tarpaulin in the back of the van.

Kev tells Babs that all he wants is the zoom lens. He's going to spy on Brian, who's sitting at a computer in his room directly opposite. "This time of night, it must be porn. Sad git." This is Rear Window for the Loaded generation. Deam conjures for Kev a slow smile of wolfish complicity, getting off on the idea of watching his mate watching women. What Kev sees on his work-mate's PC, though, is not tits but kids. Subsequently, a scene of a child cycling towards Brian's house, which would generally be peripheral, becomes a moment of high tension.

The excellent American thriller Arlington Road asked the question: "What if you thought your neighbour was a terrorist?" Abbot's script is an English equivalent, positing a paedophile across the street. The plots touch on the deepest current neuroses in each country: national security in the US, child safety here.

This bedroom scene reveals Abbot's most important dramatic gifts: narrative surprise and moral complexity. It's crucial that his hero isn't entirely clean. If the computer screen had shown a naked woman and an alsation, he'd probably have smiled. Similar psychological sophistication is shown in the next big narrative building block. In the works canteen, the day after Kev's Rear Window moment, Brian is telling a dirty joke. Kev stares at him with fearful hatred. It's clear that, 24 hours earlier, Kev would have been part of the slavering chorus waiting for the punchline. His disapproval isn't feminist. He despises his friend for posing, acting as one of the boys.

In this already layered writing, there's even another, final level at which Kev resents the fact that Brian is more popular at work than him. This becomes explicit in the last of the script's vital trinity of events. In a work's football match, Brian's swaggering run - acting, again, as one of the lads - prompts from Kev a violent off-the-ball tackle. This, once again, is a subtle variation on what we might expect: a punch outside a pub.

The episode (directed by Ashley Pearce and produced by Juliet Charlesworth) resolves these issues ambiguously but truthfully and without showing anything which might arouse the wrong reaction in a section of the audience. A critic once wrote that great scenes don't make a great play, but no drama stands a chance without them, and this hour of television contains three of the best you will see.

 Clocking Off, tonight, 9pm, BBC1

fields.headline: Radio pick of the day
fields.trailText: Book Of The Week | CD Masters | It's My Story
fields.body:
On the eve of its publication, Jack Davenport reads Matthew Collins's This Is Serbia Calling as Book Of The Week (9.45am, Radio 4). It's the story of the 10-year struggle by the independent Belgrade radio station B92 against the Milosevic regime. The station was forcibly closed when Nato began bombing Kosovo, but the government had forgotten about the internet, on which the broadcasters continued offering unbiased news.

Rob Masters, best known until now as one of Radio 3's record reviewers, has been given his own daily show. Each weekday morning CD Masters (10.05am, Radio 3) offers 90 minutes of classical performances. Masters describes his role as "part salesman, part evangelist" for material no longer available. There will be regular preview slots for memorable LPs scheduled for re-issue on CD. Listeners are also encouraged to send in their own nominations.

No one is sure of the exact numbers but it's thought that some 50 babies are abandoned in Britain each year. It's My Story (8.0pm, Radio 4) concentrates on one of them, estimated to have been only three hours old when he was discovered earlier this year. As so often happens, the hospital midwife named him, and Nicholas Christmas is now with potential adoptive parents. Meanwhile, the programme tracks the police effort to trace his mother, made harder by the law regarding her as a criminal.

fields.headline: Radio review
fields.standfirst: Big Brother is listening to you
fields.trailText: Big Brother is listening to you
fields.body:
Last week I read about yet another spin on the Big Brother format. Teams of clinically obese Americans are sweating it out, probably quite literally, trying to shed pounds in a house of temptation, stuffed full of edible treats.

Some are doing it for the money; one man hopes post-weight loss to enjoy a "full loving relationship" with his girlfriend. It's yucky, that detail, I know, but at least it firmly answers the why-do-it question.

The participants in Radio Five Live's Magnificent Seven have nothing like this to explain them selves. Holed up in a Norwich B&B for a week, there's no prize money, no guaranteed weight loss what with all those fried breakfasts, not even a minibar in their rooms (this is license payers' money after all).

Most significantly, this being a radio experience, there are no visuals. For the Seven (or Eight, if you include my favourite, Dave's dog, the blissfully silent and apolitical Otto) this means no likelihood of global fame. For the rest of us, this means no peeks of B&B life and, worse still, no visual clues for avoiding these "political mavericks" at parties. And you'd want to, believe me.

There's Chris from Oxford, whose main thrust is the somewhat surreal view that teachers are "vastly overpaid" (this is all the more odd as he is himself a teacher). There's jolly Judith, too, mistress of not swearing on-air ("a socking great student loan!"). Scottish Elizabeth introduced herself as "quite controversial - I love my garden"; while Permjot likes to look at a photograph of his six- month old baby before bed, and his Arsenal season ticket on waking.

Dave has been with Otto for 10 years. "I love him and he loves me," (this is more, much more, than can be said for the Five Live audience: Dave was first out). Ruby who moved from Grenada to London spoke of the days when landlords displayed notices saying no Blacks/Irish/children/dogs. "I realised two of those categories applied to me," she said, enigmatically. And then there's Jeff, my tip to win (as I write, Ruby, Dave and Permjot are out) because he's conservative with a big and small C, a self-made man who hates Europe and was nice to Dave after the first ousting.

The problem with The Magnificent Seven was that, as a competition it was, well, rather less than magnificent. The idea was to reveal which issues will really matter to the electorate - what it in fact revealed was this isn't the hottest idea for a show. There was still the vicious allure of who would get voted out each night, but there was no sense of the Seven as people beyond the dreary political debates, an absence of the horribly human dimension that entranced us through Big Brother and its celebrity sibling.

Holed up in a Norwich B&B for a week, there's no prize money, no guaranteed weight loss what with all those fried breakfasts, not even a minibar in their rooms (this is license payers' money after all). Most significantly, this being a radio experience, there are no visuals. For the Seven (or Eight, if you include my favourite, Dave's dog, the blissfully silent and apolitical Otto) this means no likelihood of global fame. For the rest of us, this means no peeks of B&B life and, worse still, no visual clues for avoiding these "political mavericks" at parties. And you'd want to, believe me. There's Chris from Oxford, whose main thrust is the somewhat surreal view that teachers are "vastly overpaid" (this is all the more odd as he is himself a teacher). There's jolly Judith, too, mistress of not swearing on-air ("a socking great student loan!"). Scottish Elizabeth introduced herself as "quite controversial - I love my garden"; while Permjot likes to look at a photograph of his six- month old baby before bed, and his Arsenal season ticket on waking. Dave has been with Otto for 10 years. "I love him and he loves me," (this is more, much more, than can be said for the Five Live audience: Dave was first out). Ruby who moved from Grenada to London spoke of the days when landlords displayed notices saying no Blacks/Irish/children/dogs. "I realised two of those categories applied to me," she said, enigmatically. And then there's Jeff, my tip to win (as I write, Ruby, Dave and Permjot are out) because he's conservative with a big and small C, a self-made man who hates Europe and was nice to Dave after the first ousting. The problem with The Magnificent Seven was that, as a competition it was, well, rather less than magnificent. The idea was to reveal which issues will really matter to the electorate - what it in fact revealed was this isn't the hottest idea for a show. There was still the vicious allure of who would get voted out each night, but there was no sense of the Seven as people beyond the dreary political debates, an absence of the horribly human dimension that entranced us through Big Brother and its celebrity sibling.

fields.headline: His truth is marching on
fields.trailText: Son Of God | Witness: Surrendered Wives
fields.body:
Jesus was a Marxist revolutionary, Mary was a bit of a goer who made up all that stuff about immaculately conceiving to avoid being thrown down a well, and the Three Wise Men were the ancient equivalent of Jonathan Cainer, Justin Topper and Shelley Von Strunkel. Son Of God (BBC1, Sunday) was one continuous carnival of myths exploded, parables pulverised and central planks of major world religions smashed into tiny little splinters. Jesus Christ indeed.

Jeremy "Smooth Moves" Bowen was our guide through the dirt and the dust of the Holy Land in a variety of vehicles - helicopter, jeep - all of which were very Magnum PI. Jezza began his epic journey with a word of encouragement for those tuning in expecting, ooh I don't know, a Sunday night drama.

"You don't have to believe in God to be able to accept that there was a flesh-and-blood man called Jesus who lived in this part of the world and died in Jerusalem", he said. What he meant, of course, was "Oh ye of little faith, this isn't really a religious programme. Please don't turn over and watch London's Burning."

As he travelled between Jerusalem, Bethlehem, Nazareth and other places with heavy metal bands named after them, Jezza did indeed deliver on the revelations front (that's with a small r, incidentally) with many in the same vein as those mentioned above. Thanks to clever astrology and astronomy scholars, Jesus's birthday was pinpointed as April 17th, 6 BC. (This means there are technically only 13 shopping days until Christmas.)

Other disclosures were less ground-breaking and a tad dim. "Could Jesus have really been born in a cave?" asked Jezza, the incredulity palpable in his voice. He surely could, as Jezza continued, for grottos under Bethlehem were used, as they are in bits of the West Bank today, as stables and living quarters. Wowee! And were that not enough to blow your mind completely, the programme then had some man speaking about the kind of toys Jesus would have played with growing up. He even threw a ball around to demonstrate what a game of throwing a ball around in Jesus's time would have looked like. I'm sorry but is that entirely necessary? I am thinking not.

Aside from these slightly odd, slightly irrelevant diversions - and lines as downright stupid as "I filed dozens of reports from here, but not one of my stories matched what started in Bethlehem 2,000 years ago." You don't say, Jeremy! - Son Of God was rather interesting, if a bit midweek BBC2 at 8.10pm. Visually, it was quite a treat, what with ancient harbours, great temples and cities destroyed long ago all reconstructed thanks to CGI. There were even some computer-generated quacking geese wandering around, which was a nice touch.

In the end, more revelations were promised for next week, including one which has already had much publicity - that Jesus, native of Bethlehem, looks quite like someone native to the Middle East. Jezza, bless him, was quite breathless.

Witness: Surrendered Wives (Channel 4, Sunday) has also already tweaked the public interest, focusing, as it does, on Laura Doyle's theory of the surrendered wife. Doyle advocates surrendering to one's husband ("It's not submission!" she warned) to achieve happiness. This involves agreeing with the aforementioned husband even when you don't, accepting that he is "the big daddy" and that you have to do what he says, and, as Doyle puts it, "letting our husbands be the men only they know how to be".

Now if there ever was a recipe for complete disaster, Doyle has cooked it to perfection. Connie's partner Ted is an illiberal, gun-toting Republican, Tammy's partner Ben is a lazy lump, while Merilee's partner John takes her on a date to see Gladiator even though she patently isn't a Russell-Crowe-in-a-leather-skirt kinda gal.

In what is a wonderful, if cringe-inducing, piece of television, these three desperate women are convinced that they must give up their independence and dynamism to keep their men rather than dump the losers and get better blokes. Practically prehistoric, it is hugely successful, relying on women's belief in fairy tales. Laura Doyle is writing a new book. One imagines it's about throwing yourself down a well if your husband asks you to. Jesus wept.

fields.headline: TV pickof the day
fields.trailText: The League Of Gentlemen | Entrapment | Rush Hour | The Devil's Advocate
fields.byline: Paul Howlett, Simon Burnton and  Richard Vine
fields.body:
Films

The League Of Gentlemen (Basil Dearden, 1960) 6pm, FilmFour: Proof that the Brits could pull off a heist movie to match the Americans. Bitter ex-army colonel Jack Hawkins gathers a gang of rogues and misfits and sets about a £1m bank robbery with a military precision that is matched by the efficiency of the production. Such a pity crime wasn't allowed to pay in those days. The quality cast includes Richard Attenborough, Nigel Patrick, Roger Livesey and Bryan Forbes.

Entrapment (Jon Amiel, 1999) 10pm, Sky Premier: Sean Connery once gave up James Bondage for more serious matters, but here finds himself back in much the same business: a slick, glossy, no-expense-spared action movie in which Catherine Zeta-Jones plays a high-class Bond babe. He's a master thief, she's an officer of the law out to entrap him, but falling for his grey charm.

Rush Hour (Brett Ratner, 1998) 11.25pm, Sky MovieMax: The indestructible Jackie Chan bounces back for more martial arts mayhem. He plays a Hong Kong supercop arriving in LA to find the kidnapped daughter of an old pal; Chris Tucker is the local detective assigned to keep him out of trouble, and matching with sheer word-power Chan's acrobatic fighting skills. Amid the usual frenetic, beautifully choreographed action scenes, Ken Leung makes a worthy, high-kicking adversary, but the best of it is in the chalk-and-cheese pairing of Chan and Tucker.

The Devil's Advocate (Taylor Hackford, 1997) 1.15am, FilmFour: Keanu Reeves is hotshot lawyer Kevin Lomax, who gets an offer he can't refuse: to earn mega-bucks working for a big New York firm. His boss is one John Milton (there's clue one) and he's played by devilish Al Pacino (there's clue two). Yep, it's Satan himself, and soon the company's dark dealings are making even greedy Kevin sit up and blink. Has he sold his soul, or merely leased it? More daft than dark, the whole project is as enjoyably over-the-top as Pacino's cackling, mad-eyed demon.
Paul Howlett

Sports

Live Football 7pm, Sky Sports 1 Two of the season's most unlikely challengers for a European place meet in a potentially vital encounter. Southampton were rocked last week by the defection of their manager, Glenn Hoddle, to Tottenham just as their season was looking really interesting. Ipswich, meanwhile, have been a model of stability with George Burley at the helm since 1994. But the Saints are very hard to beat at home - no one has done so since November, and they have won their last five league games without conceding a goal.
Simon Burnton

Entertainment

First Wave 9pm,Sci Fi: Traci Lords comes aboard for the third series of this sci-fi conspiracy show,as a millionaire militia leader who's been inspired by Cade Foster's battle with the aliens. Of course,they don't get on at first; then they do - but will the Antichrist get in the way of their love-on-the-run?
Richard Vine

fields.headline: Hidaya Sultan Al-Salem
fields.standfirst: Kuwaiti publisher, writer and campaigner for women's rights
fields.trailText: Journalist, teacher and short story writer Hidaya Sultan Al-Salem, who has been murdered in Kuwait City aged 64, campaigned against corruption and the police force, and for full suffrage for women.
fields.body:
Journalist, teacher and short story writer Hidaya Sultan Al-Salem, who has been murdered in Kuwait City aged 64, campaigned against corruption and the police force, and for full suffrage for women. The killing shocked the affluent emirate not only because it was "un-Kuwaiti" for a man to attack a woman - but because Hidaya was not an ordinary woman.

That day, Hidaya had been on her way to a Women and Culture conference, organised by Kuwaiti women's associations, to mark the selection of Kuwait city as "capital of Arab culture" for a year. Hidaya knew she was targeted. She had indeed written an open letter to the emir asking for protection and complaining about sabotage on the two publications she owned.

A police lieutenant-colonel confessed to shooting her six times because, he claimed, she had insulted his tribe in an article last year - for which an apology had subsequently been published. The policeman had just returned from pilgrimage to Mecca and he is detained amid speculation about the real forces behind the murder.

Hidaya, a direct relative of the ruling family, was born in Shuwaikh, Kuwait and educated at the private Koranic girls' school of Mutawia (woman teacher) Saleema, and the modern school Mutawia Mariam Al Askar until 1946. Her education concluded when she was 15 and got married.

She was only the sixth Kuwaiti woman to work as a teacher and started writing articles for Lebanese and Egyptian newspapers. In 1964, she became a founding member of the Kuwaiti Literary League; later she was a board member of the Kuwaiti Journalists Association.

Her interviews with Egypt's President Nasser, Algeria's Ben Bella, Lebanon's Charles Hilou and Sri Lanka's Mrs Bandaranaika were acclaimed. She published five books including The Arabs (1965) and Women in the Koran - an indirect criticism of the way tribal traditions oppressed women contrary to Islamic directives. In 1970 Hidaya bought and became chief editor of the Lebanese weekly, Al Majalis. She also owned Arab Sport.

The 1961 Kuwait constitution guaranteed equality and the emir granted the right in 1999 - only to be thwarted by the reactionary tribal-fundamentalist alliance in the all-male parliament. Hidaya's calls for suffrage won her prestige among women and enlightened Kuwaiti men and so did her continued presence in Kuwait during the Iraqi occupation. She took part in a women's anti-occupation demonstration and published a clandestine newsletter, Children And Women of Kuwait.

Kuwait's fundamentalist-tribal alliance is not mourning Hidaya. Apart from their successful anti-suffrage campaign, they have banned the publication of "licentious" books by two of Hidaya's female allies, Aalia Shuaib and Laila Al Uthman. The remaining sessions of Women and Culture were cancelled as a gesture of respect and protest.

Hidaya was a widow. She is survived by four sons and one daughter.

 Hidaya Sultan Al-Salem, campaigner, journalist and writer, born 1936; died March 20 2001

fields.headline: John Lewis
fields.standfirst: Classically trained musician who co-founded the legendary Modern Jazz Quartet in the 1950s and was part of the Birth of the Cool
fields.trailText: Classically trained musician who co-founded the legendary Modern Jazz Quartet in the 1950s and was part of the Birth of the Cool.
fields.body:
The Modern Jazz Quartet was laid-back long before anybody thought of the expression, and it stayed that way after it went out of currency. One of the few jazz ensembles to become widely loved outside the world of the modern jazz cognoscenti, it was also one of the longest lived. Eventually, after a 30-year career beginning in 1954, the band's tinkling, metronomic, glassily perfect music came to a halt in the mid-1970s, as if it had been generated by clockwork musicians whose springs had finally wound down. But it restarted by public demand in the 1980s and continued until mortality broke the springs for good.

Both John Lewis, the group's Illinois-born co-founder and compositional guru, and his original vibraharp partner, the late Milt Jackson, were far bigger figures than their CVs with the MJQ suggested. Lewis, who has died in New York at the age of 80, was a writer of haunting jazz themes and film-scores and a pianist of fragility and patience in an instrumental world populated by pyrotechnicians. An experimenter, his cross-genre forms predated contemporary music's open-handed swapping of idioms and methods by decades. He also confirmed, within the MJQ and outside it, that subtle arrangement - sometimes disapproved of in the more cliffhanging of jazz circles - could make the difference between a specialised audience and a much wider one.

Lewis's soft chords and glancing punctuation, against the sinewy lines of the double-bass and the shuffle and distant rumble of the percussion, made MJQ music identifiable from the first bar - even if it also drove some hardcore jazz fans into the nearest bar - and it was that chamber-group sound, emphasising the new bebop's most elegant, baroque-like formal properties, and playing down its heat, that led the band to dominate jazz record sales in the 1950s and early 1960s.

Lewis was classically trained and the MJQ's stately tempos, elegant counterpoint and borrowings from rondos and fugues testified to it. He also insisted on tuxedos for the band's performances and, wherever possible, gigs in classical concert halls and recital rooms rather than clubs - manifestations of his conviction that jazz was entitled to equal treatment and status with formal music.

The MJQ could be absorbing in its melodic cleverness, hypnotic in its restraint, prove that blues could be effective without bashing, and oblige audiences to listen below the surface. Yet the group - particularly later - also had a tendency to coyness and, at times, an avoidance of risk that could bring it close to resembling a high-class Palm Court outfit. Some observers felt that the group deployed the mannerisms and gestures of classical music and jazz without the breadth of texture and emotion of the one and the urgent spontaneity and surging pulse of the other - and even the great vibraharpist Milt Jackson came to contend that the group's artifice didn't get the best out of him, his dissatisfaction being a major impetus for the 1974 dissolution.

Lewis and Jackson were the MJQ cornerstones, but both worked in other contexts that allowed their talents to flower more vividly - the bluesy Jackson as one of jazz's most exciting vibraharp improvisers, and Lewis as a composer, educator and great-and-good figure across a span of contemporary music.

The pianist was born in LaGrange, Illinois, and initially he grew up in Albuquerque with his mother after his parents' divorce. A classical pianist from early childhood - his mother, who died when the boy was four, was a trained singer - Lewis studied music and anthropology at the University of New Mexico, met the pioneering bebop drummer Kenny Clarke on military service in Europe, and moved to New York after the war at Clarke's urging. Clarke's presence in Dizzy Gillespie's revolutionary postwar bop-influenced big band brought an offer to Lewis too - and soon, his mix of bop's advanced harmonies, classical devices, and Count Basie's minimalist melodic approach brought him freelance work with Charlie Parker, Lester Young, Illinois Jacquet, Ella Fitzgerald, King Pleasure and others.

At the end of the 1940s, Lewis participated in the famous Birth of the Cool sessions with Miles Davis, in which the trumpeter mirrored some of Lewis's gathering fascination with softer dynamics, classical textures, and more complex formal structures. These remarkable sessions did much to put the 50s Cool Jazz movement into a decade of unhurried motion.

In 1952 the Gillespie band's rhythm section (Lewis, Clarke, Ray Brown on bass) plus a Gillespie soloist, the Detroit vibraharpist Milt Jackson, began to record as the Milt Jackson Modern Jazz Quartet. But though it was to be a collectively run ensemble, it was Lewis's interests that increasingly shaped its identity. By 1954, Percy Heath and Connie Kay had come in on bass and drums, the quartet was under Lewis's musical direction, and its success story became one of the most striking jazz has ever known.

Yet from 1957 onwards, Lewis was also writing film scores - notably for Roger Vadim's Sait-on jamais? (No Sun In Venice) 1957, and Robert Wise's Odds Against Tomorrow (1959). He wrote music for ballets and symphony orchestras, stage plays and television documentaries. He was involved in the formation of the Jazz and Classical Music Society and the propagation of the mixed jazz/classical "third stream" approach. He also held academic and advisory posts and, after 1980, a raft of honorary doctorates.

For almost a quarter of a century he was musical director of California's Monterey jazz festival, and from 1962 to 1965 was a leader of Orchestra USA, a hybrid band featuring jazz instruments plus strings and woodwinds. The MJQ was reformed in 1983 for some lucrative Japanese gigs, and continued until Milt Jackson's death in 1999.

Between 1985 and 1992, Lewis was also musical director of the the repertory American Jazz Orchestra. His academic work also took in Harvard and the City College of New York. In the late 1950s he had founded the Lenox School of Jazz, Massachusetts.

Lewis remained as quiet and undemonstrative as his music throughout his life. His compositions Django (1954) and Two Degrees East, Three Degrees West (1956) are still played by jazz musicians everywhere. Evolution (1999) was an album of solo recital and its follow-up emerged earlier this year to considerable critical warmth.

John Lewis is survived by his harpsichordist wife, Mirjana, a son, daughter and three grandchildren.

 John Aaron Lewis, musician, born May 3 1920; died March 29 2001

Clarke's presence in Dizzy Gillespie's revolutionary postwar bop-influenced big band brought an offer to Lewis too - and soon, his mix of bop's advanced harmonies, classical devices, and Count Basie's minimalist melodic approach brought him freelance work with Charlie Parker, Lester Young, Illinois Jacquet, Ella Fitzgerald, King Pleasure and others. At the end of the 1940s, Lewis participated in the famous Birth of the Cool sessions with Miles Davis, in which the trumpeter mirrored some of Lewis's gathering fascination with softer dynamics, classical textures, and more complex formal structures. These remarkable sessions did much to put the 50s Cool Jazz movement into a decade of unhurried motion. In 1952 the Gillespie band's rhythm section (Lewis, Clarke, Ray Brown on bass) plus a Gillespie soloist, the Detroit vibraharpist Milt Jackson, began to record as the Milt Jackson Modern Jazz Quartet. But though it was to be a collectively run ensemble, it was Lewis's interests that increasingly shaped its identity. By 1954, Percy Heath and Connie Kay had come in on bass and drums, the quartet was under Lewis's musical direction, and its success story became one of the most striking jazz has ever known. Yet from 1957 onwards, Lewis was also writing film scores - notably for Roger Vadim's Sait-on jamais? (No Sun In Venice) 1957, and Robert Wise's Odds Against Tomorrow (1959). He wrote music for ballets and symphony orchestras, stage plays and television documentaries. He was involved in the formation of the Jazz and Classical Music Society and the propagation of the mixed jazz/classical "third stream" approach. He also held academic and advisory posts and, after 1980, a raft of honorary doctorates. For almost a quarter of a century he was musical director of California's Monterey jazz festival, and from 1962 to 1965 was a leader of Orchestra USA, a hybrid band featuring jazz instruments plus strings and woodwinds. The MJQ was reformed in 1983 for some lucrative Japanese gigs, and continued until Milt Jackson's death in 1999. Between 1985 and 1992, Lewis was also musical director of the the repertory American Jazz Orchestra. His academic work also took in Harvard and the City College of New York. In the late 1950s he had founded the Lenox School of Jazz, Massachusetts. Lewis remained as quiet and undemonstrative as his music throughout his life. His compositions Django (1954) and Two Degrees East, Three Degrees West (1956) are still played by jazz musicians everywhere. Evolution (1999) was an album of solo recital and its follow-up emerged earlier this year to considerable critical warmth. John Lewis is survived by his harpsichordist wife, Mirjana, a son, daughter and three grandchildren.  John Aaron Lewis, musician, born May 3 1920; died March 29 2001

fields.headline: David Rocastle
fields.trailText: David "Rocky" Rocastle, the footballer, who has died from non-Hodgkin's lymphoma aged 33, perhaps never quite came to terms with his ejection from Arsenal.
fields.body:
David "Rocky" Rocastle, the footballer, who has died from non-Hodgkin's lymphoma aged 33, perhaps never quite came to terms with his ejection from Arsenal. That he is still well remembered and admired at Highbury was shown when the 38,000 crowd at Arsenal stadium, before the North London derby match with Tottenham Hotspur, observed a minute's silence without the faintest interruption. Even David Pleat, manager of Tottenham for the day, remarked that he was happily surprised. Before the game he had suggested to the referee, Paul Durkin, that he blow his whistle as soon as there was any interruption to the silence, believing as he did that football crowds, in such circumstances, could seldom observe more than half a minute.

Born in Lewisham, south-east London, Rocastle, a fast, skilled, powerful outside right who won 14 caps for England, was one of three black players from the same area who played a crucial part in the Gunners' success in the late 1980s and early 1990s. Rocastle, the clever playmaker Paul Davis and the powerful midfielder Michael Thomas represented a new and positive trend at Highbury, following, in a sense, on the Irish "tendency", as represented by David O'Leary, Frank Stapleton and Liam Brady.

Rocastle joined Arsenal as an apprentice in August 1983, turned professional with them on December 31 1984, and remained at Highbury until, deeply against his wishes, he was transferred to Leeds United in July 1992.

He played a leading role in Arsenal's conquest of the League Championship of 1988-1989, not least in their extraordinary decisive victory over Liverpool at Anfield in the final match of the League season. It was one which they had to win to take the title, and this they did with a goal at the last gasp by Michael Thomas. A famous photograph showed Thomas and Rocastle joyfully celebrating at the final whistle. In that championship season, Rocastle played 38 games, scoring just half a dozen goals. In the 1990-91 season, when Arsenal won the championship again, he played 13 full games, made three appearances as substitute and scored a couple of goals.

One great disappointment was that he missed playing for England in the 1990 World Cup in Italy. He was one of 26 players chosen by the manager, Bobby Robson, to go to training camp before the tournament, but when push came to shove, he was one of four dropped from the official 22-man squad.

Altogether, Rocastle made 204 appearances for Arsenal in the League, plus 14 as substitute, scoring 24 goals. He helped them to win the Football League Cup in 1987 and was in the team beaten in the 1988 Final. His overall total of games in all tournaments for Arsenal was 260, with 17 appearances as substitute, scoring 34 goals. From such statistics, it will be seen that, despite a strong, right-footed shot, he specialised in making opportunities from the wing for other players. It would be wrong to call him, generically, a midfielder. He was very much in the tradition of Arsenal outside-rights, from Joe Hulme and Alf Kirchen onwards.

When Rocastle was transferred to Leeds, Paul Davis recalled: "He cried. We spoke about it quite often. He couldn't understand why they ever wanted him to go. The club's line was that he was injured, he was struggling with his weight, he'd had a knee operation. I don't think he ever recovered from the fact of leaving Arsenal, in his own mind."

Davis will always remember Rocky as "a bubbly character, lovely spirit, fantastic spirit. Really, he was an Arsenal person. I always remember when he left the club: it was one of the saddest moments for him."

From Leeds, Rocastle went on to play for Manchester City, in December 1993, moving back to London - but to Chelsea rather than Arsenal - in August 1994, where it gradually grew plain that something of the spark had gone. In January 1997, he went, for a spell, to Norwich City, signed for Hull City in October 1997 and finished his playing career in Malaysia.

Pleasant, modest and humorous, it was hard to upset him on or off the field. Alan Hansen relates that when, playing against him for Liverpool, he brought him down quite badly, Rocastle merely smiled at him and asked: "Getting old?"

He leaves a wife, Janet, and three children.

 David Rocastle, footballer, born May 2 1967; died March 31 2001

fields.headline: The elderly are rising up
fields.standfirst: Age? It's nothing but a state of mind these days
fields.trailText: Age? It's nothing but a state of mind these days
fields.body:
My friend Munch was Sixty last week. She had felt rather panicky in the run up to her birthday. She had a budding cold, a mystery yellow lump growing on her cheek and, worst of all, she was Sixty. A pensioner. She tried to hide in the lavatory with the Martini and some bags of crisps until it was all over, but her friends bossed her into having a party.

A sensible move, I think. What is the point of being glum when you are 60? It's only one year older than 59 and one gets a bus pass and reductions here there and everywhere. And - fabulous news - the NHS has just been ordered to look after pensioners properly. Tons more cataract, hip and knee operations are to be performed. This newspaper even has a grandparents' page.

The mood is international. The elderly are rising up and running things again. Dubya's dad and nearly-dead Cheney are helping Dubya run the world. Then there's Yeltsin planning to dredge up some elderly statespersons to have parties and exert moral influence on the world. The Japanese are really going the whole hog with their "be nice to the elderly" campaign. They have special rubber suits for the young and healthy to wear which partially cripple and squash them up and show them just what we have to put up with. Good. We are entering a new era of compassion and understanding. So I iced "Rejoice" in black on Munch's cake to blend in with the zeitgeist.

But she was already with it. Her home, which I hadn't visited for a year, is now a smart, exquisitely tasteful and spotlessly clean apartment. Not that long ago she had chickens wandering in and out of the garden, rescued rabbits which annoyed the cats, bales of hay in the hall, no locks on the doors, no central heating, no kitchen to speak of and a general air of student squat. Now she has two relaxed cats, an elegant dining room and her sister in residence, who runs the establishment like clockwork. Munch has been 18 for 59 years and now she's about 30, a proper grown-up. At Sixty.

Yesterday Gardener spotted an 11-year-old tweeny-girl on telly, looking 18, with a crotchety American psychologist who declared that all 11-year-olds must be forced to be children. What a clot. Nowadays we can be what we please. Gardener was 59 last week, going on 10. Daughter is 22, going on 35, going on four. I'm 58 and my mother thinks I'm 12. Sixty? What does that mean?

fields.headline: Ancient monument needs hi-tech rescue
fields.standfirst: Archaeologists turn to engineers to save Silbury Hill, one of the world's most spectacular prehistoric sites, from collapse after 5,000 years
fields.trailText: Archaeologists turn to engineers to save Silbury Hill, one of the world's most spectacular prehistoric sites, from collapse after 5,000 years.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
Silbury Hill in Wiltshire, one of the most spectacular and puzzling prehistoric monuments in the world, is in danger of collapse.

A hi-tech engineering solution is being sought urgently, to help archaeologists deal with the disastrous consequences of the wettest winter since records began, and the aftermath of centuries of curiosity about the largest manmade hill in Europe.

The mound, which is within sight of the great henge and stone circle at Avebury, is over 4,700 years old, but archaeologists have no idea why it was built.

It is estimated to have taken 35m baskets of chalk rubble and earth, and up to a century to build, but its purpose remains an enigma.

Despite a wealth of legends, including one of a great king buried on horseback, no trace of any chamber or burial has ever been found.

A shaft dug by an 18th century amateur archaeologist collapsed last year, and although it has partly filled up with soil and rubble it has also widened.

Further cracks have been detected during the past winter, and archaeologists now fear that the mound, which is pitted with the remains of other holes and shafts, is dangerously unstable.

"It is not good," said Amanda Chadburn, an ancient monuments inspector at English Heritage. "It is causing us concern. You and I might think that you could simply backfill the shaft and close the hole, but our expert engineering advice is that that might just make the whole thing more unstable."

Ms Chadburn and her team have been climbing to the top of the 40 metre hill every week throughout the winter to monitor its condition, and are alarmed at the evidence of movement.

In the 1960s a controlled archaeological excavation seemed to show that the hill was stable and that the largest shaft had been securely backfilled. "I fear now we took false comfort from that," Ms Chadburn said.

"It could be that what we have here is a sort of Swiss cheese, full of holes which cannot be seen from outside, and the danger is that the whole thing could almost implode," said Elspeth Henderson, of English Heritage.

English Heritage is about to seek tenders for a seismic survey, usually used in major engineering projects, which will cover the entire hill with a web of monitors linked to computers, and produce a three dimensional image of the 21,000sq metre hill, revealing the stress areas and mapping for the first time any tunnels and voids inside it.

It will be the first time the engineering technique has been applied to an archaeological site.

Any repair work will probably have to be done by helicopter: apart from the instability of the site, it is officially classified a site of special scientific interest.

The bonus is that the tomographic survey may also finally answer the question of whether there is a burial chamber in Europe's most famous pyramid. But no scientific answer is likely to end the legends and conspiracy theories: everything from links with Pharaonic Egypt to the resting place of the Ark of the Covenant has been suggested for Silbury.

While other field monuments were overgrown and lost, Silbury has been unmissable for almost 5,000 years: the arrow-straight neighbouring stretch of the A4, following the route of a Roman road, jinks to avoid the hill.

webTitle: Down's children 'denied heart ops by biased doctors'

fields.headline: Down's children 'denied heart ops by biased doctors'
fields.trailText: Doctors at a leading heart hospital discriminated against children with Down's syndrome by refusing them operations, an inquiry reports today.
fields.body:
Doctors at a leading heart hospital discriminated against children with Down's syndrome by refusing them operations, an inquiry reports today.

Parents whose offspring had the chromosome disorder were told frequently by the Royal Brompton hospital, London, that the risks of heart surgery were not worthwhile, and that the children's condition meant extra pressure on those carers looking after the patients into adulthood.

The inquiry team accepts that doctors may not have been intentionally discriminatory over treatment but concludes "that was, in our opinion, the effect of their approach".

The Down's Syndrome Association said the report vindicated the families who believed they had been discriminated against because of their children's condition, which affects one in 650 babies and leaves one in three of that number with a heart defect.

The 400-page report, covering 49 families' complaints, written by a team headed by Ruth Evans, former head of the National Consumer Council, adds that some doctors "did not focus sufficiently on what was in the best interests of the child as the patient".

The report is also understood to be critical about how parents of children who died after heart surgery were treated by the authorities - a further embarrassment to the medical profession after the Alder Hey organ scandal and the controversial heart procedures at Bristol royal infirmary, on which a report is expected later this year.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, wants to change what he fears is still a paternalistic culture among doctors, shown in their attitude towards patients' families - especially those whose children have died or are surviving with a life-threatening condition.

But the criticism from the inquiry about poor communication with parents was balanced by an understanding of the pressure doctors face making life-and-death decisions, and the lack of resources. The treatments by the hospital were said to be consistently satisfactory or good.

No one from the Royal Brompton, or its sister hospital at Harefield, where parents had also criticised procedures, is named in the report. The parents who made the complaints - most of whose children were at the Royal Brompton - had said their views were not taken into proper account. Two are taking legal action.

The report has failed to convince the Brompton and Harefield Heart Action Group. Bereaved parent Josephine Ocloo said that it failed to "penetrate the secretive and unaccountable world of medical decision-making".

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: £4m squeezed from firms
fields.body:
£4m squeezed from firms

More than £4m in unpaid wages has been won by government officers enforcing the minimum wage, it was announced yesterday. Six thousand complaints of underpayment have been made since the scheme was introduced two years ago.

Hear'Say makes pop history

Hear'Say yesterday became the first British band to top the single and album charts simultaneously with its debut releases. The album broke another record with the biggest first week sale, shifting more than the rest of the top 10 put together.

Immigration officer accused

Matthew Gilbert, 30, an immigration officer at the Eurostar terminal at Waterloo, London, is appearing before magistrates at Kingston upon Thames, west London, today charged with possessing 7 kilos of cocaine with intent to supply. Gilbert, of Brentford, west London, was arrested as he got off a Eurostar train from Belgium on Friday.

Digital TV lessons

Course material for GCSE subjects is to be made available by the BBC and Granada on digital television under plans to be announced today by the education secretary, David Blunkett. In addition, material will also be available on the internet.

March blows hot and cold

For many Britons it was the second coldest March in 14 years - but the north of England and western Scotland recorded high levels of sunshine, PA WeatherCentre said yesterday.

webTitle: Man dead in star's pool was uninvited

fields.headline: Man dead in star's pool was uninvited
fields.standfirst: Police identify body as 'gatecrasher' but continue to question Barrymore
fields.trailText: Police identify body as 'gatecrasher' but continue to question Barrymore.
fields.body:
A young man who drowned in a swimming pool in Michael Barrymore's back garden after a night of revelry did not know the TV entertainer - and had "gatecrashed" an impromptu party he was holding, police confirmed last night.

Stuart Lubbock, a wholesale butchers' supervisor from Harlow, Essex, is believed to have followed the star to his home in Roydon, Essex, after spotting him partying with friends on Friday night at the Millennium Club in Harlow.

But, though he took a taxi with two or three other men, he neither knew them nor anyone else at the gathering. "Gatecrashing's probably not the right word because no one seemed to mind he was there, but it's safe to say neither Mr Barrymore nor anyone else there knew him," said an Essex police spokesman. "It seems incredible, but they didn't even know his name - otherwise we'd have been able to identify him far quicker."

Mr Lubbock, a local man who recently split up with his long-term girlfriend with whom he is believed to have a two-year-old daughter, arrived at Barrymore's property at about 2.30am on Saturday and, some time afterwards, told the 10 or so revellers he was going for a swim.

He went outside alone and, after stripping to his grey boxer shorts, took the plunge. At around 6am, police believe the other guests decided to go outside for some fresh air and spotted his floating body.

He was pulled from the water and Barrymore, among others, tried to resuscitate him while an ambulance was called. Doctors at the Princess Alexandra hospital in Harlow also fought to revive him, but he was declared dead at 8.32am.

Yesterday, as the entertainer and his guests faced further questioning over the death, a postmortem examination revealed Mr Lubbock had died of drowning. Results from toxicology tests will not be known for several weeks but it is believed he had been drinking.

Mr Lubbock's father Terry and brother Kevin, with whom he had been living since Christmas, were unavailable for comment, but neighbours described him as a "pleasant, sociable sort of lad" who had been distressed by the break-up with his girlfriend. "He was obviously a bit lonely with his relationship splitting up," recalled Doreen Crouch, aged 45, a family friend.

Eileen Bilson, aged 76, added: "He was a very friendly lad. He always said hello and he was obsessed with his car, a grey Ford Sierra. He was always washing that car. He loved it more than just about anything."

His death could not only prove tragic for his family but very difficult for Barrymore, a man whose image as a family favourite has been dramatically tarnished since 1992 when he was named ITV Personality of the Year but who has been striving to forge a career outside the light entertainment sphere.

Notorious for his drunken public behaviour since coming out as gay in 1995, he was recently cautioned for a drugs offence after a prostitute alleged she had been raped in a hotel suite for which he had paid.

Less than three weeks ago, the star - who is said to be distraught after Mr Lubbock's death - subjected guests at a charity dinner at the Park Lane Hilton to a torrent of crude and abusive jokes after drunkenly taking to the stage, behaviour which lead to his lover, Shaun Davis, leaving him.

Stuart Lubbock, a wholesale butchers' supervisor from Harlow, Essex, is believed to have followed the star to his home in Roydon, Essex, after spotting him partying with friends on Friday night at the Millennium Club in Harlow. But, though he took a taxi with two or three other men, he neither knew them nor anyone else at the gathering. "Gatecrashing's probably not the right word because no one seemed to mind he was there, but it's safe to say neither Mr Barrymore nor anyone else there knew him," said an Essex police spokesman. "It seems incredible, but they didn't even know his name - otherwise we'd have been able to identify him far quicker." Mr Lubbock, a local man who recently split up with his long-term girlfriend with whom he is believed to have a two-year-old daughter, arrived at Barrymore's property at about 2.30am on Saturday and, some time afterwards, told the 10 or so revellers he was going for a swim. He went outside alone and, after stripping to his grey boxer shorts, took the plunge. At around 6am, police believe the other guests decided to go outside for some fresh air and spotted his floating body. He was pulled from the water and Barrymore, among others, tried to resuscitate him while an ambulance was called. Doctors at the Princess Alexandra hospital in Harlow also fought to revive him, but he was declared dead at 8.32am. Yesterday, as the entertainer and his guests faced further questioning over the death, a postmortem examination revealed Mr Lubbock had died of drowning. Results from toxicology tests will not be known for several weeks but it is believed he had been drinking. Mr Lubbock's father Terry and brother Kevin, with whom he had been living since Christmas, were unavailable for comment, but neighbours described him as a "pleasant, sociable sort of lad" who had been distressed by the break-up with his girlfriend. "He was obviously a bit lonely with his relationship splitting up," recalled Doreen Crouch, aged 45, a family friend. Eileen Bilson, aged 76, added: "He was a very friendly lad. He always said hello and he was obsessed with his car, a grey Ford Sierra. He was always washing that car. He loved it more than just about anything." His death could not only prove tragic for his family but very difficult for Barrymore, a man whose image as a family favourite has been dramatically tarnished since 1992 when he was named ITV Personality of the Year but who has been striving to forge a career outside the light entertainment sphere. Notorious for his drunken public behaviour since coming out as gay in 1995, he was recently cautioned for a drugs offence after a prostitute alleged she had been raped in a hotel suite for which he had paid. Less than three weeks ago, the star - who is said to be distraught after Mr Lubbock's death - subjected guests at a charity dinner at the Park Lane Hilton to a torrent of crude and abusive jokes after drunkenly taking to the stage, behaviour which lead to his lover, Shaun Davis, leaving him.

fields.headline: Trials of Slobodan
fields.trailText: Slobodan Milosevic should of course be tried - but in Belgrade, by Serb judges and before the Serb people who risked their lives by participating in mass strikes and demonstrations to overthrow him last year (Milosevic 'under arrest', March 31).
fields.body:
Slobodan Milosevic should of course be tried - but in Belgrade, by Serb judges and before the Serb people who risked their lives by participating in mass strikes and demonstrations to overthrow him last year (Milosevic 'under arrest', March 31). Have they not, by their courage, earned the right to settle their own scores with the man who oppressed them for so long? The call for Milosevic to be tried in the Hague is arrogant and patronising because it is based on the belief that only the west knows how to administer justice. If that were so, as Noam Chomsky once quipped, every US president since 1945 would have faced a war crimes tribunal and been convicted.

And what about the west's complicity in Milosevic's crimes? His cooperation over the Dayton agreement led to talk of war crimes charges being quietly dropped, only to resurface over Kosovo. No wonder that when Milosevic was interviewed in the Italian newspaper, La Stampa, in February, he said: "Western governments supported me for as long as it was in their interest to have stability in the Balkans. When they thought it would be interesting to have instability, I lost their support." Only the Serb people have the right to try Milosevic because they suffered under his boot and then risked all to overthrow him.
Dragan Plavsic
London

fields.headline: The heat turned on Bush
fields.trailText: President Bush may be an "oil man", but he is surrounded by advisers whose overt agenda is a nuclear power revival (EU dismay as Bush reneges on Kyoto, March 30).
fields.body:
President Bush may be an "oil man", but he is surrounded by advisers whose overt agenda is a nuclear power revival (EU dismay as Bush reneges on Kyoto, March 30). Dick Cheney's latest pronouncements on the alleged benefits of splitting the atom to boil water have been followed by reversals on environmental promises and regulations and now the withdrawal from Kyoto.

None of this should come as a surprise when examining Bush's energy coterie led by Joe Colvin, head of the nuclear industry's lobbying group, the Nuclear Energy Institute, and Tom Kuhn, a Harvard buddy who runs the Edison Electric Institute, the trade group for the US electric power industry. Energy secretary Spencer Abraham, another fan of fission, wants to end the nuclear waste debate, one of the most compelling arguments against new reactors, by opening the controversial Yucca Mountain dump soon.

He should pay attention to the protests in Germany. If Bush gives the green light to nuclear waste trains, it will serve as a red rag to hundreds of thousands of US citizens who, in poll after poll, have declared their fervent opposition to nuclear power.
Linda Gunter
Safe Energy Communication Council, Washington DC
lcpentz@erols.com

The government's nature conservation organisations are disappointed at the announcement from the White House. There is widespread agreement among scientists that climate change will have far-reaching consequences for both natural and human environments - floods, droughts and rising sea-levels.

New research into the impacts of climate change on the wildlife of the British Isles will clearly show how the unprecedented rates of change predicted for the next 50 years will adversely affect many of our habitats and species; some quite literally will have "no place to go".

The Kyoto protocol represents a vital starting point for the international community to agree mechanisms and targets for reducing global greenhouse gas emissions. Progress must now be made with or without the cooperation of the US.
Mike Harley, English Nature
Simon Bareham, Countryside Council for Wales
Marcus Yeo, Joint Nature Conservation Committee
Noranne Ellis, Scottish Natural Heritage

Stan Coveney (Letters, March 31) suggests the Kyoto protocol will prevent developing nations from pursuing standards of living that we enjoy. Unfortunately, unless we all develop different ways of achieving those standards, it will be physically impossible for all the world's people to emulate the present standards of the rich nations. The area of land and water needed to produce all the resources consumed and to assimilate all the wastes generated if the whole world lived like us would require several planets.
Dr Peter Slade
Guildford
peterslade@ntlworld.com

Under article 20 of the WTO, a government can consider using trade constraints to protect the environment. The EU, the only continent powerful enough to challenge the US, should therefore tell the WTO that it is to do just that to US exports. US cheap energy also constitutes unfair competition. Those US sectors that are the major beneficiaries of Bush's irresponsible policies should be prevented, for example, from attempting to buy their way into Europe's increasingly deregulated energy supply market.
Colin Hines
East Twickenham, Middx

I wonder if the smug liberals who voted for Nader still believe there is no difference between Gore and Bush?
Paul Lay
London

webTitle: Letters: Fcuk is just our style

fields.headline: Fcuk is just our style
fields.trailText: To compare Amartya Sen to Mother Teresa (Profile, March 31) is deeply unfair.
fields.body:
To compare Amartya Sen to Mother Teresa (Profile, March 31) is deeply unfair. Mother Teresa was a globe-trotting publicity-hungry nun who did little but talk a lot and hobnob with dictators and corrupt financiers. Professor Sen is publicity shy and has always expressed his opposition to an uncontrolled free market.
Dr Aroup Chatterjee
London

Is the policy of closing all footpaths, though most run nowhere near any foot and mouth infected areas (Reports, March 31) similar to the collection of iron railings during the second world war - ie no practical purpose but makes everyone aware there is a crisis.
John Turley
Wrexham

We hear foot and mouth is endemic in China and Saudi Arabia. No doubt this explains why elections there have been postponed indefinitely.
Patrick Nethercot
Durham

In the case of the Sellafield sheep, which end gets shot first?
Peter Rowlands Connah's Quay, Flintshire

If "chick-lit" isn't for us, sisters (Letters, March 31), how about an old bird genre?
Marilyn Floyde
Worthing, W Sussex

Nothing empowers like being on the toilet (Letters, March 31). Soon after the war, an embattled Treasury official was in the WC when a message came that chancellor Hugh Dalton wanted to see him urgently. "I'm not coming," he replied. "I can only deal with one shit at a time."
Paul Bonaventura
London

Hurrah for the Guardian, with its typographical record, to dare to print "fcuk" no less than eight times in the Stephen Marks piece (Interview, March 31)
Zoe Gleisner
London

webTitle: Letters: Primary reason for GP's elderly care fees

fields.headline: Primary reason for GP's elderly care fees
fields.trailText: The Association of Charity Officers has started a debate which should be expanded (Doctors breaking 'free NHS' principle, March 30).
fields.body:
The Association of Charity Officers has started a debate which should be expanded (Doctors breaking 'free NHS' principle, March 30). The covert privatisation of the care of the elderly has imposed enormous strains on primary care. Within the past decade, hundreds of geriatric and psychogeriatric beds have been closed. The staff (doctors, nurses and administrative) and other resources have not been transferred into primary care - but the patients have.

Since 1990 two nursing homes have opened in our practice area. Effectively, we are now expected to look after around 100 elderly, often seriously physically or mentally ill patients. To create that capacity in our local trust would cost hundreds of thousands (if not millions) of pounds. The homes surveyed had charitable status; many don't and aim to profit from the NHS discarding long-term care of the elderly. I do not condone charging for NHS services, but does the association condone extra work being dumped on primary care without sufficient resources to cope?
Dr Martin McShane
Chair, North-east Derbyshire Primary Care Group
Martin.McShane@tesco.net

The necessity for some care homes to pay retainers to GP practices was first revealed months ago in the nursing journals. This means that, for example, self-financing nursing-home residents must pay fees which not only cover their own care costs, but also subsidise those of other residents sponsored by social services - which are only prepared to pay lower non-economic fees - and make a contribution to the costs of their own and other residents' GP cover.

Of course residents make greater demands on GPs than patients of equivalent age still able to live independently. They are (or become) just as ill as those cared for in hospital and suffer from a wider range of terminal conditions than the small minority cared for in hospices, where there is "in-house" medical cover. Nursing home care is far cheaper than hospital or hospice and yet those providing it are financed inadequately and reluctantly and the quality of care is bound to suffer. Death may be the great leveller, but terminal or chronic illness most certainly is not.
Don Aston
Solihull
Don.Aston@btinternet.com

webTitle: Letters: Sexual relations and the law

fields.headline: Sexual relations and the law
fields.trailText: The appeal before the law lords against the ban on raising women's sexual history in rape trials (Conflicting rights, March 27) is a mess we predicted.
fields.body:
The appeal before the law lords against the ban on raising women's sexual history in rape trials (Conflicting rights, March 27) is a mess we predicted. The 1999 Youth Justice and Criminal Evidence Act could have protected the right to a fair trial of both women and defendants. But the government refused to make a principled distinction between a woman's relationship with the accused, and her sexual history.

While there is no justification for cross-examining the witness on her sexual relations with anyone else, the jury may need to know about a sexual relationship between the witness and the defendant. But there should be a judge's warning that having said "yes" to a man in the past is not evidence that you said yes this time. The present avoidable wrangle has held up rape trials, extending the agonising months women must wait while their case hangs over them.

Moreover, a man is still deemed innocent if he "believed" the woman consented, however unreasonably. The act should have ended this. Many men like to believe that women are always available; it's the law's job to disabuse them of this justification of a violent crime.
Claire Glasman
Women Against Rape
crossroadswomen@compuserve.com

A handful of cases have reached court because a man wished to prevent his former partner from having an abortion (Sad tale of an affair that ended, March 31). In residence and access applications children are often used as weapons between warring couples. The same is now happening with foetuses. There are no winners in this situation but if a child is born it is certain to be a loser. In May 1978 it was determined that the legality of an abortion is a matter between a woman and her doctors. The only case for changing that law is to reduce the need for two doctors in the early stages of pregnancy.
Diane Mundy
Wheathampstead, Herts
dianemunday@care4free.net

fields.headline: Ethical blur
fields.trailText: Intellectual property rights (patents) may be the lifeblood of the pharmaceutical industry (Blair sides with drug giants, March 31), but this is blood from the mass genocide of Africans.
fields.body:
Intellectual property rights (patents) may be the lifeblood of the pharmaceutical industry (Blair sides with drug giants, March 31), but this is blood from the mass genocide of Africans. Milosevic's war crimes are minute in comparison. Without affordable treatment, several million Africans will die of Aids. It is a peacetime holocaust - a humanitarian issue for which the consideration of profit has no place.
Dr Tom Waller
Woodbridge, Suffolk
tomwaller@talk21.com

Is there any evidence that prime minister "Blur" is motivated by anything other than opinion polls and focus groups (which determined his election date decision) and political support from big business (thus supporting high drug prices in Africa)? What evidence is there that his desire for re-election and his programme in the next term are likely to be affected radically by his avowed "Christian" and "socialist" principles (Blair puts his faith in religious partners, March 30)? Or has short-term political self-interest and spin "Blurred" everything?
Prof Alan Maynard
University of York
akm3@york.ac.uk

fields.headline: Ministers relax 'impossible' housing rules
fields.trailText: Ministers have relaxed the "impossible" test governing councils' access to a £160m housing improvement fund after no local authorities managed to qualify.
fields.body:
Ministers have relaxed the "impossible" test governing councils' access to a £160m housing improvement fund after no local authorities managed to qualify.

Councils had to get an excellent, or three star, best value rating to access the fund which will be available from April 2002. But in the first round of inspections this year even the most highly regarded councils found it impossible to meet the standard required.

Now, in a major concession, housing minister Nick Raynsford has lowered the rating required, after conceding that the excellence test was a "particularly challenging task" in the first year of the initiative.

Councils that now get only a good, or two star, rating will get access to half of the funds available. If councils then go on to achieve three stars the amount will be paid in full.

The scheme had been set up as an incentive to improve performance. But is also a dress rehearsal for relaxing the tight public borrowing rules, by providing extra funds to councils that set up their housing management at arm's length from municipal control.

It had been envisaged that up to eight councils would pilot the scheme in the first two years, by setting up so-called arm's length companies.

Housing professionals had warned that the £160m allocated next year for the scheme would go unspent unless the test was eased. A further £300m is available in 2003/04.

Now councils such as Carrick and Kirklees, both beacon authorities that only managed to achieve two star ratings, will be allowed access to the fund in the first year.

The excellence test was so tough it was feared that there was a danger that no councils would bother trying to achieve it. The worry was that all councils would take the easier option of transferring their homes to housing associations rather than trying the untested route of setting up arm's length companies.

The two star concession will only be applied for the first year of the scheme, but campaigners are hoping that it will be made permanent if it proves effective at improving performance.

Mike Owen, director of Choice for Housing, an agency promoting a variety of options for council housing, said: "This is excellent news, it is a really good bit of flexibility." He also revealed that several councils contacted by Choice for Housing are now considered going for arm's length status after being reluctant before the concession.

John Perry, policy director at the Chartered Institute of Housing, said: "This is exactly the kind of change which we had urged the department to negotiate with the Treasury.

"It has removed one of the main obstacles for councils who want to pursue the arm's length option without feeling that the could be doing a lot of abortive work."
